HEADLINE: Repaying the Piper

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The last week's declines in bond and stock prices generated a momentum of their own, divorced from the economy's generally upbeat performance. The momentum was fed in large part by big investors who had borrowed heavily to buy securities, gambling incorrectly that interest rates would stay down. As rates rose instead, the investors have been forced to sell their securities to cover their debts.
While the American economy has been healthier in the last six months than at any time since 1989, no one could tell that from the way the markets have behaved. Half a dozen factors, most of them unrelated to the economy and some accidental, have dragged down the markets. Losses by American investors in German bonds played a role. And tensions over trade with Japan and China made the markets nervous. But these are small-fry factors. 
 "The tinder for this fire has basically been speculation, using borrowed money on a global basis," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street bond trading firm.
The selloff -- which included a drop in the Dow Jones industrial average of nearly 9 percent from early February until yesterday, when the Dow rose slightly -- is another example of how Wall Street has ignored the lessons of previous plunges. In the 1987 stock market crash, for instance, borrowing to finance speculation contributed to the 508-point collapse.
This time, bonds rather than stocks have been at center stage. "But the leverage explanation is central," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economist who analyzes markets. Those who borrowed to speculate in effect gambled that bond prices would remain high and interest rates low -- or, if the reverse occurred, that bond prices would fall slowly enough for them to sell and get out without losses.
"Everyone had the same idea, and now they are being forced to liquidate," said Nicholas Sargen, chief investment officer for Global Advisers, a unit of Prudential Insurance that invests mostly in bonds.
For several years, until early February, the system worked. Pension funds, insurance companies, banks, corporations, individuals and money managers found ideal conditions. They could borrow money for, say, six months and pay only about 3 percent a year in interest charges on the loans.
Taking $300,000 of his own money, for example, an investor could borrow an additional $4.7 million for six months, paying 3 percent interest. The investor could then purchase 30year Treasury bonds for $5 million. These long-term bonds earned 6 percent interest -- a neat profit of 3 percent beyond the cost of the money borrowed to purchase them.
Most important, when the loan came due in six months, the investor could be confident that the bonds would still be worth $5 million. He could renew his loan without problem and his long-term investment was safe.
 
 
Borrowing Kept Rising
 That process, which goes under several names -- margin loans is the most common -- continued largely without incident until early this year, and the borrowing rose into hundreds of billions of dollars. No one knows how much was involved because no Government agency tracks these loans, although many came from banks.
What is more, the Federal Reserve abetted the investors by holding down interest rates. The Fed's goal was not to encourage speculation, but to stimulate the economy by encouraging borrowing, to make certain a weak and drawn-out recovery from the 1990-91 recession did not peter out.
 As long as the interest rates on bonds stayed down, their value or price stayed up. The price of a 30-year bond falls if its interest rate goes to 7 percent or more from 6 percent -- as the rate has since early February. The reason is that the owner of 6 percent bonds has trouble selling them. Why should anyone spend $5 million to buy bonds paying 6 percent interest, or $300,000, when he or she can buy bonds paying 7 percent, or $350,000 a year, for the same $5 million?
To lure a buyer to the 6 percent bonds, the holder has to lower his price to $4.3 million. The new buyer still gets only $300,000 in annual interest payments. But for a $4.3 million investment, that $300,000 now represents a 7 percent return. The rate, in effect, has risen as the price has fallen.
The problem is that $4.3 million is $400,000 less than the outstanding $4.7 million loan. The lender, seeing this declining value, insists that the bondholder put up an additional $400,000 in cash to guarantee the repayment of the loan.
Thus bondholders have been forced to sell, even if they do not want to, to raise the cash to satisfy their lenders. Their sales, often in panic, have further lowered the value of bonds. And as interest rates kept rising, more and more bondholders found themselves forced to sell to meet the demands of their lenders.
"People knew that someday the Federal Reserve would have to force up interest rates to deal with stronger economic growth and fight inflation," said Mr. Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston. "But they somehow believed it would be later rather than sooner and they still had time, although the danger signals began last fall."
 
 
First Rise Since '89
 The anemic economic growth finally gave way to a booming fourth quarter and a fairly robust first quarter, which ended yesterday. The Federal Reserve, seeing all of this renewed activity, worried that it might give rise to higher inflation in the future, although inflation is now mild. So, on Feb. 4, the Federal Reserve signaled that it would fight future inflation by raising short-term interest rates for the first time since 1989.
The Fed's expectation was that even though short-term rates rose, the 30-year bond rate, a benchmark for mortgages and car loans, would fall. Long-term bondholders would be satisfied that they did not need to push up interest rates to offset the costs of rising inflation. The Fed, after all, had acted with sufficient determination. And for a day, bond rates did fall. Then everything fell apart.
"What the Fed may have missed was the degree of leveraged speculation, and so they triggered a margin-call type of phenomenon," said Richard Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation, a big operator of mutual funds.
Rising interest rates set off more than requests from lenders to repay, or call, margin loans. The higher rates made stocks less appealing, by holding out hope that certificates of deposit and other interest-bearing securities would now pay more than the 2.5 to 3 percent that many have offered in recent years. Huge sums that had been flowing into the stock market, largely through mutual funds, diminished or disappeared over the last two weeks, partly because of the new lure of an alternative investment, and partly because the selloff in the bond market made everyone nervous.
 
 
Experts' 180-Degree Turn
 The disappearance of this purchase money helped to make the Dow Jones industrial average plunge by 63.33 points on Tuesday and 72.27 on Wednesday, before finally showing a slight gain of 9.21 points yesterday. "You also have the spectacle of a whole bunch of Wall Street experts who had advised people to buy stocks, now telling them not to do so," Mr. Hoey said.
In addition, margin calls in the stock market contributed to the selloff. These loans to purchase stock are tracked by the stock exchanges; they had risen to $66 billion in February from $44 billion a year earlier.
The borrowing to purchase bonds, although not measured, has been many times greater. By themselves, so-called "hedge funds" may have piled up more than $300 billion in credit; these operations raise billions of dollars from wealthy individuals and then risk the money on instruments like bonds, here and abroad, and on currency speculation -- risky investments that resulted in big profits last year, but often losses this year.
The Quantum Fund is the largest and best-known hedge fund; it is owned by George Soros and manages $10 billion raised from individual investors. And for every dollar of money from these investors, the hedge funds and other large investors often borrow an additional $5 to invest.
Aside from the United States market, big chunks of this mostly American money have gone into European and Japanese bonds. But soon after the Federal Reserve acted on Feb. 4, trouble erupted for holders of German bonds, and that trouble increased the selling of American bonds.
 
 
German Disappointment
 Because Germany is suffering through a recession, bond prices had risen in the expectation that the Bundesbank, the German central bank, would lower interest rates to stimulate the economy. It did, but by much less than the speculators expected. "There was disappointment among ourselves, and in the hedge funds and in the banks and the security companies," Mr. Sargen of Prudential said.
More than disappointment, German bond prices fell, as steeply as they have in the United States, and bondholders have sold, often to meet margin calls. The selling in Germany reinforced sales of Treasury bonds in the United States as the sellers sought to raise cash to cover debt, here or abroad.
"Is there a common thread through all these markets?" said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "You might argue that the common thread is the leveraged investors who invest their capital around the world, and often sell simultaneously in all the markets."
Whatever the global reach, long-term interest rates have risen by more than a percentage point in the United States since early February, driving up the cost of mortgages, car loans and other borrowing beyond the level apparently intended by the Federal Reserve to fight inflation. "Bond yields have become unhinged from the economy," Mr. Giordano said, "and when that happens, rates can get high enough to guarantee that the economy slows down."

HEADLINE: New York Denies Blue Cross A Raise in High-Risk Rates

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

 BODY:
Ending a long pattern of granting rate increases for Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, state regulators yesterday turned down the company's request to raise health insurance premiums for nearly a million New Yorkers.
The proposed 8.8 percent rate increase would have affected those who have the most trouble getting health insurance: small businesses and individuals who must buy insurance on their own, groups that include many of the oldest and sickest New Yorkers. 
 The decision by Salvatore R. Curiale, the New York State Insurance Superintendent, is a watershed in the state's relationship with its largest health insurer, a company whose solvency is vital to New York's health care system. A spokesman for the Insurance Department said he knew of no other instance in Empire's 60-year history when a request for an overall rate increase was denied.
G. Robert O'Brien, Empire's chief executive, said he was "disappointed with the decision to reject what I considered to be a minimal rate increase." He said the company's reserves, already far below the amount considered safe by insurance regulators, will be further eroded.
The refusal follows the most tumultuous year in Empire's history, and a particularly trying time for Mr. Curiale, an appointee of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Last summer, the staff of a United States Senate subcommittee criticized Empire for poor management and said Mr. Curiale had functioned as a virtual cheerleader for the company. And Empire conceded last summer that it had kept two sets of financial records, an accurate one for internal use and an inaccurate one that was sent to state regulators.
Mr. Curiale's decision underscores a remarkable reversal of fortune for Empire. Just over one year ago, the Insurance Department granted Empire a 25 percent rate increase, the largest in its history, for the individual and small-group policies that cover some of the people who are considered the worst insurance risks. He cited what had appeared to be the imminent financial collapse of the company.
"I think that a rate increase is inappropriate because those policies produced a gain for Empire in 1993," Mr. Curiale said yesterday. He added that Empire still had money available from a $100 million bailout approved last year by the Legislature. "In my view, that money was never used," Mr. Curiale said.
The decision means that in the New York City area, the price for Empire's most popular individual policy will remain $232 per month for a single person and $497 per month for a family.
Mr. Curiale attributed Empire's improved financial condition to a significant slowing in medical inflation costs combined with the bailout money -- a refund of payments Empire made to a state malpractice fund.
Empire's reserves, which fell to about $40 million at the end of 1992, had risen to $231 million by the end of 1993, but the figure remains far below the $583 million required by state law.
"Nobody wants to see their surplus erode," Mr. Curiale said, adding that he hoped the company would find a way to make its large accounts more profitable.
Empire has about seven million customers, most of whom are insured through the medium and large group policies bought by the companies for which they work. Empire is free to charge whatever it likes for those policies, which are supposed to produce a surplus to help defray the cost of insurance for the 916,000 people with individual and small-group policies who are considered a worse risk and whose rates are set by the state.
 
Profit From High-Risk Group
 However, last year for the first time the high-risk group produced a profit of $97 million, while those insured through big companies and labor unions produced a loss of $95 million.
Mr. O'Brien, Empire's chief executive, said yesterday that the company was attempting to determine what options it has. The company could file a new application for a rate increase, but the process takes at least three months and there is little likelihood that Mr. Curiale will change his mind any time soon.
Mr. O'Brien, who took over at Empire last fall, said the company expects to have lower operating expenses in 1994 as a result of streamlining and staff reductions that began late last year.
But if the company is to survive, he said, some fundamental changes may have to occur in the health insurance industry. One option, he said, would be to require that all companies that sell health insurance in New York contribute toward a fund that would provide insurance for all who need it.
 
Special Status
 At present only Empire, a nonprofit corporation, is required by law to offer individual policies. Most for-profit companies offer policies only to medium and large labor unions and businesses, which are considered better insurance risks.
If such changes were made, Empire might give up its nonprofit status and special place in New York's health industry, Mr. O'Brien said. Empire might then become an insurance company operating under the same rules as any other in New York, he said. "And if they want Empire to service the high-risk pool, we certainly would," he said.
Over the last year, Empire has lost more than one million customers, partly because of complaints about service by some of the large companies and partly because of the inability of individuals and small groups to pay the higher costs.
In a new plan drawn up for the state, Empire predicted that it would have to double its rates over six years to stay solvent. Such rate increases would drive away hundreds of thousands of customers, many of whom would be forced to go without any medical insurance at all, insurance advocacy groups say.
The Cuomo administration has proposed a plan that would require all health insurers in the state to contribute money to pay for insurance premiums for certain high-risk New Yorkers, but its chances of approval by the Legislature are uncertain.

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Reach Accord at U.N. on Korean Nuclear Issue

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 31

 BODY:
The United States and China agreed on a Security Council statement tonight that calls on North Korea to allow inspectors to complete an investigation into whether North Korea is secretly building nuclear weapons. The statement obliquely warns the Government in Pyongyang that it faces a trade embargo if it does not cooperate.
The statement represents a compromise between the United States, which had favored sending this message in a weightier Security Council resolution, and China, which wanted a milder statement. 
 After the United States and China reached their compromise, the Council approved the statement.
Senior United States officials said tonight that they had no assurance from either China or North Korea that North Korea would agree to the completion of the nuclear inspection.
Nor is there any certainty that China will agree to any punitive action against North Korea if the Pyongyang Government still refuses to comply with today's statement.
But the officials argued that the Clinton Administration's strategy for dealing with North Korea's suspected breach of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty is back on track.
If North Korea agrees to let the inspectors complete the work they started earlier this month, and exchanges envoys with South Korea, Washington will hold a third round of high-level talks with North Korea.
But after the vote, the North Korean representative at the United Nations, Pak Gil Yon, said that the statement "won't help solve the nuclear problems" and that North Korea had "nothing more to show" to the inspectors. The only way to resolve the problem, he added, was through negotiations between North Korea and the United States.
At those talks, the United States hopes to persuade North Korea to open two secret sites where it may have been working on nuclear weapons by offering the North new economic ties and eventually diplomatic recognition, which would end North Korea's nearly total diplomatic isolation.
The third round of talks was to have started in Geneva March 21. But the United States canceled the meeting when North Korea prevented the completion of the inspection, a survey that North Korea had originally agreed to.
This forced the inspection team to send the whole dispute to the Security Council, saying it could no longer guarantee that North Korea is not manufacturing plutonium.
Such processing would violate North Korea's obligation not to develop nuclear arms under terms of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which Pyongyang has signed.
Tonight's statement calls upon North Korea to let the inspectors finish their work "as a step in fulfilling its obligations" under the agreement it reached in February with the International Atomic Energy Agency, and thus "honoring nonproliferation obligations of the Treaty."
The statement also implicitly set a six-week deadline for compliance by asking the atomic energy agency to report whether North Korea agrees to the follow-up inspections. Such a follow-up is required within six weeks of the completion of the inspection that was interrupted.
The statement asks China, which is North Korea's only ally, to maintain its "dialogue" with the Government in Pyongyang, meaning that it should continue to encourage North Korea to abandon its nuclear ambitions in the military field.
Finally, and most crucially, the statement warns North Korea that "further Security Council consideration will take place if necessary in order to achieve full implementation of the I.A.E.A.-North Korean safeguards agreement."
United States officials said this was an implicit threat to impose a trade embargo on the North unless it agrees both to allow the completion of the inspection and to open the two secret sites to inspection.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Haitians on Both Sides Assailing U.S.

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 31

 BODY:
After months of broken commitments, diplomatic reverses and an intense wave of political repression and deepening economic misery, influential Haitians on both sides of the stark political divide have begun to condemn United States policy on Haiti, calling it everything from confused and uninspired to cynical and half-hearted.
Increasingly, Haitians who seek the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, say they no longer have any faith in an American diplomacy they describe as a woeful series of zigzags, while Father Aristide's opponents now say openly that they have nothing to fear from Washington after a long string of unfulfilled threats. 
 Haitian political analysts say Washington's sinking credibility here is best seen in the reaction this week of the two main protagonists to the latest American attempt to restart diplomatic talks.
The new proposal calls for Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras to resign his army command at the same time that Father Aristide, who lives in Washington, names a new prime minister. Simultaneously, the Haitian legislature would pass an amnesty law shielding officers involved in the September 1991 coup against Father Aristide.
 
Presented by Gore
 Scarcely had the plan been presented to Father Aristide by Vice President Al Gore than the Haitian's closest advisers began to reject it as unworkable, insisting that Washington obtain General Cedras's resignation before Father Aristide is asked to do anything further.
For his part, General Cedras -- meeting here on Monday with the United States Ambassador, William L. Swing, and Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut -- expressed what participants called a total lack of interest in any process aimed at returning Father Aristide.
Beyond General Cedras's lack of response, Haitian legislators distancing themselves from Washington say the army leader had warned some deputies that he would "wash my bayonet in your blood" if they ever sought to make any decisions about his future.
"People are laughing at the Americans because they have been so inconsistent," said Georges Leger, a former Haitian Ambassador to Washington and a strong critic of Father Aristide. "Nobody believes in any of this anymore. If Mr. Clinton had sent in a few marines earlier on, that would have been the end of it, but they have never wanted to grab the bull by the horns and tell Cedras enough is enough."
While Mr. Leger has long castigated American diplomacy, open disaffection toward Washington has recently spread among politicians who have been sympathetic both toward the United States and toward the return of Father Aristide. Disenchantment has also begun to spread in the United States Embassy itself, where some diplomats say morale is at an all-time low.
 
Embarrassments for U.S.
 For many, the mounting sense of disgust dates back to the withdrawal of a United States troopship in October because of a dockside demonstration by a rag-tag assembly of Haitian Army sympathizers. The ship was carrying more than 200 American and Canadian officers, whose training mission here was widely seen as crucial to securing the return of Father Aristide at the end of the October, as scheduled.
The embarrassment of the ship's retreat was repeated in late November, when senior officers from the United States, Canada, France and Venezuela visited Haiti to issue an ultimatum to General Cedras, saying that if he did not step down by Jan. 15, severe new sanctions would be added to an arms and oil embargo.
That deadline came and went, and no new sanctions were imposed. Instead, the United States has been involved in often open wrangling with Father Aristide in what many here see as an ill-advised attempt to wrest new political concessions from him. This occurred despite the fact that Father Aristide has fulfilled his obligations under the agreement with General Cedras that they signed in July in New York.
The newest American plan hopes to achieve several goals simultaneously, before Haiti's fractious politicians can unravel any progress. Critics here say, however, that there is no suggestion that the army will go along with any plan.
Father Aristide, smarting at being asked to make new moves after he respected past agreements, has raised objections ranging from the unclear fate of the powerful police commander, Lieut. Joseph Michel Francois, to the lack of an explicit date for his return.
 
Lack of Confidence in U.S.
 Basically, however, the Haitian leader seems almost totally to lack confidence in American promises.
"There have been nothing but mixed signals and ambiguities, and most importantly, they have not kept their word," said Lionel Delatour, an American-educated businessman who helped arrange a visit by Haitian legislators to Washington this year in an attempt to restart talks to resolve the political crisis.
"Two generals and two admirals from major powers came here and issued an ultimatum, and over 60 days have passed with nothing being done," Mr. Delatour said. "There is no more credibility, and the Americans, who have been driving the policy, have the largest part of the blame."
Although diplomats are not free to express their views openly, many in the United States Embassy now share a sense of failure. "People come out of the country meetings and say, what kind of nonsense is this?" an American official said.
Responding to reports of the growing disenchantment in the embassy,another official said, "This is not an easy place to serve, even in the best of times, but at least when things are going your way and policy is working, you can take the hardships that come with the job."

HEADLINE: Police Station Becomes a Cash Station

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 31

 BODY:
Inside the Seventh District police station, just down the hall from the handcuffed gang member and the battered wife with nowhere else to hide, Shawna Jackson came to do her banking.
A few months ago, in an experiment to bring more financial services to the poor and to cut down on the muggings that make the South Side police district one of Chicago's toughest, the city and a local bank installed an automatic teller machine in the lobby of the police station. 
 But as it spits out $10 and $20 bills over the crackle of police radios, the money machine is much more than a routine convenience. It is a symbol of hope in a struggling neighborhood and a sign of how desperate and dangerous modern times have become.
Muggers are robbing people at money machines with increasing frequency, prompting banks and some cities to take unusual protective measures. In 10 Western states, Bank of America has moved some ATM's inside 24-hour supermarkets and shopping malls. In Oakland, Calif., five busy Wells Fargo Bank branches have red emergency buttons that link ATM-users to the police. And in Los Angeles, the City Council has approved the installation of 30 new ATM's in police station lobbies.
 
'You Got to Be on Your Guard'
 But even though she was surrounded by armed officers inside the Seventh District police station here in Chicago's Englewood neighborhood, Ms. Jackson clutched her purse as she scanned the lobby for potential attackers. "No matter where you are nowadays," she said, "you got to be on your guard every minute."
A message on top of the machine tries to reassure people like Ms. Jackson that there is at least one safe place left. "Now you can feel secure withdrawing cash from an automatic teller machine knowing it's police-protected 24 hours a day, 7 days a week," the sign says.
But Ms. Jackson, a public school clerk, knows from bitter experience that beyond the glass doors of the police station, even simple tasks like withdrawing a few dollars to pay the baby sitter can get a person killed. She was mugged at an ATM a few miles from the station several months ago. The mugger took $100 and what was left of her sense of freedom to conduct business like an ordinary citizen.
These days, even if some people are brave enough or foolish enough to use an ATM in the Seventh District, they might have a hard time finding one. Only a few machines are left in Englewood. But then, few residents of the neighborhood have needed an ATM. Nearly half the people in Englewood live below the Federal poverty level, and the unemployment rate is 33 percent. Dealing with a bank teller -- human or computer -- will take some getting used to.
Otis Monroe 3d, president of a not-for-profit neighborhood training program, the Monroe Foundation, said his group came up with the idea of putting the ATM in the police station to help stop the neighborhood's physical and spiritual mugging.
"We need to begin to see other images around here other than poverty and crime," Mr. Monroe said. "We need to see investments. We need to feel as bankable as any other part of the city."
Last year the foundation persuaded the Marquette National Bank to place an automatic teller in the police station on a six-month trial basis. The machine was installed around Christmas. So far it has handled about 450 transactions a month, well below the bank's target of 1,000. Part of the problem is that not many people know that the station has an ATM.
A few weeks ago, a green and white Cash Station banner was put up on the wall outside, not far from the Stars and Stripes snapping in the cold spring wind. And Comdr. Ronnie Watson, the district commander who is a member of the foundation's board,hopes to replace the banner soon with an electronic sign that lights up at dusk.
 
Cluttered With Crime Debris
 "This is what community policing is all about," he said, sitting behind his desk, which was cluttered with the debris of a long, murderous weekend throughout Chicago. In the Seventh District alone, five people were shot to death in what the police fear is the start of yet another of the gang wars that have soaked Englewood in blood.
Despite the bloodshed, robberies and killings are down compared with this time last year, the police said.
"Every year we recover more guns than the year before," Commander Watson said. Many of the guns are used in holdups near the neighborhood's many currency exchanges, a staple of the inner city where neighborhood residents, especially welfare recipients, cash their checks for a fee.
Everyone in the neighborhood knows when the checks are due, including the robbers, many of whom were on welfare themselves before the state eliminated welfare for single adults, Commander Watson said.
The other day, as the morning shift went home and the officers on the afternoon shift checked their weapons and bulletproof vests, Keion Hightower slid his bank card through a slot in the automatic teller and punched in his identification number. But having an ATM in the station lobby, he said, does not make him feel much safer.
"It's not going to really cut down on all these robberies," he said. "Look at all the crime in this neighborhood right near the police station. What we need around here is some more jobs. Then you wouldn't need to put a cash machine in the police station."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the Chicago Police Department's Seventh District, Brenda Anderson, a neighborhood leader, makes a withdrawal from one of the first automatic teller machines to be placed in a police station for public use. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Youth In Singapore Loses Appeal On Flogging

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, March 31

 BODY:
In a move that threatens to disrupt relations, the Chief Justice of Singapore rejected appeals from President Clinton today and ordered that an American teen-ager be flogged for spray-painting cars and other mischief in this prosperous, order-loving city-state.
The case of Michael Fay, 18, of Dayton, Ohio, raises the prospect of a rift between the United States and one of its closest allies and trading partners in Southeast Asia, and American diplomats immediately protested the decision by the Chief Justice, Yong Pung How, to uphold the flogging sentence. 
 Mr. Fay has confessed to spray-painting cars and throwing eggs at other vehicles. He was sentenced to four months in prison and six lashes with a half-inch-thick rattan cane, a punishment that results in permanent scars and usually sends prisoners into shock.
President Clinton intervened in the case in early March, describing the caning sentence as "extreme" and asking Singapore to reconsider.
 
'An Excessive Penalty'
 "We continue to believe caning is an excessive penalty for a youthful nonviolent offender who pleaded guilty to repairable crimes against private property," said Ralph L. Boyce, the charge d'affaires at the United States Embassy in Singapore, who attended the appeals court hearing. "We continue to hope that the Government of Singapore will reconsider the sentence."
Mr. Fay, who arrived here two years ago to live with his mother and stepfather, has now exhausted his court appeals. His final hope for avoiding the flogging rests with Singapore's President, Ong Teng Cheong, who has clemency powers. Lawyers for the teen-ager were reported to be planning an appeal to President Ong.
Mr. Fay, who had been hospitalized for depression in the week since his sentencing, was stoical during the court hearing. The teen-ager's fear was obvious only when his feet pushed through the slats of the wooden dock. They shook frantically.
He had been free on bail, but after the Chief Justice's ruling today he was taken into custody in preparation for his caning. No date has been announced for the punishment.
His case has attracted publicity in the United States -- not all of it to Mr. Fay's advantage, since some public opinion polls taken in the United States after his sentencing here suggested that a majority of Americans would support corporal punishment in such a case.
Few Americans are likely to understand exactly what a caning in Singapore entails. While spokesmen for the Singapore Government have been unwilling recently to describe the punishment in detail, diplomats say that prisoners are tied down to a wooden trestle and are then whipped with a rattan cane moistened to prevent it from fraying. Diplomats say the initial blows tear open the skin and, within seconds, prisoners usually go into shock from the intense pain.
 
Senator Supports Youth
 Mr. Fay has received support from several members of the United States Congress, including Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, who was in Singapore today as part of a tour for the Senate Armed Services Committee.
Senator Cohen said that the case of Mr. Fay was "getting out of hand" and could disrupt the otherwise "great relationship between the United States and Singapore."
In another court case closely watched by international human rights organizations, two journalists, two private financial analysts and a Government economist were convicted today of violating Singapore's strict Official Secrets Act.
The five were fined a total of $13,370 for having communicated and received Government economic data that turned up in an article in Business Times, the leading financial newspaper in Singapore. The July 1992 article disclosed an early, confidential Government estimate of quarterly economic growth.
All five were spared jail sentences,which surprised foreign diplomats and lawyers here.

HEADLINE: Man of the Law, and of Letters as Well

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH COHEN 

 BODY:
More than a century ago Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. told a group of Harvard undergraduates: "The law is not the place for the artist or the poet. . . . The law is the calling of thinkers."
Whatever merit history may have bestowed on the second part of that assessment, it has offered a fair share of exceptions to the first. Archibald MacLeish, a Harvard Law School graduate, wrote four books of poems. And a San Francisco lawyer named Charles Reznikoff wrote an entire book of them, "Testimony," that was based on actual court records. Then there was Wallace Stevens, who was a surety bond lawyer. And Edgar Lee Masters, author of "The Spoon River Anthology," was a law partner of Clarence Darrow. 
 Indeed, it may have been Darrow himself rather than Holmes who had it right when he said, "Inside every lawyer is the wreck of a poet."
In any event, now comes Lawrence Joseph, a professor at St. John's University School of Law in New York, who, with greater effect than any of his contemporaries, is carrying on the tradition. Mr. Joseph, a winner of the coveted Agnes Lynch Starrett Poetry Prize, is the author of three volumes, most recently "Before Our Eyes," published a few months ago by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
Balancing caesuras and cases might seem unwieldly, but Mr. Joseph is managing fine. In fact, he says, his two careers are symbiotic: ideas from law often feed his poetic imagination, while "poetry informs the law by making me more sensitive to language, different levels of meaning, different perspectives and an attention to the ways things work."
For the last seven years, Mr. Joseph has taught jurisprudence, torts, the legal process and employment law at St. John's, where, he says, his goal is to "help meld creative, socially conscious, ethical and knowledgeable lawyers."
For even longer -- ever since he read Stevens's "The Emperor of Ice Cream" as an 18-year-old freshman at the University of Michigan -- he has been writing poetry. His themes range from factory work (as in "Factory Rat") to racism ("Sand Nigger") and, of course, the law ("Witness," "Material Facts").
"As a lawyer, I have to be conversant in the languages of social power, economics, history, violence, work and race, and I try to transform them into my poetry," said the 45-year-old Mr. Joseph, whose furrowed brow and slightly stooped posture suggest long nights filled with hard thought, no matter what the topic.
 
Lines of Logic
 His editor, Jonathan Galassi, who is editor in chief of Farrar, Straus & Giroux and himself a poet, finds Mr. Joseph's double career a source of richness. "His poems show a lot of logical concentration," Mr. Galassi said, "which certainly relates to his thinking as a legal scholar. I've edited a few other lawyer-writers, such as Louis Auchincloss and Scott Turow, and they're all highly organized thinkers."
After graduating from the University of Michigan Law School but before arriving at St. John's, Mr. Joseph clerked for Justice G. Mennen Williams of the Michigan Supreme Court and then litigated cases at the New York firm of Shearman & Sterling. He describes himself as an incessant note taker, a filer, a chronic clipper of articles. He is always collecting ideas and fragments of sentences, many of which are eventually woven into his poems.
With titles like "Material Facts," some of those poems clearly mine his legal career for their imagery. Others reflect his interest in subjects like race, ethnicity, his hometown (Detroit) and art and color theory, which he has learned about from his wife, Nancy Van Goethem, a painter.
In "Do What You Can," a poem in his first collection, "Shouting at No One," an old man prays to a statue of the Virgin Mary, factories turn out automobiles and a woman pockets a half-smoked cigarette. Then, in the final stanzas, Mr. Joseph leans again toward the legal world he understands so well:
I press the accelerator to keep the motor warm.
I wonder if they know
that after the jury is instructed
on the Burden of Persuasion and the Burden of Truth,
that after the sentence of 20 to 30 years comes down,
when the accused begs, "Lord, I can't do that kind of time,"
the judge, looking down, will smile and say,
"Then do what you can."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For the last seven years, Lawrence Joseph has taught law at St. John's University. For much longer than that, he has been growing as a poet. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;
A Winter of Red Ink Cancels Simulcasting

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO 

 BODY:
They pulled the plug yesterday on the great simulcasting experiment, which was supposed to rescue New York from the ravages of racing in wintertime. And after 70 days of betting on mixed programs of live races at Aqueduct plus televised races from Florida, the general reaction seemed to be: Who needs winter racing, anyway?
The weather didn't help. During the three months the experiment was allowed by the Legislature, 15 racing dates were wiped out by snow and ice, attendance plunged from 8,250 a day last year to 6,339 this year (down 23 percent) and betting dropped from $2.1 million a day to $1.8 million (down by nearly 16 percent). 
 "It didn't work the way people expected," said Gerard J. McKeon, president of the New York Racing Association. "The bettors just weren't as interested in simulcast races as they were in home races. You root for the home team in racing, in baseball, in anything. And New Yorkers are notoriously chauvinistic in rooting. Also, there were too many races, and people wanted more time between races to do their handicapping."
 
Asking for Help
 How about next winter?
"We're tapped out," McKeon said. "We simply don't have the resources to run next winter. The Legislature will have to change the laws to enable us to run and to survive financially.
"We're required to run a total of 196 days a year. We've been running longer than that to accommodate the Governor and the horsemen. We could cut that down unilaterally, but we'd rather not. We'd much rather do it with everybody's agreement. But I think the economics of the situation will force our hand. We still think racing should be suspended at least six weeks in the winter."
 
 
Side Road to Derby
 The Jim Beam Stakes, the race that launched the careers of Hansel in 1991 and Prairie Bayou in 1993, will be run tomorrow at Turfway Park in Kentucky. Whose Triple Crown career will it launch this time?
Eleven colts were entered yesterday, drawn by the twin prospects of going home with $360,000 from the purse of $600,000 plus instant stature on the road to the Kentucky Derby. The Turfway Park early line makes Southern Rhythm the favorite at 3-1, breaking from the No. 3 gate, with Polar Expedition next at 7-2 odds, breaking from the rail.
The heavy hitters on both East and West Coasts will generally be absent because they are resting or training for their next milestones back home: the Santa Anita Derby next Saturday, April 9, and both the Blue Grass Stakes and the Wood Memorial the following Saturday, April 16. But the Jim Beam has grown in importance since it was first run 13 years ago, and it is certain to enhance the standing of one or two of the candidates aiming for Churchill Downs on May 7.
 
A Launching Pad
 Recent winners of the Jim Beam have done heroic things: In 1990, Summer Squall went on to run second in the Derby and first in the Preakness. In 1991, Hansel set a track record in the Beam (1:463/5 for the mile and an eighth), then won the Preakness, the Belmont Stakes and the 3-year-old championship. In 1992, Lil E. Tee went on to win the Derby. And in 1993, Prairie Bayou won the Beam and then ran second in the Derby and first in the Preakness.
Southern Rhythm, a son of the speedcat Dixieland Band, ran second in his debut at Keeneland last October and has won three straight this year at Oaklawn Park in Arkansas. He joined the candidates on the road to Kentucky three weeks ago when he won the Southwest Stakes at Oaklawn over Dish It Out and Polar Expedition.
"He couldn't be any better," his trainer, James Keefer, reported the other day after watching his star work out at Churchill Downs. "He was out there kicking and squealing and looking for something to run at."
 
 
Sign of Spring
 The big horses are back in town. And here come some big ones tomorrow for the Westchester Handicap at Aqueduct: Colonial Affair, winner of the Belmont Stakes last year; Cherokee Run, second in the Preakness and first in the Dwyer, and Virginia Rapids, who won the Peter Pan last year. They'll go one mile for $100,000.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
Is Architecture Art?
Should architecture be considered art? In Culver City, Calif., the answer from the City Council is yes, depending on the situation. 
 This month, Culver City revised its 1-percent-for-art program, which had stipulated, as do many such programs across the country, that 1 percent of the construction cost of a building must be used for artworks. Some opponents say such laws encourage second-rate art in front of buildings that would look better without it. The Culver City law also prohibited architects from creating their own artworks to comply with the 1-percent quota.
The city has amended its policy so that the architecture itself can be considered art in some cases, and if approved by the City Council, the project would be exempt from the 1-percent law.
Culver City, which is just southwest of downtown Los Angeles, is the first place in the nation to make such a modification. Local officials say other cities may follow. "I hope they do," said Mark Winogrond, the director of community development for Culver City. "It's a fair balancing of two competing forces: on one hand, there's architecture that's art, but on the other hand, the ability to abuse the rulings by developers claiming their buildings are art is rampant. That's why each case has to be decided on individually."
The idea to change the law came from Frederick Smith, a developer who is rebuilding 50 acres of an abandoned industrial area in Culver City. While Mr. Smith conceded that developers may try to save money by saying that their buildings should be considered art, he also said that the 1 percent was a "relatively insignificant" amount.
"All I want," he added, "is for architecture to be accepted as art."
A project by the Los Angeles architect Eric Owen Moss for Mr. Smith was submitted to the Council because the developer said its sculptural nature met the art requirement.
"Eric's work became the guinea pig," said Frances Anderton, an architectural journalist who teamed up with Mr. Smith to draft a proposal to the Council. "I do believe in the 1-percent-for-art program, in principle. But I don't know if in the end it has always produced good results. I'm aware that the ramifications in changing the policy are immense."
Their proposal included endorsements from Miguel Angel Corzo, the director of the Getty Conservation Institute in Marina del Rey; Richard Koshalek, the director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, and Philip Johnson, the architect.
Peter Rowe, dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Architecture, also agreed. "That the architectural landscape doesn't count as art is a limited position and dangerous to perpetrate in public communities," Mr. Rowe said. "It undermines artistic integrity."
Mr. Moss, the architect in the Culver City project, said that he hoped "this will not bring artists out to fight architects" but that the change was "terribly important."
Others disagree. "It's a troubling trend," said Tom Otterness, a New York-based sculptor who has created major art projects on both coasts. "Public art seems to be one of the only ways for art to reach the public. This is a way of society isolating itself from art."
Max Protetch, a SoHo dealer who represents many artists working on public projects, said that he believed that "architecture isn't art" and that he had "never confused the two." "This is another excuse not to involve art in society," he added.
At the Department of Cultural Affairs in New York City, Tom Finkelpearl, the director of its percent-for-art program, says he is thankful that what has happened in Culver City hasn't "begun to ripple through the percent-for-art-world yet."
"Art and architecture are different professions," Mr. Finkelpearl said. "Both should be able to contribute. It's important to have more than one voice."
 
J. Carter Brown
 J. Carter Brown, director emeritus of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, has become the exhibition director of "Rings: Five Passions in the Art World," the first global art exhibition to be planned in conjunction with the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. The show will be at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta from July 4, 1996, through Sept. 24, 1996. It is the first show Mr. Brown, who is 60, has worked on since retiring a year and a half ago.
The show, whose cost is estimated at $3 million, is being organized by Mr. Brown in collaboration with the High Museum and the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games. It will be the centerpiece of the Olympic Arts Festival.
"The interlocking rings that symbolize the Olympic Games also represent the coming together of many people, nations and emotions," Mr. Brown said. "The show will deal with treasures that represent the five passions: love, anguish, awe, triumph and joy. Because we only have so much space, we have limited the focus to paintings and sculpture."
The show is expected to include about 100 objects and occupy 2 floors of the museum. Mr. Brown says the objects will come from museums and private collections and will be a mix of "major masterpieces and many surprises."
 
Divorce Plus Debt
 Death, divorce and debt keep the auction business going. And a double whammy is benefiting Christie's, which has announced it is selling the collection of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art belonging to the financier Meshulam Riklis, who is the owner of the McCrory Corporation five-and-dime chain stores.
Mr. Riklis and his wife, the entertainer Pia Zadora, are divorcing. And McCrory filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection two years ago. The artworks are to be sold in New York on May 3, 4 and 10.
"Mr. Riklis has a natural talent for spotting good things," said Christopher Burge, the chairman of Christie's in New York. Among the Impressionist and modern paintings to be auctioned on May 10 is Monet's "Red-Colored Boat," from 1890. While the catalogue reads "estimate on request," Christie's officials say they expect it to sell for about $7 million. Also being offered on May 10 is Leger's "Contrast of Forms" (1913), estimated at $3.5 million to $4.5 million. Among the contemporary artworks for sale on May 3 is Jackson Pollock's "No. 22" (1949), expected to fetch $2 million to $3 million.

HEADLINE: Review/Photography;
Soft-Focus Portraits Yield to Hard Images Of Depression Poverty

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN 

 BODY:
In 1930 Dorothea Lange was a genteel portrait photographer in San Francisco, producing slightly soft-focus, moodily lighted images in a style recalling that of her teachers, the well-known pictorialists Arnold Genthe and Clarence White. Over the next five years, though, Lange traveled a remarkable distance in her work, turning from polite portraits to the searing, unforgettable images of migrant workers and rural poverty that cemented her fame.
This shift is the unstated subject of the fascinating if somewhat jumbled show of Lange's photographs now at the Houk-Friedman Gallery. This show includes some of Lange's most famous images, including "Migrant Mother," the classic 1936 photograph of a woman, her face lined with worry, whose children press themselves to her body. 
Also included are photographs from the 1950's, including two from a project on trials, taken in an Oakland courtroom. But nearly half of the 41 pictures here were made in the three years before 1935, when Lange was invited to join other photographers in documenting the work of the Resettlement Administration, the New Deal farm agency better known by its later name, the Farm Security Administration.
Not surprisingly, the catalyst for Lange's transformation from portraitist to documentarian was the Depression. In 1932, with poor and unemployed people crowding San Francisco, she took her camera into the streets. One of the first images she made working in this new way, "White Angel Bread Line," has become an icon of the period. In it, a man turns away from a crowd lining up for food, his stained, shapeless hat pulled down around his ears and his mouth set in a grim line.
Several photographs here were taken during political demonstrations or labor disputes, including San Francisco's General Strike of 1934. In another famous picture, a policeman in a dark uniform towers over a cluster of sign-carrying demonstrators behind him.
One of the most remarkable aspects of these early political pictures, though, is how little attention Lange pays to their subjects as individuals. People are reduced to social types, with their faces often hidden in heavy shadows. As a result, the photographs sometimes take on the predictability and emotional flatness of political cartoons. Even when a person's face is visible, its features may be twisted into a snarling caricature, as is the case in the close-up of a speaker at a May Day rally.
However distanced they may be emotionally, Lange's pictures from this period demonstrate her masterly use of eloquent gestures and telling details as clues to a person's situation and character. One particularly striking photograph focuses on a woman's crossed legs, with the patched and knotted stockings suggesting her attempts to maintain dignity in the face of difficulties.
Lange brought this awareness of the symbolic power of details to the pictures she made for the Farm Security Administration. In these later pictures, though, she seemed to relax and to get closer to her subjects, both physically and emotionally.
Many of Lange's pictures after 1935 have a remarkable openness. Perhaps because of her skill as a portraitist, she was able to get her subjects to offer themselves to the camera seemingly without reservation, whatever their social situation. In these pictures Lange balances her earlier tendency to treat her subjects as social types with a direct, personal connection to them. By combining the intimacy of personal contact with the analytical distance of sociology her photographs offer a particularly powerful blend of insight and emotion.
Lange's odyssey in these years was personal as well as professional. In 1935 she met Paul Taylor, an agricultural economist, and the two began to work together, gathering information and pictures exploring the plight of migrant farm workers. Both were already married; Lange had two children and Taylor three. But they fell in love and, after each had divorced, they were married at the end of 1935.
For the next five years Lange worked on and off for the farm agency until 1940 when she was let go in a budget cut. Despite legendary battles with Roy Stryker, the head of the agency, over the control of her negatives, she produced many of the project's most famous pictures, and she later photographed for the Sate Department and the Office of War Information.
Illness and family obligations limited Lange's photography after the early 1940's, although in the next decade she pursued projects for Life magazine and other publications. Many of her later pictures were made during extensive trips that she and Taylor took to Ireland, Indonesia and other countries; they often demonstrate the same ability to connect with her subjects that is apparent in her Depression-era images, but the sense of urgency has dissipated.
This tantalizing but frustrating show provides marvelous examples of Lange's work, particularly from the early 1930's. But pictures seem thrown together for no particular reason, with little attempt to shape them into a coherent story that conveys the drama of her life and her images.
A major retrospective of Lange's work is to open at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in May, traveling to the International Center of Photography in 1995. It may do a better job of recounting Lange's amazing flowering as a photographer.
Photographs by Dorothea Lange remain at the Houk-Friedman Gallery, 851 Madison Avenue, at 70th Street, through May 7.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Mended Stockings, San Francisco" (1934), by Dorothea Lange. (Houk-Friedman Gallery)

HEADLINE: In Michigan School-Tax Shift, the Poor Lose

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As you indicate in "Fairer Schooling for Michigan" (editorial, March 18), the school reform measure in Michigan -- to finance public schools by sales and other taxes, rather than property taxes -- was successful because there was something in it for both conservatives and liberals, or so they believe. 
 For conservatives, the measure represents a shift in the tax code. As the preponderance of sociological and economic research has shown, property taxes fall disproportionately on the wealthy, while sales taxes fall disproportionately on the poor.
For liberals, the measure represents a shift in educational spending away from inequitable financing that favors the wealthier districts. Yet this supposed "benefit" for the poorer school districts flies in the face of nearly 30 years of sociological research that has found that levels of spending on education do not make a difference in the educational achievement of students.
Liberals, then, really got nothing for something: at the expense of a more regressive tax code, liberals won acceptance for changes in educational expenditures, which will make about as much of a difference in the lives of inner city students as cloud patterns in Moldavia.
For those, whether liberal or conservative, who are interested in improving the lives of inner city youths, a less regressive tax code, in combination with broad-based educational reform along the lines being attempted by New York City's Schools Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, would be preferable to the pyrrhic victory in Michigan.
 
HAROLD WENGLINSKY
New York, March 24, 1994
The writer is a teaching assistant in sociology at New York University.

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Reassurance

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, March 31

 BODY:
Seeking to reassure investors whose nervousness has sent the stock market plunging, President Clinton expressed confidence today that the economy remained strong.
Mr. Clinton urged investors not to "overreact" to the weeklong fall of share prices and said he hoped the market would "rebound quickly." He said there was no reason to believe that the drop in the market represented more than a periodic correction. 
 "What I'm trying to do is to reassure people because no one believes that there's a serious problem with an underlying economy," Mr. Clinton told reporters here this morning. "It is healthy, and it is sound."
He said he had spoken at length this morning with Robert Rubin, head of the National Economic Council. Mr. Clinton said an "exhaustive review" conducted by the Administration since the market began to fall had found evidence pointing only to continued economic growth.
"No one should make any decisions based on a worry about some inflation factor they don't know about or some impending problem in some sector of the economy," he said.

HEADLINE: The Muted U.S. Outcry Toward Japan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The Government released its list of countries erecting egregious trade barriers today, singling out Japan as the worst offender. But senior officials said they were not, for the moment, contemplating any new sanctions against Tokyo.
The Clinton Administration has decided to give the Japanese more time to flesh out their sketchy offer, made earlier this week, to break the trade deadlock. This restrained response by the Administration to a Japanese trade package deemed wholly insufficient is in striking contrast to some of the tough language of recent months. 
 It is a direction that comes straight from the White House, officials say, and reflects concern about destabilizing world markets as well as a need to enlist Japan's support to deal with North Korea and China.
 
Just Enough Good Faith
 In economic terms, President Clinton has decided that there was just enough in the Japanese offer for him to feel that Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa was making a good-faith effort to reform the Japanese system.
The vague Hosokawa package says that Japan would spend the next three months devising steps to eliminate red tape in 11 important areas where foreign companies believe they are systematically being frozen out of the Japanese market, but would not decide until June on specifically how to loosen government regulations or increase spending.
While the Hosokawa offer falls well short of what the United States wants, the White House believes that it is worth giving the Prime Minister a little time -- no one will say how long -- to see if he can come through with the substantive details it is demanding. If he fails, the Administration will opt for more sanctions.
In the meantime, though, American officials say that the marketplace is already exerting intense pressure on Tokyo, by driving up the value of the yen. They seem to feel that additional sanctions by the United States now would be superfluous, and, given the volatile condition of the American and other stock markets, too dangerous to impose at the moment. One of the factors that led to drops in many stock markets was concern about an American-Japanese trade war.
Since the Hosokawa offer was deemed "a work in progress" by the Clinton Administration, currency speculators have driven up the value of the yen, assuming that the United States would deliberately drive it up sometime later. When the value of the yen rises, it makes Japanese exports more expensive and results in Japanese businesses losing market share. It has the effect of a tariff imposed on everything Japan sells abroad, which is worse than any formal sanction the Clinton Administration could devise.
 
Letting the Yen Do It
 This, in turn, has caused a howl of complaints from Japanese businessmen that the Hosokawa Government is not doing enough to break the trade deadlock. As American officials see it, this is the best kind of pressure. It comes from Japan and is directed at the truly vulnerable points. They want to let it percolate more. The officials insist that they are doing nothing to manipulate the value of the yen, but they do not have to -- market is doing it for them. In Tokyo today, the dollar closed at 102.80 yen, down 0.50 yen from Wednesday's close.
Another important factor muting the American response to Japan is that the strategic environment between Washington and Tokyo has changed in the last few weeks.
Analysts point to two factors. Prime Minister Hosokawa's recent visit to China, when he went out of his way to distance himself from American human rights demands, was a subtle reminder to the United States that it should not drive Japan and China together by getting into trade conflicts with both at the same time.
There is a triangular strategic relationship in the Asia-Pacific region. But rather than the Soviet Union, China and the United States do-si-doing with each other, it is now Japan, China and the United States -- with each wanting to make sure that it is not left isolated by the two others.
Second, the collapse of negotiations with North Korea over inspections of its nuclear program has put the United States on a path where it is will soon have to make specific decisions about how to deal with the Pyongyang Government, whether by a trade embargo or some military measure. This is not the time when American officials want to be in a trade war with Tokyo, whose support will be critical in dealing with North Korea.
 
Kantor's Twin Gambits
 "The Japanese themselves said that they will be coming forward with more details," the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said of the Hosokawa package. "So the ball remains in their court, and under the circumstances, we intend to react in a careful and measured way."
Mr. Kantor, though, laid the legal groundwork today for any additional sanctions with the publication of the National Trade Estimate Report. This annual report to Congress detailed "onerous restrictions" to free trade imposed by Japan in markets ranging from cars to medical equipment. These have been the subject of the failed negotiations between the two countries for the last year.
According to the Super 301 trade provision revived by President Clinton a month ago, the Administration has until September 30 to identify any one of these Japanese barriers as a "priority foreign country practice," which should be eliminated. That, in turn, starts a clock ticking, under which Japan must respond by taking down the barriers or face punitive tariffs on some of its products coming into the United States.
Nearly 40 other countries were also criticized for their trade practices in today's report, with China severely chastised as failing to clamp down on the piracy of American videos, software and compact disks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mickey Kantor, the U.S. trade representative, leaving a briefing Tuesday on Japan's proposals. (Associated Press) (pg. D12)

HEADLINE: Economist, And Now A Politician

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 31

 BODY:
Foreign investors got what they wanted when a classically trained economist was selected to replace the governing party's slain presidential candidate in Mexico, but now they are concerned that the candidate's great strengths in handling the economy may turn out to be a weakness in handling the country.
Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon has a doctorate in economics from Yale and such extensive experience in Mexico's central bank and its budget ministry that if he is elected president on Aug. 21, as expected, he would become one of the most economically skilled heads of state in the world. 
 So why should financiers worry? Because Mr. Zedillo has never before run for office, and because he has a wooden style of speech and an aloof manner that will not help much in calming a nation distraught by three months of violence and demands for social justice. Many investors are now concerned more about political instability than about inflation.
The Mexican stock exchange, which reacted modestly to Mr. Zedillo's selection on Tuesday, was closed today for the long Easter weekend.
 
Politically Educable
 "What's not clear is the sort of political skills he might bring to the job," said Lawrence D. Krohn, chief Latin American economist at Lehman Brothers. "To what extent he might command the support of the majority of poor and lower-class Mexicans is another area of concern. He's reputed not to have the common touch, but then neither did Salinas. He's young enough, though. He could learn."
Mr. Zedillo, 42, is widely known as a free-market economist who cut his teeth within the polished walls of the Banco de Mexico, the nation's conservative central bank. He has been a key member of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's team, serving almost four years as Minister of Planning and Budget and two years as Education Secretary.
He is expected to continue most of Mr. Salinas's economic programs, having had a strong hand in carrying them out, and is known to support the North American Free Trade Agreement. Mexican business was pleased with his selection. Luis German Carcoba Garcia, president of the Business Coordinating Council, said the choice of Mr. Zedillo was a clear signal that current economic programs would continue.
 
Yale, and the Baja
 The candidate is no stranger to the United States. Years before his time at Yale, he grew up on the poor streets of the border city of Mexicali on the Baja peninsula.
He attended Yale on a scholarship from the Mexican Government. A thesis adviser, Gustav Ranis, remembers Mr. Zedillo as "always a moderate in his view, not a rabid free-marketeer nor an interventionist -- a very mature person even at a young age."
"He is someone who believes in the role of government very much," Professor Ranis, an international economist, continued, "but he wants the government to work with the market, not obstruct it."
While at the Bank of Mexico in the years after the Mexican debt crisis of 1982, Mr. Zedillo oversaw a multibillion-dollar trust set up to help private businesses that could not pay their international debts because the peso had been devalued and dollars were hard to come by. The trust made sure that dollars were available, and also protected the businesses from further peso fluctuation.
"It was an amazingly successful program that has not received much public attention," said Gabriel Szekely, a Mexico City consultant. "But for the business community it was very relevant, which explains why Zedillo has so much clout with business."
 
Experience Under Salinas
 In 1988, Mr. Zedillo joined Mr. Salinas's Cabinet. He took control of the Office of Budget and Planning, the same office once held by Mr. Salinas and by the President before him, Miguel de la Madrid. Mr. Zedillo played a key role in drawing up a national development plan and the programs that have helped lower Mexico's inflation rate to single digits.
As Education Secretary, he dismantled the federal education system and gave responsibility to the 31 states. In doing so, the power of the national teachers' union was broken.
The slain candidate whom Mr. Zedillo replaced, Luis Donaldo Colosio, had also been seen as representing continuity. However, after impoverished Maya Indians in Chiapas state took up arms, Mr. Colosio moved slightly from a technocratic approach of the Salinas reforms toward the view that Mexico had too many millionaires and too many poor people to continue without a clash.
Raul Munoz Leos, president of Du Pont of Mexico, looked to the future. "We should not kid anybody into thinking that he isn't in for a tough time," he said of Mr. Zedillo. "Like Salinas, he will need an excellent team. If he can put it together it will not be a cake walk, but I feel confident that he will be able to do it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Companies Cut Back New Issues

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Frightened by the prospect of rising interest rates and economic uncertainty, American corporations' appetite for cash from the public markets decreased in the first three months of this year, and in turn, investment firms saw their fees drop.
The pullback, while slight, is the first after 13 quarters of increasing demand for public cash and is perhaps the strongest sign yet that Wall Street's biggest and longest payday in history may be drawing to a close. 
 Corporations issued $262.1 billion in debt and equity securities in the first quarter, ended yesterday, down 2.6 percent from the $269.2 billion issued in the first three months of 1993, according to the Securities Data Company, a research company.
With years of interest rate declines, corporations rushed to refinance debt at lower costs, even as investors weresearching for higher yields. That search helped the equity markets, allowing companies to fetch top dollar for new stock issued to the public.
But now that interest rates are inching up, the trend is reversing. Corporations are holding fast to recently issued lower-rate debt, and the equity markets have been battered, making new equity issues more difficult.
So after more than three years of celebration on Wall Street, underwriters are looking ahead with concern. "Clearly if this market goes on, we're going to have a bit of trouble," said John R. Barber, managing director and head of equity capital markets at Kidder, Peabody & Company, a unit of the General Electric Company.
On the debt side, the drop in corporate issues was offset in part by a big increase in debt issues by Federal credit agencies. These issues jumped to their highest level ever for a three-month period.
As a result, underwriters said the quarter was busy, but far from exciting. "If you can have such a thing as a quiet $100 billion quarter, it was a quiet $100 billion quarter," said Grant Kvalheim, head of the debt capital markets desk at Merrill Lynch & Company.
The effects of the quarter's downturn are already being seen on Wall Street's bottom line. Disclosed fees dropped in the quarter to $2.1 billion, down 2.8 percent from the fees in the first quarter of last year.
The biggest underwriter for the quarter was Merrill, the perennial leader since 1988. The firm issued $43.1 billion of securities, capturing 16.5 percent of the market, down from 19.1 percent in the first quarter of 1993.
The big news on Wall Street was the performance of Kidder, Peabody, a firm that had seen its fortunes slide significantly since the late 1980's amid a series of missteps.
In a strong sign that the firm may have put its bad days behind it, Kidder jumped to second place as an underwriter, up from sixth in the first quarter of last year. Such a big move in the underwriting rankings is rare, and Wall Street executives said the firm's performance in the next few quarters would be critical in deciding whether it signaled a long-term recovery.
Almost all of the change came from Kidder's decision to focus on mortgage-backed debt, through issuing what are known as collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.'s. With C.M.O.'s, mortgages are pooled and separated by maturity. Those separate tranches, as they are called, then pay varying interest rates.
Kidder issued $29.2 billion in domestic new issues during the quarter, of which $25.4 billion, or 87 percent, were mortgage-backed debt.

HEADLINE: Fourth-Quarter '93 Gain For Economy Cut to 7%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The economy surged ahead at its briskest clip in 10 years in the closing months of 1993, the Commerce Department said today, even though growth was not quite as strong as previously projected.
The Government lowered its estimate of fourth-quarter gross domestic product from a month ago to show national output expanding at a 7 percent annual rate instead of 7.5 percent in the last quarter of 1993. 
 But it still was the strongest quarterly growth since the beginning of 1984, when the Reagan-era expansion hit its stride with a first-quarter gain of 7.9 percent.
The G.D.P. measures all goods and services produced by workers and capital in the United States.
 
 
Market Decline Eases
 Mounting evidence of solid expansion has driven long-term interest rates higher, sending the stock market into a five-day dive that finally appeared to lose steam today.
"The paradox is that the terrific performance of the economy in part has caused the Federal Reserve to start raising interest rates," said Allen Sinai, a Lehman Brothers economist in New York.
"This is a very, very powerful upswing in the economy during the fourth quarter, driven by private spending and still with low inflation and it has continued into the first quarter," Mr. Sinai said.
Other economic reports today also showed strength.
The Chicago purchasing managers said their regional business barometer rose to a seasonally adjusted 66.5 in March from 60.3 in February with its employment measure the highest in five and a half years.
Brighter job prospects, usually associated with rising wages, showed up in a report from the Labor Department saying new jobless pay claims fell to 330,000 last week from 340,000 a week earlier.
And the Conference Board Help Wanted index, which tracks advertisements for new jobs, rose 10 points in February, to a seasonally adjusted 115 from 105 in January.
 
 
Further Growth Foreseen
 Even with harsh winter weather and a California earthquake, Mr. Sinai predicted that the gross domestic product would grow again in the current first quarter at a 3 to 3.5 percent rate -- a slower but still healthy rate of expansion.
The key reason for lowering fourth-quarter G.D.P. -- less inventory-building than first thought -- in fact suggested strength rather than slackening since it meant companies had leaner stocks of goods ready to sell as 1994 began.
The other reason for the revision was slightly less vigorous consumer spending than first estimated for the fourth quarter. But it was a smaller factor than lower inventories.
