HEADLINE: For Many, Buyout Offer Is Too Small, Workers Say

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
In the corridors and offices of government buildings throughout New York City, municipal workers expressed skepticism yesterday over the severance packages that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is offering as a way to cut the size of government, saying the size of the money offers was unappealing.
But a few said they would jump at the chance to leave their jobs; some older workers saw it as an opportunity to retire early, while younger ones saw a chance to pursue other career goals. 
 Under an agreement that Mr. Giuliani and leaders of the municipal labor unions reached Wednesday evening, 80,000 workers will be offered sums ranging from $3,500 to $15,000 to leave their jobs. From the 80,000, the administration hopes to eliminate 7,600 positions.
Although administration and union officials were optimistic that enough workers would accept the offers, interviews with dozens of city workers yesterday indicated that the plan was not being embraced wholeheartedly.
 
'I Still Have Bills'
 "I don't want to be laid off, but I don't consider this severance package to be very appealing, either," said Sarah Peoples, a 36-year-old supervisor at the headquarters downtown of the city's Human Resources Administration.
With 11 years of service, Ms. Peoples, the mother of a 15-year-old son, would receive a $10,000 payment if she decided to take the severance package. "But then what would I do?" she asked. "I still have a son to support. I still have bills. Then what?"
Like Ms. Peoples, other workers spent the day grappling with what the plan meant for them. They wondered how far the money would take them. They asked themselves whether it was too late to begin another career or whether finding a new job was realistic in a city struggling to recover from a recession.
"I guess the Mayor is trying to downsize the government, and I understand that," said Edwardo Walker, a 34-year-old caseworker for the Human Resources Administration. "But I just came to this job in September after working for years as a salesman in clothing stores. I came here for the security. And a severance package of $3,500 isn't much security. I'm I going to take it? I don't think so."
At age 65 and with 30 years' tenure, James Flanagan is the kind of worker that administration officials consider the most likely to take the package. But Mr. Flanagan, who processes eligibility information for the Department of Social Services in an office in TriBeCa, said he was not interested.
"I don't really think it's that great," Mr. Flanagan said of the severance package. Although he is eligible to retire and plans to in a few years, he said: "You have to look at it very carefully. I have a job I enjoy."
Under the agreement, the severance offers will range from $3,500 or two weeks pay for newly hired workers to $15,000 for workers with 30 or more years of service, as well as nine months of health care benefits for all who accept the package.
Many workers said that they might take advantage of the offer if they were closer to retirement age or young enough to begin a new career or if they were interested in moving to another city. But most said they had families and roots in New York and did not see a severance package of, say, $10,000 as a sufficient nest egg in an uncertain economy.
"I don't like it," said a nutritional aide at the Queens office of the Department of Health, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "I prefer to have my job. It makes absolutely no sense. What do they think they're dealing with, stupid people? Nobody should agree to this unless they are going to quit anyway."
However, a few said they welcomed the opportunity to move on.
"I've been here 11 years and I need a break," said David Ortiz, a 37-year-old manager at Human Resources. "To me, it's a fair offer. I want to go for a Ph.D. in social work administration. My feeling is, I'm young and I have time to create a new career. I'm not fearful of getting out there. But a lot of people are."
Julio Perez, who works for the tuberculosis division of the Department of Health in Jackson Heights, Queens, said many of his colleagues were considering taking the severance package. "Some of my friends say they hope they get it," Mr. Perez said. "In tuberculosis, the turnover is very high. Since most people are on the way out, they'll take the buyout."
Union offices were bombarded with questions from workers yesterday. Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America even set up a special telephone line with a recording explaining details of the severance package. "The phones are jumping, people calling in," said Stanley Hill, the executive director of the city's largest union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
 
'People Will Be Devastated'
 Although many workers expressed concern about their own employment situations, they also pointed out the pain the work force reductions would cause in their agencies. "It's definitely going to hurt people," said Cheyenne Isom, who works in the infectious disease division of the tuberculosis control office. "Why cut programs that help people? A lot of people will be devastated."
He, too, said he finds the severance package unappealing. "Two weeks' severance pay is not enough for baby food," he said. "In four weeks you're out on the street."
Another worker in tuberculosis control, Damita Evans, said that the reduced staff will cripple services to patients. "Having less staff will hurt our patients," she said. "I know these people personally. The buyouts are not a good idea. I like my job. I want to be here for my patients."

HEADLINE: Spring Ritual In Albany: Lots of Talk, No Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 1

 BODY:
New York State began its fiscal year this morning without a budget, the 10th consecutive year that has happened, as negotiations between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature remained deadlocked over a broad range of issues.
Despite a full day of furious negotiations yesterday, Mr. Cuomo and leaders of the Democratic-controlled Assembly and Republican-controlled Senate could not agree on even the broad outlines of a budget by midnight, as they had hoped. 
 "It should be on time, there's no excuse for it not being on time," Mr. Cuomo said in an afternoon news briefing. "It is a more orderly thing."
The two houses did pass legislation providing nearly $12 billion for the operation of state agencies, ensuring that state workers will be paid next week. That bill also included $23 million intended to decrease prison overcrowding by creating 950 new prison beds.
But nearly every major budget issue, including whether the state should assume the Medicaid costs of county governments, what taxes to cut and how to allocate billions in aid to schools and local governments, remained unresolved.
 
'A Lot of Heavy Lifting'
 "There's a lot of heavy lifting yet to go," said John A. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican.
Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said through spokesmen that they hoped all three leaders could meet later this morning to reach a "handshake agreement" on a budget.
At best, aides to Mr. Cuomo and the leaders said, that agreement could provide a balance sheet overview of how to cut taxes, how to spend about $33 billion in the coming year and how much in revenue the state can expect. But negotiations over the difficult details of the budget will not really begin until next week.
Among the major sticking points in negotiations is how, and whether, the state should pick up Medicaid costs now borne by county governments. Mr. Cuomo has proposed a plan that would call for the state to assume those costs gradually over several years. Local Medicaid costs total $3.4 billion this year.
The Medicaid takeover plan is particularly important to New York City because Mr. Cuomo's plan had called for injecting $130 million into Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget for the city fiscal year beginning July 1. Mr. Giuliani is struggling to close a projected $2.3 billion deficit.
The three sides also remain far apart in talks over how much to cut taxes. Mr. Cuomo, when he introduced his $33.4 billion budget in January, proposed a package of business tax cuts totaling between $200 million and $300 million in this fiscal year.
But last week, the Senate offered a competing plan calling for $700 million in cuts, most of them for businesses. Mr. Cuomo and the Assembly Democrats argue that there is not enough money to make cuts that deep.
Just as thorny is the issue of how much money to give to local schools. Mr. Cuomo has called for increasing school aid by about $200 million in the coming year, but the Legislature is pushing to nearly double that amount.
One group closely watching the budget process is the bond raters who have given the state the second lowest bond ratings of the 50 states. Today, bond raters said that late budgets, while not a major reason for the low ratings, indicate the inability of Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature to agree on how to fix the state's fiscal problems.
"When other states were confronted with similar problems in the recession, many made hard decisions to cut services or raise taxes," said Catherine Fleischmann, a vice president with Moody's Investors Service.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rise Following Early Slide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury prices recovered from an early plunge to end slightly higher yesterday as traders bought securities to unwind speculative positions ahead of the Government's report today on March employment.
The bond market will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond, down nearly a point in early trading, closed up 7/32 point, or $2.19 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, fell to 7.08 percent, from 7.09 percent on Wednesday, after surging above 7.18 percent in early trading.
Prices initially tumbled after the Chicago Purchasing Managers Association reported that its index of Midwest business activity rose sharply last month. A widely watched component that shows prices paid for raw materials was also up.
The report reinforced the inflationary fears that have hammered the market in recent weeks. Stronger economic growth can aggravate inflation, which erodes the value of fixed interest-bearing investments.
"This is a market that has an extreme intolerance to any strength reflected in economy numbers," said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets.
Aggravating the price decline, some managers of investment funds sold 7- and 10-year Treasury notes to minimize their losses in mortgage-based securities, said Frank Sannella, money market analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
But the Treasury market regained ground, partly because the tumblng stock market reassured some traders that investors would seek out fixed-income securities as an alternative.
 
Employment Data Awaited
 Bond traders also braced for a key barometer of economic performance, the March employment report. Short-sellers, who had sold borrowed securities with the intention of profiting from a price decline, bought them back in order to close out their positions before the weekend, since the bond market is closed today. The heightened demand prompted by these purchases drove prices up in what is known as a short-covering rally.
Short-term Treasury issues fell 1/32 point, while Treasury notes with intermediate maturities rose 2/32 to 4/32 of a point.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.12, to 1,244.55.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, surged to 4.5 percent ahead of the holiday weekend, up from 3.36 percent late Wednesday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9118/32 , down 19/32 from late Wednesday. The average yield to maturity was 6.36 percent, up from 6.26 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Concerns Over U.S. Stocks and Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday as weakness in the stock and bond markets and uncertainty ahead of a holiday weekend prompted investors to sell.
Stocks and bonds were lower for much of the day although they recovered somewhat near the close. Analysts said this weakness was enough to drive the dollar lower. 
 Concerns about the Government's report today on March unemployment also persuaded investors to sell dollars.
"People were just divesting," said Hillel Waman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company. "Foreign money that was invested in the dollar market disappeared."
Mr. Waxman said the weakness in stocks and bonds was prompting investors -- particularly market participants from overseas -- to pull their money out of dollar-denominated investments, driving down demand.
 
New U.S.-Japan Concerns
 Also putting pressure on the dollar were new concerns about trade tension between the United States and Japan, as Washington singled out Tokyo as the worst offender when it released its annual hit list of countries erecting egregious barriers to trade.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 102.75 Japanese yen from 102.85 yen.
The dollar also fell to 1.6730 German marks from 1.6755 marks.
The stock and bond markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Good Friday and many overseas markets will also be closed. But there will be limited currency trading.
The stock market experienced its worst weekly decline since October 1989 this week. Bond prices have weakened as well, ever since the Federal Reserve decided in early February to push up short-term interest rates to head off inflation.
Normally, higher interest rates tend to help the dollar, noted Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group.
Several economic reports that showed the economy growing corporate profits up in the final quarter of 1993 were not enough to stem the dollar selling.
The British pound was trading late in New York at $1.4845, up from $1.4795 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Wednesday, included: 1.4125 Swiss francs, down from 1.4185; 5.7180 French francs, down from 5.7265; 1,613.00 Italian lire, down from 1,630.00 and $1.3825 (Canadian), up from $1.3793

HEADLINE: Prepaying Mortgage Adds Up to Big Savings

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Michael and Maria Walters, like millions of other Americans, refinanced their mortgage last year, paring their monthly payments and saving thousands of dollars in interest. But they didn't stop there.
The Walters are adding $134.46 to their new monthly payment of $902.44 to reduce the loan principal. At this pace, they will pay off their $127,500 fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage in 20 years and save $76,019 in interest over the life of their new loan. 
 "It is amazing," Mrs. Walters said. "For just a little bit more money, it makes so much difference."
No statistics are available on how many Americans are regularly prepaying their mortgages by using what some homeowners call "pocket change." The number, though, is thought to be increasing. Indeed, with the number of refinancings declining and mortgage interest rates rising, prepaying may now be the most practical way to shorten the length of a mortgage or hold down costs.
"It doesn't pay to take that extra money that it costs to refinance into a new loan," if there is not a difference of at least two percentage points in the interest rates, said Anita Amlong, a mortgage consultant with Hudson City Savings in Rhinebeck, N.Y. "People would be better off prepaying on the principal."
The technique is a simple one, and borrowers should be wary of expensive software and books that promise to show the best way to prepay a mortgage. Products like the Mortgage Controller often provide little more than mortgage amortization tables, which are generally available in bookstores at a fraction of the cost.
Borrowers should also scrutinize services with official-sounding names like the BiSaver Program and Billie Mac, the Biweekly Mortgage Acceptance Corporation. Borrowers send mortgage payments once every two weeks to these services, which then pay the lenders; the 26 installments result in an extra monthly payment each year, which is supposed to reduce the mortgage principal.
In some cases, the additional payment, when received by the lender, is not applied to principal but is deposited in an escrow account for taxes or credited partly or entirely toward interest.
"People should not waste any money on middlemen to do something they can arrange for themselves with their lender," said Paul Richard, vice president and director of education for the National Center for Financial Education, a nonprofit organization based in San Diego.
All it usually takes to pay off a mortgage early, Mr. Richard said, is putting an extra amount in the monthly mortgage check. A note should be made on the payment coupon stating that the additional money is to be credited toward principal.
Follow up with a phone call to the lender after the first prepayment, he said, to make sure it is properly credited. "People get into trouble sometimes when they just send in the extra money without an explanation," he said.
Aside from overpriced, gimmicky services, there are a few useful and inexpensive guides, Mr. Richard added. He likes the Banker's Secret, a computer program selling for $39.95, which helps homeowners calculate how much they will save if they prepay various amounts. It could be particularly useful for someone who wants to pay off a loan before an anticipated life event, like retirement or a child's entering college. The Banker's Secret is also available in book form for $14.95. (Good Advice Press, Elizaville, N.Y., 12523. 800 255-0899.)
"If folks have the extra money, prepaying is something that they should definitely do," Mr. Richard said. "We recommend that people do everything they can to reduce debt."
Of course, taking out a shorter-term mortgage, like a 15-year loan, can result in similar savings. With a shorter-term loan, however, credit hurdles may be higher, and down payment requirements may be larger. Borrowers are also locked into bigger payments each month.
"Prepaying gives you flexibility," said Mrs. Walters, who stays at home to care for Lisa, 7, and Diana, 3, while Mr. Walters works as a police officer. "If there is an emergency, and you need money for something, you can get it by cutting back on the extra amount you are paying."
Even homeowners with 15-year mortgages, already saving substantial amounts in comparison with 30-year mortgages, can save more interest -- and build equity faster -- by prepaying. For example, a 15-year $100,000 mortgage at 7.5 percent can be paid off eight months sooner by adding $25 to every $927.02 payment, and $3,585 in interest will be saved.
Rob Rosenblatt, director of surveys for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a trade group based in Washington, said most lenders no longer had or enforced penalties for such prepayments. "It has become a standard practice to accept them, and the service departments are already geared up for them," he said.
Where prepayment penalties exist, they often cover just the first few years of a mortgage, said Marc Eisenson, publisher of the Bankers Secret, and they are minute, generally 1 percent of the amount prepaid.
Prepayment penalties are remnants from the days when there were few fees or closing costs associated with a mortgage, he added. Today, closing costs and fees more than cover lenders' losses on prepayments.
"Nowadays, you can even ask the lender to remove the prepayment penalty from the mortgage, and they are very likely to," he said.
A final note of caution: homeowners should make prepayments only after they have paid debts with higher interest rates. "If you have credit cards charging 16 percent, you should definitely pay that down before you prepay your mortgage," Mr. Eisenson said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Maria and Michael Walters at their home in Massapequa, L.I., where they are prepaying their mortgage. (Vic DeLucia for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 456,000 Jobs Added in March, Largest Payroll Gain in 6 Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Rebounding strongly from the effects of harsh midwinter weather, the economy generated 456,000 new jobs in March, the largest expansion of employers' payrolls in more than six years and nearly twice the growth that analysts had expected, the Labor Department reported today.
At the same time, the unemployment rate, which is calculated from a separate survey of the nation's households, was unchanged at 6.5 percent, the department said. 
 The agency's monthly jobs report, combined with separate figures from the Commerce Department showing hefty advances in incomes and spending for February, sent interest rates soaring in limited holiday trading.
Traders and investors fear that overly rapid economic expansion will revive inflation at a time the Federal Reserve is trying to quell any such outbreak before it becomes evident.
The 30-year bond, a benchmark for long-term interest rates, plunged $19.38 for each $1,000 of face value in a shortened trading session, raising its yield to new buyers to 7.26 percent, from 7.08 percent. [Page 35.]
The nation's stock exchanges, which failed in strenuous attempts over several weeks to persuade the Government to switch publication of the employment data to either Thursday or Monday, were closed in observance of Good Friday. Because officials would not give in, investors were largely precluded from reacting, from Thursday afternoon to Monday morning, to news that deviated more than usual from economists' expectations.
At a White House briefing, the President's top economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, said the bond market seemed to be "overreacting" in its extended slide. She said inflation remained subdued, or was still declining, by almost every published measure.
"The picture is a moderate, sustainable recovery with very little in the way of inflationary pressure," Ms. Tyson said of the results an nounced today. She said she was sticking with a forecast for 1994 of 3 percent economic growth and two million more jobs.
The economy raced ahead at a rate of 7 percent in the final quarter of 1993, a level that nobody expects will be sustained in the face of restraining forces like tax increases, higher interest rates and significantly lower car production.
The University of Michigan struck a cautionary note today when it informed subscribers to its consumer survey that confidence had eased in March to a reading of 91.5 in its overall index, from 93.2 in February. That was in contrast to a sharp gain in consumer confidence reported this week by the Conference Board.
In yet another report, the Commerce Department said the value of construction at schools, factories, churches, highways, houses and other public and private projects amounted to $488.8 billion at an annual rate in February, 1.2 percent below the January pace.
 
 
Broad Gains in Jobs
 But the surprisingly good employment report dominated the economic news. The payroll expansion impressed analysts perhaps as much for its breadth as for its magnitude.
The construction industry added 74,000 jobs, lifting employment after two months of declines to well above the level that prevailed before the onset of especially severe winter weather.
Factories added 12,000 jobs in March, the sixth consecutive monthly gain; factories had shed 1.8 million jobs from the start of 1989 to last September, said Katharine G. Abraham, Commissioner of Labor Statistics.
Almost all categories of service jobs posted sizable gains, including a second straight jump in business services, mainly reflecting temporary help and employee leasing. Health services grew by 45,000 jobs, more than twice the average for January and February. Gains in restaurants and bars accounted for almost half of a jump of 74,000 retailing jobs.
The economic expansion "broadened considerably," said Mark Vitner, economist at the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C., suggesting that growth in the quarter that ended Thursday could be in a range of 3.5 to 4 percent.
 
 
Longer Hours
 Also impressive, analysts said, was the fact that factory workers put in longer hours, an average of 42.2 a week, and more overtime, at 4.8 hours, than at any time since World War II. The factory workweek soared by a full hour, more than making up for a decline of 36 minutes in February.
 The department's survey of households showed considerably less vigor -- in fact, employment declined by 221,000 -- but analysts noted that the survey had been overhauled and should probably be considered less reliable than the payroll survey -- at least until new seasonal adjustment factors are available.
This decline in jobs, about matched by a decline of 196,000 in the labor force, left the unemployment rate unchanged at 6.5 percent, the same as the fourth-quarter average.
Among the unusually large gyrations were a 184,000 rise in the ranks of people out of work for less than five weeks and a drop of 178,000 among people jobless for 5 to 14 weeks. Normally, such a jump in the newly unemployed would be an ominous sign of job-market deterioration, but officials discounted this move since it was not confirmed by weekly reports of first-time jobless claims.
Officials also attributed various suspect results to the overhaul of the household survey, which included changes in definitions and phrasing; the new survey was introduced with the figures for January. And they particularly noted that they must continue to rely on seasonal adjustment factors based on information collected under the old method.
Today's report also showed a very large increase -- 349,000, to a total of five million -- in the number of people working part time who wanted full-time employment, the so-called partly unemployed. This, however, was thought to be unreliable because of the faulty seasonal adjustment and because of a new definition.
The number of people with two or more jobs climbed 150,000 last month, to account for 5.9 percent of employed people, from 5.8 percent in February.
The total of so-called discouraged workers -- those who have given up looking for jobs because they think they cannot find any -- rose by 44,000 in March, to 533,000.
Among the largest states, only three showed changes of clear statistical significance in their unemployment rates. These were jumps of 1.7 points for Pennsylvania and 1.6 points for Florida, and a decline of 1.4 points for Michigan.
The jobless rates were mixed in the two largest states. California's rate dropped to 8.6 percent in March, from 9 percent in February. In New York State, the rate rose to 8.1 percent, from 7.8 percent in February.
In New Jersey, the rate was 7.9 percent, compared with 7.3 percent in February.

HEADLINE: Charlotte's Downtown Manages To Stay Up Late for Tournament

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 1

 BODY:
It's been called Potemkin Village with a drawl.
Whatever it is, the basketball fans and corporate bigwigs flocking to this shiny banking center for college basketball's Final Four weekend are enjoying a new dimension in disposable culture -- an instant downtown as permanent as a movie set. 
 Charlotte's downtown -- it goes by the perky appellation of "uptown" here -- has been abuzz since Thursday night with a vibrant street life of youngsters bouncing Pizza Hut basketballs, revelers slurping pina coladas and hoop fans strolling to and from clubs offering everything from country to Cajun to comedy. The festivities are concentrated in a four-block area just off the heart of downtown that is modestly being called "The Street of Champions."
Come Tuesday, most of this bustling entertainment zone will revert back to the somnolent streetscape of abandoned buildings and vacant lots it was at the beginning of the week.
"We have never pretended that this was anything more than a temporary fix," said Brandon Uttley, a spokesman for the Charlotte Organizing Commitee, which raised $2 million to lure and stage the Final Four and created the entertainment zone. "Charlotte is a city of suburbs, a city of malls. We needed to augment what was already uptown."
But in this prosperous citadel of gleeful sprawl, where the booster gene is the dominant biological strain, the effort has a familiar ring.
"The shame of it is that the city looks absolutely gorgeous," said Ron Morgan, a local architect and former professor at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "It's swept clean and polished. But nobody's there. We've created the most beautiful downtown of any new city in the United States, but in many ways it's empty and antiseptic."
Indeed, Charlotte's shiny new collage of mirrored glass, capped by the 60-story Nations Bank Corporate Center, has the eerily immaculate feel of an instant metropolis. The trouble is, it is pretty much a ghost town outside 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. on weekdays.
"Usually, there's no one here," said Brian Murphy of nearby Denver, N.C., as he sampled the wares today at Fat Tuesday's, which for five days will be dispensing frozen daiquiris, "jungle juice" and something ominously called "190 octane" from an other-times vacant savings and loan building. "Downtown is empty after 5 P.M. There's nothing to do."
So the organizing committee brought in six clubs, four in vacant buildings, two in huge tents placed on vacant lots, plus armies of street vendors, to create instant night life and grazing stations for the fans coming to see Duke, Arkansas, Arizona and Florida face off in college basketball's biggest event.
The Comedy Zone, a fast-paced entertainment spot, is next door to The Zone, a noisy sports bar and disco. There's Cajun music, black beans and rice and jambalaya at Mardi Gras, while country music serenades listeners at Diamond Spur. The shop hawking Final Four souvenirs and T-shirts at the corner of Third Street and South Tryon either occupies a building that used to house a financial institution, or it is the only T-shirt shop in history insured by the F.D.I.C.
 
Meeting Visitors' Needs
 The businesses are renting the space and giving 15 percent of their gross to the organizing committee.
Organizers say the idea is to meet visitors' entertainment needs, not to fool anyone.
"I guess that it's fake and chicanery when your in-laws come to see you on Easter and you go out and cut the yard and rake up the leaves," said Johnny Harris, chairman of the organizing committee. "You know we have about 3,200 restaurant seats in uptown Charlotte. If you figure 25 percent of the 80,000 people coming to town will end up uptown that's 20,000 people. If they want to eat, what are they going to do in 3,200 seats?"
Still, in this famously eager-to-please town, where even the normally gung-ho Charlotte Observer today headlined one column -- "Please try to like us a lot. Please." -- the effort has drawn considerable notice.
 
'Anything to Please'
 In the spirit of the occasion, a local weekly, Creative Loafing, printed a picture of the New York skyline on its cover with the words, "Welcome to Charlotte! Final Four Fans, We'll Do Anything to Please You." Inside it offered its own tour of "The City of Champions" with the White House as the Mayor's Mansion, The Eiffel Tower as James K. Polk's birthplace, and the Taj Mahal as the city's Mint Museum.
To be sure, if Charlotte is the kind of place inordinately given to showing off, part of that reflects the fact that it has a lot to crow about these days.
Charlotte and Atlanta have consistently vied with each other to lead the nation in job growth over the last five years. Largely because of the breakneck growth of Nations Bank, it has become the nation's third largest banking center, behind New York and San Francisco. Its unemployment rate is below 4 percent.
"I resent the suggestion that we're just all image," said Mayor Richard Vinroot, noting Charlotte successes ranging from scattered-site housing for the poor to a successfully integrated school system. "We're the No. 1 job creating city in America. That's substance. That's what it's all about."
City officials add that a new convention center and new football stadium, along with concert and cultural institutions at the other end of downtown, will begin breathing more life into the area. Others are less sure, saying Charlotte's glossy skyscrapers, connected by antiseptic skyways and filled with elegant urban malls, and its suburban culture are antithetical to the urban feel the Street of Champions is artificially creating.
And no one denies that Charlotte has its share of drugs, crime, poverty and the other ills of modern urban life.
"They've taken a lot of vacant buildings and built a temporary circus, but when the circus leaves, there's nothing left behind," said Burton Gellman, who recently closed a restaurant and jazz club that vainly tried to make it downtown. "Charlotte is nothing more than one large suburban community. People in Charlotte are scared to death of the center city."
Still, for now, the dogwoods are in bloom, the President is coming to town, North Carolina fell but Duke made it to the final games; even the few cynics can't get too upset.
"You know, these days, when so many cities have clouds hanging over them and people afraid, this place is really not too bad," said Bob Raiford, a radio disk jockey with a reputation for being a perennial malcontent. "As much as I try to be a burr under their saddle, I wouldn't want to live anywhere else."
He paused, thinking of all the well-scrubbed movers and shakers bustling around town, and added, "I really think, though, if you added some ladies' coleslaw wrestling, something that would bring in a lot of bikers, it might liven things up, wouldn't you think?"

An artist, Joann Wilcox , put the final touches on the street. (Donna Bise for The New York Times) (pg. 7)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
 
More Americans found jobs in March than in any month in six years, the Labor Department reported. The economy generated 456,000 new jobs in March, nearly twice the growth that analysts had expected. At the same time, the unemployment rate, which is calculated from a separate survey of the nation's households, was unchanged at 6.5 percent. [Page 1.] Employment in New York City increased sharply in March, but was little changed in New York State and New Jersey, the agency said. [36.]
 
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani won the crucial approval of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation to use a $200 million surplus to pay for severance packages the Mayor hopes will cut 7,600 jobs from New York City's municipal work force. [1.]
 
 
Markets
 
The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 7.26 percent, the highest since January 1993, in limited and thin holiday trading, reacting to the surprisingly strong jobs data. The price of the long-bond dropped, but the decline may have been exaggerated by the absence of many investors on Good Friday. The stock market and most futures markets were closed. [35.]
 
The moves by the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates took a toll on a wide swath of stocks in the first quarter of 1994, many included in closely watched benchmark averages. [38.]
 
The dollar jumped against most leading currencies as American interest rates surged after the Government's report showing the biggest jobs gain since 1987. [38.]
 
 
International
 
Two Chicago entrepreneurs see a $1 billion market in instant lotteries in the former Soviet Union, where they are aggressively using Western-style marketing to generate interest. [35.]
 
A unit of Telefonica de Espana has snapped up Latin American telephone interests and made them profitable, beating American companies for deals in their own backyard. [35.]
 
Japan's leading semiconductor companies are planning a collaborative research institute aimed at improving their technology and competitiveness. [37.]
 
The French Government canceled the sale of Banque Hervet after disclosing heavy losses at the bank, a move that was the first big hitch in France's ambitious privatization program. [37.]
 
 
Companies
 
Novell was expected to announce the successor to its chief executive, Raymond J. Noorda, who is retiring. Industry speculation has identified two front runners for the job: Robert Frankenberg of Hewlett-Packard, and Ellen Hancock, the highest-ranking woman executive at I.B.M. [35.]
 
Citicorp completed the sale of its Quotron Systems unit to Reuters Holdings for $12.8 million, ending a long quest by the banking company to shed the money-losing business. [37.]
 
Former corporate raider Paul A. Bilzerian has been hired by a Utah software company to help resolve its financial problems. [37.]
 
 
Your Money
 
Conservative investors should consider buying stocks that pay generous dividends, given the uncertainty of how high interest rates will rise. [33.]
 
Investors in El Paso are reluctant to buy Mexican securities, a hint that the ability to survey a foreign market by looking out the window may be worth something. [33.]
 
Prepaying mortgages can slash interest costs and shorten the length of the loan. [33.]
 
Looking for a last-minute tax deduction? There is still time to put money into a tax-deferred retirement plan. [34.]

HEADLINE: Jobs Data Push Rates Up Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates climbed to their highest point in 14 months yesterday, as traders rushed to sell Treasury securities after the Government reported that the growth in jobs in March was far stronger than expected.
Trading was very thin in a short Good Friday session, exaggerating the price moves. Several analysts called the selloff an overreaction and were quick to question how much the surge in interest rates reflected the market's underlying sentiment. 
 "It's not justified, and the selling has reached the point of absurdity," said James Hale, a fixed-income analyst at MMS International.
Analysts also wondered how the bond and stock markets would react on Monday in a full trading session.
Little bond trading had been expected yesterday because the stock market and most other markets were closed in observance of Good Friday. But the strong employment report set off selling in Treasury futures trading in Chicago, which quickly spread to the cash market in New York.
Although the Public Securities Association had recommended closing the Treasury market for Good Friday, many securities firms had taken the precaution of having skeleton trading staffs on hand in case the employment report caused any market turbulence.
It certainly did.
 
A Surprisingly Big Number
 At 8:30 A.M., Eastern time, the Labor Department reported that the economy had created 456,000 jobs in March, the largest expansion of employers' payrolls in more than six years and nearly twice the growth that analysts had expected.
Almost immediately, traders began dumping Treasury securities on fears that the Federal Reserve would move again to push up interest rates in an effort to head off inflation in a rapidly growing economy. Within 30 minutes, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond had fallen about 2 points, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, surged to about 7.28 percent.
Trading ended before noon, with the 30-year bond down 129/32 , to 8727/32 , and its yield at 7.26 percent, up from 7.08 percent on Thursday. The 7.26 percent yield was the highest since Jan. 21, 1993, when the 30-year bond yielded 7.29 percent.
For investors holding 30-year bonds, the price decline meant a loss of $19.38 for each $1,000 invested.
For the week, the 30-year bond has risen a quarter of a percentage point.
Yields of other short- and intermediate-term Treasuries were also driven higher yesterday. The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose 13 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.60 percent. The yield on the five-year Treasury note rose to 6.43 percent, from 6.21 percent on Thursday, while the yield on the 10-year note jumped to 6.93 percent, from 6.73 percent.
The March employment report also showed that the jobless rate remained at 6.5 percent. But other figures reinforced the notion that the economy was surging. The Government said personal income rose 1.3 percent and spending increased 1 percent in February, the largest gains for both figures since last April.
Investors had been hoping that the economy would begin to slow, reducing any pressure the Fed might feel to push up interest rates. Some analysts said the strong pickup in new jobs in March reinforced the bond market's notion that interest rates were headed higher.
But other analysts are not sure how much the stronger-than-expected gain in employment was a result of weather distortions and how much was from a genuine acceleration in economic growth. They said the economy's average growth rate over the first quarter suggests that growth is not accelerating as much as yesterday's employment report would imply.
 
A Dissenting View
 Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, disagreed, saying he thought that the monthly average for job growth in the quarter, of 208,000 jobs, understated the true trend rate of payroll growth. "I see 250,000 to 300,000 in terms of trend, which is stronger than people have assumed," he said.
The bond market will be putting an intense focus on April's employment report, which will be released next month before the Fed's Federal Open Market Committee meets on May 17. The committee will decide what further action, if any, to take on interest rates.
Analysts at MMS International, a market research and analysis firm, quoted a Federal Reserve governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., as saying yesterday that the Fed must "see what the future brings" in terms of setting rates.
Mr. Kelley reportedly said that the market was being jolted by "emotion," and that he did not expect a surge of inflation, adding that there was still slack in the economy, though it may be diminishing.
 Mr. Fine said he expected the Fed to make its next move relatively soon, but he thought that would be good for the bond market.
"The sooner they get to 4 percent on the Federal funds rate the better in terms of convincing the bond market that its inflationary fears are overblown," Mr. Fine said. "And to tell you the truth, I don't know if the next move will be 25 basis points or 50 basis points."
Since Feb. 4, the Fed has moved twice to push up the Federal funds rate, the overnight rate on loans between banks. The rate has risen to 3.5 percent from 3 percent.
Mr. Hale of MMS International called yesterday's bond market selloff a "blood bath."
"There was no question that the reports were bearish in nature," he said. "You have to realize it's even more bearish considering the market's condition and its frenzied state. Anything that hints of bearish news is magnified by the nervous market."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Keeping Alive a Dream Snatched Off the Streets

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman 

 BODY:
JUST as Huberta Schroedel, a deaf educator, was about to seize her dream and open a newsstand where she could train deaf students to run their own businesses, someone stole the kiosk.
In mid-Manhattan, on Tuesday, in broad daylight, somebody took the entire structure in which Ms. Schroedel had invested more than $25,000 and years of effort. 
 "I first noticed it was gone when I came back from work," said the 50-year-old woman, who last saw the stand eight hours earlier as she passed it on her way to the campus of LaGuardia Community College in Queens, where she works with deaf youngsters.
"I was shocked, devastated. I freaked out," she said. "I just stood there at the spot on 57th Street near Ninth Avenue looking at nothing but the sidewalk. My little boy looked at me and told me not to cry."
"Who would steal a newsstand?" asked the robust blonde woman, still looking dazed two days after the theft. She said some shopkeepers on West 57th Street told her they had seen three men loading the stand onto a truck around noon, apparently in no hurry.
Though Ms. Schroedel appeared momentarily defeated, she is normally resolute, and her friends expect her to struggle on. They point out that not only had she fought hard to get as far as she did with the idea, but that she also had managed to earn two master's degrees, a principal's license, and to become a mother at the age of 45.
"I first thought of the newsstand six years ago," she explained. "I felt I could supplement my income and at the same time provide business training for deaf high-school students."
She applied for and received a license from the Department of Consumer Affairs. She designed the steel-and-wood kiosk and had it built. She took courses in business practices offered by the American Women's Economic Development Corporation, an organization that encourages women to be entrepreneurs. She began ordering publications and merchandise. When Con Edison demanded $15,000 to install electricity and the phone company asked for a similar amount, Ms. Schroedel contacted local officials who helped her negotiate more affordable terms.
"I also signed up five young people to work with me as interns," Ms. Schroedel said after answering questions for a detective. "Now there is nothing," she said. She shook her head and repeated, "Who would steal a newsstand?"
Robert Bookman, the head of the New York City Newsstand Operators Association, said he had never heard of such a crime. "Nobody steals news stands," said the director of the trade group. "We've had instances of vandalism and holdups, but never the complete removal of a stand."
Mr. Bookman, who had helped Ms. Schroedel obtain her license, said his first reaction after he heard of the stand was that perhaps the city had ordered it removed, because of some administrative ruling, or by mistake.
But Pat Cohen, a spokesperson for the Department of Consumer Affairs, which is supposed to know about any such move, reported that the city was not involved.
So who did? And why?
 Mr. Bookman said the only other motive he could imagine was that "people who did not want or did not like the idea of a newsstand being operated in that location may have decided to take the law into their own hands." He said he knew of instances in which newsstands had been vandalized for such reasons.
He said he had heard that, during the two years the stand stood unused, some neighborhood people had complained about it. But Ms. Cohen said there was no record of any complaints.
And on West 57th Street, as Ms. Schroedel was left wondering whether the police would find the thieves and recover the stand or whether her insurance would pay for the loss, the only comments on this day reflected sympathy for the would-be entrepreneur, and wonder at what the world was coming to.
The desk clerk at the Henry Hudson Hotel said he was aware the stand outside the hotel doors had vanished and he had heard it had been stolen. "That's terrible," he said. "We're living in craziness."
The manager of Body Holiday, a beauty shop, said she saw the stand being dismantled and assumed Ms. Schroedel, whom she knew on sight, had decided to move it elsewhere or to abandon the project. "I never thought they were stealing," she said. "How could you think something like that? It's like stealing a hydrant or stealing a street."
Or, as Ms. Schroedel is learning, like stealing a dream.

HEADLINE: Scandal Threatens Japan Premier's Hold on Power

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 1

 BODY:
With his coalition Government already pulling apart at the seams, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa has been plunged into a new crisis over questionable financial transactions that pose an increasingly serious threat to his precarious hold on power.
For days now Mr. Hosokawa, who was elected last year because of his image as a clean outsider ready to change the corrupt world of Tokyo politics, has been forced to answer questions about his financial dealings while he was governor of one of Japan's southern prefectures. There are widespread suspicions, which Mr. Hosokawa denies, that he received a $1 million loan from a trucking company now in the center of other political scandals and diverted it to a secret political fund. 
 While Mr. Hosokawa's political enemies have demanded answers and documents, Parliament has been frozen and the country entered a new fiscal year today without a budget.
 
Rising Tensions With U.S.
 The budget delay also worsens tension with the United States, which is pressing Tokyo for a quick, large-scale stimulation of the economy to boost imports. With Mr. Hosokawa's approval ratings having dropped below the 50 percent level, American officials say they are increasingly concerned that the growing political turmoil could force him out or derail any chance for Japan to make progress on its trade disputes in the first half of this year.
"It is beginning to look very serious," a senior American official here said this week. "Once again, everyone is wondering whether he will survive."
One of the questionable transactions involves a million dollar loan from the company at the center of the scandal that pulled down the Liberal Democrats, who were ousted from office last summer for the first time in 38 years.
Seeing a chance to taint Mr. Hosokawa with the same brush, the Liberal Democrats have stopped all legislative action for nearly four weeks now and turned parliamentary sessions into an inquisition. Mr. Hosokawa spent much of the week under harsh questioning and sidestepped repeated demands that he resign.
 
Trucking Company Loan
 The $1 million loan was made in 1982, just as Mr. Hosokawa became Governor of Kumamoto. Mr. Hosokawa said he borrowed the money from the Tokyo Sagawa transportation company, which at the time was beginning to pump cash to politicians as it sought regulatory clearance to expand its routes in Japan. He said he used the money to buy a small apartment in a Tokyo neighborhood and to repair his house in Kumamoto.
Mr. Hosokawa has insisted that he paid the loan back. But his only evidence that the loan was repaid is a receipt for the last installment, and the receipt does not bear the name of the lender or a seal or stamp, all of which are customary.
The company removed any claim regarding the loan in late 1991, though under Japanese law that does not necessarily mean the loan was paid back. The official recording of that change took more than a year, and happened just a few months before Mr. Hosokawa became Prime Minister.
Mr. Hosokawa has said he is unable to find other receipts, and he has twice changed the account of how he paid the money back. He will not permit his former secretary, Masatoshi Fukayama, to testify.
"If the loan has been for secret political funds, how could I have done such conspicuous things?" he asked on Wednesday.
 
Questions on Stock Purchase
 There are also questions of how Mr. Hosokawa's family obtained 300 shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone stock when the nationally controlled telecommunications company was sold to the public in 1986.
It was a virtual certainty that the shares would soar in value, so the stock offering was oversubscribed. Most investors were able to buy only a fraction of the stock they sought. But the Hosokawas managed to obtain all 300 shares they asked for, reportedly paying around $4 million. After the stock rose in value, two-thirds of the shares were sold to pay off the loan that financed their purchase, leaving a profit of roughly $500,000.
Mr. Hosokawa has angrily insisted that the transaction was in the name of his wife's father, who died last year, and that he was not involved. But a financial adviser said this week that he had arranged the loan to finance the purchase with one of Mr. Hososkawa's political aides.
Mr. Hosokawa said on Thursday that he has never met the consultant, Shuzo Fujiki. But, obviously exasperated, he raised his voice at politicians questioning him about the transaction, saying "Supposing it was my deal, what's wrong with that?"

HEADLINE: Budget Deal Announced But Details Are Lacking

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 1

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state's legislative leaders announced today that they had reached an agreement on the broad parameters of a $34 billion state budget, but then broke for the holiday weekend without actually enacting the budget or even providing details of their plan.
So for the 10th consecutive year, the state fiscal year started today without a budget in place, and there was no clear indication of when one would be adopted. 
 In a sketchily worded press release, Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders said the agreement would cut taxes, increase aid to local schools, create a college scholarship program for poor students and finance new construction projects.
Though state officials were reluctant to release details, some said the tax cuts, mostly for businesses, would be worth between $410 million and $460 million, a relatively small slice of the more than $30 billion the state expects to collect in taxes next year. School aid would be increased by about $400 million from the current $9.1 billion, they said, and the construction projects would include repairs to New York City schools and the building of new stadiums in upstate cities.
But Mr. Cuomo and the leaders failed to reach agreement on the Governor's proposal to have the state assume all Medicaid costs now borne by county governments, which this year are expected to reach $3.4 billion. Instead, they agreed on the broad outlines of a plan to have the state take over a small portion of those costs.
It seemed likely that the agreement would fall short of providing the $275 million in additional state aid that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had already calculated into his budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. But it seemed likely to come close to providing the $130 million that Mr. Giuliani had projected would come from a Medicaid takeover plan.
Officials close to the negotiations said New York City would receive about $130 million partly through state assumption of some Medicaid costs and partly through a new form of aid to all local governments.
"It is our belief that we will satisify the $130 million in the city's fiscal year," said Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker and a Manhattan Democrat. "Everybody's committed to doing that."
Last year, one minute after midnight on the first day of the fiscal year, Mr. Cuomo and the leaders also announced a budget agreement, then shook hands for television cameras and rushed off without providing details. It then took five days for the actual budget to be adopted.
Mr. Cuomo and all 211 lawmakers are up for re-election this fall, and chronically late state budgets have been a popular anti-incumbent theme in past races. Wall Street credit-rating firms have also said that late budgets are a factor in their decisions about grading state bonds, which currently have the second-lowest rating among the 50 states.
Even some officials close to the negotiations cast today's agreement in sardonic terms. "It's certainly not a handshake; it might have been a long-distance wink," said one of those officials, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Silver and his Senate counterpart, Ralph J. Marino, the majority leader and an Oyster Bay Republican, will seek approval of the agreement from their party colleagues on Monday. Until then, aides to both men said they could not release more information out of concerns that lawmakers would object to reading such details in newspapers before hearing them firsthand.
 
Benefits for Businesses
 "It's more important to get this done as quickly as possible," said John A. McArdle, a spokesman for Mr. Marino. He said that full adoption of the budget is not likely until late next week.
Most of the tax cuts are likely to be for businesses. When he introduced his budget in January, Mr. Cuomo recommended a package of reductions that included reducing the corporate surcharge to 12.5 percent from 15 percent, phasing out the 5 percent state tax on hotel rooms that rent for over $100 and giving poor working families a credit on the state's personal income taxes.
Since then, Mr. Cuomo has added a proposal to give companies a tax credit on operating losses dating back to 1990. All together, Mr. Cuomo's tax cut proposals would cost the state about $250 million in revenue during this fiscal year.
Last week, the Senate Republicans released their own tax cut plan that would call for $700 million in reductions, almost all for busineses, in the coming fiscal year. The plan included all of Mr. Cuomo's cuts, but deepened some, speeded up others and added several more to the list.
Today's agreement included a proposal from the Governor to create scholarships for poor high school graduates seeking to attend college in New York State. Known as Liberty Scholarships, the program was to have begun in 1991, but no money was provided because of budget cuts during the recession. Mr. Cuomo had asked for $68 million to start the program this year, but it was not clear whether he received that much in the agreement.
Under the agreement, the state capital budget will include several major construction projects sought by lawmakers. The Senate Republicans had requested over $60 million for new stadiums, swimming pools and recreational centers for the suburban towns and upstate cities many of them represent.
The Assembly Democrats had in turn sought about $60 million for a special fund to repair decrepit schools in New York City and its suburbs. It was not clear how much was allocated to each side, but officials close to the negotiations said the final amounts would be close to both sides' original requests.
They also agreed not to do several things that Mr. Cuomo had proposed when he introduced his budget in January. They rejected, for the second straight year, a proposal to create a state-run Keno game, which Mr. Cuomo said would have generated $74 million in state revenue this year.
They also killed a proposal by Mr. Cuomo to have the state take $70 million in unclaimed bottle deposits from beverage distributors. The money would have been used for park improvements, protecting wild land and closing landfills. Mr. Cuomo has said he will continue his efforts to seize the unclaimed deposits after the budget is adopted.

HEADLINE: After Fed Moves, the Quarter Ends Badly for Many Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
After playing host at a three-year party for the stock market, the Federal Reserve Board in the first quarter did what its former chairman, William McChesney Martin, once said the central bank inevitably had to do: It took away the punch bowl.
Not surprisingly, stocks were not ready for the music to stop when the Fed on Feb. 4 nudged up short-term interest rates, making it more expensive to borrow money. A second move by the Fed to raise short-term rates on March 22 only made it worse. 
 The message was not the sort that stock investors wanted to hear, especially after they piled money into shares as the Fed sharply lowered interest rates over the first three years of the decade. As such, the first three months of 1994 ended on a decidedly more discordant note for the stock market than they began.
"It was a gut-wrenching quarter," said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm.
The steep rise in interest rates that occurred in the first quarter took a toll on a wide range of stocks, many included in the closely watched market indexes. But the quarter was a good one for a large number of stocks, especially those whose fortunes are tied to a healthy economy.
Of the nearly 6,000 issues tracked by Media General Financial Services, more than 3,700 declined in value during the first quarter, while almost 2,100 moved higher. Just 163 emerged unchanged.
The brunt of the damage was done on the New York Stock Exchange, where declining issues outnumbered gainers by a ratio of more than 2 to 1. Losers also outnumbered winners on both the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq over-the-counter market, but by a much smaller order of magnitude.
That weakness dragged down the Big Board's important averages: the blue-chip Dow index fell 3.15 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 4.43 percent and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 4.29 percent.
More important, according to David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, was the year-over-year change in the S.& P. 500 index. For the first time since 1990, he said, the index ended a quarter lower than it had been a year earlier.
 
Climbing With the Economy
 Among industry groups, the quarter's best performers were generally those closely tied to upswings in the economy, a group that included engineering and construction companies, semiconductor manufacturers and trucking companies. Interest-sensitive stocks like savings and loans had a miserable three months, as did airlines, oil and gas drillers and houseware manufacturers.
Rising auto sales, a clear sign of healthier economic times, worked wonders for Breed Technologies, the Big Board's best performer during the quarter. Breed, an air bag manufacturer, saw its share price rise nearly 114 percent in the quarter.
Many investors in emerging markets got roughed up, thanks to rising interest rates and political uncertainty. But people who had invested in two Hungarian telephone ventures were all smiles. Hungarian Teleconstruction was the best-performing stock in Nasdaq trading last quarter, rising by more than 240 percent. Shares of Hungarian Telephone, the other company, rose 88 percent.
In a quarter littered with losers, there were nevertheless some spectacular declines. On the Big Board, Pharmaceutical Resources saw its shares lose nearly half their value after price cuts hurt sales of its generic drugs. Two companies that lost big postal contracts in the first quarter, Electrocom Automation and U.S. Banknote, fared almost as badly.
Harvard International Technologies, a maker of french-fry vending machines, was the worst performer on the American Stock Exchange. The company, which said during the quarter that it might seek court protection from creditors, saw its shares fall by 66.7 percent.
Analysts are now nervous about the stock market's outlook for the second quarter, following yesterday's selloff in the Treasury market, which pushed the yield on the 30-year bond to a 14-month high of 7.26 percent.
Bond prices fell in response to an unexpectedly strong report on employment conditions in March. Trading was very thin, indicating that the selloff was exaggerated. The stock market had no reaction; it was closed in observance of Good Friday.
The March employment figures were the strongest since those for October 1987, the month of the stock market crash.
"The bond market was reacting to the fact that credit demand is alive and well," Mr. Shulman of Salomon Brothers said. For the stock market, he said, "that means Monday is not going to be a pretty day."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on U.S. Report Of Big Job Growth in March

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar jumped against most leading currencies yesterday as American interest rates surged after a Government report showing the largest growth in jobs in more than six years.
Traders started buying dollars after the Labor Department said the economy had added 456,000 new jobs in March, nearly twice the growth that some analysts had expected. 
 "This was an earth-shattering employment number," said Alfonso Alejo, senior proprietary trader at Sakura Bank Ltd. "The economy has gathered a lot of momentum, which could mean a turning point for the dollar.
The unemployment rate remained at 6.5 percent. But another Government report noted that personal income rose 1.3 percent and spending 1 percent in February, the largest gains for both figures since last April.
In New York, the dollar rose to 1.6970 German marks, from 1.6730 on Thursday.
It also rose to 103.60 Japanese yen, from 102.75. But for the week, the dollar has fallen by 1.21 yen.
Currency trading was thin and ended around midday because of Good Friday. Financial markets in London, the world's biggest foreign-exchange center, and elsewhere were closed.
Investors often buy dollars after reports of economic strength, betting that growth will prompt the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates to keep inflation under control.
Until yesterday's rally, the dollar had fallen almost 4 percent against the mark since Jan. 1, hurt by sinking stock and bond prices and concerns about the Whitewater affair. Stubbornly high German interest rates also weighed on the dollar.
The dollar began its rise against the yen in early Tokyo trading, after the Bank of Japan bought dollars, traders said. The central bank bought dollars throughout March in an effort to keep the yen from rising. A strong yen hurts Japan's manufacturers by making their products more expensive abroad.
The dollar has fallen almost 5 percent against the yen since American-Japanese trade talks collapsed on Feb. 11.
The Canadian dollar tumbled to a seven-year low of 71.97 United States cents amid persistent concerns about Canada's debt. The Federal Reserve bought Canadian dollars to try to stem the slide, traders said. The Fed was probably buying on behalf of the Bank of Canada, which was closed for Good Friday.
The British pound finished in New York at $1.4740, down from $1.4845.

HEADLINE: New York City Gained 92,000 Jobs Last Month

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Employment in New York City increased sharply in March, but was little changed in New York State and New Jersey, the Labor Department said yesterday.
The employment data for the region reflected a less vigorous rate of economic expansion than for the nation as a whole. Only in New York City, which gained 92,000 jobs, were the employment gains similar to the surge experienced nationally. The department said 456,000 jobs were added nationwide last month. 
 New York City's job gains accounted for more than the 81,000 jobs that the agency said were added for all of New York State, meaning employment dipped slightly in communities outside New York City. In New Jersey, there were 31,000 fewer jobs in March than in the previous month.
 
Jobless Survey Is Changed
 The Labor Department said its method of figuring the unemployment rate -- which has always been a different measure of economic activity -- was changed last month. As a result, the agency said unemployment rates were higher throughout the region.
In New York City, which for years has had higher unemployment rates than the rest of the region, the jobless rate rose to 10.3 percent in March, from 10 percent in February, the agency said. In New York State, the rate rose to 8.1 percent, from 7.8 percent in February. In New Jersey, the rate rose to 7.9 percent, from 7.3 percent.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said yesterday that the increase in the actual number of jobs in New York City had brought employment in the city back to about the January level. The decline in February was due in part to the winter storms, he said.
 The employment data released yesterday covered only the largest industrial states, as is the case at the beginning of each month. March data for Connecticut were not included.
 
New Questionnaire
 Mr. Ehrenhalt said the Federal agency's method of calculating unemployment rates, which relies on a survey of households, was changed to include a new questionnaire and greater use of computers to analyze the results.
Because the unemployment rate is a measure of the part of the population that was not only out of work, but looking for jobs, Mr. Ehrenhalt said the changes were intended to provide a more accurate count of those who had been seeking work.
The new method identifies more women, teen-agers and people older than 65 who had made some effort to find jobs, and who might not have been counted in the past. It therefore tends to show a higher overall unemployment rate than was indicated under the previous method.

HEADLINE: Giuliani And Rangel Strike a Deal On U.S. Aid

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Congressman Charles B. Rangel said yesterday that they had reached an agreement on the boundaries of a Federal inner-city development program that has become the focus of a bitter political tug-of-war.
The program, the Government's largest inner-city development effort in a decade, is expected to bring $100 million in Federal money for job training, drug treatment and other social services to parts of the city. In recent weeks, Mr. Rangel and the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, have been battling over whether the money would go to the Bronx or Harlem. 
 According to the compromise, the money would benefit both.
 
Discussed With the Governor
 The Mayor said he had reached a compromise with Mr. Rangel during a private meeting early yesterday morning and later had discussed the deal with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who must also agree before a plan is presented to officials in Washington. Mr. Giuliani said the Governor had expressed preliminary support of the plan and a final announcement of the details would come next week.
"Between ourselves, we reached a final agreement," Mr. Giuliani said. "There are a few other people to discuss it with."
The heart of the compromise is an agreement to extend the area covered by the development program into the South Bronx in order that Yankee Stadium and other industrial tracts along the Harlem River can take advantage of special tax incentives, aides to the Mayor and the Congressman said. The plan might allow the New York Yankees and businesses near the stadium to take advantage of special tax exempt bonds and tax credits in return for employing local residents.
By including Yankee Stadium in the compromise, Mr. Giuliani was able to appeal to another constituent, George Steinbrenner, the owner of the Yankees, who has urged the city to improve conditions around the stadium and who has hinted that he would consider moving the team elsewhere.
 
Harlem as 'a Magnet'
 Mr. Giuliani said the Governor had expressed support for the compromise. He said the plan would "continue to solidify Harlem as a magnet" while allowing the city "to use some of the benefits that emerge from this legislation that the Congressman has been so instrumental in getting through Congress to help areas of the South Bronx."
Mr. Rangel said he had agreed to include Yankee Stadium and industrial areas in the Bronx in exchange for the administration's support for the neighborhood in his district originally proposed by former Mayor David N. Dinkins: Central Harlem, East Harlem and Washington Heights.
"I thought the Yankees would be something that everyone would love," Mr. Rangel said. "This would be very, very important to the Mayor."
Officials declined to specify exactly where the boundaries would be, saying those would be announced next week.
Thomas Conroy, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, confirmed that the Governor supported the compromise as it was outlined for him by the Mayor.
Under President Clinton's empowerment zone program, the Mayor and the Governor must jointly nominate up to three separate sections of the city to receive the Federal money.
 
Makings of a Feud
 Mr. Dinkins, in one of his last acts as Mayor, designated Harlem and Washington Heights as the city's sole choice for the program. The designation was a favor to the Mayor's political ally, Mr. Rangel, a ranking member of the House Ways and Means Committee who fought to include the legislation in the President's budget last summer.
But Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, scotched the Dinkins plan after winning the November election, saying other neighborhoods, like the South Bronx and parts of Brooklyn, were just as deserving. There followed a political feud that threatened to jeopardize the application, pitting Mr. Rangel, the city's senior black politician, against Mr. Ferrer.
Aides to the Mayor said the compromise reached yesterday will still leave most of the zone within Harlem, although it would stretch to the north to take in many industrial sections of the southern Bronx, including the area around Yankee Stadium.
The applications are due in Washington by the end of June, and Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is expected to make a decision by late summer. Because Mr. Rangel sponsored the legislation, officials take it for granted that New York will be one of the six urban zones chosen for the program.
