HEADLINE: Budget Assumptions;
Whitman's Planners Base Projections On Lower Pension and Health Costs

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
When Christine Todd Whitman presented her budget for New Jersey last month, she seemed to be getting something for nothing.
Committed to financing a $549 million personal income tax cut on top of a looming $2 billion gap between projected outlays and revenues, the Governor outlined a plan that promised remarkably little pain. How was that possible? 
 Mrs. Whitman's experts say they discovered that New Jersey was saving far more money for employee pensions and health care costs than it really had to. Not surprisingly, they decided to tap those funds rather than to hack away at state programs or retreat from Mrs. Whitman's pledge.
Behind the arcane budget language, the issue turns on nothing more complicated than an effort to set aside less money now to pay the pension and health care costs for the state's retirees, both present and future. The budget would also tap surpluses built up in a variety of special state funds. Together, these savings add up to almost $1.5 billion, or more than half the amount needed to bridge the budget gap for 1994 and the first half of 1995.
Mrs. Whitman's budget alarmed the unions that represent state and local government employees. They charge that putting aside less for the pensions they will eventually collect -- and nothing at all for the health care they will eventually need -- must inevitably cost the state much more tomorrow. (The Whitman plan would pay retirees' medical bills only as they actually come in.)
Everything the Governor has proposed awaits legislative action.
"They can balance the budget any way they please as long as they don't balance it on our backs," Robert Yackel, chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s public employee committee, said at a news conference on Monday.
Charles H. Marciante, president of the New Jersey branch of the labor federation, warned of job actions if the measures are not changed. "No one looks for confrontation," he said, "but we're not shying away from it."
The issue, however, is far from clear. Independent experts say that the Whitman team may be testing the limits of proper action, but that it does not appear to have crossed the line.
 
'The Far End of the Range'
 "I wouldn't characterize the pension proposals as gimmicks," said Howard Young, a professor of actuarial science at the University of Michigan. "They're within the range of acceptable measures, though you'd have to say it's at the far end of the range."
The Governor's budget people stoutly defend their plan as legitimate and quite unlike the outright postponements of pension payments that past governments have sometimes chosen. But even they acknowledge that their proposals are not so cautious as current practice. The actions are justified nevertheless, they argue, because other choices would have been worse.
"We're very sensitive to the pain caused by layoffs," said Arthur J. Maurice of the New Jersey State Treasurer's office. "We looked at everything under the sun, and relative to other changes, these were the least painful ways to achieve our goals."
To some extent, New Jersey may simply be postponing painful choices. Standard & Poor's, a credit-rating agency, stated recently that Mrs. Whitman's budget continues a pattern of stop-gap measures the state has adopted in the last few years.
State budget officials concede that they are relying on $827 million in one-time savings, but said that last year New Jersey depended on $1.5 billion in similar measures. By postponing the day of reckoning, the "one shots" can push today's problems into tomorrow. But they also give New Jersey politicians more time to work out less onerous ways to reduce state spending.
Doubts remain on Wall Street, though. "Professional actuaries may find both the state's current process, as well as the proposed revisions, acceptable," wrote Hyman C. Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's. Still, he added, "there is some degree of risk for the longer term beyond 2000." Without stronger economic growth, Mr. Grossman suggested, New Jersey taxpayers could end up mortgaging a portion of their children's future.
But the state is chalking up genuine gains as well.
The relentless rise in health care bills, for example, has slowed dramatically in the last two years, making it likely that future costs will be lower than expected. Rates that health insurers charge for New Jersey employee health care expenses will fall by 5 percent next year.
Consequently, Mrs. Whitman's experts no longer assume that health care costs will rise at 12 percent a year, as Gov. Jim Florio's last budget did. Instead, their figures project that the rise in medical costs will slow from 8 percent in 1993 to 6 percent by the late 1990's. While health care inflation has clearly diminished, not all experts are convinced that pattern will continue, particularly if there is no Federal overhaul of the health care system.
The reduction in costs for employees' health care and the return to a "pay as you go" system for retirees' health costs, a method used until two years ago, are expected to save $268 million this year, $341 million in fiscal 1995 and $376 million in 1996. Most states, as well as nearly all private companies, rely on "pay as you go" to finance retirees' health care costs.
But the unions for public employees want to keep the advance financing even if it is more costly. They do not want the retirees' health care to depend on a fresh legislative decision every year.
"We're afraid that health care would end up as simply a pawn in the annual appropriation process," said Karen Joseph of the New Jersey Education Association.
 
Supplemental Payment
 Most disturbing to state employees is Mrs. Whitman's plan to drop a supplemental payment that dates from the 1950's and 60's. The state started a system of reducing its pension payments to retirees who also received Social Security. To make up for those reductions, Trenton agreed to pay a portion of its employees' pension contributions. New Jersey is the only state to continue the practice after the reduction of pensions was stopped in 1966.
"It's unfair to ask taxpayers to keep paying for a program that should have ended in 1966," said Brian W. Clymer, the State Treasurer.
That is little comfort to state workers. A public employee earning $50,000 would pay $1,000 a year more toward retirement. After taxes, that would mean about $650 less in take-home pay.
The Governor's aides note that workers outside government, many of whom lost their jobs in the long recession, have had to absorb much greater blows.
"Everybody is having to learn to do more with less," said Alan J. Bowers, a Whitman adviser and managing partner for New Jersey for the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand. "The underlying philosophy behind many of these changes is that we're trying to put the state government on a more businesslike basis."
Topping that list is a shift in the treatment of pensions that, together with smaller changes, would reduce the state's contribution from $602 million this year to $243.2 million. And those savings would continue. State spending on pensions would be only $479.7 million in fiscal 1998, compared with $1.36 billion if the current practice remains unchanged.
New Jersey, like most governments, now tries to smooth the state's contributions to pension programs over an employee's working life, just as some homeowners choose to avoid seasonal peaks by averaging their fuel bills over an entire year. In an employee's early years, the state's payments are higher than necessary to finance a pension based on his salary, but as he nears retirement the payments are lower.
The proposed method, which is followed by most corporations and by a growing number of states, increases payments in step with salary increases as an employee nears retirement.
As long as the average age of the state's work force stays about the same, its pension contributions will remain steady as a share of total payroll costs. But if normal employee turnover were to diminish and the average age of the state's workers rose sharply, its required pension contributions would rise dramatically as well.
"It's something like the difference between term and whole life insurance," said John Mackin, a senior vice president at the Segal Company, a leading employee benefit consulting business based in New York. "You can't say one is better or worse than the other. They are both legitimate, equally effective, ways of budgeting for future retirement system costs."

HEADLINE: Company News: New Career in Consulting;
Bilzerian, Once a Raider, Now Rides to the Rescue

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
A small Utah company is seeking help from an unlikely patron: Paul A. Bilzerian, the former corporate raider.
Mr. Bilzerian has been hired as a management consultant by Cimetrix Inc., an Orem, Utah, company that says it has software marketing contracts with I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard. Under his contract, Mr. Bilzerian received an option to buy 20 percent of Cimetrix stock for $1 million. He also received the right to vote an additional 50.4 percent of the shares for three years on some issues, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday. 
 "I am very impressed with the person," the president of Cimetrix, Lincoln Daftrup, said of Mr. Bilzerian. "He has a wonderful track record; he is a genius, and he has a Harvard M.B.A."
He also has a prison record.
Mr. Bilzerian was convicted of violating Federal securities laws a year after he won the Singer Company in a $1.06 billion hostile takeover in 1988. He served 20 months in prison.
Mr. Bilzerian could not be reached for comment yesterday. His lawyer, Arthur Mathews of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, said he was not sure what Mr. Bilzerian had been doing since he left prison. "To the best I know," Mr. Mathews said, "he lives in Tampa and he has been spending all of his time litigating various issues in his bankruptcy."
None of this appears to have fazed Cimetrix. Its contract with Mr. Bilzerian says, "Whereas Bilzerian has experience and expertise in the purchase, sale, financing and management of various businesses, Cimetrix desires to employ Bilzerian as a management consultant to advise and assist Cimetrix in resolving its current financial crisis."
The company, which until recently had software products only in the development stage, has been posting losses.
"We are just ready now to hit the market with a finished product," Mr. Daftrup said. Cimetrix hired Mr. Bilzerian "to come into the company and give us the kind of management that we need."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
In El Paso, a Reluctance To Buy Mexican Shares

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson 

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
WHEN David J. Lemaster, the manager of the Dean Witter office here, suggests that his clients get their feet wet in foreign markets, they could act on his advice by walking about 10 minutes south, the Rio Grande border patrol permitting. But many in El Paso, having already invested in their own Mexican business ventures, are reluctant to place their savings on the same bet.
"Maybe because we've lived with some of the problems Mexico has experienced over the last 20 or 30 years," Mr. Lemaster said with the calm, slow emphasis of one who's seen it all, "we might be more skeptical." 
 El Pasoans may be in the vanguard of international business dealings, but they are resolutely cautious in buying international securities. United States investors who piled into foreign markets last year, especially emerging markets, and have watched these markets retreat this year, might well listen to business people who can survey a foreign market with a glance outside their windows.
Albert Beckman, an exporter of promotional merchandise whose office entrance looks across the border over Ciudad Juarez, talks not about Telmex, Cifra or other Mexican stocks. He wants to show off the caps, postcards, T-shirts, mugs, keychains and refrigerator magnets, emblazoned with sports or product logos, that he is shipping to the south.
Having pursued a variety of cross-border businesses for 14 years, surviving the bridge blockades set up by the opposition party that governs the state of Chihuahua, he merely shrugs at the latest political unrest.
After rising 48.5 percent in dollars last year, the Mexican market has slipped 14.5 percent this year, buffeted by the uprising in Chiapas, a recession and the assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio, the governing party's presidential candidate. Most Mexican stocks are down to levels last seen before the North American Free Trade Agreement was passed in November.
Although Mr. Beckman muses about the profits he could have made from buying stock in Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, a couple years ago, he had other things to do. "I was too busy running my business," he said. Besides, at age 56, he is in no mood to take risks with his savings, putting only about 10 percent in a Dean Witter global mutual fund.
Mr. LeMaster, his broker, advises clients to invest in foreign markets, but to limit their holdings to 20 or 25 percent of their money, with just a fraction of it in emerging markets. He usually directs them toward well-diversified mutual funds. His firm also recommends a few Mexican stocks, but only those with American depository receipts traded in dollars on United States exchanges.
Mr. Lemaster stands ready to make the case for emerging markets more generally, however. A binder of charts displayed on his desk was opened to a page showing that the real gross domestic products of emerging markets grew by 4.5, 4.7 and again 4.7 percent in 1990, 1991 and 1992, compared with 2.2, 0.3 and 0.9 percent in those years for the three largest markets, the United States, Japan and Britain. Last year, funds that invest in the developing nations of Asia and Latin America gained a third, a half, sometimes more.
But even a diversified fund can't always compensate for the volatility of these markets, as well as the currency risks. Michael Miles, executive vice president of his family's El Paso-based customs brokerage firm, which aids shippers, believes the peso is still 30 or 40 percent overvalued.
Although he has put a small portion of his savings in a European mutual fund, when it comes to Mexico he prefers to find partnerships or start new businesses, where he has control.
"If I'm going to be an investor, I'm going to be a full-time investor," he said. "Otherwise, you're just rolling the dice."
The current global trend may be toward lower trade and investment barrier, but some in El Paso remember when the winds sweeping through their high desert valley seemed to be blowing the other way. In the early 1980's, many deposited their money in Mexican banks, earning rates of interest surpassing 20 percent. But then the Government nationalized the banks, making it difficult for foreign investors even to get their money back. "Those memories aren't completely out of everyone's mind," Mr. Lemaster said.
One of the few El Pasoans who feel they can pick Mexican stocks like a pro, in fact, manages money for a living. David Austin, whose duties at El Paso Natural Gas include running a $450 million pension fund, has put about a quarter of that into foreign stocks and bonds, and about 3 percent of the total in emerging markets.
Mr. Austin's company is a partner in building a gas-fired power plant south of Ciudad Juarez, with a gas pipeline to Mexico also in the works. And he has put more than 20 percent of his personal portfolio into the United States shares of Cifra, a Mexican retailer, and Vitro, a glass maker.
Mr. Austin's broker, Ruben E. Guerra of Smith Barney Shearson, has gotten dozens of calls recently from clients on both sides of the border who worry about the Mexican market after the assassination.
But Mr. Austin said that the market's resilience after such tragedies proves that the nation's economy has fundamentally changed, with rewards to the patient. "I don't expect to make money overnight," he said.
More El Paso investors, however, are busier figuring out what they can sell across the river, or what the Mexicans can make most efficiently and ship back. Then, whatever earnings they don't plow back into their businesses go into the sorts of diversified portfolios that would make good sense anywhere.

HEADLINE: Records Show Mrs. Clinton Took Big Risks in Trades

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton apparently took huge risks to earn profits in the early phase of her commodities trading, an analysis of her trading records indicates. She made purchases that had to be sold the same day because she would probably have been unable to put up the money required by the commodity exchange to allow her to hold the investments overnight.
The White House disclosed this week that beginning in October 1979 she made a $100,000 profit over 10 months of commodities trading, after starting with a $1,000 investment. 
 Her first commodities trade, on Oct. 12, 1978, produced a profit of $5,300 for a day trade -- a transaction in which the investment was opened and closed on the same day. Tables printed in newspapers show that Oct. 12 was a relatively peaceful day on the commodities markets, and to make that much money would have required the purchase of at least 12 cattle futures contracts.
At the time, the minimum amount that a customer had to post to deal in cattle futures, as set by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, was $1,200 a contract. That means the amount, called the margin, required on 12 such contracts would have been $14,400, far more than the $1,000 Mrs. Clinton had deposited in her account. The posting of margin is to protect the brokerage if the market goes against the investor.
 
Substantial Risk for Clintons
 At that time, such an amount would have been a substantial one for the Clintons. In 1978, Mr. Clinton earned $26,500 as Arkansas Attorney General, and Mrs. Clinton's received a salary of $24,250 from her law firm, according to the tax returns made public by the White House.
As a practical matter, commodity exchanges do not require brokerage firms to put up the margin money for their accounts until the close of trading, and so day-trading, as Mrs. Clinton engaged, does not make the actual exchange of cash necessary. But such trading is inherently risky, because it means the investment must be liquidated the same day, whether or not the market has moved in the expected direction.
Had the market gone against her that first day, Mrs. Clinton could easily have lost $5,000 or more, far more than the $1,000 in her account. Many brokerages would be reluctant to allow such trading from an account with so little cash in it, and the willingness of her brokers to allow it at least raises the possibility of preferential treatment.
The fact that she had substantial losses on some trades in November indicates that her trades were genuine and that, as the White House has said, she was risking her own money.
In trading commodities, a speculator enters into a contract promising to buy a given amount of the commodity -- 42,000 pounds of cattle, for example -- or to sell it on a certain date in the future. Such a contract is traded and retraded for months before its actual expiration date.
The trading records made public this week by the White House do not show what Mrs. Clinton bought and sold in her day trades. Instead, they show only the profit or loss on each trade. The White House said she traded mostly cattle futures, which were then falling because of concerns about more cattle coming to market.
In cattle, for example, the largest daily move then was 1.1 cents a pound, in the January 1979 contract for feeder cattle. Each contract covers 42,000 pounds of beef, so a lucky trader who sold a contract early in the day, at the day's high price of 71.2 cents a pound, and bought it back later at the day's low of 70.1 cents a pound, would have made a profit of $462 before commissions.
To make $5,300, a purchase of at least 12 contracts would have been needed -- more if Mrs. Clinton did not have the good fortune to buy at the exact bottom and sell at the exact top.
The White House said she had also traded in lumber, soybeans, hogs, sugar and copper in the years she was active in the commodities market. Of those, only soybeans was especially volatile on the first day of her trading, records show. Had she traded soybeans, it is conceivable that she could have traded as few as four contracts. But the initial margin on those contracts, was $2,250 a contract, meaning the minimum margin had she held such a position overnight would have been $9,000.
 
First 3 Trades
 Mrs. Clinton's first three day trades, in October 1978, were profitable, but in November she lost on three of the five trades for the month. The last of those losses, on Nov. 22, produced a loss of $17,400, which almost decimated her account. It was left with a balance of just $1,401, although Mrs. Clinton had earlier taken out $5,000 in profits.
The Nov. 22 trade came on the day before Thanksgiving, a day that often produces sluggish markets. That year was no exception. The biggest swing in cattle was again 1.1 cents a contract, for a maximum possible loss of $462 on a contract. The largest swing among any of the commodities in which the White House said she traded was in lumber futures for January 1979, where the prices ranged from $196.20 to $202 for 1,000 board feet of lumber.
With each lumber contract controlling 100,000 board feet, she would have needed to trade at least 30 contracts to lose that much. And had she held that many contracts overnight, the minimum margin would have been $27,000, at $900 a contract.
 
3 Profitable Trades
 In December, Mrs. Clinton had three day trades, all profitable, and at the end of the year she was able to withdraw another $15,000 in cash from her account. She made another profitable day trade in January 1979, leaving her with enough cash in her account to make her first trade that was held at least overnight. In that trade, she bought 14 April 1979 cattle futures contracts on Jan. 26. By then, her accumulated profits were enough to cover the needed margin. She sold them in late February, making a profit of about $19,000.
The late 1970's were a time of rising commodity prices as inflation accelerated. But one of Mrs. Clinton's boldest, and most profitable moves, came in the summer of 1979, when she sold 65 cattle contracts, betting that the price would decline. It did, and she made almost $25,000.
Until she stopped trading in 1980, Mrs. Clinton made a profit of almost $100,000, the White House has said.

HEADLINE: Mayor Derides Cortines's School Cutbacks as Inadequate

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
A day after New York City Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines offered a new plan to cut costs at the Board of Education, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani derided the proposal, saying it did not attack the board's "bloated overhead" with sufficient vigor.
Aides to Mr. Cortines, meeting yesterday to formulate responses to the Mayor's vehement remarks, said they were searching for new cost-cutting measures that would allow them to comply fully with Mr. Giuliani's request for a $332 million decrease in the board's $7.5 billion budget. But they repeated their contention that few additional reductions beyond cutting about 700 jobs and eliminating 500 vacant posts could be made at the board's central headquarters organization without throwing schools into chaos. 
 The central board administration has 6,300 full-time positions, and Mayor Giuliani has asked for a cut of 2,500 positions.
Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Cortines have been at odds since February, as the Mayor has sought to cut school spending to help close a $2.3 billion gap in the city's budget for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1.
 
Compromises Obscured
 And in a day of new skirmishes in the war over the school budget, two members of the central board also waded into the debate. Michael J. Petrides, the Staten Island representative who last fall both helped to hire Mr. Cortines and to elect Mr. Giuliani, said that the angry public outcry has obscured budget compromises emerging behind the scenes. And Dennis Walcott, appointed to the board by former Mayor David N. Dinkins, said he would fight plans announced by Mr. Cortines on Thursday to reduce the free-lunch program and to eliminate school bus services for sixth-grade students.
Mr. Giuliani fired the first volley in a morning television interview.
"There's no question that he can do better than that," Mr. Giuliani said of Mr. Cortines's board reorganization plan. "And we're going to have to work with him to try and see if we can focus on that overhead -- the very famous, well-known, bloated overhead at the Board of Education."
"Maybe this is a day I'm particularly frustrated," he continued later on a radio talk show. "I've asked the Chancellor to find 2,500 positions in a school system bloated with administrators.
"Give me a break, you can find that in the system," he said.
And at a City Hall news conference, Mr. Giuliani said that what Mr. Cortines had done with his latest proposal was "kind of slide back" from earlier promises to cut 1,000 board employees.
After all that, Mr. Giuliani said: "I think my relationship with the Chancellor is a good relationship."
 
'A Misunderstanding'
 Mr. Cortines's plan, presented to reporters Thursday, promised to cut 678 of the 6,300 full-time positions at the board's central headquarters and to eliminate 513 unfilled jobs by July 1995, for a total cut of 1,191 positions. "The Mayor's reaction has been born of a misunderstanding, as angry reactions often are," said John. H. Beckman, Mr. Cortines's spokesman. "What we presented yesterday was only a part of the budget proposal, not the budget proposal."
The reductions in central staffing and in busing and lunch services outlined in the board plan released Thursday offered savings of $76 million, far short of the $332 million Mr. Giuliani has demanded. But Mr. Cortines intends to release another proposal next week that will outline a strategy for cutting the full $332 million, the board's budget director, Leonard Hellenbrand, said yesterday.
"We are developing plans to meet our responsibilities," Mr. Hellenbrand said. "People may not like the way we do it -- we may not like it -- but if we are responsible for absorbing a cut, we will make a cut."
 
No Details Given
 He declined to detail the strategy, but he said most of the remaining savings will not come through further reductions in the headquarters staff.
"We've said from the beginning that you can't make a 2,500 person cut" at board headquarters, he said. "That's not doable unless one believes that there are hundreds and hundreds of people just twiddling their thumbs -- and that's not the case."
Mr. Petrides expressed concern that the dispute between the Mayor and the Chancellor could obstruct recent progress in the budget negotiations.
"The Mayor is into head count, and the Chancellor is into partially meeting that head count, and is exploring other options," Mr. Petrides said. "And I think that there will be closure at a certain point."
"But today I'm concerned," Mr. Petrides said. "I hope that people are talking."
Lost in the battle have been the magnitude of the cuts Mr. Cortines has promised so far. Nearly 700 employees, many of them professionals, are to be dismissed by July, and some have already begun receiving informal notifications. One school official said a dismayed professional who has worked at the board for 17 years called her yesterday, distraught about the prospect of circulating her resume in a bleak economy.
"And we're going to get more calls like that," the school official said.

HEADLINE: A Latin Strategy for Spain's Telephone Company

BYLINE: By ANA WESTLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADRID, April 1

 BODY:
Barely three years ago, Spain's giant telephone monopoly looked like another corporate dinosaur facing extinction, as inevitable competition imposed by the European Union loomed in 2003.
Instead, Telefonica de Espana took a modest international subsidiary that once sold hardware, injected it with $824 million in capital and built it into a major player in the international communications world. The subsidiary, Telefonica Internacional, has been snapping up Latin American acquisitions as soon as they come up on the privatization block and transforming them from chaos to profit-generating enterprises. 
 Telefonica has put two Spanish executives educated in the United States in charge of the unit, and has beaten American companies for deals in their own geographical backyard. Telefonica's stock, capitalized at $13 billion as of Jan. 31, is quoted on stock exchanges in New York, London, Paris, Frankfurt and Tokyo, as well as Madrid.
 
'Best Ditch-Digging Technology'
 Telefonica has succeeded by tapping its experience building telephone systems at home practically from scratch and by backing them up with heavy investment. It has also benefitted from Spain's linguistic and cultural ties to Latin America.
"We have the best ditch-digging technology around," said Inaki Santillana, Telefonica Internacional's chief executive and the architect behind its international expansion. "When it comes to installing a million access lines in record time, no one can beat us."
What Mr. Santillana described as technology is really an operating strategy: buying the latest equipment in bulk, installing new networks at top speed and overhauling old ones, using teams of Spanish technicians sent in like shock troops.
Last month, Telefonica bid a record $2 billion for 35 percent of Peru's telephone companies, Compania Peruana de Telefonos and Entel Peru, to consolidate its leadership position in South American telecommunications. The successful bid, the largest made by any Spanish company for any acquisition, was more than double that of its closest rivals for the deal, Southwestern Bell and GTE.
Telefonica Internacional now owns stakes in Argentina, Chile, Venezuela, Columbia, Uruguay and Puerto Rico, in addition to ventures in Portugal and Romania. Telefonica itself has become Spain's largest company by sales, accounting for 1.8 percent of the nation's gross domestic product.
Telefonica Internacional is also discussing market-sharing alliances with two or three leading American phone companies, which Mr. Santillana would not identify. The company broke into the American market last year when it bought 80 percent of Puerto Rico's long-distance company, Telefonica Larga Distancia.
Telefonica has come a long way since 1990, when its international unit lost 800 million pesetas, then worth more than $8.25 million, in operations limited to peddling its hardware at international trade fairs. Today, the subsidiary is a leading Spanish multinational on its own, with assets that have more than quintupled initial acquisition costs, to 645.6 billion pesetas, or $4.5 billion.
Last year Telefonica Internacional's net profits surged 127 percent to reach 21.3 billion pesetas, about $150 million. In dollar terms, this increase was 83 percent, taking into account several devaluations of the peseta. Net profits for the Telefonica group rose 17.7 percent last year to 95.079 billion pesetas, about $670 million.
Telefonica, the parent company, developed its skills by laying new access lines in Spain at a rate of a million lines a year for the last five years. Telefonica had to deal with hundreds of thousands of irate potential customers who waited months, or sometimes years, for a simple telephone.
By the end of 1993, Telefonica had wiped out waiting lists and had modernized much of Spain's telecommunication infrastructure, replacing old networks with digital and fiber optic systems. Spain now has 15 million telephones for a population of 40 million. Along the way, the company improved its once disastrous reputation for both local and international phone service. International calls remain the most expensive in Europe.
Telefonica Internacional was transformed from a sleepy international sales company into a modern telecommunications competitor, with an initial outlay in 1990 of 79.9 billion pesetas, then worth about $824 million.
Mr. Santillana, a 45-year-old economist who holds a doctorate from Indiana University, was brought in from the parent company's financial planning department. Francisco Ros, a 43-year-old telecommunications engineer with a doctorate from Massachusetts Institute of Technology, headed Telefonica's technical team.
"We decided it was time to share not only language and culture, but also business," said Candido Velazquez, chairman of the Telefonica group, who predicted "wonderful opportunities" in Latin America.
 
Tough Case in Argentina
 What Mr. Velazquez called "wonderful" was enough to scare off United States rivals. Telefonica's first plunge came in 1990 with the purchase of nearly 20 percent of Telefonica de Argentina, as well as management control, for $415.7 million. The company covers the southern half of the country, including the financial district of southern Buenos Aires.
"It looked like a total disaster," Mr. Santillana recalled. Some employees were rerouting company lines and pocketing the charges. Pirating of telephone lines flourished. Some residents shared phones by stringing their own wires from window to window. Lack of maintenance left many networks inoperable. Equipment, bought years earlier, sat in warehouses unopened. And some veterans of the Falklands war with Britain drew their pensions in the form of telephone company salaries.
"Despite the chaos, we realized this was something we could handle," Mr. Ros said. "They had the same technical problems we had five years earlier, only worse."
American companies were installing 30,000 to 40,000 lines a year, of which most were replacements, not new access lines, Mr. Ros said. "There are not many international companies that have the capacity or experience to deal with huge magnitudes in short periods," he said.
"We sent in our own technical lightning brigades and in two years and one million lines later we were making money," Mr. Santillana said. As a result, the Argentine company Telefonica de Argentina S.A., or TASA, had net profits of $301 million in 1993.
Although Argentina was one of the worst cases, Telefonica had similar experiences in other countries like Chile and Venezuela. The bid in Peru for 35 percent of CPT and Entel Peru has been its most controversial purchase, partly because it involved a country considered in the backwaters of the communications world.
In the face of criticism in the Spanish press that the bid was excessive, Mr. Velazquez, the Telefonica chairman, told a parliamentary commission that the $2 billion cost "was no scandal" and promised the company "will make lots of money." The Spanish Government owns about a 30 percent stake in the telephone company.
S. G. Warburg Securities in Madrid noted in its analysis that Telefonica was paying for tremendous future growth potential and termed the bids by Southwestern Bell and GTE of $857 million and $803 million, respectively, as "unrealistically low."
"For us it was an important piece of the puzzle," Mr. Santillana said, "one of the last major privatizations for a while, and fills out our network." With the acquisition, Telefonica now serves a population of 110 million people in Latin America, in addition to 40 million Spaniards.
 
Criticized at Home
 While preaching the virtues of privatization internationally, Telefonica has not yet outlived its reputation for monopolistic abuses at home in Spain, where memories of waiting lists and surly operators die hard.
Some analysts feel Telefonica should concentrate more on trimming its work force of 74,000 employees at home and become more efficient when the Spanish market soon opens to outside competition. The European Union has declared all member nations must open their phone systems to competition by 2003. The Spanish Government has set a goal of doing so by 1998.
 Miguel Angel Fernandez Ordonez, president of the Tribunal of Competition, a governmental regulatory agency, has accused Telefonica of dragging its feet of preparing for liberalization. "Telfonica's monopolistic high rates have a negative effect on Spanish business, making them less competitive," he said.
Alberto Martinez, a Telefonica spokesman, rebutted that by saying: "Our hands are tied. The Government has to authorize price changes." He said that the Transportation Ministry justified Telefonica's income from high prices because it must be used to subsidize phone service in rural areas.
