HEADLINE: Growing Up A Haldeman

BYLINE: By Peter Haldeman;. 
Peter Haldeman, a contributing editor of Travel and Leisure, lives in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
The turbulent Washington waters have claimed many public figures over the years, but few as powerful as Harry Robbins (Bob) Haldeman. Chief of staff to Richard Nixon, Haldeman served from the President's election until April 30, 1973, when he, along with his college friend John Ehrlichman and other top Nixon appointees, resigned amid mounting accusations of efforts to cover up the political scandal that began with the break-in of the Democratic national headquarters at the Watergate complex.
 H. R. Haldeman, a successful Los Angeles advertising executive, worked for the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket in 1956. Looking, he said, for an adventure beyond advertising, he was drawn to Nixon by opportunity as well as ideology -- both he and Nixon were active in California business circles. But he also admired Nixon's "fighting" spirit. Haldeman served as Nixon's chief advance man in his race against John F. Kennedy in 1960, as manager of Nixon's 1962 gubernatorial bid and as manager again of Nixon's triumphant 1968 Presidential campaign.
 Such was the power he came to wield as White House chief of staff that Haldeman became known as "Nixon's S.O.B." and the "Iron Chancellor." His fall was as steep as his rise. Haldeman was tried and convicted, in January 1975, on charges of perjury, conspiracy and obstruction of justice for his part in the cover-up. He served 18 months in prison. 
 In his 1978 book "The Ends of Power," Haldeman asserted that Nixon -- who resigned from the Presidency on Aug. 9, 1974 -- had "initiated the Watergate break-in." Yet he also acknowledged that in his job as chief of staff he "put on too much pressure, and in the process laid the groundwork for the mental attitude that 'the job must be done,' which badly served the cause when Watergate struck."
 H. R. Haldeman died last November at the age of 67. He is survived by his wife, Joanne, and four children: Susan, Hank, Peter and Ann. He also left behind a journal of his White House years, which Putnam will publish this June. The following is a different remembrance of those same years, and some that followed. Written by Haldeman's son Peter, it is a demonstration that history is not selective in those it takes in its wake.
On my father's last birthday, two weeks before he died, my mother telephoned me from their home in Santa Barbara to say she was afraid I was ruining his chances for a recovery. She was referring to a call I had made the day before, to a woman we had known in Washington, named Jeanette McGuiness. Mrs. McGuiness was my father's practitioner, or Christian Science healer. Until I had contacted her, Mrs. McGuiness had been planning to fly from Washington to California for the weekend in order to, as a Christian Scientist might say, work with my father on his situation. A basic tenet of Christian Science is that to specify a physical problem is to empower it. For this reason, and because at his request no one had seen or spoken with my father since he had taken ill except my mother, who is also a Christian Scientist, the nature of his illness was unclear. From my mother's telephone reports, my brother and two sisters and I, who all live within driving distance of Santa Barbara, had gleaned only that he had been in bed for three weeks with stomach pain and was eating very little. We were instructed not to share this information with anyone.
 I had phoned Jeanette McGuiness to ask her to give my father a message. For whatever it was worth, I wanted him to know -- and her too -- that I hoped he would consider medical treatment at this point. Mrs. McGuiness informed me that, as his practitioner, her exclusive responsibility was to carry out my father's wishes. I asked her whether, as a compassionate human being, she would pass along the suggestion. She said she would not. I then told Mrs. McGuiness that if my father died I would hold her, as his practitioner, accountable. That evening she telephoned my mother to say she was growing uncomfortable with the idea of coming out.
 I know this is how she put it because I kept notes. Ever since my father had become sick, I'd been documenting my phone conversations with my mother. The news, almost always bad, at least seemed more real on paper. I have a manila envelope stuffed with scribblings on the order of: Not leaving bed now and Had water this A.M. Another note: Call Jeanette -- apologize. As it happened, Jeanette McGuiness overcame her discomfort and made the trip. And, for reasons that remain vague to me, a few days after she'd returned to Washington, the rest of us were allowed to see him too.
 To see him was, I think, the most anyone expected. I know the inability to do so is what prompted my call to Mrs. McGuiness. The first night we were in Santa Barbara, my brother, Hank, gave my father a shave. I sat on the edge of his bed and found myself offering a morbid and inopportune account of the Malibu fires I'd seen on the drive up from Los Angeles. The whine of the blender drifted up from the kitchen, where my mother prepared flavored ice shavings, the only thing he could get down.
 The next day, he asked for fruit. I spent an hour in a Goleta health food store loading up on out-of-season strawberries and raspberries, packets of Emergen-C, apple juice. My brother logged onto the computer in my father's office to go over his bills. My older sister, Susan, arrived and went through the mail. A Christian Science night nurse came to spell my mother, who stayed up anyway. Within another few days, my younger sister, Ann, had shown up, and we'd settled into the not-unfamiliar rhythms of the family catastrophe. Returning inquisitive messages on the answering machine, taking care as advised not to "raise any red flags," I experienced again the comforts and the anxieties peculiar to our brand of collusion. I knew I was no longer ruining it for him, but I also knew I wasn't saving him.
 IN THE AFTERMATH OF MY FATHER'S DEATH, I've been working at sorting out the disruptions of death from those attributable to my father. I still get mail from people I don't know or don't remember. An old neighbor called -- the mother of a friend I haven't seen since elementary school. She wanted to tell me about the time she drove by the house and saw my father out on the front lawn playing the ukulele.
 I learned how to tune a uke from my father. Every Thursday, when his oxford shirts came back from the dry cleaners, he gave me the cardboard to draw on. At U.C.L.A. basketball games in Pauley Pavilion, he'd study the moves of Lew Alcindor and Lucius Allen while I, lulled by the cadence of sneakers on polyurethane, tried to keep my eyes off the clock. He signed the lines in my Cub Scout handbook certifying that I'd tied a slide knot, scaled an eight-foot wall, started a fire with a magnifying glass and paper. (My mother signed the rest.) The things we did together had the generic quality of the handbook's roughed illustrations. His efforts in this direction were earnest but sporadic. I tried too, but only when he did. I also used those shirt cardboards to make "Keep Out" signs for my bedroom door. One reason she'd never forgotten the sight of my father with a ukulele, said our old neighbor, was that it wasn't very often she saw him at all.
 The easiest way to identify the neighborhood is by contradistinction, which is largely how it identifies itself. It's not Hollywood. This is Los Angeles with a hard "g" -- as some of my grandparents persisted in pronouncing it -- a zone defined chiefly by tradition. Psychologically, it stretches back to the Midwest, where most of my great-grandparents had come from. Cultural totems include the now-defunct Bullocks tearoom, a box at the Hollywood Bowl and security by Pinkerton's. More often than not, we lived in Hancock Park, a lush enclave near downtown regarded by its inhabitants as a "less flashy" alternative to the West Side. The house I remember most vividly was a shingled Colonial with backyard features that I considered providential: a 60-foot pool, an avocado tree big enough to spend the night in and a badminton court that was better for roller-skating.
 For years, my father came home from work in the latest model Thunderbird convertible. The car was one of the perks of managing the Los Angeles branch of J. Walter Thompson, whose clients included Ford. He'd bring home account products like Shake-a-Puddin' or Superstuff -- inventions that, if you were a certain age, ranked with Fred MacMurray's discovery of flubber. Walt Disney was another client. Every Christmas, crates of complimentary Disney merchandise stood sentinel over the small city of other packages filling the living room. I don't remember any dinner-table speeches about it, but we were encouraged to believe that advantages like these were deserved, dividends of principle as much as effort. It was a tacit thing, like not going to the doctor. We were rewarded with root-beer floats for struggling with "Science and Health" at Sunday school; the center-court seats at Pauley Pavilion came our way because my father had raised most of the funds for the stadium. 
 And whenever we did homework, we were reminded of his most recent political crusade, a lost battle but one he had religiously spearheaded: a single rib of every pencil in the house read "Nixon for Governor."
 In the governor's residence in Sacramento, my mother took pictures of us dipping into Ronald Reagan's jellybean jar -- Jul 67, as the Kodachrome borders used to specify. My father had organized the trip, a driving tour of California. We chased grunion at Pismo Beach and drove the station wagon through hollowed-out sequoias and trooped through the Winchester Mystery House in San Jose. The president of the new U.C. Santa Cruz campus took us on a golf-cart junket past redwood groves and barefoot students in shawls dancing and blowing soap bubbles. A couple of them threw pebbles that ricocheted off the golf cart's thick tires. At night, we pulled into A.A.A.-endorsed motels, places with pool slides and souvenir shops. I avoided the shops. We'd been given small allowances, but I held onto mine meaningfully. I wanted to fall into line, wanted it to last like this -- us together, away. The farther up the coast we got, the more virtuous I felt. By the time we reached San Francisco, I had $7. At a novelty shop in Chinatown, eyeing something I was considering buying -- a rubber chicken -- thinking it was well within my means and this was what saving was all about, I realized I'd been pickpocketed.
 I used those shirt cardboards for "Keep Out" and "No Trespassing" notices, but I also made Nixon signs out of them. A few months after we returned from our California tour, my father was tapped to manage Richard Nixon's Presidential campaign. Like most of his involvements, this one chiefly meant we saw less of him. We wore campaign buttons to school with a vague smugness and ate dinner with my mother at the breakfast table. I attended a single campaign rally, in Santa Barbara -- an event I remember less well than the preparations for it. Ann and I got out of school early to spend the afternoon making signs in the driveway with my mother. I went through my cardboard collection writing, over and over in wobbly Magic Marker, Nixon's the One.
During the four and a half years he worked in Washington, at the urging of a Madison scholar, my father wrote or dictated daily diary entries pertaining to his job. I learned of his journal, along with his intention to have it published, several months before he died. No one except the young man he had enlisted to help him publish it knew anything about its contents or its length until after his death. The complete manuscript numbers 1,400 double-spaced typed pages. In an effort to determine how it might be reduced to a readable size, my mother, who inherited the rights to it, distributed portions to me and my sisters and brother to review. I received the 13th and 14th quarters -- 300 pages spanning January to June 1972. I'm not sure what I had in mind, but I found the material more absorbing than I'd expected. In part I think this is due to to the particular events documented -- the mining of Haiphong harbor, the Moscow summit, the first media tricklings concerning the Watergate break-in. But in some ways I found the narrative less interesting than the narration. The dedication my father brought to his job has not gone unremarked. For me, going over these pages felt something like examining the evidence of a love affair we'd only dimly apprehended -- by his absence, which was relatively brief, and his penance, which never really ended.
 The dinner-table announcement about the move to Washington focused more on what we were leaving than why: the house with the badminton court would have to be sold. My brother vowed he would buy it back someday. My designs were more immediate -- I saw myself exhaling wisps in a camel's-hair coat or a down parka with Velcro pockets. As it turned out, most of us spent only three winters in Washington; the first few hundred pages of my father's journal were composed in a hotel room somewhere near the White House while we finished the school term in California with my mother. In the fall of 1969, Susan started Stanford and Hank and Ann and I were sent to the Washington schools my mother had selected as carefully as the schemes for our bedrooms in Chevy Chase, Md.: a traditional boys' school for my brother, a traditional girls' school for my sister and Sidwell Friends for me.
 The Quaker faith is by definition an informal one, and Sidwell Friends casually articulated its Quaker affiliation. There were moments of silence before lunch and "meetings" instead of assemblies, and there was also an emphasis on causes usually identified as liberal -- volunteer programs in Anacostia, ecology drives, special awareness days for the women's movement and the peace movement. In 1970, the strong Quaker tradition of pacifism had yet to reach its fullest expression at Sidwell Friends, but one of my first official acts as a student there was to send away for a P.O.W. bracelet.
 At 13, my grasp of politics was still more intuitive than practical. I imagine this is the way most 13-year-olds perceive politics, but Washington 13-year-olds are not most 13-year-olds. I recall a girl in my class sidling up after a meeting to ask me whether it was true my father had snubbed the Secretary of the Interior. She wore knee socks and a hair band and belonged to a small tribe of students who wrote editorials invoking the moral majority. I said I didn't know, which was true. I knew enough. I knew (or had heard) Grace Slick planned to crash Tricia Nixon's wedding and spike the punch with LSD. I knew my father's zeal for his work had begun to earn him a few epithets -- Kremlin commissar, Nixon's son of a bitch. Cartoons depicting him with fangs or in Fascist regalia resurfaced on a wall in his office at home. A new fluttery thrill attended these notices, but I also recognized that he had been deemed fallible.
 Camp David was supposed to be our safehold. It was where he attempted to juggle his job and us and it was where, in Washington, most of my mental home movies are set. In a typical scene, we're bowling, taking turns hurling unmarked balls down a one-lane alley buffed glassy by Navy Seabees. Present or absent are the Ehrlichmans, the only family we did anything with in Washington. There's something funny and embarrassing about the monogrammed balls, their finger holes scaled to the various Nixons like little porridge bowls. We take care not to touch them. The phone in the wall rings. My father is saying, "Right-o," giving us the signal to evacuate because Julie and David want to bowl and are on their way over. Or he says, "Right-o," and changes his shoes and slips out the door.
 Another reel, 1970 or '71. A fall afternoon. We're loading the car in Chevy Chase, getting ready to meet my father at Camp David for the weekend. My mother leans against the trunk for a moment. "Wouldn't it be marvelous just to stay?" she asks. It's a rhetorical question, but wishful too: our neighbors are burning leaves and there's a football game at my brother's school. My father tried not to "bring home" his work; summits and bombings were not raised at the dinners and birthdays he still managed to fit in. But in Washington, the familiar rituals came to seem a little smaller and duller to me, like old rooms. In some ways, the big absences were the easy ones. What was missing could be so slight I wasn't always sure what it was. I'd say now it falls under the category of footballs not tossed, summits not discussed.
 That spring, after 17 years underground, several million cicadas shed their skins, climbed virtually every tree in the city, snapped their thorax membranes like drum heads and, one week later, died. The problems posed by their carcasses created many first-time callers to an agency known as the "complaint center," where my mother volunteered answering phones. My sister locked herself in her room with her parakeet and her pug. I flattened the locusts like potato chips with my combat boots. At Sidwell Friends, where I was overlooked by scrimmage captains and not overlooked enough by algebra and biology teachers, I'd fallen in with the other pariahs. Somewhere between eighth grade and ninth, the stigmas changed. We wore iron-creased jeans and were pursued by the moral majority one year; the next, we were the ones who kept bongs in our lockers.
 Out of the house, I'd started wearing a black armband honoring the dead soldiers. There were moratorium marches every weekend. One Saturday morning in 1972, I slipped on my armband and caught a bus into the city. All the roads between Pennsylvania Avenue and the Mall had been closed to traffic. Outside of Disneyland, I'd never seen so many people. Couples bounced children on their shoulders; vets in wheelchairs tossed Frisbees; kids dangled out of trees. Over a loudspeaker, someone described the deformities of babies born in napalmed villages. A man passed me a wood chillum. He wore a silver puzzle ring and a grown-out shag and had a bony face that made me think of some French character in a textbook -- Jean Jacques Rousseau, maybe, or Roget, the thesaurus author. When we stood to link arms and sway, he and a woman in a quilt got on either side of me and gently leaned.
 One evening, shortly before my 15th birthday, I picked up the phone in Chevy Chase to call a pizza parlor and heard a man with a nasal voice not unlike Maxwell Smart's ask, "Are all the taps in place?" To celebrate my 15th, I bought a gram of hashish from someone at school. I was sitting at the bus stop in front of Sidwell Friends, fingering the tin-foil nugget inside my parka, when I realized I was being watched. The light changed, some other cars honked and the man in the Buick drove on. But in another minute he was back. I was a little shaky by then, but prepared. I stuck out my thumb. The car's door locks thudded up, and I found my legs carrying me over and in. Through the dirty windows I regarded Peoples Drug Store, Fort Reno Park -- all the places I passed twice a day on the bus. I couldn't bring myself to look at him. He made the turn off Wisconsin Avenue that takes you to Chevy Chase, and it occurred to me that we were going home. Some F.B.I. agents and the young men who worked for my father would deliver speeches in the kitchen about buying drugs and getting into cars with strangers. When he reached for the glove compartment, I braced for a pistol. Instead he removed a pack of Benson & Hedges 100's, punched in the lighter and let his hand fall on the knee of my army fatigues. "So," he said. "What's your name?"
 A sequence of infractions on the order of cutting class and smoking on campus led to a conference between the dean of Sidwell Friends and my mother, at which psychotherapy was strongly recommended. The dean offered the names of some doctors. My mother requested that I be allowed to visit a Christian Science practitioner instead. This is how I came to meet Jeanette McGuiness. Once a week, I took the bus to Mrs. McGuiness's apartment complex in Foggy Bottom, a cluster of recurved luxury buildings known as the Watergate. Her sunny office smelled of potpourri. She often got started by observing that I had a particularly thoughtful expression. Whatever thought I had would instantly vanish. Then Mrs. McGuiness might smile in a way that suggested infinite patience and say something like: "The only reality is divine mind, anyway, dear. Mrs. Eddy teaches us that human thoughts are not spiritual. For instance, if I have a bad dream that seems very vivid, very real, does that make it real?"
 To facilitate current-events discussions, world history students at Sidwell Friends subscribed to Newsweek. A disturbing picture of my father appeared on the cover of the March 19, 1973, issue. Under the headline "Nixon's Palace Guard," the photograph had been enlarged and cropped to reveal both the pores on his face and a microscopic American flag on his lapel. A single paragraph inside referred to the "ramifying scandal named Watergate," identifying the close connections between two men who worked for him, and the Creep underground. About Watergate I understood there had been a break-in and a bugging. When I tried to picture the perpetrators, I saw "Get Smart" KAOS agents. I carried my copy of Newsweek to school but elected to skip history. A month later, I was expelled from Sidwell Friends. I believe my final breach was not showing up for a weekend detention -- but it could have been anything. Two weeks after that, my father resigned.
 "Admit the existence of matter, and you admit that mortality (and therefore disease) has a foundation in fact," writes Mary Baker Eddy in the Christian Science textbook "Science and Health." "Deny the existence of matter, and you can destroy the belief in material conditions."
 In addition to my mother and Mrs. McGuiness, a pair of Christian Science nurses ministered to my father. The order not to discuss his condition held. Almost everyone he knew learned of his illness and his death at the same time -- from newspaper and television accounts. Among the family members aware of his illness in advance of his death, there was strong concern about the news media getting word of the illness; afterward, the worry shifted to what the media would make of the death. His ailment was never officially diagnosed. The wording of the cause listed on his death certificate -- "intra-abdominal neoplasm" -- derives from several negotiations with the Santa Barbara coroner in anticipation of questions from reporters. In the end, the questions never came.
 Outside my grandparents' summer house on an island in Newport Beach, Calif., a bridge and vigilant neighbors kept news crews at bay, but every 20 minutes a tour boat fetched up in front of the house for a picture-taking session. Like everyone else, we spent the first half of the summer of 1973 in front of the TV. I remember a somewhat unlikely gathering -- relatives I hadn't seen in years, people from the island, an old boyfriend of my sister's. My father sat in an armchair by the television, listening more than watching, filling legal pads with his notes, in blue Pentel, on the hearings. He'd pause now and then to deliver a comment on the testimony or the questioning. The bombast of Sam Ervin offended him -- he perfected an imitation of the Senator's drawl. He was convinced John Dean had undergone hypnosis in order to improve his memory. When his own turn came to testify, in July, he was diplomatic, receiving either high marks for tact or low ones for vagueness.
 In the spring, just before my father resigned, a reporter had tracked down my sister at college; the interview ran in a local paper under the headline "Susie Haldeman Calls Her Father a 'Fun Guy.' " After his Senate testimony, a Paul Conrad cartoon appeared in The Los Angeles Times depicting my father with stitches zippering his forehead and a bolt stuck through his neck: "Son of Nixonstein." We had been urged to regard "the media" as purveyors of lies, but I was beginning to approach their disseminations as something closer to riddles. Two other news items preoccupied me that summer. One of these, an article in Time titled "Learning to Live With the Scandal," termed my problems at school "an anguished reaction to Watergate." I used to keep a copy of this article in the outside pocket of my backpack, folded like a tiny road map alongside a pack of Marlboros and my P.O.W. bracelet, which had left a greenish indentation around my wrist. I first became aware of the other story two days after a Los Angeles Times photograph of Sam Ervin signing T-shirts silk-screened with his likeness marked the recess of the hearings. On Aug. 9, a grainy picture of detectives training their flashlights on a bloody sheet signaled the discovery of eight more corpses buried in a Houston boat storage lot by a 33-year-old bachelor electrician. Most of the victims in the Dean Corll murder case -- teen-age males who had been raped and strangled or mutilated -- were described as vagrant hitchhikers.
 With my first few paychecks from a gardening job that summer, I bought a 10-speed. I'd planned to use the bike mainly to get to and from drivers education at Corona del Mar High School. But when school let out, at noon, I often found myself heading toward Laguna Beach instead of Newport Beach. Pacific Coast Highway had steep grades and roared with traffic, but the scenery wasn't bad. I rode past mustard fields and little coves colonized by mobile homes. About halfway to Laguna, I usually stopped at a Hadley's stand for a date shake. I never had a terminus in mind. I'd also bought a sleeping bag that summer, one ingredient in a cloudy formula to go somewhere for a long time, and frequently I'd start out on my bike with the intention of not coming back. But my destination never suggested itself. Eventually I'd turn around. At Bay Island, a pile of mail waited for me, letters that sometimes arrived bearing no more than my name and a stamp. Dear Peter Haldeman, these missives would begin, usually handwritten. Between you and your father, you have a normal haircut. Why don't you cut your hair and he can let his grow a little?
 In November, my brother and I and 70 Republican businessmen, attorneys and party figures attended a stag luncheon in my father's honor at Perino's -- a 40-year-old Hancock Park establishment favored more for its velvet banquettes and baroque chandeliers than its menu. We had returned to a sycamore-shrouded mock-Tudor house in our old neighborhood. After the roast beef and cottage fries and apple cake a la mode, there were tributes from a couple of my uncles. Then my father got up to say a few words. In his rep tie and new, mod hair style and sideburns, he looked as genial as a talk show host. He affirmed his confidence in both the President and the judicial system and expressed his intention to cooperate fully with the latter in order to clear his name. We were familiar with this formulation from a single discussion at the dinner table and from a couple of statements issued on the front lawn. He reiterated it two weeks later, when an audit of White House tapes revealed an 18 1/2-minute blank segment on a recording of a conversation between himself and Richard Nixon three days after the Watergate break-in.
 At a basketball game that fall, my father was booed out of Pauley Pavilion. The Los Angeles Country Club, where one of my grandmothers had been living for several years, revoked his membership. Residents on Haldeman Road in Santa Monica, named for my great-grandfather, an early Los Angeles booster, were circulating a petition to have the street renamed. I don't know what these events meant to my parents, because they were never discussed, at least in front of us. I learned about Haldeman Road -- the road itself as well as the petition -- from the newspaper. At Harvard School -- the former military academy in the San Fernando Valley from which my father had graduated and in which I had been enrolled -- the announcements read in homeroom included the notice one morning that anyone interested in joining the tape recorder club should see Peter Haldeman.
 Most of the older students at Harvard School exhibited more passion for their cars than anything else -- ideally Bavarian, with fleece seatcovers and surfboard racks. The political climate here was decidedly milder than at Sidwell Friends. But in some ways, the entire world had changed since we'd left Washington -- and the tape recorder club was not an isolated incident. Your dad's going to jail. Where are the tapes? By the time I'd turned around, it could have been anyone. The easiest response was to sleep. I slept from 3:30, when I got home from school, until 7, when we had dinner. Then I'd go back to bed. I came to the dinner table exhausted and prickly, riled by something as small as the chewing noises people made. My parents did their best not to notice. They would focus on my sister instead. Something odd had happened to Ann. She was narrower and blonder, and at Marlborough School she'd hooked up with all her old Hancock Park girlfriends. She would cheerfully provide detailed accounts of volleyball tournaments or Doobie Brothers concerts. Along with my parents, I listened raptly, silently thanking her for slipping into normalcy.
 On a rare visit to the Sidwell Friends library to research a paper on "The Odyssey," I'd removed the H drawer of the card catalogue, idly flipped back to "homosexuality," inventoried the listings -- there were two -- and returned the drawer to its slot, forgetting to look up "Homer." At Harvard School, I looked up "suicide": one of the titles was "I Can't Face Tomorrow." I glanced up from a blue book during an exam that spring and, in the instant before she looked away, caught an expression on my English teacher's face that I associate with accident gawkers. A Harvard student a year ahead of me recently confided that he used to wonder whether I had a bad slouch or a deformity.
 In the pause before I scared him off, this individual became the closest thing I had to a friend. In his present incarnation as my better half, he enjoys reminding me of 20-year-old events -- incidents perhaps more remarkable or amusing to the observer than to the participant. On Aug. 7, 1974, two days before the President resigned, my father received a call from F.B.I. officials regarding a threat that had been made on his life by an unidentified man in Boston. The previous day, the tape auditors had disclosed a recording of a meeting during which my father and Nixon discussed authorizing the C.I.A. to limit the F.B.I. Watergate investigation. We were back on Bay Island. My friend says that, while a pair of plainclothes F.B.I. agents patrolled the island, the Coast Guard surveyed the shore and a police helicoptor hovered overhead, the Haldemans went about their lives. My mother made tapioca. My father placed a call to the White House to request a Presidential pardon while Nixon was still in a position to grant one. I napped. Everyone else went to the beach. 
 My father's trial began in the fall. My parents rented a small house in Arlington, Va., that my mother sent us pictures of when it had become apparent we would be spending Christmas there. We found the usual mound of presents under the tree. On a snowy morning two days after Christmas, we piled into an old Checker cab borrowed from friends in Chevy Chase and drove to the Federal courthouse to hear the closing arguments in the case of the United States v. Harry Robbins Haldeman. We sat behind my father's lawyers in the dim, unexceptional courtroom and listened to Richard Ben-Veniste, an eloquent Government attorney, present his summation. Ben-Veniste borrowed an image from "Winnie-the-Pooh" to describe my father's connection to the several hundred thousand dollars the Watergate burglars had received a few months after the break-in. He said my father had the "jam" stains of hush money "all over his face and his hands" and he couldn't lick them off. Outside the courtroom, camera crews shoved and strained like dividing cells. I offered my arm to my mother. She said, "Oh, Peter," impatiently, as if I were being melodramatic, and pushed it away. On the drive back to Arlington, in the middle of one of the narrow bridges spanning the Potomac, the Checker cab broke down. My father got out to raise the hood and quickly returned. It had started to snow hard. Several months ago, I had lunch with a friend who mentioned that an acquaintance of his had once shared a hospital room with my father. He said he thought this had occured during the period my father was in prison. I told him this person must have been confused; my father had never seen a doctor, let alone been admitted to a hospital. But last November, when it had become obvious that my father's illness amounted to something more serious than a stomachache, I got on the phone to track down the source of this story. By the time I reached him, in Seattle, I'd prepared a little interrogation. He had most of the answers. He gave the name of one of two hospitals within driving distance of the Lompoc Federal Prison Camp and a date that fell three months after my father's incarceration. He said that he himself had been hospitalized with acute appendicitis and that my father had seemed more concerned about his condition than about his own -- a hernia. He provided other details that checked out and only one that didn't: he thought he remembered my father mentioning a job in the print shop at Lompoc. My father worked in the sewage treatment plant. I called the office of records at the Valley Community Hospital in Santa Maria. They had no documentation that he'd been there.
 During the year and a half my father spent in prison, I visited him once. In September 1977, on my way up the coast to Santa Cruz, I stopped at Lompoc for lunch. At a metal picnic table under a eucalyptus tree losing its leaves and seed buttons, we shared meatloaf sandwiches prepared by my mother. At other tables, families unwrapped steaming Mexican dishes and young, skinny white and black couples in French jeans got reacquainted. It was like a rendering of millennial harmony in a Jehovah's Witness pamphlet. My father asked questions about U.C. Santa Cruz, where he was once a regent and where I was about to start school. We went over finances; the recession had drained the college fund set up by my grandparents and he wasn't able to replenish it. We also discussed a book by Will and Ariel Durant. When he wasn't analyzing waste matter, my father worked his way through the eleven volumes of "The Story of Civilization." We talked for about an hour. It was, as far as I recall, the longest exchange we ever had.
 My father was a member of Mensa and a reputed anti-intellectual. An alumnus of U.C.L.A., he once told me, apropos of a report card at Sidwell Friends, that college was not for everyone. In the two years since I'd managed to graduate from Harvard School, Santa Cruz was my fourth stab at it. The college guidance counselor at Harvard had recommended Vassar; he knew I wanted to get away and they were said to need men. At Vassar, an English professor who cultivated a resemblance to Virginia Woolf stirred some previously dormant impulse to work. I was the only student in this class to make it through the syllabus, which ended with "Our Gang," Philip Roth's Watergate parody. I wanted to stay away. Berkeley offered intensive language classes that lasted all summer. Here I spent most of my time by Strawberry Creek, copying Chinese characters into a notebook, contemplating the faint pulse of the tom-toms outside the student union. The easiest way to transfer to Berkeley was to accumulate another year of language credits through the extension program at U.C.L.A. But at U.C.L.A., I lost my momentum.
 Driving home from Westwood in the thickening afternoon smog, I tallied the reasons not to have returned. The list was long and petty, from the sudden profusion of CB radio antennas to lawns the size of putting greens in front of Hancock Park's antebellum mansions. At home, the brick walls of the den muffled the joking and sparring between my father and his ghostwriter. While awaiting a ruling on his appeal, my father had watched Richard Nixon tell David Frost that he held his chief of staff partly responsible for the Watergate cover-up; the book he's started had been conceived as a response. I still hadn't gotten used to having him around during the day. His presence reminded me of the unexpectedness of my own. I usually slept until dinner. Ann concentrated on college applications and my mother concentrated on Ann and my father. Status quo when the appeal was rejected.
 Sometime in the spring, I began utilizing the research library at U.C.L.A. On the fifth floor, at a carrel by a window overlooking a bank of cafeteria dumpsters and a parking lot, I perused books about suicide. The selection here surpassed that at Harvard School; there were statistical analyses of rates and methods by country and profession, biographies of famous people who had taken their lives, anthologies of suicide notes. I never checked anything out. What the books did was help define the afternoon. Afterward, outside, the light would have contracted a little and I could smell pine needles. At home, in a similar spirit, I experimented with razor blades. For a while, the sight of them in the medicine cabinet amplified whatever I did instead of using them. When I did use them, I was judicious. What I wanted to injure was the urge.
 I DROPPED OUT OF Santa Cruz within the quarter. Back in Los Angeles, most of the members of my family were busy preparing for various Christmas rites, which my father had been granted a furlough to attend, and for the 43d Las Madrinas Debutante Ball in the Beverly Hilton, at which my father would not be present. Las Madrinas committee members had been prevailed upon to let Ann be presented to 800 formally attired supporters of Childrens Hospital on the arm of my brother in lieu of my father. My father's confinement did not interfere with the success of his book, either, which was published two months later and contained enough revelations along the lines of the one identifying Nixon as the most likely engineer of the 18 1/2-minute erasure that it occupied the New York Times best-seller list for nine weeks.
 I didn't read "The Ends of Power," probably because I was afraid I'd find something in it to like. What I needed, I thought, was distance. I returned to the Bay area and sort of hit the road, moving from San Francisco to Berkeley and back to L.A., signing monthly leases and taking temp jobs. I walked into a glowing, pounding place called the I-Beam one evening, bumped into a guy with a tamborine and spent the night at his gingerbread-trim house in the Haight. It was refreshing to wake up in strange surroundings. In San Francisco, there might be expresso in the kitchen and a sliver of a bay view; in L.A., Donna Summer on the stereo and the shadows of giant bird of paradise -- clues to a purposeful existence, either way.
 My older brother and sister had started careers. Ann was at Stanford wieghing the benefits of sorority life. On Dec. 20, 1978, my father was released from prison. My mother held an open house that was so well attended most of the guests I spoke with had been unable to find my father in the crush. Then another Christmas, the tradition that says whatever the world inflicts, we'll always have this. On Christmas Eve, my father's relatives came in tuxes and long bowed dresses to eat Harry & David pears swathed in cream cheese and pomegranate seeds and deliberate over the aerodynamics of whirligig centerpieces from Switzerland. I remember some discussion about two events planned for that summer -- my brother's wedding in June and a family trip to Egypt in August. My memory here owes less to the importance of these occasions than to the fact that they were announced at a time when I was coming to regard future events of any magnitude as challenges.
 Someone at the Hollywod ticket agency where I worked took me to his psychic that spring. I asked her if I would be traveling soon. She clasped my hand, gazed through a curtain of beads at the traffic outside and said, "Yes." "In August?" I asked. "To Egypt?" The psychic said I would not only go to Egypt, I would not return. She was wrong on at least one count. A month or so after my brother's wedding, on a warm Friday evening dense with car exhaust and orange blossoms, I unreeled the bamboo shades in my studio apartment, got a bottle of Smirnoff out of the refrigerator and a bottle of sedatives out of the bathroom and swallowed the capsules with the vodka until I passed out. I'd left a note: Tell my parents they have nothing to do with this. I figured its significance would be lost on the L.A.P.D. officer who woke me up with his baton.
 Instead of Egypt, I was taken to a hospital in Pasadena, a 100-year-old sanitarium where doctors and nurses walked crisply along oak-shaded paths and patients in bathrobes shuffled in and out of wooden cottages. I took to it the way other people take to college. The doctor assigned to me was a student of transactional analysis. I bought a notebook in the pharmacy and filled it with diagrams of circles and arrows. My mother sent postcards of pyramids and, when they returned, visited regularly. My grandmothers came too, carrying boxes of candy from See's in their purses, eager to relate how, many years ago, they had discovered the teachings of Mary Baker Eddy.
 Understandably, my father was concerned about the cost of all this. It turned out that, after a couple of weeks, I was covered by insurance. My first hospitalization lasted half a year. The novelty wore off, along with something like hope. I put down "I'm Okay You're Okay" one afternoon and saw my father standing outside the screen door of my cottage. He held a cookie tin. "How about a game of backgammon?" he asked. He hadn't been to the hospital before, and I didn't want him to get the impression I wasn't making progress. In the recreation room, they were showing "The Other Side of the Mountain." We played in the frosty glow of the snow scenes, divvying up the tollhouse cookies my mother had made, pretending to ignore both the shaking caused by my medication and the details of Jill Kinmont's miraculous triumph over quadriplegia.
 Unhealthy food and daytime television had once satisfied my darker urges. When I returned to Hancock Park, I found the kitchen stocked with Pop-Tarts and frozen mini-pizzas and other things my parents didn't eat. I slept during the day and ate at night, watching TV until the stations signed off with "America, the Beautiful." Once or twice a week about 8 in the evening, there'd be a knock on my door and I'd wash my face and get dressed to play a few games of backgammon in the den. I left the house twice. The first time, I drove to a hardware store to buy some rubber hosing wide enough to fit over the exhaust pipe of my Volkswagon and long enough to clear the window. On a gusty April morning after a week of rain, I put the hose in the back of the car, filled the car with gas and set out for Laguna Beach.
 ON GOOD DAYS, I consider it a comeback; on others a reprieve. At the end of a long dirt road in Laguna Canyon, another conk-out of the will: before yielding to carbon monoxide, my brain gave in to whatever fear stimuli were in effect. I fell out of the car gulping chunks of cool, salty air. I spent another three months in the hospital. For years, I continued to view self-extinction as a sound contingency plan. But I never came as close to implementing it.
 One response to the insistence that the world is an orderly or orderable place, despite all evidence to the contrary, is to marshal the evidence. Back in Hancock Park, I found a book one night in the den called "Them," by Joyce Carol Oates. "Them" is a novel -- one of the few on those shelves -- about a couple of generations of a family in Detroit. A preponderence of Wendalls are raped or murdered or both; the other thing I remember about "Them" is an author's note asserting that the book is based on the experiences of a former student of hers. A day or two after finishing "Them," I showered and put on some clothes and went to find some more books by Joyce Carol Oates. When I returned to school the following year, I switched majors from Chinese to English and resumed the business of reading novels. After school, I turned to writing. As a journalist, I have been accused of writing fiction. I have also been charged with failing to document the more singular details of my own experience.
 What happened to the rest of my family was they went on. My father did not, unlike his friend John Ehrlichman, move to Santa Fe and marry a woman the age of his children and write political thrillers. He did, like me, like most of us, spend the last decade finding a comfortable remove from his past. Apart from the periodic Watergate anniversary, he successfully avoided much public attention. He invested in real estate, taught Sunday School and got around in a Cadillac Sedan DeVille with a license plate frame that read, "I'd Rather Be in Santa Barbara." In 1986, my parents moved from Hancock Park to a region of Santa Barbara where most license plates are obscured by horse-trailer hooks. When he wasn't in front of the computer or on the phone tracking his various investments, my father liked to take his quarter horse, Sam, out on the trails, tend his beds of hybrid tea roses and, when they came along, play with his grandchildren. He generally is said to have "mellowed" in his later years. If he had any personal regrets, he remarked not too Continued on page 64
long ago, he was sorry that we, his children, had not been provided a more thorough schooling in Christian Science.
 His public image evolved -- if that's the word -- from punch line to villain to punch line again. The joke is one I sometimes expect to be hearing for the rest of my life. In the last Clint Eastwood movie I saw, the biggest laughs come when my father is referred to as "a sack of excrement in a cheap suit." I still mumble my name to receptionists and operators and interview subjects. Every now and then, a news item will surface to remind me of the stretch of my father's professional shadow. A few years ago, a researcher turned up a memo from my father to J. Edgar Hoover requesting F.B.I. information on suspected homosexuals in the Washington press corps. I was living in New York at the time but happened to be in California when this discovery was reported. In the category of embarrassing revelations, it's the only one I ever raised with him. We were at the dinner table, and when I asked, my face reddened like a time-lapse rose bloom. Of the thousands of memos he dispatched on the President's behalf, my father said, it didn't ring a bell.
 This squares with my current understanding of how he approached his job. A few years ago, scanning the $3-and-under bin at Crown Books, I came across a copy of "Stonewall," Richard Ben-Veniste's book. I've since read Theodore White and Steven Ambrose and John Dean. I've spent hours in periodicals rooms reviewing 20-year-old issues of The Washington Post and The New York Times -- instinctively scrolling up the reel of microfilm when someone walked by and there happened to be a headline on the screen like "Nixon Gave Tapes to Haldeman." These sources allowed me to piece together the ramifying scandal named Watergate, as Newsweek had it -- the ramifications comprising, in large part, the moral lessons discerned by media heroes and learned the hard way by White House heavies. In one form or another, the lessons concern power. I've been pondering these ramifications lately, along with the significance of the events of the last few months. I think I'd rewrite the moral. For all the power he exercised, I suspect my father was after something closer to its opposite.
 When I finally gave "The Ends of Power" another try, I discovered I needn't have worried about liking it too much. My father, not his ghostwriter, is the invisible one here. He always regarded the book as distorted in its exclusive focus on Watergate -- and he ultimately disclaimed its least faithful portions, attributing them to his collaborator. The 1,400-page journal was intended to provide the big picture. The journal contains new disclosures about his boss and his colleagues and the events of the day. It amply documents Nixon's anxieties about his image. About my father it reveals nothing more and nothing less than this: roughly three-quarters of the sentences in the diary begin with "He" or "The P." The posthumous timing of its publication has been publicly described as an accident. I don't believe the book's schedule is any more random than that of his death.
 There's a Washington scrapbook in my parents' house with an epigraph borrowed from a Nixon speech: Until he has been a part of a cause larger than himself, no man is truly whole. I'd venture that, for my father, the cause itself was secondary. Last November, I got out that scrapbook to study, for maybe the hundreth time, my mother's painstaking documentation of four luminous years in Washington. I also read my father's horoscope in The Santa Barbara News-Press every morning I was there. I remember picking up the phone in his office and realizing that, if automatic-dial numbers are any indication, I'd never heard of most of his closest contacts. I got to know some of them through the messages they left on the machine or the notes they dropped off along with quarts of Haagen-Dazs -- the only mail my father would bring himself to read during his illness. These were his current proteges, the bright, invariably attractive young men whose enterprises he capitalized, and they exemplified the loyalty he prized. In an interview my father gave The News- Press -- his last and the one he disliked the least -- he described his relationship to these men as that of a "father figure."
 Among his other stipulations, my father dictated that there be no observance of his passing. It was the one condition my mother was willing to disregard. She, my brother and sisters, his brother and sister, respective spouses and I gathered in Santa Barbara for a meal and a walk and, in his memory, some readings from "Science and Health." There were to be no personal remembrances -- but here I transgressed. Of everyone seated around the sunny, picture-filled family room, I had the loosest day-to-day connection to my father. I was also probably the quietest by nature, but after a few passages had been read I focused on a little stain in the pale Berber carpet and started to speak. I said it had been difficult to watch him go the way he had, but that certain things had made it less so. Seeing him had been helpful. It was encouraging to find his sense of humor intact. I might have said the same of his intelligence or his humility. I might, too, have thought to add some expression of genuine gratitude for the rich and eccentric architecture of our lives. Instead, I recalled the night a week earlier, when we were summoned to his bedroom at 4 because he felt he had arrived at "a point of transition." He'd uttered a few words -- they were rare enough to repeat then and not now. Then he'd cleared his throat and straightend himself against his pillows, and my mother had said whoever wanted to leave the room was free to go.

HEADLINE: Only the Accused Were Innocent

BYLINE: By David M. Oshinsky; David M. Oshinsky, a professor of history at Rutgers University, is completing a book about race and punishment in the American South.

 BODY:

STORIES OF SCOTTSBORO
By James Goodman.
Illustrated. 465 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $27.50. 
 IT began with a fight between white and black hobos aboard a freight train bound for Memphis in the winter of 1931. Word of the brawl reached the sheriff in Jackson County, Ala., who deputized a posse to round up "every Negro" on the train. Dozens of heavily armed white men stopped the slow-moving freight at an isolated depot; a search of the boxcars and gondolas turned up nine black youths, ranging in age from 13 to 19. They were arrested for assault, chained together with a plow line and driven on the back of a rickety flatbed truck to the county jail at Scottsboro, a farming town of 3,500 in the lower Tennessee Valley.
Later that afternoon, a far more serious charge emerged. Two white women found running alongside the railroad tracks had accused all nine suspects of raping them on the train. As news of their story spread across the county, a huge crowd, chanting "Give 'em to us" and "Let those niggers out," threatened to storm the Scottsboro jail. A desperate phone call alerted the Governor of Alabama, who wisely sent in the National Guard.
The trials were held in a Scottsboro courthouse ringed by troops in full battle gear. The star witnesses -- Victoria Price and Ruby Bates -- recalled the heroic struggle they had waged aboard the train to ward off their attackers. "It took three of those Negroes to hold me," said Price, an unemployed cotton mill worker from Huntsville, Ala. "Six of them had intercourse with me." Their testimony was so shocking that women of all ages and men under 21 were barred from the courtroom.
The juries barely deliberated before convicting eight of the youths and sentencing them to death. (The case of 13-year-old Roy Wright ended in a mistrial when his jury could not decide between life imprisonment and the electric chair.) "The courtroom," said Haywood Patterson, the most outspoken of the defendants, "was one big smiling white face."
The press called them the Scottsboro Boys, and for many in America their plight became a symbol of the oppression faced by black Americans in a region where white supremacy was an uncontested fact of life. "Countless people were outraged by the trials and death sentences," writes James Goodman in "Stories of Scottsboro," a superb retelling of this vital but largely forgotten episode. "Countless others were outraged by the outrage. Appeals led to seven retrials and two landmark Supreme Court decisions. The defendants spent no less than 6, and as many as 19, years in jail."
Mr. Goodman, who teaches history at Harvard, owes a great debt to Dan T. Carter's absorbing account of the case, "Scottsboro: A Tragedy of the American South," published in 1969. Yet Mr. Goodman breaks fresh ground himself by ignoring the boundaries of narrative history and moving back and forth across time to provide multiple versions of each crucial event. The result is a complicated, often perplexing story in which the perceptions of Scottsboro's major characters -- blacks and whites, Northerners and Southerners, patricians and dirt farmers, defendants and accusers -- clash repeatedly in search of the truth.
One truth was apparent from the start. No group worked harder or longer to free the "boys" than the American Communist Party. Within days of the arrests, the Communists were providing both legal assistance and editorial support. To party leaders, the Scottsboro trial was a political bonanza, a perfect example of "ruling-class justice" in action. The young men, after all, were the barely literate sons of sharecroppers and servants. As blacks, they faced crippling race prejudice in a nation that preached equality for all; as jobless drifters, they mirrored the pain that capitalism's ultimate failure -- the Great Depression -- had inflicted on the masses.
Many distrusted the party's motives, fearing it wanted dead martyrs above all else. Actually, the opposite was true. As Mr. Goodman demonstrates, the Communists almost certainly saved the young men by insisting on their innocence at a time when other groups, including the N.A.A.C.P., were wary of defending any black accused of raping a white woman. Indeed, the youths and their families chose to be represented by the party's International Labor Defense because, as one of the mothers noted, "they are the only ones who put up a fight to save these boys and I am with them to the end."
The Communists picked an outsider, a mainstream defense attorney with no radical connections, to represent the youths at the new trials and appeals. His name was Samuel Leibowitz, and few could doubt his record or his skill. A tall, heavyset New Yorker, Leibowitz "had excelled at drama and debating" at Cornell, and "his vibrant voice and extraordinary sense of timing were as useful to him as his prodigious preparation, attention to detail and mastery of the law." In 15 years of practice, Leibowitz had defended 78 people accused of first-degree murder; 77 had been acquitted, and in the one other trial, the result was a hung jury. He decided to represent the Scottsboro Boys without fee after a black Communist lawyer convinced him of their innocence. What Leibowitz demanded in return was the freedom to defend these young men without political interference. The Communists agreed.
Leibowitz came on board several weeks after the Supreme Court of the United States had overturned the Scottsboro convictions by ruling, in Powell v. Alabama, that the defendants were effectively denied counsel in violation of the 14th Amendment's "due process" clause. At their second trial -- held in 1933 in Decatur, Ala., a Ku Klux Klan stronghold 50 miles west of Scottsboro -- Leibowitz quickly took charge. He moved for a dismissal on the ground that blacks had been systematically excluded from Alabama's jury rolls. To prove his point, Leibowitz questioned a series of black and white witnesses, none of whom could recall a single black ever having been called for jury duty. The difference, however, was that the whites could not understand why anyone would choose to have it otherwise. To their thinking, blacks simply lacked the character to judge other people's fates. Did that mean they were dishonest, Leibowitz asked a local newspaper editor. "Yes, sir," he replied. "They will nearly all steal."
Judge James Horton denied Leibowitz's motion and ordered the trial to begin. But Horton, a wealthy landowner with deep antebellum roots in Alabama, was clearly troubled by the case, Mr. Goodman explains. For one thing, he did not believe that all nine of the defendants could possibly have taken part in the crime. They had been captured in groups of two and three aboard a very long train. One of the youths was nearly blind; another had been suffering from a case of venereal disease so painful that he had to walk with a cane. How could they have jumped from car to car to take part in a brawl -- or a rape?
Horton was even more troubled by the claims of the two women, Price and Bates. They said that a terrible struggle had ensued, yet their bodies were barely bruised. One of their examining physicians told Horton, in confidence, that the women had lied about the rape and "laughed at me" as they were being tested. "Judge, God knows I want to, but I can't," the doctor said when Horton urged him to testify. "If I testified for those boys I'd never be able to go back into Jackson County."
It probably wouldn't have mattered. Leibowitz produced one bombshell after another, to no avail. His first major witness, a white hobo who had boarded the freight train with Victoria Price, described her -- accurately, it turned out -- as a prostitute and an adulterer. And his next witness was none other than Ruby Bates, who had decided to tell the truth, she said, after months of soul-searching and prayer. There had been no rape on the train, Bates stammered. Victoria Price had made up the story because she feared that the posse would arrest her for transporting a minor -- Bates was then 17 -- across state lines for the purpose of prostitution.
The prosecutors were stunned. They lashed out at the witnesses as ugly liars, pawns of Jews and Communists, and traitors to the South. At the end of his summation, one prosecutor asked the jury to consider a single question: "Is justice in the case going to be bought and sold in Alabama with Jew money from New York?"
The jurors obliged. Their verdict, once again, was guilty, and the sentence was death. Believing that Ruby Bates had been corrupted by Northern infidels, Mr. Goodman says, they saw no alternative but to accept the word of her traveling companion, Victoria Price. The fact that Price had led a hardscrabble life -- that she had grown up poor, quit school early, worked as a mill girl, lived in hobo jungles and made some poor moral choices -- seemed only to soften the hearts of these 12 plain, stern, white Alabama men. Leibowitz, who had confidently predicted an acquittal, now exploded in rage. Asked by a reporter to explain the verdict, he portrayed white Southerners en masse as "lantern-jawed morons," adding, "If you ever saw those creatures, those bigots whose mouths are slits in their faces, whose eyes popped out at you like frogs, whose chins dripped tobacco juice, bewhiskered and filthy, you would not ask how they could do it."
THE verdict may not have surprised Judge Horton, but it surely embarrassed him. Horton, Mr. Goodman writes, well understood the deep sexual fears that Southern whites harbored toward blacks. He had seen his share of lynchings over allegations far less spectacular than those reported in the Scottsboro case. He knew that many white men considered blacks primitive beings who ravaged white women out of lust, revenge or sometimes both. He knew that many white women lived in constant fear of being sexually assaulted by blacks, though such offenses were extremely rare. And his years on the bench had taught him that whites routinely accused blacks of crimes in order to conceal evidence of their own misconduct.
As Mr. Goodman makes clear, however, the behavior of Leibowitz and other supporters of the Scottsboro Boys was not without serious moral flaws. In his summation, Leibowitz played shamelessly on the racial prejudices of the jury by describing his own client as a "poor, moronic colored boy." And his cross-examination of Victoria Price raised the dangerous notion that prostitutes did not deserve the full protection of the law -- a notion widely accepted by Northern civil rights advocates at this time. Indeed, the black writer Langston Hughes ended his bitter essay on Scottsboro by asking, "And who ever heard of raping a prostitute?"
In an astonishing reversal, Judge Horton set aside the convictions, citing the "unreliability" of the state's only major witness, Victoria Price. His words bristled with a contempt born of gentlemanly breeding as he charged that women of her "character" were prone to make "false accusations" of rape "for ulterior purposes." In a sense, Horton had done the unthinkable by chastising a white woman who had accused black men of sexually assaulting her. But Victoria Price was not a true representative of Southern womanhood, Horton believed, and that put her beyond the reach of his chivalrous protection.
As expected, the state of Alabama ordered an immediate retrial. Judge Horton was replaced by Judge William Callahan, an ignorant 70-year-old jurist who assumed, among other things, that black men could not keep themselves from raping white women and that white women would never willingly have sex with black men. The prosecutor summed up his case by warning that an acquittal would force the female population of Alabama to "buckle six-shooters around their middles" so as to protect "the sacred parts of their bodies" from oversexed blacks. And the jurors brought in the predictable verdict and sentence: guilty and death.
Once again, the Supreme Court intervened. In a ground-breaking 1935 decision, Norris v. Alabama, it reversed the convictions on the ground that blacks had been excluded from the juries that indicted the youths. By this time, the story of the Scottsboro Boys had become a national obsession. Tales of Southern racism ran side by side with articles about Hitler's racism in Germany, writes Mr. Goodman, "and for many Northerners one story became an aid to understanding the other."
As Northern protests mounted, Alabama's once-steady resolve began to waver. The clear majority of whites, Mr. Goodman says, still wanted the Scottsboro Boys to hang. Anything less, warned J. Thomas (Cotton Tom) Heflin, a former United States senator, would place "wicked thoughts in the minds of the lawless Negro men." Yet a number of influential whites now urged clemency for the youths as a way of protecting Alabama from further ridicule and abuse. "I don't care what they do," the editor of The Montgomery Advertiser fumed, "so long as they do it in another state, preferably Ohio or New York. I don't care if they eat one another without benefit of pepper sauce. I do not know whether they are guilty or innocent of the rape of two cut-rate prostitutes. I do not care."
In 1937, the state released four of the Scottsboro Boys -- the two youngest and the two most sickly -- as a gesture of good will. The other five were retried, found guilty and sentenced to long terms in prison. But as time passed and memories dimmed in Alabama, four of them were quietly paroled -- one in 1943, two in 1944, another in 1946. Haywood Patterson, described by state parole officials as "vicious" and "incorrigible," escaped from prison in 1948 and fled to Detroit. Arrested two years later by the F.B.I., Patterson was set free after Michigan rebuffed Alabama's halfhearted attempt to have him returned.
Freedom did not prove kind to the Scottsboro Boys, Mr. Goodman reports. The products of violent homes and prison beatings, they drifted north to places like New York and Cleveland without skills or clear direction. Most of them found trouble, and some went back to jail. Roy Wright, the youngest of the Scottsboro Boys, committed suicide after killing his wife. Patterson died in a Michigan prison after murdering a man in a barroom brawl. "Everywhere I go," said one of the nine, "it seems like Scottsboro is throwed up in my face. . . . I don't believe I'll ever live it down."
Mr. Goodman tells us nothing about the later lives of Ruby Bates, Victoria Price and Samuel Leibowitz. The two women went their separate ways and were quickly forgotten. Leibowitz returned to New York, became a criminal court judge and made headlines with his stormy behavior and his harsh treatment of defendants. As a lawyer, he recalled, "my job . . . was to sell my client's cause to the jury." As a judge, he added, "I was tough with hardened criminals; toughness was all they understand." He died in 1978.
The injustice of Scottsboro has long since faded from view. The names of Roy Wright and Haywood Patterson and the others do not appear alongside the names of Rosa Parks, Emmett Till and Medgar Evers on the list of those who made a difference in the struggle for civil rights. Yet one cannot read Mr. Goodman's remarkable book without being moved by the courage and resilience of these simple young men. Clarence Norris was 18 when Victoria Price accused him of rape. Facing the death sentence at his third trial, he was asked if he had anything to say. "Yes, sir," Norris calmly told the judge. "They didn't find me guilty. They just thought they did. I am accused of a crime I never even thought about committing."
