HEADLINE: GENERATION RAP

BYLINE: By Sheila Rule; Sheila Rule reports on popular music for The New York Times.

 BODY:
IN 1968 A TRIO OF BLACK poets went on stage in Harlem at a commemoration of Malcolm X and framed their political verse with a chant: "Are you ready, niggas? You've got to be ready." That was the beginning for the Last Poets, influential forefathers of rap. The original members -- Abiodun Oyewole, David Nelson and Gylan Kain -- and the Last Poets who succeeded them welded revolutionary politics, incendiary street language and jazzy musical accompaniment into a polyrhythmic wake-up call to America.
A quarter of a century later, Ice Cube lifts his voice and commands worldwide attention as one of hip-hop's angriest young men. He first appeared with N.W.A. (Niggas With Attitude), the Compton, Calif., group that put the sub-genre called "gangsta rap" on the charts, and now sells millions of records solo with his hard-core imagery of an urban landscape bristling with blood and bullets, profanity, misogyny and potent beats. 
 Today Mr. Oyewole, 46, is a consultant for creative writing to New York City schools and uses material from the Poets, as well as his more recent poetry, in his teaching. He can be heard on a new Last Poets album, "Holy Terror," which was released in Japan last year on the P-Vine record label and is to be released here later this year. Ice Cube, 24, who has become a follower of the Rev. Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam, recently released his fifth recording, "Lethal Injection" (Priority Re cords). It peaked at No. 5 on Billboard's chart of the 200 best-selling albums.
The record's success comes amid ever more vocal outrage over hard-core rap's graphic depiction of sexual conquests, drug use and gangs, and its glorification of violence toward women and homosexuals. WBLS-FM in New York City and other radio stations around the country are limiting air play of hard-core rap, playing edited versions or banning it outright; Congress has examined it in hearings on Capitol Hill; black leaders are denouncing the music as immoral and self-destructive and are organizing demonstrations at record stores and elsewhere. The backlash was given more fuel by the arrests of three major hip-hop artists on charges including sexual assault and murder: Tupac Shakur, Flavor Flav and Snoop Doggy Dogg, whose album, "Doggy style," was released in the midst of his troubles and was the first debut ever to enter the Billboard album chart at No. 1. And last month, T-Bone, one of Ice Cube's back-up singers, was also charged with murder. With critics particularly agitated over what influence the music may be having on young listeners, gangsta rappers say: don't shoot the messengers -- we are simply chronicling life the way it is in the jagged-edged inner city.
The New York Times Magazine invited Mr. Oyewole and Ice Cube to have a conversation across the generations. They had never met. They got together one sunny afternoon at Ice Cube's Street Knowledge production offices, in South-Central Los Angeles, and talked about a range of topics, including the messages and motivations of rappers, their own personal visions and being black in America.
ABIODUN OYEWOLE: We're 20 years apart, almost exactly 20 years. I started at a young age, dealing with some words that were earth-shattering. My mother would not even listen to the records I made back in those days because of the language we used. But we moved the people to think and change. Was that a mission with you when you first started writing?
ICE CUBE: Well, basically, I was a fan of the music, being 10 years old when the first rap jam came out. I was just out of nursery rhymes. So I tried it and fell in love. I said, I'm going to do records my homeboys down the street like. That was my main concern, you know, just recognition in the neighborhood. What I wanted to do was be witty.
A. O. : All the young brothers that were writing poetry -- sisters, as well -- we didn't just want to deal with complaining about how the system has got its foot on our necks. We had a particular ideal for the life style we wanted, and we were willing to give our lives to live that life style. Did you have a personal ideal, besides wanting to be witty?
I. C. : Well, not when I first started. When I first started, I was dead. I never went outside, or if I did I had negative thoughts. Who gonna see me? If they do see me, what's gonna pop? But when I was able to travel and kind of open up -- you know, getting love, you want to give love. But you got to give it in the right context.
A. O. : So you're waking up.
I. C. : Yeah. Some people don't like us because we distribute information without going through WBLS. I don't care if WBLS never plays one of my songs. It's not going to matter, because I think the people feel the same way I feel. They're gonna seek my stuff as long as I stay true.
Now, what we have today is some rappers want to put knowledge in their records, and some rappers don't. You got the older generation of so-called leaders want to come talk to us, want to sit down and rap to us. But it's no dialogue there. They always let the small things or small differences interfere with the bigger picture. If I use the word "bitch," to me it's just language.
A. O. : But language does control. Language sets us up for a whole bunch of things. Language incites us. That's why when we used words like "bitch" in the Last Poets, we made it clear that those words were used not loosely, but specifically to talk about a particular character in the community, not everybody. It really hurt me when N.W.A. sampled us on "Real Niggers Don't Die," and they sampled "Die Nigger" and they had, I think it was, "Niggers die, niggers die for 400 years. Die, nigger, die, nigger, die, nigger, die." But then the brother comes in and says, "Real niggers don't die." And they missed the most important part, because that poem says, "Niggers watch Nat Turner die, niggers watch Emmett Till die, niggers watch Medgar Evers die, watch niggers die, die, die. Die, nigger, die, nigger, die; they can die so black folks can take over." And that's the point. Get rid of the nigger, you get rid of the bitch, so that the beauty of your folks will emerge.
I. C. : But I can't go to the Japanese talking Chinese. I have to speak the language of the street to get their ear. See, the teacher, the preacher, the politician won't talk real to the kids. So that's why they won't listen to them. You got to talk in their language and guide them to the place, and that's exactly what we're doing. When I talk about a certain problem in the community, I'm not talking about everybody; I'm talking about people I call suckers. I call them Negroes. Sex rules countries, so it's ruling our neighborhood. If you ask anybody in the streets, they say if you have a Benz, you can get all the women. And that's what the brothers fighting over. So material things become more important than the person.
How do you deal with that? You have to tell the brother who does that material thing to get the woman, you a fool. And you got to tell it to the woman, and they have to be called something that nobody likes to be called. Malcolm X said, Throw a rock in a pack of dogs and the only one hollers is the one that gets hit. So if you see yourself in my lyrics, then you got to change what you're doing.
A. O. : It's like, if the shoe fits wear it. You just explained it beautifully. It's the same thing we did in the Poets. But you have to spell it out for the folks sometimes, and you have to take time out to do that.
When we see the devastation of our people, then we have got to make "sister" a word in the 'hood, so it's not a foreign word to the brothers and sisters. I have this piece that I do in the schools all the time, just to prove a point. I say, "How many of you brothers and sisters in the school deal with 'bitch' as a word?" Everybody raises their hand. Then I tell the brothers to tell their girlfriends this: "Brown sugar, honey bunny, lady chocolate supreme, you are the one that I see when I'm having a dream.' The point being, I would much better infect your mind with a positive antidote for you to take as opposed to taking you on the bitch trip just to try to turn you around. If I go into any community in this town right now, Crenshaw, Compton, anyplace in this town, and I run "Brown Sugar" down, I'm gonna get nothing but praise from all the sisters and the brothers because we want to hear something good about ourselves.
So some time you're going to have to try to explain to people: "I'm not talking about all my sisters. You know, I'm not talking about my mother." It's got to be clear. And then people start to say, "Oooh, so when he says 'bitch,' he really means 'bitch.' "
I. C. : I'm with that 100 percent. The thing is, it's not like we're going this negative route to go a positive route. The negative route was set in motion and most of us, with no knowledge, jump in that motion and are still turning with that motion.
What happened to the word "brother" -- and "sister" -- so many people said it and didn't mean it. That's what killed that word, because so many people said, "Brother, I love you," and didn't mean it.
A. O. : The difference between you and me and then and now is that my whole thing was specifically from a political arena. The Last Poets came on to rebel against a system that had us all in check, whereas the kids like you all have been seen as coming on as a cartoon.
I. C. : Yeah. You all come from way different backgrounds. See, the reason why I go to the defense of brothers like Snoop and Tupac, I used to be right there. I think they're still looking for recognition from the homies. These people became stars overnight. Everybody in the neighborhood got a certain rank. And the so-called O.G.'s [original gangstas] gave them a rank. So when they became famous, they kind of surpassed the O.G.'s, but they still looked up to them. So they pick them up and drive them around. So now they riding around, boom, boom, boom, boom. They got to show they still down even though they doing records, that they ain't selling out.
This stardom has come so fast they can't feel it. They still can only feel it within their circle of homeboys, or peers.
You really have to get on the boat and throw the life jacket and say, "Let me pull you on the boat." You can say to that same O.G., "Yo, man, I'm doing this video. I can get you on a job as a grip where you can learn something." That's better for the O.G. than going, "I'm here. I'm still down."
A. O. : This addiction to sex and violence, what happened? This was an area of the country the Panthers came out of. There was some serious black stuff going down out here. What happened to that, man?
I. C. : The TV taught the kids more than the parents because the TV was 24 hours a day. And you sit up here 24 hours a day looking at foolishness, and so you're addicted. You want to see the cartoons -- very violent. That's the first thing. There are more weapons in Toys "R" Us than there are at the gun shop.
Now the people from the older generation, they remember life without television. We don't know that.
A. O. : I'm this old guy, man, and I got this ideal that we're gonna get to a point where we can just do like Nina Simone said when she did her album called "Black Gold." I don't know if you've got it. It's the first time that she ever sang "Young, Gifted and Black." She said: "This next song is not a protest song. It is not a protest song against any white person who may be in the audience; it is just simply ignoring you." [Sings] "To be young, gifted and black." And I mean, that was one of the most revolutionary statements I've ever heard in my life because the song had nothing to do with whites. How come we haven't gotten to the point where we understand there's only one bank to feed, and it's ours? It's only one love to love, and it's ours. How come we can't see that?
I. C. : Man, you know why? Because the school system is teaching our kids. The people that won't treat you right won't teach you right. Until we start teaching our own that's never gonna come about. Schoolbooks teach you if it's white, it's right. That's why you have a kid that, before he even gets to school, is so smart. Get in school and seem like he got a lobotomy. So I'm saying it's perfect for us to start changing it around.
The kids want to separate from this culture. People started wearing different hair styles. People started wearing their clothes baggy, so they can let the system know that we ain't with this. We're our own people. And we gonna stand on our own, and we gonna try to get some of the fire that was given off in those times for today. People who talk about black nationalism, we just want to control the world we see because we know once we control what's in our neighborhoods, we can control the people in the neighborhoods.
So once we can control, you know, not in a negative way, but just supervise what's going into the heads of our kids, then we can have unity and become an economic strength. And once you become an economic strength here, you got no problems, no more problems.
But some people like a dark room. They done been there so long they don't want you to turn on the light. So you got to light a candle and just place it in a corner, and pretty soon you can light another, pretty soon a whole lot. But if you just turn on a light, you got a fight.
If you look at the course that the rap is going, you have 100,000 so-called gangsta rappers oversaturating the market. Me, I don't consider myself a gangsta rapper.
A. O. : The kids call you an educated gangsta.
I. C. : I consider myself reality because I could give you the gangsta stuff, and I could also give you the knowledge at the same time. What is happening is so-called gangsta rap is starting to look like a comic book to many kids.
The consciousness is starting to seep into the music. Chuck D set in motion the same things that you all set in motion. Trying to build it back up. And you have gangsta rap, which is the negative image of all that, and the negative things that are happening is at the peak.
A. O. : I try to make it clear to a lot of the brothers and sisters who have this problem with gangsta rap and the roughnecks and the hard-core that, you know, these are our warriors. This is our army. These brothers are looking for rites of passage. There ain't no lion for them to go out in the jungle and kill and come back and say, "I've killed the lion. Now I'm a man." So they kill each other. They kill whatever is there, but there's a rebellious spirit that is in all of us. I have a piece that's on our "Holy Terror" album called "Black Rage," and the hook line is "Grenades in their eyes." And I see the grenades in the brothers' eyes. And I understand it. I'm not afraid of it, but it terrorizes my mother. My mother's not going to cross the street if she sees three baggy shadow boys standing on the corner. She's gonna wait for the cops to come because she don't know if they gonna rip her off or take her purse, when it should be that she sees them and she's protected by them. And that's got to come out in the lyrics.
Rap has made itself a billion-dollar industry, and you and some other brothers are sitting at the top of the charts because of the simple reason that people have a need to express themselves and hear their own voice. And you have been that mirror, reflecting a lot of the pain and the joy within the pain they have felt. But the reality is, what we got to do is take all of that pain and joy and give it some focus and direction so we can have a tomorrow. But not only for you -- for me, too, as old as I am. I'm 40-plus. I still got to grow. And I've got to respect and recognize that your rebel spirit is the same rebel spirit I had.
I. C. : And we're just running with it, and we run into each other with it. We're running all over. I mean, we're terrible.
A. O. : It's the absence of a movement. You see, the one thing we did have were the Panthers, even though I was not a Panther, but they were there giving you those slogans and a 10-point program, breakfast programs, school programs. There was the Nation of Islam. I wasn't a member, but they were there. There was a movement going on. Martin Luther King was marching. You all haven't had that. So that's why you all go run into each other. I couldn't talk to brothers -- a lot of the brothers I respected who were street knowledgeable of other things -- without having read Harold Cruse's "Crisis of the Negro Intellectual," without having read thoroughly "The Autobiography of Malcolm X." I had to read Chancellor Williams's "Destruction of Black Civilization." I had to sit down and read those books because folks were quoting things out of the pages and I didn't know what they were talking about if I didn't read the book.
I. C. : I'm not really, to be honest, a book person. You know, I'm just inspired by people.
A. O. : And that's beautiful. But, still, those of us who realize that we should not let any discipline be an obstacle to our growth need to encourage reading of some materials, because we've got some brothers and sisters who have written something for us to know.
I. C. : What books do you suggest?
A. O. : One of the books I would suggest you get in your library, especially since you're a rapper and use words well, is "Black Fire." It's an anthology of poetry and it's as thick as the Bible. It's an anthology of the baddest poetry written in the 60's.
I. C. : A lot of the rappers don't know nothing but what they know. And people are trying to clump us all together. I mean, don't come against us. We're the only people who can distribute information without going through any kind of channels. What I want to do is be able to talk -- I want the brothers in L.A. to know the same thing the brothers in New York know, same thing, boom, boom, the brothers in Jamaica know.
A. O. : You want lines of communication to be open for all of us.
I. C. : Rap music is that only line. These kids are fired up. They just have to know directions, because our so-called leaders are trying to make the public school better instead of trying to build our own schools. A lot of people feel that people from the 60's took their eyes off of the prize in the 70's. And we picked it up ourselves, and now they want to show us how to do it. They want us to do it the same way they did it, and it didn't work. So you have kids who don't want to listen. Or you have leaders, spineless, just no kind of strength.
A. O. : We fell short on a lot of levels in terms of securing a place for you all. I've done a decent job with my kids, thank God, and I've had a lot of help to do that, but we had a lot of brothers and sisters who didn't, and they let their frustrations take charge of their lives and, consequently, they also sent their kids to the room and told them to watch television.
The bottom line is, I do know that at this point in time if we don't make some serious collaborations to try to develop some programs and activities to save our people, we're full of it.
I.C. : Oh, yeah.
A. O. : And if we make some opportunities in terms of the record business to get some words out there, we've got to think about how those little minds are gonna take whatever we say and run with it because they've got nothing else. If they like you -- especially if they love you -- they're going to take whatever you say as the truth.
I. C. : Yeah. It's not just slang.
A. O. : So what do we do? How do we try to empower ourselves? What can we do to build up our people again?
I. C. : One thing I believe we need to do, we got to separate. We really have to say, "O.K., white folks. You want to help us? You go to your community and break down the walls." When they're in there talking in the board room, talking about us, you go correct them. Don't come here picking up trash.
A. O. : Yeah. Being a missionary and all that stuff.
I. C. : We can do that. You handle yours, we'll handle ours.
A. O. : That's true, and in doing so, Cube, we're going to have to be ardently serious about instilling values, because we've got kids who think it's cute for a girl to give somebody [oral sex] in public. The sacredness of us is gone, man, and that hurts me so much because we're a loving, ritualistic people.
I. C. : I'm telling you, the only way we can achieve this, man, is to separate. That's the only way we can achieve it. We have too many outside influences.
A. O. : You are a young teacher, and I have to truly give you credit, Cube. From what I know from hearing stuff early on and now talking to you personally, I love your evolution, brother.
I. C. : Thank you. I'm still growing, man, still growing.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
From Stereotypes of Urban Decay to Signs of Life

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
ONE DAY, WE WILL HAVE A generation of public servants who recognize that the urban park system is the supreme democratic art form. I wish that day were here, for we have in hand a plan that could help rejuvenate that art form in America's largest city.
"Public Space for Public Life: A Plan for the 21st Century" provokes hope and despair in equal measure. Prepared under the auspices of two private groups, the Parks Council and the Central Park Conservancy, the $3 billion, 10-year plan offers inspiring proof that the civic spirit lives in New York City. At the same time, as the plan documents with depressingly stark graphs and charts, the public has lost ground in the fight to keep the city green. 
 New York, a city that gave birth to the parks movement nearly 150 years ago, now ranks 19th among major American cities in dollars spent per citizen to maintain its park system. The system's operating budget, per acre, is one-sixth that of Chicago, half that of Los Angeles. In the past three years New York's Department of Parks and Recreation has been forced to cut its full-time staff by a quarter. Today the work force tending the parks is half the size it was in 1960.
The numbers may surprise those who have been dazzled by some recent, well-publicized successes: the miraculous rebirth of Bryant Park, the creation of Riverbank Park in Harlem and Hudson River Park in lower Manhattan. But these achievements, made possible by money from private sources and New York State, have obscured the steady decline in the city's system. By laying bare the grim statistics, "Public Space for Public Life" hopes to stir people to action.
The plan is not all it could be. For one thing, it is misleadingly titled. This is not, alas, a 21st-century plan, or even a 20th-century plan. It is, for the most part, a sensible, well-thought-out extension of Frederick Law Olmsted's 19th-century ideas into a late-20th century metropolis. All of the plan's major recommendations -- community parks, greenways, riverside esplanades and wilderness preserves -- derive from Olmsted's pioneering vision. This doesn't mean they are obsolete. Olmsted's ideas demonstrate their enduring value every day. But his pastoral vision of nature does not accord with our increasing understanding of the ecologically complex relationships between cities and their environments. An urban park system should lead the way toward forms that enhance this awareness.
It is also disappointing that the plan does not foresee a more important role for design. Why should Barcelona be the only city with the nerve to enlist emerging architects in a citywide program of new public spaces? As the Architectural League's 1992 "Productive Park" show made extravagantly clear, there's no shortage of talented New York designers eager to apply their skills and imagination to the public realm.
Fortunately, the plan, which has the support of Henry Stern, the Parks Commissioner, does not preclude modifications along these lines. At once comprehensive and flexible, it carves out a network of places where many different ideas about the public and natural realms could be pursued. Its strategy for community parks, in particular, holds great potential for innovation.
A hundred new parks. No, better than that, 100 miniature park systems, each reflecting the different needs and identities of 100 diverse New York neighborhoods. Yet the communities designated by the plan to receive these new public spaces have some features in common. All are densely populated; most have less than the average amount of park land (1.5 acres for every 1,000 people).
And they all suffer from more than their share of inner city woes: poverty, high crime rates, derelict buildings, drugs. East New York, Central Harlem, the South Bronx: even their names are synonymous with urban
decline.
Yet as the plan points out, the problems afflicting these neighborhoods have created opportunity as well as need. As a result of economic decline, the city has acquired more than 20,000 parcels of vacant and abandoned land. Utilizing about 1,000 of these lots, 500 acres in all, the plan proposes a cluster of parks for each neighborhood: a two-acre "central park" supported by four smaller satellite parks, gardens or playgrounds.
The key to the concept isn't size, location or design. It is staffing and management. Each neighborhood park system would be supervised by the Parks Department but sponsored by one or more community groups, a church or a school, say, which would help design the park, set up programs and organize local volunteers. In addition to the volunteers, six full-time workers would be needed to operate each system, half of them Parks Department employees, the rest paid by private groups or other government programs. Thus the park becomes a place to bring together public support and neighborhood responsibility.
While Olmsted envisioned community parks, he did not foresee this degree of community involvement. But the community-based park idea has been tested in neighborhoods throughout the city, in projects like the aptly named Success Garden in central Harlem, sponsored by the Parks Council and School Community District 5. The plan seeks to increase such initiatives to the level of critical mass.
The estimated cost of these parks is
$195 million, plus $20 million a year in operating expenses. To a degree, this can be regarded as a public investment. As Olmsted foresaw, parks improve property values. Community-based parks also provide poor neighborhoods with jobs and training.
But something else is going on here that's just as important as economic revitalization. Community parks have the power to reveal that these neighborhoods, even in their present condition, are integral parts of the city. New Yorkers live here. They work and pay taxes. They've invested in the city's future. What the plan is calling for is not scenic welfare. It is equity.
And it would do more than transform vacant lots. It would also change symbols -- turning the lurid stereotypes of urban decay into signs of life. The rubble-filled lot reflects a reality, but also distorts it. It casts a community in the image of its dregs. Imagine how Central Park would look if, like the picture of Dorian Gray, it expressed the baser instincts of those who inhabit its prized perimeter. Think how much pruning and planting it takes to keep that side from showing. "Public Space for Public Life" could not only change New York. It could reveal the face of a city that is already here.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
New Disney Park Raises Environmental Concerns

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NOW that the Virginia state legislature has agreed to financial incentives for the Walt Disney Company to build a new theme park in the countryside outside Washington, environmental groups are turning their attention to the changes in land use and transportation patterns that would come with the $650 million project.
The largely agricultural region around Haymarket, Va., where the 3,000-acre historical theme park is to be built, would sprout a big entertainment complex along with offices, shops, hotels and 2,500 homes under the Disney plan. 
 Environmental groups said the state
should plan for the resulting air pollution and development pressures throughout the region, lest it lose more than it gains economically from the giant project.
While the decision by the legislature, and its endorsement by much of the local zoning board, makes it less likely that the project will be blocked, environmentalists have vowed to carry on the fight.
"We don't view this as a fait accompli, and certainly everything we are doing, we hope will improve the project," said Josephine deGive of the Piedmont Environmental Council, a local group that opposes the project.
The administration of Gov. George F. Allen pushed hard for the state to support Disney in the legislative session that ended March 19, arguing that the theme park, emphasizing American history, is expected to generate 19,000 new jobs.
"This is a project that will be the envy of the entire nation," said Governor Allen, who pushed a package through the legislature that financed the building of roads and other improvements on the understanding that the Disney park would create enough tax revenues to service the debt. The company hopes to break ground in late 1995 and open in 1998.
But there are broad social costs to be considered, environmental groups said.
"The Disney America project will undoubtedly change the face of Northern Virginia," said Ralph Grossi, the president of American Farmland Trust, a rural conservation organization based in Washington.
The group says that if the plan proceeds thousands of acres of farmland will face growing pressures of urbanization. It called on the state to devise plans to avoid the destruction of farmland, saying that the 6,000 farms with 1.2 million acres in 12 nearby counties account for a seventh of the state's farmland and farm production, and that the farmers spend $216 million a year.
And eight environmental groups, including the Environmental Defense Fund, warned that the project will make it harder for the metropolitan Washington region to come into compliance with the Clean Air Act. Disney has predicted that at least 77,000 additional vehicle trips a day will result from the project, including twice the normal traffic on Interstate 66, which connects the building site to Washington, 35 miles to the east.
Air quality in Virginia has steadily declined for decades, and during the 1980's the average number of miles driven per person increased by more than 50 percent.
The metropolitan region's governments must come up with plans by November showing the Federal Government how they will meet Federal health standards for air quality, largely by controlling automobile emissions. If they fail to do so they could lose Federal transportation grants worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
A recent report by the Environmental Law Institute, based in Washington, said the state's prosperity was linked both to tourism and to the environment. "In 1990, domestic and international travelers spent more than $8 billion in Virginia, and travel related businesses supported 159,000 jobs and paid $380 million in state and local taxes," the report said.
It recommended that Virginia "mobilize vigorously" to protect its natural resources "so that it can prevent potentially detrimental impacts resulting from the same visitors who generate income for the Commonwealth." The organization has not taken a formal position on the park.

LENGTH: 213 words

HEADLINE: THE SOUND OF NON-MUSIC

 BODY:
John Tierney is living in a fantasy version of New York (The Big City: "The Sound of Non-Music," March 13). His New York is filled with demonic theatrical unions and innocent, beleaguered producers who have (so sadly) failed to form a monopolistic cartel.
Obviously, Mr. Tierney is unaware of the reality on Broadway, which is far less romantic than he might wish. To wit: 
 1) The cost of producing Broadway shows has risen dramatically over the past 20 years while the cost of employing musicians has actually declined as a percentage of the total, and has barely kept pace with inflation.
2) "Tommy" is the first musical in 5 years to have "walkers," and is the first new production in 15 years whose producers have chosen to use an orchestra smaller than contractually agreed upon.
Mr. Tierney's straw man arguments (e.g. musicians' rigid work rules are driving up costs on Broadway) may seem persuasive on the surface, but they obscure a far greater danger -- that technologically reproduced music (synthesizers and tapes) will replace live music in the theater. Live music is having a tough enough time surviving in New York without the appearance of an anti union diatribe disguised as a feature about Runyonesque local color.
 
ANDY ZOOB
New York, N.Y.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: ART;
The Travails of Victorian Women Achieving Fame as Artists

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

 BODY:
THE show now at the Yale Center for British Art leads off with books, several of them classics like "Wuthering Heights" and "Jane Eyre." It also takes its title, "A Struggle for Fame," from a book by Charlotte Riddell, the Irish novelist who was living in London at the end of the 19th century.
Though Riddell went on to achieve fame, this, her first effort, written in 1883 when she was 51, has remained obscure. It would seem, however, that the story, based on the writer's own experience of breaking into the literary world, sums up the difficulties faced by Victorian women trying to make it as writers and artists in a man's world. 
 In any case, the show's curators, Susan P. Casteras and Linda H. Peterson, use the novel as a jumping-off point for their catalogue essays. As explained by Ms. Casteras, who is the center's curator of paintings, a "key message" concerns "the mixture of conflict, ambivalence, frustration and guilt at the prospect of fame and its attendant power generated for her and other women."
Ms. Casteras, who is the more polemic of the two writers and the more inclined to view history through contemporary eyes, covers the lot of 19th-century women from many angles, finding much cause for irony. At the same time, she concedes that where art was concerned, men were no more likely to contest the status quo than women.
Thus, the generally conservative output of women should be viewed not as "a sign of simple compliance or timidity" but as "a byproduct of female inbred servility to male authority and of women's insecurity in the art world."
Nevertheless, the curator is quick to praise the artists in the show for their ability to produce, "in the face of overriding cultural disadvantages," pictures of "women's cultural tradition, history and heroism" that belong to a "seemingly endless iconological as well as ideological 'struggle for fame.' "
In her essay, Ms. Peterson, who is a professor of English at Yale, takes a less partisan view and focuses more on individual artists. She also shows a touch of humor, as when she refers to an 1893 book that counseled women intent on combining marriage with a career to get a good housekeeper and send the children to school -- advice that is as sound today as it was then.
Still, for all the information and insights that it provides, the catalogue leaves the viewer in a familiar predicament. To put it simply, with emotions drained by contemporary horrors ranging from widespread poverty at home to atrocities in the Serbian-Croatian conflict, how does one muster passion about the hardships faced by Victorian women artists scarcely less middle class than their male oppressors?
Fortunately, the show comes to the rescue by retrieving many good artists from obscurity. High on the list of graphic performers are the Claxton sisters, Florence and Adelaide, who seem to have been the Peggy Bacons of the 1860's and 70's. In a two-part engraving called "Choice of Paris," Florence aims at Pre-Raphaelite claptrap by setting the contest in a salon full of creative types striking attitudes -- note the esthete scrutinizing a woman's foot through a magnifying glass. Adelaide, though a touch less acerbic than her sister, does a good job on a crowd of Christmas belles, particularly the one in the center who seems to have moths in the brain.
Noteworthy in the painting department are the interiors by Jessica Hayllar, especially "Castle Priory," in which patterns of all kinds swarm over curtains, wallpaper and Oriental porcelains. She is also represented by the head of a woman beautifully painted in oil on paper. Hayllar's sisters -- Edith, Kate and Mary -- had the same gift for scrupulous realism, particularly Mary in a scene of a woman seated with her dog at a tea table beside a window overlooking fields and trees. But the most impressive painting of all is the profile of a mulatto woman done by Joanna Boyce Wells in 1861, the year in which she died at the age of 30. She is a real loss to art history.
Of special interest is Rebecca Solomon's image of a dark-haired governess dressed in black who minds a small boy while her mistress, a blonde in pink, is at the piano entertaining an admirer. The intensity with which the scene is rendered suggests that the artist knew all about gentlemen preferring blondes. Incidentally, her brother, Simeon, enjoyed success with paintings and wood engravings of Biblical themes until, like Oscar Wilde, he was martyred for his homosexuality. His life shattered, Solomon more or less disappeared from view to scratch out an occasional living as a pavement artist and, despite the concern of friends like Dante Gabriel Rossetti and other Pre-Raphaelites, he wound up in the workhouse. The catalogue hints that his sister's life also ended tragically.
Surprisingly enough, members the English royal family do quite well as artists. Princess Helena, Queen Victoria's third daughter, is represented with a watercolor of two women conversing, one of them on horseback, and Princess Victoria, the Queen's firstborn, with a profile of Helena in pencil and chalk and a still life of oversized fruit in oil.
Kate Greenaway is also on board, but mostly with reproductions of her children's book illustrations. Beatrix Potter addicts should have no trouble spotting her pencil drawings of rabbits (one cleaning itself, two picking apples), but they may be shocked by Ms. Casteras's view of Potter's animal characters as "surrogate children in their anthropomorphized and infantile behavior." Peter Rabbit -- infantile? Potter herself, though successful, did her share of suffering in childhood -- from loneliness and a surfeit of lamb cutlets. But it is worth noting that, upon getting married in later life, she abandoned art for the breeding of sheep, apparently without regret.
The show also covers writers from Elizabeth Cleghorn Gaskell to George Eliot and from Elizabeth Barrett Browning to Harriet Martineau, the author of "Illustrations of Political Economy.
"A Struggle for Fame," through May 8, Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street, New Haven.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "The Governess," left, an 1860 oil by Emily Mary Osborne. "A Coming Event," above, by Jessica Hayllar. (Yale Center for British Art, Paul Mellon Fund)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Tax Rollbacks for 'Paper' Subdivisions on Farmland

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THREE months from now, in July, Samuel and Ruth Paletsky of Morris will be getting some money back -- $24,222. It's a refund on their 1991 and 1992 property-tax payments.
Samuel's brother, Bernard, and his wife, Mildred, will get a refund of $3,391. James and Beatrice Greaves are getting $5,747. Andrew Anderson awaits $1,986. Computations for the refund due Abdullah El-Hachem, an absentee landowner from Nigeria, have not yet been completed. 
 The Town of Morris, with 2,000 residents in 18 square miles of Litchfield County's rural countryside, got into the embarrassing position of overcharging by upholding its assessor's interpretation of Connecticut Public Act 490. This 1963 law allows farmland, forests and other open space to be taxed at 10 percent of the local property tax rate. At least 150 of the state's 169 towns, including Morris, have adopted the legislation, and other states have similar laws.
The trouble in Morris began after a revaluation in 1991. The assessor, Harold Maddocks, noticed that the five farmland owners now due for a refund had at various times filed for subdivisions on portions of their property. He ruled that those portions should be fully taxed, even though the lots had not been sold or developed and their use had not been changed.
That meant that Mr. Paletsky would owe $16,000 rather than $3,500. The others were not hit quite so hard because they had filed for much smaller parcels.
The First Selectman, Philip Birkett Jr., backed Mr. Maddocks, as did most of some 270 townspeople who attended four public meetings in which the farmers tried to have the assessor removed and a board of assessors elected in his place.
In August 1992 the five farmers sued the town in State Superior Court in Litchfield. Judge Walter M. Pickett Jr. accepted their charge of unlawful assessment and allowed a year in which the parties could settle matters among themselves. Failing that, he would set a trial date.
Neither side would budge, so the first of what was to be five trials was held early last month.
After Judge Pickett heard testimony in the Greaves case in court, said Michael Rybak, a lawyer with the firm of Guion, Stevens and Rybak of Litchfield who defended the town in the lawsuits, "he told us in chambers how he was inclined to rule, leaving no doubt that he would have ruled against the town."
"He felt that the filing of a subdivision map alone did not constitute a change of use," said Mr. Rybak.
The remaining cases were settled in negotiation by the Board of Selectmen and the lawyers. "It was a question of spending more money on an appeal or waiting until the facts or the law changes," said Mr. Rybak.
Taxes computed for 1993 are not due until July 1 of this year and will not include the larger amount.
But, noted Peter Litwin, of the Litwin and Kleeman law firm in Litchfield, who represented the plaintiffs, the settlements have "no precedential value."
"It was not a judgment of the court," he said, "but the court's favorable attitude makes it unlikely that without changes in the legislation assessors would not again take this position on the subject of paper subdivisions."
Selectman Birkett now plans to turn to the Legislature for help. "We want anything that can be taxed fairly and equitably in the community to be taxed," said Mr. Birkett. He believes that subdivisions are made for the sole purpose of development, and subdivided land will bring 10 times Public Act 490 taxes.
Mr. Maddocks, the assessor, has retired after some three years with the town and a 30-year history as an assessor in elsewhere.
"IT was my determination that I was following appropriate procedures indicated by the law," he said. "All towns need additional revenues." Morris, he added "never runs a deficit."
Mr. Birkett's co-Selectmen -- fellow-Republican Edward Dorset and Arnold Bohanon, a Democrat -- are in agreement on approaching their legislators, although Mr. Bohanon emphasized that his main concern was "to have the law clarified."
"I don't want to see the farmers forced out of here," he said. "I want the land preserved, and I was pleased with the settlement."
Adela Eads, State Senator from Morris, and Robert A. Maddox Jr., the State Representative, both Republicans, have not yet heard from Mr. Birkett, but Mr. Maddox observed that "every year we have bills on 490 but nothing has passed to change it substantially."
"Those of us in rural districts," said Senator Eads, "want to see 490 continued. Some people feel that other people use it unfairly to reduce their taxes, and of course any way a town can get money it's likely to try."
"If the use of the lots changes in any way, if they list them for sale, sell them as building lots, stop cutting hay three times a year as they do now, the town will look at them differently," Mr. Rybak said.
Figures on the ultimate cost of the proceedings to the town of Morris have not been compiled, but estimates range widely according to various town officials, from $20,000 to $70,000. The plaintiffs will pay anywhere from $3,000 to $10,000 each, depending on technicalities in individual cases. Some plaintiffs will pay more than they receive in refunds, but they will save large sums on taxes in the long term, and they are secure in the knowledge that they will not be forced off their land.
"Preserving the land by helping to prevent conversion to development, which is the purpose of 490, is important to the state," said Marcia Standish, municipal assessment adviser at the Office of Policy and Management in Hartford. The agency updates the value of farmland every five years, thus setting guidelines for taxing 490 land.
Since 1982 the amount of farmland in Connecticut has decreased from 444,242 acres to 370,000 acres in 1993, according to the State Department of Agriculture. Large dairy farms, like Samuel Paletsky's 190 acres, his brother's 150 acres and the Andersons' 247 acres, are the most threatened because they are so desirable to developers.
While there has been little development during the recession, as the economy improves owners of large farms will again be besieged with offers that are hard to refuse.
"FOR centuries farmers have used their farms as banks," said George Malia, appraiser with the Southern New England Farm Credit Bureau in Litchfield. "When farmers needed money they sold a piece of land. They never sold the whole farm, just enough to save the rest.
"Their land, whether it's used for haying or grazing or growing corn or tobacco is not taking any services from the town. It produces no children going to school, no sewer hookups. Farm folk in the state watched this trial very closely. It could have shaken up their lives considerably."
According to Walter Welz, spokesman for the Connecticut Farm Bureau in Windsor, "subdivided lots are sometimes never sold."
"The plaintiffs in Morris could have made a killing selling off land during the 80's, but they didn't," he said. "Why should they be taxed on money they haven't made yet and may never make?"
Samuel Paletsky, who is 86 years old, subdivided 30 acres in 1977, two years before Morris adopted zoning regulations. He bought the original farm in 1938, adding to it in 1951.
"He sold off a 3-acre piece and a 12-acre piece in 1956 and 1961," said his son David, who operates a real estate business in town. "This case was a total waste of the taxpayers' money." he added.

HEADLINE: Jockeying for Long-Held Political Terrain

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON 

 BODY:
THE first evidence of a stirring in the political terrain of the normally serene Hudson Valley region came only three weeks ago when a Republican State Senator, George E. Pataki, formally announced that he intended to challenge Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in this year's election.
This prompted two elected officials and a previous officeholder to begin thinking in terms of replacing Senator Pataki, assuming he would give up his 37th Senate District seat if he survived the Republican primary in September. 
 But then came an aftershock at least as powerful as the Pataki jolt, an announcement by Hamilton Fish Jr., the 13-term United States Republican Representative and member of a distinguished political family with roots to the country's founding. He said he would not be seeking re-election because of cancer.
This produced another cluster of tremors in the form of six potential candidates for Mr. Fish's seat, which includes the northern half of Westchester County, all of Putnam County and small parts of Dutchess and Orange Counties.
Nobody believes the political landscape will remain tranquil, with a half-dozen additional names being mentioned for one or more of the seats, and because some of the potential challengers are officeholders, any success on their part would leave other elected posts unfilled.
The three, so far, who are considering the Pataki Senate post are former County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, a Democrat from Lewisboro who practices law in White Plains; Assemblyman Vincent L. Leibell, a Republican from Carmel in Putnam County, and Timothy S. Carey, a Republican member of the County Board of Legislators.
Mr. DelBello's decision to seek the Senate seat, which includes northern Westchester County, all of Putnam County and part of Dutchess County, puzzled some experienced politicians who saw him as a better candidate for the Congressional post. His extensive public service, from Mayor of Yonkers to Lieutenant Governor under Mr. Cuomo, gave him experience and recognition unmatched by any potential opponents.
But Mr. DelBello said, "My interest is in state issues -- education, the economy, Medicaid reform, welfare reform, and, in any case, I like the Senate and am familiar with it." As Lieutenant Governor in the Cuomo administration he presided over that chamber from 1983 to 1985.
Mr. DelBello is also identified with several Hudson Valley planning groups he helped establish in his eight years as County Executive, particularly the Mid-Hudson Health Planning Region, formed around the Westchester Medical Center to serve seven counties.
Two Republican officeholders, Assemblyman Vincent L. Leibell 3d of Patterson and County Legislator Timothy S. Carey of Montrose, have also expressed interest in Mr. Pataki's Senate seat, assuming that he relinquishes it.
Mr. Carey, a close political associate of Mr. Pataki's and the architect of his victory over the seven-term Republican State Senator Mary Goodhue in 1992, said, "We who support George have to give him as much room as possible to run for Governor." He said he would wait for the state Republican convention in late May, a week before the county convention, before making his move.
There is one exception, however. "If Vinny Leibell says he is in the Senate race, then I'm in right after," Mr. Carey said. He said that he could not afford to leave fund raising to a political rival in a campaign that might require $750,000 to finance.
More crowded, and more complex, is the race for the Congressional District, one with a heavy Republican registration. The 93,000 Democrats and 2,300 Liberals represent only 31 percent of registered voters. The 115,000 Republicans and 7,500 Conservatives represent 40 percent. There are 88,000 unaffiliated voters, or independents, representing 29 percent.
 
Lobbyist in Albany
 Representative Fish has represented the district for nearly three decades, but the redistricting that resulted from the 1990 census brought a profound change in the district's shape. It made the Westchester portion 50 percent, and as a result the Fish pluralities of 75 percent to 80 percent dropped to 60 percent, still a wide margin but one that Democrats feel is challengeable, especially as an "open" seat.
First to enter this year's contest was Guy Parisi of Chappaqua, a lawyer long associated with the Republican Party's county leadership. Mr. Parisi also served as counsel to the Board of Legislators for a decade ending in 1990 and since then has been the Board's lobbyist in Albany.
Mr. Parisi's early candidacy, expressed in terms of challenging the venerable lawmaker in a primary, surprised some observers. "I sensed that Fish was going to retire, although I had no idea he was in ill health," Mr. Parisi said. "I thought there was a sense that people felt a quarter of a century in office was long enough."
Mr. Parisi has the support of Anthony J. Colavita, the Republican Party county chairman, who has declined to back Mr. Pataki in his bid for the gubernatorial candidacy. Mr. Pataki had been put forward by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Mr. Colavita instead supported Herbert London, a New York University professor who has the support of Ralph Marino, the State Senate Majority Leader.
Another Republican seeking the Congressional seat is John F. Flanagan Jr., a brigadier general in the Air Force Reserve who ran briefly in 1992 against Representative Nita M. Lowey, the Democratic incumbent whose district was redrawn that year to include a heavily Democratic bulge in Queens.
"I stayed in the race for three weeks, or long enough time to see what the preponderance of Democrats would mean," Mr. Flanagan said. He said he would bring greater perspective to the Congressional post being abandoned by Representative Fish.
 
Some Early Political Experience
 Born in Peekskill, he had some early political experience, accompanying his father, who was clerk to the Putnam County Board of Supervisors, distributing leaflets. Mr. Flanagan is currently a professor at St. Francis College in Brooklyn and at the Staten Island campus of St. John's University.
He has appeared before executive committees of county Republican organizations but says "the party should avoid making premature endorsements until the people have had a chance to choose a candidate in a primary."
The Democrats, delighted by the prospect of an empty seat and undaunted by the heavy Republican registration in the 19th Congressional District, are providing an interesting slate of candidates, with possibly more to come.
Dennis Mehiel, the former County Democratic Party chairman, entered the race a week before Mr. Fish's announcement, prompting him to say, "I had spent three months trying to figure out how to unseat Ham Fish; now I have to concentrate on how to capture the seat."
Mr. Mehiel, who quit his post as party chairman to make the race, had an earlier try at a Congressional post, but lost in a three-way Democratic primary to Ms. Lowey in 1988, who then won a narrow victory over the incumbent Republican, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, for the 20th Congressional District.
Mr. Mehiel hopes his political and business experience will win the nomination. With his brother, he founded the Four M Corporation in 1966. It is the country's largest independent maker of corrugated packaging and employs 1,800 workers in 21 plants nationwide.
An even earlier entrant in the race, Al Lynn of Pound Ridge, has a business background that he says is suited to the work of a Congressman. A Bronx native who began work as a New York City Welfare Department caseworker after graduating from Hunter College, he soon became a supervisor.
He worked in two New Jersey banks as personnel officer and director of human resources, then founded A-L Associates, a concern that expanded to Manhattan, Washington, Los Angeles and Tokyo. With a professional staff of more than 100 and annual revenues of $25 million, he branched into home health care.
His Medlinc Inc., has 14 offices in the New York City area, employing more than 5,000. Medlinc has since merged with Lifetime Inc., the country's largest provider of home-care services.
Mr. Lynn has no political experience, but doesn't think he needs it. "The people of the Hudson River Valley are hurting; many are out of work, and many share a cynicism about the political process," he said. His political aide, Martha-Lee Bohn, said, "He may not have name recognition, but he comes across as a self-made man with experience in starting a small business and expertise in home health care and job placement."
Neil McCarthy not only has political experience but he was also the last Democrat to run against Mr. Fish, in 1992. And he has already learned something about the difference: "When you are running against an incumbent, the chances of getting substantial financial support are minimal. I raised $150,000, while Fish spent $600,000. Thus, with no incumbent, it should be much less difficult to raise money."
 
Law Practice in Albany
 Mr. McCarthy sees considerable discontent in the valley. "There's a white-collar depression, and people in the district are really scared. Republicans may have the edge in voter registration, but I think we can compete, especially with the economic problems that dominate people's thinking."
The 38-year-old Democrat practices law in Albany and Westchester. He had worked as an Assistant United States Attorney in New Hampshire and then practiced as an lawyer for a Manhattan law firm, a job he left to devote full time to the campaign against Mr. Fish in 1992.
There will, in fact, probably be a Hamilton Fish in the 19th Congressional District race this year, but he will be the Congressman's son, a Democrat who has already made an effort to win a Congressional seat, losing in the 1988 primary that also saw Mr. Mehiel succumb to the eventual winner, Ms. Lowey.
Mr. Fish, who assisted his father last weekend as he was admitted to a hospital, said he intended to wait until his father's condition was clear before deciding whether he would join the crowd vying for Representative Fish's post.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

JOYCE SERIES
Joyceans, rejoice! A four-part discussion series about James Joyce, the Irish author whose works continue to provoke ire and admiration in almost equal measure, will begin Friday at 10:30 A.M. at Manhattanville College in Purchase.
Led by Eileen O'Gorman, professor emeritus of English at the college, the sessions will continue on successive Friday mornings, covering Joyce's influence on 20th-century novelists, his inner torments as an Irish Catholic, his self-imposed exile on the Continent and the well-known day in the life of Leopold Bloom (the central figure in "Ulysses"), which took place in Dublin on June 16, 1904. Published in Paris in 1922, the book was banned in the United States as obscene until 1933. 
 The series will be held in Barat House on the campus at 2900 Purchase Street, and the fee is $35. Individual sessions may be attended for $10, lunch included. Call 694-3425 or 694-3389 for reservations or more information.
 
REFINISHING SCHOOL
 The art of finishing or refinishing fine furniture will be taught on Saturday in four one-hour workshops by Waclaw Godziemba-Maliszewski, sponsored by the Pound Ridge Historical Society.
Scheduled at 9:30 and 11 A.M. and 1 and 2:30 P.M., the sessions will be held at Mr. Maliszewski's restoration shop, London Joiners, on Route 124 in Pound Ridge. Mr. Maliszewski said he encourages women as well as men to learn the craft for fun and profit.
In each session he will demonstrate wax polishing and French and Italian polishing, compare their merits and put them in historical perspective.
The ancient Egyptians were the first to burnish wooden surfaces by waxing -- rubbing them with layer after layer of lac, a resinous, shellac-like or lacquer-like substance made by bees, other bugs and some plants.
The process was refined by the French in the 18th century, when mentholated spirits were added as a solvent and quick-drying binder. The Italians perfected a method combining mineral oil with concentrated lac flakes, providing a barrier against oxygen.
The discussion will extend to marquetry, parquet, inlay, joinery and gold leaf. Each workshop is limited to 10 people and costs $10. Call 764-4538 to register or obtain more information.
 
HALLE'S HOUSES
 Hiram Halle, after whom the Pound Ridge Library is named, died in 1944 after restoring about 30 Colonial houses, creating a preservation core by sometimes moving the houses to a central location. The Pound Ridge Historical Society has mounted an exhibition honoring his efforts, called "The Houses of Halle," to remain on view through Aug. 15.
Six of the renovated buildings, some of them listed on the State and Federal Historic Registers, are documented in vintage and updated photographs, blueprints, sketches and artifacts, while the entire collection is on a topographical map. The museum, at the junction of Routes 172 and 137, is open Saturdays and Sundays from 2 to 4 P.M. Admission is free, but contributions are welcome. Call 764-4333 for more information.
 
'SNOW WHITE' MINUS 6
 The Kids' Theater of Mount Kisco has created an audience-participation musical based on a Brothers Grimm fairy tale. It follows most of the elements in the story, but with a marked difference exemplified by the title, "Snow White and the One Dwarf!?!"
It is left to the audience, led by the performers, to find the six missing dwarfs before a happy ending can be achieved.
Christopher Rich composed the music and lyrics and Missy Slaymaker wrote the book. They are the theater's directors as well as instructors at the Dance, Drama and Song Performing Arts School in Bedford Hills.
Performances are on Saturdays at 11 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. through April 30 and on Sunday, April 17, at 1 and 3:30 P.M. in the Manufacturers Outlet Center, second floor, Route 117 in Mount Kisco. Tickets at $6 are available by calling 666-0223, or 15 minutes before showtime at the door.
 
INTERNATIONAL TRADE
 Strategies for local businesses and municipalities to participate in international economic development will be addressed by Leslie H. Gelb, president of the Council on Foreign Relations in Manhattan, on Wednesday at 6:30 P.M. at the Ramada Inn in New Rochelle. The evening, which begins with a cocktail reception, was organized by the New Rochelle Overall Economic Development Corporation.
Mr. Gelb grew up in New Rochelle and received his master's and doctoral degrees from Harvard University. A career in journalism earned him a Pulitzer Prize and a Front Page Award, and from 1977 to 1979 he was Assistant Secretary of State.
He will discuss the North American Free Trade Agreement, the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade and the current impasse on trade between the United States and Japan.
For reservations, call (212) 759-3300, extension 315. A contribution of $7.50 will be requested for admission.
 
A CAPPELLA CONCERT
 An exuberant group of 13 young men and 17 young women from Amherst College in Massachusetts will give a concert on Friday at 8 P.M. in the Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road.
The men's group, founded in 1927, is called Double Quartet in spite of its numbers, and the women's group, which began in 1989, is named Bluestockings for some 19th-century Englishwomen who met to discuss politics and literature. The two groups will sing together and separately. The program, which is all performed a cappella, ranges from the classics to 1920's jazz, doo-wop, rock-and-roll, college songs and pop tunes from the last two decades.
Tickets are $10; $5 for students and people 65 and older. Proceeds will aid the Deer Hills Conference Center, a nonprofit, interfaith retreat in Wappingers Falls. Call 725-1643 for more information or reservations.
 
GARDENING CLASSES
 Growing and using herbs, selecting colorful woody plants, soil preparation, seed sowing, ornamental grasses, renewing an old garden, dealing with deer and designing a perennial border are among the subjects to be discussed by master gardeners at the Fourth Annual Spring Gardening School of the Cornell Cooperative Extension Center in White Plains.
The classes will be offered on Saturday from 9:30 A.M. to 3 P.M., with participants permitted to choose four out of eight classes.
The fee will be $20 and includes educational material to take home. Participants should take a lunch; beverages will be provided.
Advance registration is recommended, but there will be a registration period on Saturday at 9 A.M. for any classes not filled. The center is at 214 Central Avenue, and the phone number for registering or obtaining more information is 285-4640.
 
SQUARE DANCING
 The Loft, a Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center in White Plains, has scheduled an evening of square, two-step and line dancing on Saturday at 7 P.M. at the South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway in Dobbs Ferry.
The session will last about four hours. Admission will be $10, with food and soft drinks available for purchase. Proceeds will go to the Loft's building fund. For more information, call 948-4922. ELEANOR CHARLES
