The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 3, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3654 words

HEADLINE: A Wall St. Star's Agonizing Confession

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR with ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
Larry Kudlow seemed a master of the universe. Being a top Wall Street economist was not the half of it. Mr. Kudlow had been a prominent member of President Reagan's economic team. He helped conceive and fight for the tax-cut proposal that helped Christine Todd Whitman become Governor of New Jersey. One of the nation's most articulate and charismatic commentators on financial issues, he has become the economic guru of Jack Kemp and of the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh, as well as a regular on television interview programs and a speaker commanding hefty fees. He even starred in Cadillac ads.
To hear some leading Republicans, the 46-year-old Mr. Kudlow has nowhere to go but up. They consider him a hot political property, a potential challenger for the Senate seat of Daniel Patrick Moynihan in New York or, should a right-leaning Republican like Mr. Kemp win the White House in 1996, a shoo-in for a Cabinet position. John Sweeney, executive director of the New York State Republican Committee, last week called him "one of the brightest stars." 
 But last week, in an interview, Larry Kudlow had a confession to make: behind the polished facade lived a troubled and deeply unhappy man who has been battling an addiction to drugs and alcohol.
Swiveling in his chair in the offices of his new employer, National Review magazine, Mr. Kudlow lighted yet another Merit Ultra Light and began an explanation that many others would not summon the courage to make: Fifteen months ago he took a four-week medical leave of absence from his Wall Street firm, Bear Stearns.
"I went into drug rehab," Mr. Kudlow said, deciding to discuss his problem after being told he was the subject of a profile. "I had an alcohol and substance-abuse problem that needed to be taken care of."
He said that for 15 months he has been attending twice daily a self-help program for recovering addicts.
"I am willing to share with you my problem," he said, following the example of many people in programs like Alcoholics Anonymous. "Anyone who blames Bear Stearns is not right. I take full personal responsibility."
Then this dapper man in a blue pinstripe shirt and monogrammed cufflinks, a man sometimes described as poker-faced, began to cry. Sounding scared, not at all like the suave raconteur and deft name dropper of two hours earlier, Mr. Kudlow said he lived in fear of sliding backward. "I live my life day to day," he said.
Mr. Kudlow said he was talking largely because he wanted to be honest and because his story might benefit other families with alcohol and drug problems. "I'm on top of this thing, God bless," he said. "Maybe somebody reading about this somewhere will be helped."
Mr. Kudlow is still striving to understand what drove him to depend on drugs and alcohol, and the elaborate lying and dodging that are required to conceal such habits from friends, family and colleagues. Whatever the reasons, it is clear that there are many Larry Kudlows. One in 10 Americans has some form of alcohol or drug-abuse problem, recent studies show. America's success-conscious society is full of people who are less afraid to snort a line or put away a fifth than they are of letting someone else see that they are not all they appear to be. Everyone knows someone talented, ambitious and magnetic who has a serious problem but chooses to ignore it for a long time, hoping that other people will look the other way too because he's so valuable.
Several people inside and outside Bear Stearns say Mr. Kudlow used cocaine. Mr. Kudlow refused to say what drug he used or to be specific about how his drug use began. He did say that he began drinking regularly in the second half of 1970's and that his drinking led to drugs.
Mr. Kudlow attributes his slide partly to pure pressure. On Wall Street there are producers and then there's everyone else, and the pressure to produce helped drive Mr. Kudlow to drink and drugs.
Then there was the exhausting travel and entertaining. "You think you're a superman, you think you can do anything," he said. "I felt invincible and that there were no limits as to how late I could stay up or how much I could travel. Today, I can see how tough it was."
There was also the easy availability and acceptability of alcohol and drugs, especially in the 1980's, combined with having plenty of money to throw around. And he had no children to ground him.
Another problem was that when he felt down, he didn't know how to turn to a friend. He described himself, for all his gregariousness and bonhomie, as a man who spent much of his life isolated, ashamed to let others know him well enough to share his failings and embarrassments along with the successes.
"I never had any friends beyond a certain superficial level," he said. "We hate to admit weaknesses. We were raised to want to get ahead, to be good and clever and successful. You're just ashamed to open up."
John C. Glidden Jr. described his longtime friend this way: "There's a searching for approval, for acceptance. You can trace it right back to high school. His father and my father were a lot alike. They both set high standards for their sons."
 
The Early Years
From the S.D.S. To Wall Street
 Lawrence A. Kudlow was an early Baby Boomer, born in the summer of 1947. He grew up in Englewood, a northern New Jersey suburb with many upwardly mobile families. He was one of a couple of Jewish boys at a private school called the Englewood School for Boys, a tennis star, editor of the student newspaper, an actor in school plays. The family owned a textile business, worked hard for Republican causes and frequently replaced the Jaguar in the driveway with a new model.
Had it not been for the Vietnam War, Mr. Kudlow's years in the University of Rochester's class of 1969 might have been best remembered for his star performance on the tennis team. But at some point Mr. Kudlow, a history major, traded in his Porsche for a VW bus, let his hair turn "fuzzy" and joined the left-wing Students for a Democratic Society. Asthma saved him from the draft.
What distinguished his brief career as a radical and antiwar organizer was less what he accomplished than that he managed to have it chronicled by The New Yorker magazine in a piece about the leaders of a nationwide protest in 1969. That was an early sign of Mr. Kudlow's gift for attracting media interest.
Indeed, Larry Kudlow has always had a knack for reinventing himself to adapt to the times, and the persuasiveness to make others follow him.
Some people dismiss Mr. Kudlow as an ideologue. Others find him slick, shallow, overly opportunistic. And true, to paint himself in the best possible light, he has been known to edit and embellish the facts of his life as reflexively as most people clear their throats. A fellow conservative, the columnist Jude Wanniski, described him as "a swashbuckler, a car salesman, a gunslinger."
But even most of Mr. Kudlow's critics find him hard to dislike, and he has many admirers. Sophisticated, funny, slightly outrageous, always ready with a sound bite, Mr. Kudlow exudes both confidence and vulnerability. Many people cite his generosity and loyalty. His interest in politics and ideas is infectious. "He's noted for not being a sycophant," said another old friend and political ally, the economist Arthur Laffer. "I've never heard him pull punches because he was worried about his audience's reaction."
As the war wound down, Mr. Kudlow studied politics and some economics in graduate school at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University. He left without collecting a master's degree, though a recent resume dances around that. His first full-time job was as a junior economist at the New York Federal Reserve, a time-honored launching pad for a Wall Street career in economics.
In 1974, in yet another brush with The New Yorker, Mr. Kudlow married Nancy Gerstein, an editor in the magazine's fiction department and the first of three wives. The marriage lasted about a year.
The next year, Mr. Kudlow jumped from the Fed to Fed watching on Wall Street. At the age of 28, with no degree in economics, he became the chief economist of one of the nation's biggest brokerages, Paine Webber, doubling his salary in the process. Quotes from Mr. Kudlow, sometimes coupled with a description of him as a maverick, began to appear regularly in the financial press.
While he had no extensive formal training in economics, he had an innate understanding of how markets worked and was comfortable with numbers. And he worked hard to teach himself.
Mr. Kudlow says he made his name in the late 1970's in good part by correctly taking a far more bearish position on interest rates and inflation than the consensus on Wall Street. By 1979, the 32-year-old Mr. Kudlow had moved to Bear Stearns, a very prosperous upstart firm that liked his outspoken free-market ideas, as chief economist.
Mr. Kudlow says he can't pinpoint when his social drinking turned into a habit on which he depended, but he did begin drinking regularly at home alone or on the road by the late 1970's, when he was making a name for himself. And, as is the case for many people, "Alcohol was the gate-opener to everything else," Mr. Kudlow said.
"If you go out with clients in any business, you have a round of drinks and you say big deal," he said. "And that's how it starts."
Once he got used to loosening himself up with a drink before dinner, he said, it was hard to resist other temptations young professionals of his generation faced frequently. "Recreational drugs -- until recently that stuff was acceptable," he said.
Shortly after the 1980 election, Mr. Kudlow, who was becoming increasingly interested in conservative economic ideas, was drafted into the ranks of Ronald Reagan's revolutionaries -- an experience again chronicled in The New Yorker in a 1982 article about Reaganomics.
One day David Stockman, the President's newly appointed budget director, and a caravan of "supply siders" -- dedicated to lowering tax rates to stimulate economic growth by encouraging thrift and work -- came to see him on Wall Street. In his book "The Triumph of Politics," Mr. Stockman recalls being impressed by Mr. Kudlow, who was worried about deficits and called for steeper cuts in government spending as well as tax cuts. "Here, I realized, was a fellow traveler," Mr. Stockman wrote.
A newcomer at Bear Stearns, Mr. Kudlow made the most of his exalted guests. "I called up one of the big shots at Bear and said, 'I've got Dave Stockman here and Jack Kemp,' then a Congressman. 'Do we want to do anything?' " Soon, Bear Stearns's partners were raising sherry glasses to the Reaganites in the private dining room. Mr. Kudlow said he was quickly invited to become a partner. But two weeks later, he was on his way to Washington.
From the start, Mr. Kudlow, chief economist of the Office of Management and Budget and effectively Mr. Stockman's No. 2 man, was at the center of the action.
During this time Mr. Kudlow remarried; his bride was Susan Cullman, the granddaughter of a Bloomingdale. The Washington wedding was presided over by John Sirica, the renowned Federal judge.
 
The Ascent
A Rise to Fame At Bear Stearns
 By the end of 1983, the economy was roaring back, the Federal deficit was mushrooming and Mr. Stockman had lost most of his influence after The Atlantic magazine quoted him as calling the Reagan tax cuts a "Trojan horse." Mr. Kudlow bailed out.
He decided to start a Washington consulting firm. But after a couple of years he had grown weary of that. And by 1985 his second marriage had fallen apart.
Time to go back to Wall Street and to the Bear. "He had a very expensive career in Washington," said Lee J. Seidler, a former partner of Bear Stearns, referring to the fact that Mr. Kudlow would have made millions if he had still been with the firm when it went public just before his return.
Mr. Kudlow asked his new girlfriend, Judy Pond, later his third wife, to join him. Mr. Kudlow calls her "the love of my life."
Bear Stearns welcomed Mr. Kudlow back in his old job of chief economist, but his life there was different this time.
He was promoted to senior managing director, one of 200 or so in a firm that had mushroomed in his absence to 7,000 employees from 1,000. He was also named the chairman of the investment policy committee, which determines the recommendations the firm makes to its clients.
Chief economists predict the course of the economy, interest rates, prices and the dollar. But they are, first and foremost, salespeople expected to help attract clients.
Mr. Kudlow did it well. "Larry was an outstanding rhetorician, a very good speaker, very clear," said Brian Barish, head of emerging-markets research at Lazard Freres who worked in Bear's research department. He added: "If there was any person I tried to model my own public speaking after, it was Larry."
Mr. Kudlow's forecasting record, while far from perfect, has been relatively strong. For example, he correctly anticipated the timing of both the 1990-91 recession and the subsequent recovery. Increasingly, he appeared on television programs, from Larry King to MacNeil/Lehrer. The most controversial appearances were in broadcast and print ads for Cadillac for which Mr. Kudlow received, among other things, a one-year lease on a red 1993 Cadillac Seville. (The firm's chairman, Alan C. Greenberg, used to joke, "If Larry can turn G.M. around, more power to him.")
But the pressure on Mr. Kudlow was incredible. The travel, report writing and speeches were becoming increasingly burdensome. "It got tougher," he said. "It was all bigger. You're stressed out. You're tired. You realize you may not be able to do this anymore. It creeps up on you."
 
The Descent
A Hard Time Saying No
 As he tells it, Mr. Kudlow hid his problems well. Tim Kearney, an economist at Fidelity who worked with Mr. Kudlow, recalls that he never saw Mr. Kudlow other than "in complete command of himself."
But colleagues did notice that Mr. Kudlow was losing weight. And an investment banker at Bear Stearns said that Mr. Kudlow was not very dependable. "There's been a lot of last-minute cancellations. After a while there was a certain exasperation level."
"People always wanted to know, where is Larry?" he added.
Mr. Kudlow's personal problems worsened in 1992. "All of a sudden I could not face the three-day road trips," he said. "The two or three plane flights in a day. I was having trouble facing it. I was dreading it."
"So here I am in Salt Lake City, Indianapolis, Chicago, Paris, Frankfurt, Buenos Aires, Budapest. Not only am I tired, dragging my feet, but I've got responsibility and the show's gotta go on."
On top of the demands of the firm and its clients, Mr. Kudlow had a full plate of extracurricular activities. "If the producer of 'Cross-Fire' called me to go that night to Washington, I'd go," he said. "If Jack Kemp called, I'd go."
"I'm a person who has a hard time saying no and it gets me into trouble because I sometimes overreach."
It was on the road -- at client dinners, and later at the hotel -- where Mr. Kudlow lost control. "I'll give you an example," he said. "One drink over dinner turns into two and pretty soon your problem becomes a bigger problem."
Mr. Kudlow said no one at the firm complained about his performance at the time. "No one at the firm ever found . . . ," he said, stopping himself and reformulating the thought. "Ironically, the last few years have been the best performance years for me. My ratings in the I.I. polls" -- a reference to the magazine Institutional Investor. "I was second in bonds, third in stocks. I published more op-ed pieces and was more productive."
But "my personal life was getting bumped," he added. "I valued my marriage." By autumn 1992, things were spiraling out of control.
Judy Kudlow, now a painter of flowers and landscapes, says that it was her husband who decided that he had to act. "He's the one who knew he needed to get help," she said. "And I was behind him. I was aware that he had a problem. We're devoted to each other. We did it together, but he is the one leading the way."
In mid-December 1992 Mr. Kudlow and his wife met with the firm's chairman, Mr. Greenberg. Mr. Kudlow asked for, and received, a leave of absence in order to enter a treatment program.
The treatment program involved spiritual counseling, introspection and group therapy. Since his release, Mr. Kudlow has been attending a self-help program for recovering addicts -- as often as every morning before work and every evening after work -- where people, some of whom have been sober for years, help each other struggle with their demons.
He said the firm had not made him submit to extraordinary supervision or drug testing. "They were generous and kind," Mr. Kudlow said.
Mr. Kudlow didn't miss a beat when he returned toward the end of January last year. Around that time, Christine Todd Whitman came to Mr. Kudlow for advice at the urging of their mutual friend, Forbes magazine's publisher, Steve Forbes Jr. Armed with facts showing that New Jersey's economy had become hopelessly noncompetitive, Mr. Kudlow argued for a state version of the original Reagan tax-cut plan.
Ten months later, Mr. Kudlow stood behind Mrs. Whitman, in full view of the camera, as she proclaimed her upset victory over Jim Florio in the governor's race.
 
The Resignation
A Missed Meeting And Many Rumors
 Then this year, on Tuesday, March 1, Mr. Kudlow was scheduled to speak to a large group of institutional investors in Boston. Two hundred people turned up for lunch at the Hotel Meridien. But Mr. Kudlow, the featured speaker, failed to show.
Given Mr. Kudlow's recent troubles, a lot of people at Bear Stearns and on Wall Street were suspicious. But Mr. Kudlow said last week: "I was sick. It was not a relapse. I know there were rumors."
Why would he not have called to say he didn't feel well and wasn't coming? "Unfortunately, there was a communications gap," he said. "I wish I could make amends to every person who was there. That was not the reason for the resignation."
Mr. Kudlow said "the explosion hit" when he went into the office the next day.
"Being unreachable was a fairly high-level sin," said Mr. Seidler, the retired managing director.
Mr. Kudlow handed his resignation to the firm's general counsel that day.The decision was his, Mr. Kudlow said, though the firm made it clear, in an unusual news release, that it felt Mr. Kudlow's departure was also in its best interest. Bear Stearns officials refused to discuss Mr. Kudlow's departure but the firm described it as a "voluntary termination" in mandatory public filings made with securities regulators.
Missing the luncheon, Mr. Kudlow said, "reinforced to me the notion that I needed a less stressful and less energy-consuming job. It's as if you had cancer, or a heart attack, or had your hip replaced. You've got to make changes in order to live a healthy life."
An executive recruiter familiar with the firm said Mr. Greenberg and James E. Cayne, the firm's president, were "heartbroken, really bummed out. They loved him. He brought in huge business. In fact, that he even got a second chance was a testament to how much they liked him."
 
The Rehabilitation
A Run for Office? There's Hope
 Within two days Mr. Kudlow had negotiated a position as economics editor of National Review, for perhaps a tenth of his former income of nearly $1 million. He was soon crowing, "You know, this is a real job," and preparing for tapings of "Firing Line," the television program hosted by his new boss, William F. Buckley.
Mr. Kudlow says that he has been in recovery, the term used by addicts for being free of drugs and alcohol, for more than 15 months. One thing helping him now, he said, is sharing his experiences with younger men and women in the program who are struggling to take the first steps to help themselves.
He has also turned to the spiritual counsel of the Rev. C. John McCloskey, a Roman Catholic priest and a former Wall Streeter who now counsels high-powered people.
Sitting in the couple's Upper East Side apartment, surrounded by richly flowered tapestries and carpets and gleaming Biedermeier chests, Judy Kudlow says: "He is better than he's ever been. He's stronger."
Mr. Kudlow, seated at the polished cherry desk that he brought from Bear Stearns to his new office, said he has put any political plans on hold. But he doesn't rule anything out. Punditry, politics and the lay priesthood -- and more remotely, a return to Wall Street -- are all possibilities.
Can he still make it in politics? The decision by the media-wise Mr. Kudlow, whose wife was once a Reagan press official, to go public with his problems may be the best way to put the problem behind him and preserve some chance.
Indeed, some politicians who admitted such problems have gone on to victory. Ann Richards, one of Mr. Kudlow's idols, became Governor of Texas even after acknowledging she was a recovering alcoholic. Chuck McDonald, a spokesman from her 1990 campaign, said voters might be less forgiving about drugs. But "you can overcome anything if people believe you've changed your ways. He's got to get some time on his side and some years of sobriety under his belt."
Even Robert J. Strang, a hard-nosed private investigator who spent two years undercover on Wall Street looking for drug abusers, gave Mr. Kudlow a chance of a comeback. "Ten years ago, I would have said no," he said. "But today there are enough people in this country who can identify with his story."
Mr. Kudlow certainly hopes so: "In our society there are a lot of people who have suffered from alcohol or substance abuse -- you name it -- and society has been understanding. Listen, I have a lot of faith and a lot of hope."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A Stumble for Small-Stock Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
THE stock market chugged along nicely in 1994 until mid-March, when the market began a decline that took the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 250 points in two weeks. That knocked the average diversified domestic stock fund from a 3 percent gain as of mid-March to a 3.2 percent loss for the quarter, according to Morningstar Inc., fund researchers in Chicago.
Hardest hit were the technology stocks, the driving force behind an exceptional showing up to that point in small-capitalization stock funds. Technology stocks still ended the quarter with a gain of seven-tenths percent, while small caps took second place, finishing down 2.9 percent. Overseas investors garnered the quarter's best overall performance, with Japan funds up 18.3 percent -- and the worst, as Pacific region funds dropped 12.3 percent because of a slump in Southeast Asia. 
 Big stocks dominated much of the 1980's, beating mutual fund managers year after year; so marketers created funds to mimic the S.& P. 500. But the tide turned in 1990, and small stocks have had a strong run.
Can it continue?
Yes, said Robert C. Czepiel, who runs the $210 million Robertson Stephens Emerging Growth Fund in San Francisco. "Size and economies of scale were important; now, it's responsiveness to the marketplace," he said.
Robert L. Rodriguez, who runs the $173 million FPA Capital Fund, is one of the group's biggest bears. But he said that while valuations between small- and big-cap stocks are nearly level, "maybe we're only halfway through the cycle, or slightly more," of small-company stocks outperforming the big corporations.
Most of the small-cap managers with the best showings in the period had big technology holdings, but they won in different ways.
Despite the difficult two weeks, Ronald E. Elijah, who runs the $64 million Robertson Stephens Value Plus Fund, is sticking with his tech stocks. "I believe that we're within a week of the market turning around," he said. A third of his fund is devoted to health care, including hospitals (11 percent) and nursing homes (9 percent) as well as H.M.O.'s (13 percent). He likes Columbia Healthcare and two nursing homes, Grancare and Living Centers of America. Semiconductor companies are the second-largest chunk (21 percent). Unlike many managers in this group, he caps the price he will pay for stocks (at 25 times trailing 12-month earnings).
By contrast, Mr. Czepiel, who also rode the strength of the technology sector, shifted gears last week, drastically reducing his position from one third of his portfolio to 6 percent. He's also raising cash to 50 percent, anticipating heavy redemptions as mutual fund investors see the first-quarter results. A third of his portfolio remains in health care because Mr. Czepiel figures the market is independently coming up with solutions to fit the Administration's pursuit of reform. His heaviest concentration is in H.M.O.'s like Health Source, Mid Atlantic Medical Services and Pacificare Health Systems.
The $45 million Pilgrim Baxter Emerging Growth Fund, which turns a year old in June, looks for companies with market capitalizations of less than $250 million, said its manager, Christine M. Baxter. She wants rapidly growing companies and anticipates earnings-per-share growth of 50 percent in the next 12 months. The portfolio is tilted toward technology (39 percent), with heavy holdings in health care (24 percent) and consumer goods (23 percent). The fund's largest holdings are Cyrk, which produces promotional materials; Microchip Technology, which makes chips and semiconductors, and Three Five Systems, which makes display panels.
The 15-month-old $50 million Govett Smaller Companies Fund, however, stays "broadly diversified by industry and company," said its manager, Garrett Van Wagoner. Technology, health care, cyclical and consumer stocks each account for about 20 percent of the 125-stock fund. "Small stocks should continue to do well as the economy does well," he said. Cost-cutting is the theme of his health care investments, which include H.M.O.'s like Wellcare and Mid Atlantic Medical.
The $1.3 billion MFS Emerging Growth Fund is available only through 401(k) plans. John W. Ballen, its manager, said, "We're pretty optimistic that we can find small, rapidly growing companies at reasonable valuations." His biggest industry is entertainment and leisure (24 percent), with companies like Sholodge, a hotel operator, Grand Casinos and Applebee's, a restaurant chain.
John C. Bogle Jr. runs the $69 million Quantitative Boston Numeric Fund, which has a median market capitalization of $800 million, larger than many of these funds because "we buy small or growing companies," he said. Stock picks are based on a computer model that looks at changes in earnings expectations and stock prices, seeking the best combination of value and earnings momentum. The fund, started a year and a half ago, tends to own technology shares (27 percent) and consumer cyclical stocks (25 percent). Because the model is always re-evaluating stocks, the fund's average annual turnover exceeds 200 percent.
That contrasts with FPA Capital, which has held Seagate Technology, its largest position, since 1988. FPA's turnover is less than 20 percent. Mr. Rodriguez sees little value in today's market except in small pockets, like companies with market caps of less than $100 million, and he was a net seller of stocks this year until Wednesday, when he began buying "because of the change in valuations," he said. "It's a pretty healthy correction."

HEADLINE: Investors Who Discovered Africa

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
MORE than 100 years ago, American adventurers in pith helmets roamed Africa, searching for fortune and fame. In 1994, they're back -- but this time they're wearing pinstriped suits. And they are taking investors with them.
Africa, particularly that part of the continent south of the Sahara, has become a hot new target for international investing. In the last two months, brokerage firms in New York have floated three new funds -- and raised more than $350 million -- to invest in southern Africa. And according to Fund Decoder, an industry newsletter, four more funds are in the works, including two that plan to invest across the continent. 
 There is good reason to be hopeful about the long-term investment prospects for many African countries. The coming multiracial elections in South Africa, the abolishment of apartheid and the end of international sanctions bode well not just for that country but for many of its neighbors. Investment experts also point to a variety of factors, from the end of the cold war to signs of improving commodity prices, that may ultimately make Africa the greatest emerging market of them all.
But there are enormous risks for American investors, particularly in the short run. They include political instability, weak currencies, fledgling stock markets and, ironically, the very fact that investing in Africa is becoming such a fad.
"There's more money being raised now than there are stocks in Africa. It can't go on," said James P. Rogers, an investor famous both for his acumen and his adventurousness. From 1990 through 1992, he rode a motorcycle around the world, accompanied for part of his trip by television cameras. Mr. Rogers was an early investor in African stocks, and now has holdings in Ghana, Botswana, Zimbabwe, South Africa and Zambia, as well as in companies that do business in Nigeria, Kenya and the Ivory Coast.
But he said he will not invest more until the current financial craze has run its course. "This is the dying gasp of the emerging markets thing, and Africa is ringing the bell," Mr. Rogers said, referring to the current mania for investing in what used to be known as less developed countries, and the booms and busts that have been created of late in markets from Malaysia to Peru.
"That is not to say that long term, there isn't true opportunity," Mr. Rogers added. "But short term it could leave investors with a horrible, horrible taste in their mouths for Africa, because they'll get banged around badly."
The allure of Africa is its potential for economic growth that will far surpass that of the industrial nations. A few African countries, including Botswana, Ghana and Kenya, have sustained growth rates of 5 percent a year in their gross national products, said Michel ZhuParris, a portfolio manager for Morgan Stanley Asset Management in New York. That's almost twice last year's growth in the United States.
Many African countries could benefit from the fact that the 10-year bear market in commodities finally seems to be drawing to a close. And some nations have unrecognized manufacturing capabilities, as well as undervalued natural resources. Compared with some other emerging markets, "Africa is definitely starting from a lower base," Ms. ZhuParris said. "But that is where the upside is to be made, if you get in at these levels."
WHAT may unleash growth in Africa are the economic reforms that are sweeping across the continent. Some African nations are rejecting the socialist policies they adopted after colonial rule ended. Others are being pushed to reform because old sources of money, such as payments from rival superpowers, have dried up.
"For me, the most important thing has been the end of the cold war," said Miles Morland of Blakeney Management, a London firm that specializes in emerging markets. Governments are finding it necessary to adopt the reforms demanded by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. "Now that they can no longer play cold-war blackmail, they either eat at the I.M.F.'s table or they don't eat at all. The trend, politically speaking, has been improving for three or four years."
The World Bank says more than half of Africa's countries have economic reform packages in place. But those statistics may well be overly optimistic. For example, they include Zaire, which seems in a state of economic and political collapse under the dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko, as well as Nigeria, which is threatening to default on its debt.
But there is a trend to establish stock markets, and to open those markets to foreigners. By Morgan Stanley's count, a dozen African countries already have stock markets, with more on the way. The International Finance Corporation, an affiliate of the World Bank, tracks seven stock markets, of which all but Nigeria's and Kenya's are open to overseas investors.
Much of the new interest in Africa began in South Africa, where the stock market is relatively large and well established. When sanctions were lifted last year, foreigners rushed in. The Johannesburg market, though big, is not very liquid, which means it is difficult to buy stocks without pushing up prices. And that's exactly what happened: In 1993, South African shares rose 26 percent on average, according to Birinyi Associates. That's not much more than London's 22 percent increase, to be sure, but far larger than America's average 7 percent rise or Japan's 2 percent gain.
Other African markets have shown even more spectacular increases, at least in local currencies. Last year, for example, stocks rose 41 percent in Nigeria, 67 percent in Mauritius, 116 percent in Ghana, 117 percent in Kenya and 161 percent in Zimbabwe.
Nevertheless, the stocks remain inexpensive by most measures. According to International Finance Corporation figures, for example, stocks in Mauritius trade for just 12.8 times earnings, and that is the highest multiple on the continent. The stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average, by contrast, trade for an average 29 times last year's earnings.
But Africa's emerging markets are far riskier than those of the big developed countries, in part because they are so small. The largest market outside South Africa is in Namibia, with a capitalization of about $2.7 billion. That's about a thousandth the size of the New York Stock Exchange. Ghana's entire market barely tops $100 million, less than the value of I.B.M. shares that change hands on an average morning. Mauritius, one of the oldest and most established stock markets, is open just three days a week, for an hour before lunch. Only 30 companies are listed.
All that is a problem because too many American dollars can end up chasing too few foreign stocks. The three closed-end funds floated this year are Morgan Stanley Africa Investment Fund, Alliance Capital Management's Southern Africa Fund and Robert Fleming's New South Africa Fund. While the latter plans to invest 80 percent of its assets in South Africa, the other two funds have broader mandates. Fund Decoder newsletter reports that a number of other investment managers, including James Capel and Oppenheimer, have registered Africa funds.
To see what trouble such an influx can cause, take a look at Turkey; the stock market there is down more than 60 percent this year, after tripling last year.
But the number of stocks available in Africa will grow rapidly, investment managers argue. Frank Savage, chairman of Alliance Corporate Finance Group, which is involved in managing the Southern Africa Fund, cited Ghana's move to sell shares in its Ashanti gold mine, which should be listed on the London Stock Exchange within a few weeks. He said he expected African governments to follow Latin America's example by turning their telephone companies over to the private sector. He also sees opportunities in other infrastructure plays, as well as in consumer-products industries.
Nevertheless, huge risks remain for Africa investors, chief among them political instability. For example, the recent violence in KwaZulu and Natal has frightened investors and helped send the price of the Morgan Stanley Africa Investment Fund down 10 percent last week.
Investors also face risks linked to structural problems, such as investment limits and currency controls. There are also few financial institutions like banks to serve as custodians. (Right now, only a handful of markets meet United States regulatory requirements for mutual-fund investment.) Furthermore, companies must report little or nothing about their activities or profits.
Then there's the fact that, though investment managers may have traveled in Africa and have relationships with local investment firms, that's not the same as being there, said Justin Beckett, president of New Africa Advisers, which has an office in South Africa.
Investors who want to invest in Africa can temper their risks by putting money in a mutual fund that invests in emerging markets around the globe. William McBride, who runs the emerging markets fund information service at Lipper Analytical Services, said he expected that some African funds that came to market this year would find their way into the portfolios of broader-based funds.
A final possibility is to follow in the footsteps of Jean-Marie Eveillard, who runs the Sogen International Fund. Interested in Africa but concerned about the thinness of local markets and the lack of custodian banks, he has invested in companies that do a lot of business across Africa, but whose shares trade in London or Paris. His biggest Africa-related position is Lonrho P.L.C., which has extensive holdings in mining, agriculture and hotels throughout the continent, and is based in London. And he's looking for more.
"What else is left?" he said. "If you look at South Africa, the smaller markets in the Pacific Rim, Poland, China -- all are up considerably. The only emerging market where investors' expectations are low, though not as low as they used to be, is Africa."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1356 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: March 27 - April 1

BYLINE: By Frederik Eliason 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Bear Sightings Reported on Wall Street
The stock market was on the front pages last week, and the news was bad. Despite a rebound just before trading closed for the week on Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average finished the week 8.6 percent below its all-time high of 3,978.36, which was reached on Jan. 31, after a rise of 68 percent that began in October 1990. The recent decline, which has become more intractable day by day, is seen, at best, as being part of a "correction" -- a retreat of roughly 10 to 15 percent from a market high. If this is just a correction, sunny days may not be far away. But some investors are worrying about a full-blown bear market -- a prolonged decline. Excluding the crash of 1929-32, when the market fell 89 percent, the average drop in a bear market has been 36 percent. And that kind of a decline would take us almost back to where the bull market started. 

Hillary Clinton's Bull Market
Listeners to radio financial advice programs are familiar with advertisements trumpeting the spectacular profits to be made in commodities trading. Now they may pay closer attention in light of Hillary Rodham Clinton's adventures in cattle futures trading: an initial $1,000 investment turned into net gains of more than $98,000. It is said that three of four commodities investors lose money. But Mrs. Clinton had the benefit of free advice from James B. Blair, a friend who happened to be an exceptionally skillful trader, and a commodities broker, Robert L. Bone, who has been accused by regulators of bending rules for his best customers. For all their promises, the radio ads cannot offer friends like that.
 
The Stat Behind the Debt
The so-called sabermetricians who mine and refine mountains of baseball statistics have learned that even the most straightforward numbers do not tell the whole truth. The shortstop with the best fielding percentage is probably not the best fielder, for instance. Lawrence B. Lindsey of the Fed may have been practicing something like sabermetrics when he dug into the good news that the debt level of United States households was just 16.2 percent of after-tax income last year, just slightly higher than in the good old 60's and 70's. But Mr. Lindsey found that if you factor out the rich and the elderly, the middle class debt load was really 22.9 percent. That means robust consumer spending is not sustainable for very long, unless income growth picks up.
 
Executive Privilege
An executive with a huge block of his company's stock that has risen handsomely has a bit of problem: if he sells, he must pay a capital gains tax and his voting power will be diminished; if he holds, his profits are only on paper. (We should all have such problems.) But now even this inconvenience is avoidable through an "equity swap" in which a bank or investment firm takes the stock and any dividends it generates for a specified time. The executive, meanwhile, collects income generated when the firm invests an amount equal to the stock's value. Such deals are not available to investors whose holdings are measured in thousands rather than in millions.
 
A Hot Report on Jobs
The most nervously awaited economic report last week was Friday's data on employment in March. The unemployment rate stayed at 6.5 percent, but the economy added an expectedly high 456,000 jobs in March -- the biggest one-month gain in more than six years. Bond traders immediately started thinking the Fed might try to cool things off by raising rates again. In limited trading on Good Friday, Treasury bond prices fell two points.
 
INTERNATIONL
 
Unhappy Warriors
With unexpected suddenness, the Clinton Administration ended export controls on the most advanced commercial telecommunications and computer equipment last week, coinciding with the end of the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls. For big high-tech companies like A.T.& T., eager to sell in places like Russia and China (which alone may spend $40 billion to upgrade its phone system this decade), the policy change is enlightened and beneficial, and simply acknowledges that such technology is already available internationally. But some arms control experts are unhappy, arguing that powerful United States computers will easily make their way via third parties into the few nations, like Cuba, Iraq and North Korea, that are still supposed to be off limits.
 
Outdone, and Glad of It
It has become numbing in recent years to read of the various foreign threats to United States competitive pre-eminence. Still, it is shocking to learn that the rate of car theft in England and Wales now exceeds the nationwide rate in the United States. This has not translated into higher insurance premiums on average for British drivers than for Americans, but it has produced an array of sophisticated antitheft technology -- offered routinely on new cars in Britain, but available only as high-priced options here.
 
One Car for All
Reports are coming out of Detroit and Europe about an impending meeting involving 400 senior executives of Ford at which the chairman, Alex Trotman, will reorganize the company according to functions rather than geography. The notion is that the company does not need separate lineups of cars for North America, Europe and Asia. Ford has already started selling a compact car, the Mondeo, in Europe that it expects to introduce in the United States. If one menu can work for McDonald's in 70-odd countries, it seems reasonable to expect Ford to come up with models that can find buyers around the world.
 
COMPANIES
 
The July Cola Has a Nice Bouquet
Last week's big marketing idea was dreamed up at Pepsico to counter flat sales of diet soda. Its solution, backed up by a $25 million ad campaign, is to stamp the bottom of Diet Pepsi cans with freshness dates. Not that a cola more than 14 weeks old is undrinkable. Still, the move won praise from the New York State Consumer Protection Board and from various beverage industry experts. At last, a solution to a problem we never knew existed.
 
Strong Reviews, Weak Profits
To outsiders, the Saturn, the small car from General Motors that was designed to be an import-fighter, is a clearcut success. It has carved a niche in the low-price end of the
market; its owners rave about its quality; and its dealers' above-board sales methods and attentive service are being imitated by others. To G.M. insiders, the picture is more fuzzy. The Saturn unit is barely profitable, and its leaders think they need to produce a lot more cars. Dealers' inventories of Saturns are far above the industry ideal, and as one analyst put it, the brand is facing a "shortage of car buyers."
 
Minding Their Merger Manners
Finding itself with two suitors, Grumman seems to have decided not to subject itself to the kind of messy spectacle that swirled around Paramount for six months. So it told its two swains -- Martin Marietta and Northrop -- to make their best cases for a marriage by 5 P.M. on Thursday, seal their offers and not disclose the contents until Monday. But Grumman may have overlooked something in choreographing this little ceremony: Northrop and Martin Marietta might choose not to be decorous. What happens if one of them comes back with a counteroffer after a winner is announced. Grumman's holders may choose dollars over etiquette.
 
Turmoil at Spectrum, Continued
In this week's episodes, 7 of the 11 directors resigned at Spectrum, the Long Island company that burst on the scene when it hired John Sculley as its chief executive. Among those leaving the board was Peter T. Caserta, who recruited Mr. Sculley. He earlier took a leave of absence as president after his son-in-law and other employees of a second company, Paradigm, which he founded, were arrested and accused of fraud. Then Edward W. Maskaly resigned after all of nine days as Spectrum's chairman and chief executive. He was mentioned in the Federal complaint at Paradigm, but he attributed his departure to reporters' hounding the company. No successor has been named.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
As Italy Turns Right, Stocks Turn Up

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THE election celebrations in Italy began among investors on the Milan stock exchange even before the polls closed last Monday. A mixture of rumor and exit-poll data led investors to conclude -- correctly, it turned out -- that the right-wing coalition led by the businessman Silvio Berlusconi would win a solid victory in the national elections. The market, believing that a clear-cut victory for the right would provide sorely needed political stability and give direction to economic policy, rose sharply.
The Milan market bounced around for the rest of the week as analysts debated whether Mr. Berlusconi would be able to hold together his disparate coalition partners and form a government. The trend, however, was clearly upward. By the end of the week, the Milan BCI index of leading stocks reached 722.99, up 53.26, or nearly 8 percent, since Monday, a performance that had to be considered especially strong in a week in which most other world markets fell precipitously. 
 Whether the market's buoyancy will continue depends to a large extent on whether the right-wing parties can translate their vaguely defined free-market economic philosophies into a workable government policy.
The markets are looking to Mr. Berlusconi and his allies to continue bringing Italy's huge budget deficit under control, to step up the pace of privatization in a nation whose public sector is a bigger part of the economy than in any major Western country, and to loosen the grip of unions.
There are considerable uncertainties as far as economic policy goes, not the least of which is how he will mesh his supply-side campaign rhetoric about simplifying and reducing taxes with the need to continue slashing the budget deficit. At around 10 percent of gross domestic product, Italy's deficit is the largest in the European Union.
There is also the question of whether the neo-Fascists within the electoral coalition would push the nation so far to the right that it would become destabilized.
Still, analysts said they thought the election results would give a sustained psychological boost to the equity market, which was already benefitting from falling interest rates and an economic recovery.
"The market outlook is surely positive in the long term, although the markets now are fairly jittery," said Giorgio Radaelli, an economist who follows Italy for Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Radaelli said the prospect of falling interest rates should eventually help the bond market in Italy as well. Bonds have remained sluggish, largely because of the Europe-wide sell-off in bonds precipitated by rising interest rates in the United States.
Marcus Grubb, a strategist at Salomon Brothers in London, recommended last week that investors increase the proportion of their investment holdings in Italian stocks following the election and raised his year-end target for the BCI index to 775 from 750. He said the fundamental outlook for the market, in terms of interest rates, economic recovery and corporate profits, was positive.
"There may be some near-term weakness in the market if the right-wing alliance has difficulty forming a government, but we would see that as a buying opportunity," Mr. Grubb said.
Italy is slowly emerging from recession, and is expected to record economic growth this year, Salomon Brothers said, of 0.7 percent, although other estimates run as high as 2 percent.
Inflation, however, remains quiescent, and the lira is relatively stable, so most economists expect further reductions in short-term interest rates, probably to around 6.5 percent over the next year, from 8 percent now.
"We expect consumer price inflation to fall gradually to a 24-year low this year and the January data confirmed a deceleration in wage inflation," Mr. Grubb said. "The trend in inflation and the weak economy justifies further rate cuts in coming months."
Even before the election, the stock market was gathering a head of steam, having risen 14.5 percent since the beginning of the year, according to Salomon Brothers.
The market is getting expensive -- it is trading at around 19 times estimated 1994 earnings -- but the index is still well below its historical high of 906, reached in 1986. Moreover, Mr. Grubb said, earnings should surge by 35 percent to 40 percent over the next year.
Marie-Christine Keith, who follows Italy for Natwest Markets in London, said she was recommending cyclical stocks such as Pirelli and Fiat, which should benefit from the economic rebound this year, as well as insurance-industry stocks. Insurers are benefitting from falling interest rates and from a planned liberalization of auto-insurance rates.
Mr. Grubb said Salomon Brothers was recommending interest rate-sensitive equities such as banks, including Banca Commerciale Italiana, and insurers, including Toro Assicurazioni.
In addition, he said, investors should consider stocks in sectors like telecommunications that are likely to be affected by a right-wing government's commitment to privatization and deregulation. He said S.I.P., the main provider of telephone service, was particularly attractive.

HEADLINE: At Work;
A Health Risk Escaping Regulators

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
YOU have an illness that makes you feel faint, pitch over and pass out or vomit. It causes your blood pressure and heart rate to rabbit around. You lose a day or two of work here and there, and sometimes you need treatment in a hospital emergency room. You are worried, and chances are, if you are a white-collar employee and your symptoms appear at work, your employer, and perhaps even local public health officials, will be too.
If you happen to be a tobacco harvester, doing seasonal work, there's a good chance you recognize those symptoms. They are typical of green tobacco sickness, an illness that, as one Kentucky tobacco farmer put it, "can make you feel like you're going to die." Despite evidence that the illness, essentially a form of nicotine poisoning that can affect field workers when wet tobacco touches their skin, is endemic among tobacco pickers, it is widely regarded as a nuisance and a cost of doing business. 
 This is in sharp contrast to concerns over indoor air quality, and especially secondary cigarette smoke, expressed in the form of new regulations proposed late last month by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Assuming the rules go into effect, some six million indoor workplaces in the United States will be virtually free of secondary smoke, which afflicts anyone within breathing distance. But the rules won't cover thousands of harvesters, the workers most directly at risk of tobacco-related health hazards in the workplace.
Green tobacco sickness is not new. Dr. Stephen Gehlbach, now dean of the School of Public Health at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, and colleagues reported in a 1974 article in the Journal of the American Medical Association on research conducted among harvesters in North Carolina. They learned that an illness among tobacco workers that appeared to be pesticide poisoning was actually caused by nicotine absorption through the skin. Often tobacco workers carried wet tobacco leaves under their arms or worked in the rain or early-morning dew. "Harvesters would get absolutely drenched in water and solubilized nicotine," he said. "It was like having a poultice of nicotine and water sitting next to the skin."
The reaction to the research, he said, was "an astounding lack of interest. Here were young people working summer jobs, getting sick on this noxious stuff which has no beneficial purpose." Every so often a flurry of interest in the topic would stir -- and die.
The latest flurry occurred last year, when the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health reported a 1992 outbreak of green tobacco sickness in south-central Kentucky. It was discovered almost by accident when a project financed by the institute to monitor farm injuries began picking up reports of severe attacks of dizziness, nausea, extreme weakness and other symptoms that required a trip to the hospital.
Epidemiologists studied 47 cases from emergency-room records in the Bowling Green-Elizabethtown area. Extrapolating, they estimated that as many as 600 of Kentucky's 60,000 tobacco workers would have had cases serious enough to require medical attention. The report noted that the figure probably underestimated the incidence of green tobacco sickness because "many affected persons may not seek hospital treatment." The results prompted the institute to issue a health warning.
THE 1992 research is Kentucky-specific, but the study's principal investigator, Dr. Terri J. Ballard, said the illness is the same as the one identified in North Carolina. "It is highlighted in Kentucky because we have a surveillance system in place. I have spoken with people in North Carolina. They are seeing it in migrant clinics," said Dr. Ballard, an institute epidemiologist based in Cincinnati.
It is virtually impossible to speculate about the illness' impact beyond Kentucky because data on it are not collected systematically. Workers who come down with green tobacco sickness are likely to lose a day or two of work and incur the costs of visiting a hospital, which in the study ranged from $250 to $2,041. Tobacco workers typically are not covered by workman's compensation, and they often do not have health insurance.
Despite the economic and health costs and that nothing is known about the long-term effects of repeated episodes, green tobacco sickness doesn't command as much respect as some other occupational health issues.
"It is a problem, but in the grand scheme of life, there are more things you need to worry about," said Dr. Michael Auslander, an epidemiologist at the occupational institute's Kentucky project.
He worries far more on behalf of harvesters about other injuries, like cuts from the tobacco knives, impalements on spears used to hang tobacco and falls from the rafters of tobacco barns, all of which can have more serious consequences than green tobacco sickness. "It's like the flu. No one likes having it, but you aren't worried about dying," he said. Workers know to use protective clothing when feasible, or they can take on other kinds of work.
The alternatives for workers in the area typically are minimum-wage jobs. A very fit and fast tobacco worker can make up to $20 an hour, but most make closer to $8 an hour. Dr. Gary Palmer, an agronomist at the University of Kentucky in Lexington, said local people increasingly are choosing fast-food outlets over the tobacco fields. "If you've ever worked in tobacco, you know that being in an air-conditioned building flipping burgers is attractive," he said.
Many harvesting jobs have in recent years been filled by migrant workers, mostly from Mexico, Central America and Haiti, who cannot flee to other jobs if they turn out to be susceptible to green tobacco sickness.
As more becomes known about the illness, more farmers are getting interested. The institute project in Kentucky sends public health nurses to agricultural fairs to give out information. "The farmers care about it because it affects productivity," Dr. Ballard said. Dr. Gehlbach, who has moved on to other research, can still summon up some quiet outrage about the lack of institutional interest in the problem. "It's another very unattractive aspect of the whole tobacco problem in this country," Dr. Gehlbach said. "It is bad enough that the end product causes the problems it does, but even the processing causes misery."

HEADLINE: Profile;
Relighting the Fires at Avon Products

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
THERE'S a flowering plant on Christina A. Gold's desk. She's not sure if it is an azalea or a hibiscus or what. But she loves that plant every bit as much as the more familiar blooms she tends at home.
"A sales rep sent it to me," Ms. Gold said with visible pride. "The note said, 'Thanks for bringing springtime back to Avon.' " 
 Avon Products Inc. has gone through a series of emotional seasons every bit as harsh as the actual winter that just passed. In November, after 24 years with Avon's Canadian division, Ms. Gold was called to New York to become the first woman to head the United States, Canadian and Puerto Rican operations of the direct-sales beauty company. She replaced Walker Lewis, who resigned after only 19 months.
Avon insiders say that Mr. Lewis, a former management consultant, ran Avon entirely with his head. Now Ms. Gold is trying to put heart back into the place.
"Walker was a brilliant strategist," said James E. Preston, Avon's chief executive. "But now we need someone whose first priority is to re-energize the sales force."
Mr. Lewis, reached in Greenwich, Conn., refused to comment. But Avon insiders say it is no coincidence that Mr. Preston says re-energize, not simply energize. For the last five months, Ms. Gold, who is 46, has been reconstructing some of the motivational institutions that Mr. Lewis so carefully took apart.
"Over the last few years, the whole program for incentives was skinnied down," recalled Brian C. Connolly, whom Ms. Gold plucked from the Southeast sales region to become director of national incentives and motivation -- a position that Mr. Lewis had abolished. "The push was toward advertising and chasing fringe customers."
Actually, many of Mr. Lewis's strategies worked. Avon's new "800" number, which allows customers to bypass the Avon Lady to buy direct, has added incremental sales. Anew, Avon's high-tech skin care product, has been successful, as has a new line of skin care products for men. And most analysts have high hopes for lingerie, a new product for which Mr. Lewis laid the groundwork.
Avon's stock, which bottomed at about $19 five years ago, closed at $56.25 on Thursday, the final day of trading last week. The company has stayed independent, despite Chartwell Inc.'s takeover run in 1990.
Ms. Gold's division, which represents about 40 percent of Avon's $4 billion in sales, predicts a first-quarter sales increase of at least 5 percent and a pretax profit increase of better than 25 percent. The increases will happen on Ms. Gold's watch, but they certainly reflect Mr. Lewis's programs.
"Her real test will be the second quarter forward," said Diana K. Temple, an analyst at Salomon Brothers who says she likes Avon stock.
Avon is in fact still reeling from a horrid 1993, when United States sales dropped 1 percent, to $1.40 billion, and pretax profits sank 22 percent, to $152 million. Part of the reason was a money-draining giftware line, and increased costs for marketing and selling. But part was also a general demotivation among the Avon Ladies -- the now politically incorrect term that most people outside the company still use for the 400,000 women who ply Avon products in the United States.
"Walker had some interesting merchandising ideas, but he did not grow the sales staff like he should have," said Jack Salzman, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs who rates Avon stock a "hold."
Ms. Gold concurs. "The sales reps were worried and they were alienated, and they simply were not selling as aggressively as we would like," she said.
During his short reign, Mr. Lewis pared the value of the trips and prizes and commission guarantees that the sales representatives could earn. He stopped sending birthday presents to the high performers. Avon insiders say he even tried to end the practice of giving porcelain statuettes of Mrs. P. F. E. Albee, the first Avon Lady, to the more productive reps.
"The district managers rose up like a tidal wave when Walker tried to do away with the Mrs. Albees," said an Avon veteran who insisted on anonymity. "Women leave these figurines to their daughters and granddaughters, they are so proud of them. Walker just didn't understand."
Still, Ms. Gold and Mr. Lewis are alike in many ways. He paid more attention to sales reps than his "strategy only" reputation might indicate. And she is as interested in new products as he was. She just introduced lingerie and plans to introduce a line of vitamins later this year. She is spearheading a search for "the right gifts at the right price," in hopes of giving Avon's giftware line a broader appeal. And she is trying to streamline the flow of information between Avon's order processors and its distribution centers, so that sales reps can get products to customers more quickly.
BUT Ms. Gold's budgetary strategy has been the mirror image of her predecessor's. She has cut spending on fliers and brochure inserts and insists on testing new marketing plans before rolling them out nationwide. And she's plowing the money that is being freed up into sales incentives.
Avon has long given its sales reps points for dollars of sales, tradable for various gifts. Mr. Lewis made them redeemable only for savings bonds. Ms. Gold's staff has rushed a new catalogue of gifts onto the presses.
"Bonds don't have the same effect as a private catalogue," Mr. Connolly said.
Ms. Gold has resumed sending birthday gifts to high performers. And about a month ago she asked every salaried Avon employee, from forklift operators to Mr. Preston, to handwrite 100 brief thank-you notes to sales reps, for delivery by March 19, which four years ago the company declared to be Avon Representative Day.
Jennifer Evans, a sales rep in Brewster, Wash., says she received an "atta girl" letter from Ms. Gold when she was a few thousand dollars shy of the $75,000 in sales she needed to win a trip to Orlando. "Sure, I would have worked hard without it, but the fact that she took the time to write it meant a lot," said Ms. Evans, who did win the trip. "Christina Gold has added the personal touch back in."
Not that Ms. Gold is not a bottom-line stickler as well. Under her aegis the Canadian division's sales increased at an annual compound rate of 8 percent, and profits went up at a rate of 6 percent -- not bad for a mature market in a deep recession.
"She is disciplined and focused, and by any measure she has delivered financial results," Mr. Preston said.
Ms. Gold clearly attained those results through people, though. In Canada, she brought her district managers to headquarters for three days twice a year, and sounded them out on everything from proposed pricing to ways to introduce commission changes. She offered training in time management and sales techniques to reps. She set part of every day aside to call representatives, and often joined them on sales calls.
"I'd go out with the sales reps who were doing well and with the ones who were doing badly, and I'd pass what the successful ones were doing on to the others," Ms. Gold said.
Now she's trying to open similar lines of communications and meetings in the United States. "Motivation isn't all prizes and things," Ms. Gold said. "It's listening."
Ms. Gold did more of her share of listening in her younger days -- in good part because she was too painfully shy to do much talking. The second of three children, Ms. Gold was an overweight teen-ager, and an introverted one. Born Christina Engelsman in the Netherlands of a Dutch father and Canadian mother, she moved with her family to Canada when she was 4. Her mother, a painter and a nurse, was expansive and outgoing. But, Ms. Gold recalls, her father, a former military officer and Olympic gymnast, set the household's tone.
"He was a hard worker, but he was not an outgoing person," Ms. Gold said. "It was a long time before I realized I had inherited my mother's great love of people."
So sales, with its obligatory schmoozing, was not a career she planned; indeed, she never planned any career. Freshly graduated from Ottawa's Carleton University in 1969 with a degree in geography -- not exactly up there with an M.B.A. in job-grabbing ability -- she took a job at a coupon-center clearinghouse, tallying the cents-off coupons that had been redeemed at supermarkets, then switched to being an inventory control clerk at Avon "because it paid $100 a week, $10 more than I was making."
She did so well keeping track of inventory that she quickly was promoted to marketing. She seemed to be on a fast track -- except that in 1972, Avon folded Canada's marketing operations into United States headquarters. Her husband, Peter Gold, a lawyer whom she met in college, couldn't move his general law practice to the United States. Avon Canada shunted Ms. Gold off to sales promotion, a decidedly non-fast-track area.
There she might have stayed but for Mun Lavigne, then the Canadian division's head of human resources.
"I read her performance appraisals, and I knew this woman should be moved ahead," said Mr. Lavigne, who is now retired.
R. LAVIGNE persuaded Ms. Gold, still only in her 20's, to take a demotion to a supervisory position to get line-management experience. And he persuaded her to come with him to New York to make a presentation to management -- a nightmare task for someone with Ms. Gold's fear of public speaking.
"I was afraid of the people who worked for me, so imagine how I felt about addressing management," Ms. Gold recalled.
Mr. Lavigne recognized the fear, and worked with it. "I made her polish her speech, look people in the eye, vary her tone of voice," he recalled. "I worked her so hard that by the time we went to New York, she wouldn't speak to me on the plane."
Mr. Lavigne didn't let up. A couple of years later, Ms. Gold asked to run sales in a suburban, English-speaking part of Canada. So, he made her head of sales for downtown Montreal, where French is spoken. There followed a series of jobs up the sales and marketing ladders, culminating in her being named head of the Canadian division in 1989.
"I'd keep pushing her to try new things," Mr. Lavigne said. "We had a love-hate relationship, but we ended up with a lot of love and very little hate."
Ms. Gold, who smiles at the memory of Mr. Lavigne, puts it succinctly. "He was my mentor," she said.
Mr. Lavigne was not able to exorcise all of Ms. Gold's demons. She still has terrible stage fright whenever she must speak publicly. And, she acknowledges that she is impatient, a trait that can be offputting to people not as quick as she is and that can sometimes causes her to leap in the wrong direction.
She recalls rolling out a profit-sharing plan in Canada without giving employees a chance to sign off on it. "A lot of them thought it was inequitable," she recalled. "It's no fun having a plant full of people rise up against you." Several group meetings later, a chastened Ms. Gold introduced a plan that better suited the employees.
She is also a self-acknowledged chronic worrier, which has made the move to New York a wrenching one. She's still "shaky" about how corporate performance affects stock price, which as a newly appointed corporate senior vice president she must now worry about.
And the move itself is problematic. Although her husband is looking at business opportunities in New York, for now theirs is a commuter marriage. He lives in Montreal, she's taken a one-year lease on an apartment on 52d Street and Second Avenue. (They have no children.)
"Peter's never begrudged me my job; he's my best cheerleader," Ms. Gold said.
When she's not on the road visiting outlying territories, Ms. Gold is in her West 57th Street office by 8 A.M. and out by 7 P.M., with time for lunch in the employee cafeteria. She rarely brings work home. In Montreal, her passion is downhill skiing. Here, on nights without business dinners, she watches television or plays Nintendo, which she says she enjoys as much as any teen-ager.
And anyone who doubts that she emphasizes people over numbers should just ask her what type of computer she uses, at home or at work. "I've never gotten around to buying one," she says, only a bit abashedly. "I guess I'll have to learn eventually."
 
Christina A. Gold
 
 Born: Sept. 12, 1947.
 
 Home bases: Montreal and Manhattan.
 
 Family: Husband, Peter, and a huge Irish setter named Yogi, who both live in Montreal.
 
 Ideal vacation: "Anyplace with skiing and without a phone."
 
 Favorite reading: Anything by Danielle Steele.
 
 Computer: Doesn't use one.

HEADLINE: The Economy Should Work for Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Group of Seven conference on employment in industrialized nations, held in Detroit this month, brought with it suggestions that the Europeans and Japanese could learn from the United States how to make their work forces more "flexible" by eliminating some job security, encouraging people to relocate and curtailing unemployment benefits. 
 As an American worker in construction, shipyards and electronics for the last 20 years, I think this puts the matter backward. In democratic societies, the raison d'etre of the economy should be to provide the greatest well-being for the greatest number. Well-being requires -- along with a decent standard of living -- equity, community and, particularly, security. When anyone in a society is insecure, it tends to undermine the security of everyone else, and it corrodes communities. Economies, in other words, need to be user-friendly for the least of their users.
Much of the mammonic savagery haunting our society has spread because we deny economic security to groups on the bottom rungs of our ladder. Violence and substance abuse, illiteracy and infant mortality are toxic externalities of our economy. They are not captured by gross domestic product or even unemployment, but there they are on the corner every day.
The humanity of a society depends on the conditions not of the average but of the lowest percentile. And these, the poorest people, are precisely those who depend on the safety net that would be pulled out from under them with what is being called work force flexibility.
No doubt the experts believe that most workers will ultimately benefit from more "flexible" work forces, and certainly European-style safety nets have a price. But workers, which is to say the majority of us, live in the present with rent to pay and kids to raise regardless of the vagaries of the world economy.
In recent years, productivity increases have too often translated into a lower standard of living for many of us. Why should we now believe that more of the same will provide us all jobs at living wages? If the social security to which workers in most developed countries have grown accustomed reduces the efficiency of some market mechanisms, that may not be a bad price to pay for more secure families and neighborhoods.
The French students who are in the streets protesting a lowered minimum wage have got it right; markets, especially labor markets, are not ends in themselves, but means to social goals. If the markets don't further these goals, they need to be channeled or buffered or changed.
The United States unions that are supporting the right of Mexican workers to organize also have it right. Capital, although it darts around the globe these days at the speed of light, still needs to be held accountable to human values. The labor and environmental standards of international trade must be harmonized upward rather than downward, and we can only accomplish this by practicing solidarity across geographic and economic borders.
I would say we Americans have more to learn about economic security from the rest of the world than vice versa.
 
PETER COSTANTINI
Seattle, March 24, 1994

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
In Political Bloopers, Practice Is Everything

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A REPUBLICAN Senator from Virginia named William Scott moved quickly to contain the damage in 1974 after he was branded "the dumbest Congressman of them all" on the cover of New Times magazine. He called a news conference to deny it.
Ten years later, Jerry Springer, a Democrat who was running for Governor of Ohio, also tried to confront a weakness in a public forum. Hoping to neutralize an embarrassing personal incident before it became a campaign issue, Mr. Springer broadcast a television commercial in which he admitted he had paid for the services of a prostitute. By check, no less. He lost the primary but, appropriately, went on to fame as a talk show host. 
 These days, politicians are still getting themselves into trouble. As if blissfully unaware of the obvious consequences, they are still joining all-white country clubs. They are still forgetting to register to vote, or to show up at the polls. They are still making racial slurs.
Maybe the political fraternity missed the latest news about Senator Bob Packwood; clumsily brazen sexual come-ons, it seems, are still the order of the day. In the latest episode, a writer named Lisa DePaulo said Mayor Ed Rendell of Philadelphia repeatedly made suggestive remarks to her when she spent the day with him for a profile in Philadelphia magazine. When Ms. DePaulo was having problems getting through a metal detector, for example, the Mayor joked that she was wearing "a spiked metal bra."
At a news conference after Ms. DePaulo's article hit the streets, Mr. Rendell said, "I feel a little stupid."
Well, yes. But the Mayor did not try to answer the broader question, which is: How can anyone be so stupid? Some authorities favor the arrogance explanation.
"Isolation and hubris account for most of it," said Frank Mankiewicz, a public relations executive who has long been active in Democratic politics. "You get someone who's been in the Senate for 24 years, probably never paid for a haircut, never made a dinner reservation or parked a car. So they're likely to make dumb mistakes."
Others have a simpler answer: "The reasons that politicians do dumb things is that many of them are just plain dumb," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch. "It shouldn't shock you."
If not shocking, it is striking how politicians do not learn from their own mistakes -- or those of their predecessors. They cannot seem to stop themselves from repeating vintage blunders.
 
Open Mike, Insert Foot
 Unbelievable as it may seem, politicians often forget that the microphone hears everything. Take Representative Martin Hoke, a freshman Republican from Ohio. He got caught on video recently ogling a television producer and commenting to a colleague on the size of her breasts.
Thanks to a "body mike," the world heard it when, on their first full day at the White House, Hillary Rodham Clinton snapped at her husband because people were kept waiting at their open house. She should have remembered the trouble Mr. Clinton got into during the primaries when, told incorrectly that the Rev. Jesse Jackson planned to endorse Senator Tom Harkin, he accused Mr. Jackson of "back-stabbing."
As a onetime radio broadcaster, President Reagan should have known better. Remember the microphone test when he joked about attacking Russia? "We begin bombing in five minutes," he said sternly.
 
Makeup by the Taxpayers
 Somehow, Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly of Washington must have forgotten President Clinton and the $200 haircut. While her city may be facing bankruptcy, Mayor Kelly insists there is nothing wrong with her spending public money on a makeup artist for her television appearances.
"Vanity, vanity, that will always bring you down," Mr. Koch said of Mayor Kelly. "I guess she looks in the mirror every day and says, 'Mirror, mirror on the wall, who is the most beautiful mayor of all?' "
 
Into the 19th Hole
 For all their appeals to common folk, politicians seem to be drawn to country clubs that keep out blacks or Jews or women. The most recent is the new Governor of Virginia, George F. Allen, a Republican. He actually joined a club that his three predecessors refused to go to because it bans women. Wisely, he quickly changed his mind. So did Bill Frist of Tennessee, who is seeking the Republican Senate nomination; he recently quit an exclusive club. (But Mr. Frist has another problem, shared by Hugh Rodham, a candidate for the Democratic Senate nomination in Florida: he never registered to vote -- in his case, until 1978.)
There are other reasons why politicians might think twice before joining golf clubs. After all, President Bush was hardly convincing when, standing on the green, he said there was no recession.
 
Texas-Sized Stupidity
 The aforementioned examples do not particularly impress Molly Ivins, the Texas writer who has made a career of chronicling political bloopers. "Let's talk seriously dumb," she said before selecting her personal hall of fame.
One member is Reagan Brown, who in his 1982 campaign for re-election as agriculture commissioner stood before the cameras to demonstrate the dangers of fire ants. When he stuck his hand into a mound, he was stung so badly that he went straight to the hospital. He lost.
There is also Mike Martin, a Republican state representative who arranged for his cousin to shoot him (only slightly wounding him, of course) so he would garner sympathy from the voters. First he blamed the attack on devil worshippers, then on his political enemies. Finally, he pleaded guilty to a perjury charge in 1981 and withdrew his re-election bid.
Blaming the press for destroying his career, Mr. Martin vowed to leave Texas, change his name and become a carpenter. At least in political circles, he was never heard from again.
