HEADLINE: Eugene Keilin Emerges From Rohatyn's Shadow

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
At a farewell dinner last fall for Felix G. Rohatyn, one staff member rose to pay tribute to the man who led the State Municipal Assistance Corporation from its birth in 1975, when New York City's fiscal crisis first erupted.
"As far as I'm concerned," she said, "Bruce Springsteen will always be the Boss, and Felix Rohatyn will always be the chairman of M.A.C." 
 Surprisingly, Eugene J. Keilin, who was chosen by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to replace Mr. Rohatyn, actually enjoys telling the story.
"I'm like George Selkirk, the guy who took Babe Ruth's place in right field at Yankee Stadium," Mr. Keilin said. "Nobody remembers his name."
Much as he might like to avoid George Selkirk's fate, Mr. Keilin (pronounced KAY-lynn) faces a daunting challenge.
 
A Different Era
 Even under Mr. Rohatyn -- who had enormous personal clout because of his reputation as a savior of New York City -- the influence of the agency was already waning. Set up by New York State to help the city avoid bankruptcy in the 1970's, the agency remained important through the 80's primarily because it found itself in control of billions of dollars in excess funds from sales-tax receipts that the city craved.
Now, with its decision to release the $200 million surplus it held, the agency appears close to its last hurrah.
"My impression is that M.A.C. has relatively few bullets left," said Donald Kummerfeld, a former first deputy mayor who held several important fiscal posts and is still prominent in New York City affairs. "It's not out of business, but M.A.C. has already done for the city, for better or worse, most of what it could do."
That doesn't mean Mr. Keilin, 51, is about to give up. Already well-known within the tight circles of New York City fiscal experts, he recently emerged from obscurity by publicly questioning Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's policy of largely exempting the police and fire departments from budget cuts.
 
'Nobody Elected Him'
 In the past, when Mr. Rohatyn scolded mayors and the municipal unions about what he considered the city's free-spending ways, his victims usually held their tongues. But this time, the Mayor blasted right back.
"It isn't his role or M.A.C.'s role to be suggesting the budget priorities or political priorities of the city," Mr. Giuliani said at a City Hall news conference recently. "Nobody elected him to make determinations like that."
Although the agency no longer has the authority to intervene directly in the budget process, it controls the $200 million surplus that Mr. Giuliani needs for his ambitious severance program to eliminate about half the 15,000 jobs he plans to cut in the next 15 months. On Friday, the M.A.C. agreed to release the surplus, with the condition that the city repay the money if the Mayor does not manage to slash the 15,000 jobs.
Like Mr. Rohatyn, his long-time mentor, Mr. Keilin is no stranger to controversy, having played an important backstage role in prior budget battles. But unlike the vocal Mr. Rohatyn -- who was not elected to anything either -- Mr. Keilin says he does not plan to seek it out.
"I don't think you'll see me looking for a spotlight," Mr. Keilin said in a recent interview. "But I don't think you'll see me hiding from it if it focuses on me."
 
Behind the Scenes
 For nearly two decades, Mr. Keilin has worked in the shadow of Mr. Rohatyn. A young lawyer in the city budget office when the fiscal crisis began in the mid-1970's, Mr. Keilin represented New York City in its early negotiations with New York State and the M.A.C. He was plucked from that post by Mr. Rohatyn and given the top staff position at the assistance corporation.
With Mr. Rohatyn out front and Mr. Keilin working on the details behind the scenes, the agency helped nurse the city through intensive care.
"I remember we were outside City Hall one day standing next to my BMW, which was kind of beat up," Mr. Rohatyn recalled. "A reporter came up to us and was a bit surprised: 'The Batman and Robin of New York City ride around in that Batmobile?' he said. We thought that was rich."
After two years, Mr. Keilin was offered a job with Lazard Freres & Company, the investment-banking firm where Mr. Rohatyn reigns as the most prominent partner. Mr. Keilin joined the nine-member board of the M.A.C. under Mr. Rohatyn's chairmanship and became a Lazard partner himself in 1984, specializing in employee takeovers of companies at risk of going under.
Mr. Keilin left Lazard in 1990 to set up an investment-banking firm with Ronald Bloom, another Lazard partner, that has carved out a role in advising unions on corporate restructurings and bankruptcies.
 
'Gene Was the One Constant'
 In that position, he has demonstrated what friends and supporters say is probably his greatest strength: patience.
Charles N. Goldstein, the lawyer for the United Airlines' pilots, who are nearing the end of a long struggle by employees to acquire the company, said: "During the almost seven-year-long effort, Gene was the one constant. He never gave in and never gave up."
Mayor Giuliani may have slapped down Mr. Keilin's first effort to serve as a bridge between City Hall and the unions, but his persistence could still hold him in good stead.
"I had chalked up some useful experience and was thinking about going back to the private sector when the fiscal crisis first started to appear in 1974," Mr. Keilin said. "Everybody said to get out. Bankruptcy is not a nice thing to have on your resume. But I believe you don't leave the ship when it's in trouble."
Mr. Keilin says he shares many of Mr. Giuliani's economic views and also believes sacrifice by public employees is needed. But he argues that everyone -- including the police, firefighters and teachers -- must share the burden to avoid harsh cutbacks.
A soft-spoken man with a well-trimmed gray beard, Mr. Keilin carefully chooses his words, a habit honed from years of practice in the often highly charged atmosphere of city politics and management-union negotiations.
He has none of Mr. Rohatyn's public aura to rely on as a shield. Yet he cannot be easily dismissed, simply because he holds one of the state's most prominent offices and serves as an important pipeline from Albany to the city. And his knowledge and experience could make a big difference as New York continues to struggle with its fiscal problems.
"Gene is a pro," Mr. Kummerfeld said. "The Mayor would be crazy to ignore him."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
D'Amato's Diction Backfires With Greek Americans

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
George Stephanopoulos has taken his lumps as President Clinton's adviser -- most recently for a heated conversation with a top Treasury Department official over an investigation into the failed savings and loan at the center of the Whitewater affair.
But his critics mess with this prominent Greek-American's patrimony at their peril, as Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato recently learned. Discussing the White House's efforts to portray his inquiries into Whitewater as mere partisan politics, the Senator from New York last month repeatedly and pointedly mispronounced the names of several Clinton aides, including Mr. Stephanopoulos's, which came out "Steppin' ah-full-us." 
 That did not go down well with some Greek Americans who had long viewed Mr. D'Amato as a friend. Greek organizations beseiged the Senator with protests defending the honor of Mr. Stephanopoulos, who is descended from a prominent family of Greek Orthodox priests and whose father is the dean of the Greek Orthodox Cathedral in New York.
"Greek Americans feel strongly about the respect that should be shown for another's sacred legacy from their ancestry -- their family name," Archbishop Iakovos, primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, said in a statement. "It is particularly disrespectful to ridicule a family which has for generations brought honor and distinction to its name."
Andrew Manatos, head of a Washington consulting firm that represents Greek-American groups, said Mr. D'Amato had insisted that he meant no offense.
Andrew Manatos, head of a Washington consulting firm that represents Greek-American groups, said Mr. D'Amato had insisted that he meant no offense. "The Senator has been smoothing things over," he said.
 
Queens Wins Contest For U.S. Office Building
 The tug of war over a new regional heaquarters for the Food and Drug Administration has been won by Queens, ending an interborough rivalry over 300 permanent jobs.
The new building is to be on the site of a parking lot at York College in Jamaica. Representative Floyd H. Flake and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan had sponsored an appropriation for the project in the budget last year -- but only for that site.
Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn cried foul, since the lab and headquarters have been on the Brooklyn waterfront for years. City University, York College's parent, balked at losing 275 parking spaces. But after Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens agreed to find other spaces, the CUNY Board tentatively approved the deal last month.
The Senator insisted no favoritism was at work, only an effort to help one of the more economically distressed areas of the city.
Several years ago, Mr. Moynihan got a new regional Social Security office for Jamaica, one of New York's oldest settlements.
"Jamaica was Jamaica before Brooklyn was Brooklyn," he said.
 
Politics of Inclusion Includes Council Minorities
 Speaker Peter F. Vallone has long had as strong a hold on his City Council membership as any legislative leader, but as the Council grows ever more diverse, he is taking no chances. Last week, he announced the appointment of four members of the Council's black and Hispanic caucus to new committee chairmanships.
Council aides said the new jobs were intended to inspire loyalty in the approaching vote on the municipal budget, which some minority members have threatened to challenge because of Mr. Giuliani's proposed cuts in social services.
Mr. Vallone named Juanita E. Watkins of Queens to head the subcommittee on women and Una Clarke of Brooklyn to head the subcommittee on mental health. He also created two new panels, one on youth violence to be led by Lawrence A. Warden of the Bronx and another on abandonment, foreclosure and disinvestment, to be run by Antonio Pagan, an openly gay member from the Lower East Side.
"All of these subcommittees were formed," Mr. Vallone said in a statement, "to focus more attention on pressing social problems."
 
City's Only Big Enough For One Top Crime-Fighter
 A postscript on President Clinton's visit to Brooklyn last month, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision not to join him for a talk-show style discussion of crime there:
When the White House first started planning the event, an official there called Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, who said he would be delighted to attend, said a top city official familiar with the exchanges.
Then the White House official called Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, told him how much the White House hoped the Mayor would join the President, and mentioned in passing that of course, Mr. Bratton was a national leader in crime-fighting. To which Mr. Powers coolly replied, the city official said, that the only national leader in crime fighting in New York was Mr. Giuliani himself.
Mr. Giuliani eventually met with the President at his hotel.

HEADLINE: Another Round of Humbling for the Men of Harvard;
Women Have Been There

 BODY:
"The Humbling of the Harvard Man" (March 6), Louis Uchitelle's report on the men of the Harvard class of 1958 who have fallen on hard times, drew a large response from readers. Some offered advice, some lamented the demise of corporate loyalty, some drew parallels to the hurdles faced by a generation of professional women. Running through many of the letters, however, was a bitterness toward institutions like Harvard and a sense that arrogance and privilege had received just retribution.
 
To the Editor: 
 Having recently published a novel about the class of '58 at Sarah Lawrence College, I read with interest your article on the men of Harvard's class of 1958. I saw it as the male version of what happened to the women of my generation.
The men you profiled have taken an economic hit they couldn't have foreseen -- not to mention a cruel loss of status and bashing of their self-esteem. We women haven't fallen nearly so far partly because most of us never attained the career pinnacle to fall from. True, after graduating college, the rebels among us pursued some form of work, though the culture trumpeted that marriage and family alone could offer a woman fulfillment. However, only a minority pursued seriously remunerative careers with a long-term payoff. We took jobs that offered a second income that would complement a husband's -- became teachers, writers, jewelry designers, toilers in the fields of not-for-profit; we rarely conceived of a job as something that might have to support not only us, but also -- as it happened when marriages dissolved in the 70's -- our children.
Though we haven't, like the men, gotten "tumbled out" of Corporate America, we share some of their problems, while incurring heavy-duty ones of our own. We face the same age discrimination, in spades, as in magazine writing, where Generation X appears to be running the show.
Unlike Harvard '58, though, few of us can count on pensions or severance; except for married women and those with family money or fat divorce settlements, few can contemplate a "comfortable" retirement with a home on Marco Island. As well, the beleaguered Harvard grads probably have long-suffering -- maybe second -- wives who offer not only that now essential second income, but companionship and solidarity. Compare the divorced women from '58 who are struggling to survive on their own without the emotional cushioning of a partner that might ease the slings of fortune. Still, since our career expectations were so much lower -- and certainly newer -- perhaps we're less shellshocked than our male counterparts. We've had postgraduate schooling in resilience.
 
ERICA ABEEL
Manhattan, March 17
 
The writer, professor of French at John Jay College, is the author of "Women Like Us," a novel published in February by Ticknor & Fields.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE ROCKAWAYS;
Visions Of Casinos Return to the Beach

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Casino advocates say they sense a real chance of legalizing gambling in the state, and as the discussion picks up in Albany, it's also picking up in the Rockaways.
"The Rockaways is ideal, with that largest strip of unused property right on the boardwalk, two airports and major highways," said Councilman Alfonso C. Stabile, who represents the western Rockaways. Vincent Castellano, chairman of Community Board 14, says the board is likely to review the issue soon. 
 And State Senator Alton Waldon Jr. said that he supports the move toward legalization and that the Rockaways would be a good location. He said he would be guided by the results of a poll he intends to conduct in the area.
But whether political reality will ever allow casinos in the area remains unclear. The last time the idea of casinos in the Rockaways -- an area with an oceanfront site, depressed economy and, perhaps above all, a vast stretch of vacant land -- got serious attention was in the 1970's. The idea faded when Albany stood firm on laws banning casinos.
Opposition has significantly eased since a 1988 Federal law permitted gambling on Indian reservations. In upstate New York, the first such casino has opened, a second is planned and a third is being considered. Access to casinos upstate and in Atlantic City and Connecticut reduces the effectiveness of the New York ban, and enhances the lure for New York to get in on the business and tax revenue.
"Rockaway has hit bottom, and we have to put something there," said Mr. Stabile. "It has very little industry, very little business. Casinos would be a shot in the arm."
The political process for change is complex. A constitutional amendment must be approved by two separately elected State Legislatures and adopted by a statewide referendum. The earliest that could be completed is next year.
And some key officials still oppose casinos for the Rockaways. They include Queens Borough President Claire Shulman and City Councilwoman Juanita Watkins, whose district includes a 300-acre site in Arverne, which advocates say would be ideal for a casino.
One other possible wrinkle is an Indian claim on the Arverne site. Chief Osceola Townsend of the Matinecock Nation of Queens and Long Island contends it is ancestral Indian land, and he threatens to sue if anyone attempts to open a casino there without including his people in the project. But the Matinecocks are not officially recognized as a tribe and have never gone to court to enforce their other land claims. B.L.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LEFFERTS GARDEN;
Testing a Definition of Family

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
A century ago, the heirs of Pieterse Lefferts, a wealthy Dutch immigrant who was granted his vast land holdings by Peter Stuyvesant in 1661, carved up a piece of their farmland and built stately Victorian homes for affluent Brooklyn residents.
In the face of increasing immigration and a shifting economy, a covenant to keep out boarders and renters was established between the remaining Lefferts heirs and new home buyers: only single-family houses could be constructed, and only families could live in them. The community changed in the 1950's and 60's as black families began to move in and whites moved out, but the covenant, bolstered by zoning laws, held. As of today, with three-quarters of its residents black, the community remains solidly composed of middle-class single-family homeowners. 
 Now, though, the covenant is facing its first real challenge, and the community group that represents the area is prepared to go to court to defend it.
Catholic Charities, a large social services agency, is trying to buy a home for four unrelated women.
The organization argues that the women, who are mentally retarded and developmentally disabled, are like family to one another, having lived together since childhood just two blocks from their proposed new home, said Margaret Keaveney, a spokeswoman.
"We really don't see how this can be a violation of the covenant if we're buying the home for a family," she said.
But the home, a $190,000 three-story brick and limestone building at 156 Midwood Street, would be purchased by Catholic Charities and not the individuals themselves, she said.
If the sale goes through, Catholic Charities would be the first agency to sidestep the covenant and possibly open the door for other social service agencies to enter the community.
The covenant "is what people are buying into and this is what our association is mandated to protect," said Stephen McGill, president of the Lefferts Manor Association. "If you paid a premium because you wanted to live in a certain neighborhood and it changed, you would be upset."
The covenant, which covers an eight-block area of 600 homes south of Crown Heights and east of Prospect Park, was written into the original deeds of the homeowners, Mr. McGill said. The validity of the covenant was upheld in State Supreme Court in 1950 when a couple was ordered not to open their home to boarders. And in 1979, the city zoned the area for single-family homes, reinforcing the community's covenant.
Community Board 9, which represents the area, approved Catholic Charities' use of the house almost two weeks ago at its monthly meeting. The board's chairman, Rabbi Jacob Z. Goldstein, said he was unaware that it violated the community's covenant or zoning laws and that he would look into it. He said public hearings were held and that the issues were never raised.
"The public hearing was heavily attended, and this matter never came up," Rabbi Goldstein said. "The fact that no representatives from this particular community were there concerns me."
Mr. McGill said representatives from the association were not at the hearing because they did not know about it.
"We were misinformed about this whole process," Mr. McGill said. "The community board is supposed to represent us and so far no one is willing to help us through this." L.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
Staten Island Ferry Revives a Battle of Boroughs

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE 

 BODY:
The Staten Island Ferry will resume transporting vehicles by late May, officials say, and like other interborough issues, views on the matter are divided according to which side of the water one is standing on. To Staten Island leaders, car ferries are a blessing in an area with limited mass transit; to some public officials in Manhattan, they cause congestion and pollution.
On March 21, Mayor Giuliani announced his decision to restore car ferry service to Staten Island. The service was suspended after a fire damaged the Whitehall Ferry Terminal in lower Manhattan in 1991. Mayor Dinkins made the suspension permanent the next year to discourage people from driving into Manhattan. 
 In reversing the decision, Mayor Giuliani may be conducting a bit of a political payback. In the 1993 Mayoral elections, Staten Island delivered a plurality of more than 88,000 votes to Mr. Giuliani, who won the election by 50,000, while Manhattan gave Mr. Dinkins a plurality of 73,000 votes.
 Also looming large for the Mayor is Staten Island's movement to secede from the city. Although reviving car ferries may not slow the campaign, the service has been an issue, said Guy V. Molinari, Staten Island Borough President and a supporter of secession. "There are many far greater issues, but the administration is being more sensitive to Staten Island," he said.
Previously about 1,000 vehicles entered Manhattan daily by taking the 20-minute ferry ride, said Lisa Daglian, a spokeswoman for the Department of Transportation. Agency studies show that people have continued to drive into Manhattan, she said, but by the Gowanus Expressway and local streets through Brooklyn, "polluting the air even more than when they crossed the ferry with the ignition off." The trip, via the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, can take up to an hour.
Elliott G. Sander, the Transportation Commissioner, initially opposed a return to car ferries but now supports the idea. He said at a recent town hall meeting on Staten Island that its residents have fewer ways to reach Manhattan than the other boroughs.
The new service could delay by about six months the $112 million plan to renovate the Whitehall Ferry Terminal, to begin in 1996. Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for the Economic Development Corporation, said the design must now make space for 40 vehicles queuing up on the plaza. Such changes could cost about $500,000, she said.
For now, new controls are being put in place at two ferry slips to enable vehicle loading in May. Officials are also studying the fare structure. Mr. Molinari has proposed a $1 fare increase, to $3 a car, for a projected revenue of $1 million that would cover an anticipated deficit of $405,000 in ferry operations next year and pay for the service.
Ruth W. Messinger, Manhattan Borough President and a vigorous Dinkins supporter, has been a vocal opponent of the service. "It's bad for traffic, bad for the environment and bad urban planning," she said.
One of the principal objections on the Manhattan side is that car ferries will disrupt plans for a pedestrian esplanade from Battery Park City to the South Street Seaport. Concerned that pedestrians will "lose the plaza," Kathryn Freed, City Councilwoman for lower Manhattan, said: "It just shows that Staten Island's interests are more important than Manhattan's. I'm fed up; we should secede." MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: Older People and the Need for Assistance

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
IF we live long enough, many of us will fit the profile of an older person: living alone, independent, with mental faculties intact but having a need for stimulation and possibly requiring some physical assistance to perform routine chores.
Now there is help for older people who want to remain independent but yearn to live richer lives. Selfhelp Community Services, a 58-year-old nonprofit agency, has started a household-manager program to bridge the gap between companionship and traditional home care, said Elizabeth N. Radow, the program's director. 
 "The first household-manager program was opened in White Plains last September to provide services to help improve the quality of aging residents of Westchester," Ms. Radow said. "A similar program was opened in Manhattan in November."
The population of Westchester is getting older. Quoting 1990 census figures, Ms. Radow said, "There are 33,400 people older than 65 listed as living alone in Westchester. And the number of people 85 and older was 14,104, which represents 35.9 percent growth over the 1980 census." The household-manager program, she said, is a logical extension of Selfhelp's existing services for older people.
 
Giving Something in Return
 Selfhelp Community Services, she said, was begun in 1936 by refugees from Nazi Germany to help other refugees find jobs, homes and schools in American communities.
"Over the years, Selfhelp's programs were expanded, and services were extended to the community at large," Ms. Radow said. This came about "because of the strong desire of those who once were refugees to return something to everyone in the community for the support they received when they first came to the United States."
Today, Selfhelp Community Services is one of the major nonprofit geriatric and home-care social agencies in the New York City area, offering programs at six centers for the elderly, which they operate, and four apartment houses, which they own and operate in Queens, in addition to offering services to individuals in their own homes. The average age of those in the apartments is 80.
Some of the Selfhelp programs are offered free to Holocaust survivors, but other programs, like the new household-manager program, are offered on a fee basis. Selfhelp receives financial support from U.J.A.-Federation and other philanthropic agencies along with donations and government funds for certain programs, Ms. Radow said, adding that Selfhelp's overhead costs are among the lowest in the field of elder care.
 
Trained Companions Offered
 Regarding the household-manager program, Ms. Radow said it is a fee-for-service program priced at $16 an hour during the week with a minimum of two hours. "But most all of the fee, $10 plus $2 for Social Security and unemployment, goes to the employee," she said. "The remainder, $4, goes to offset our overhead costs. We haven't reached the break-even stage yet, but we hope that over time we will be able to sustain ourselves."
What the household manager program provides are trained companions who deliver a variety of services to people in their own homes.
"Because the success of the program is largely dependent on the caliber of the companion, companions are chosen very carefully," Ms. Radow said. "They can be student nurses, free-lance writers, homemakers, office workers, retired executives -- but all of them have the ability to do what may be required of them, which can include such things as reading aloud and discussing current events, assisting with paying bills, walking a dog or shopping, preparing and serving lunch to a bridge club. However, one prerequisite is that the companion has to own and drive a car. In Westchester, especially, what many people need is transportation to stores, to see the doctor or even to the theater."
Ms. Radow, a real estate lawyer, has been a member of the New York State Bar Association special committee on seniors and has published a report on housing for the elderly. She was a member of Selfhelp's executive board when she was chosen to head the household-management program.
"I was enthusiastic about taking the job because I feel that this is an exceptional, unusual home-care service, and as far as I know there is nothing like it in the area," she said. "I do the interviewing myself," she added, explaining that candidates' backgrounds and references are checked thoroughly before the applicants are sent to Selfhelp's Guthery Institute in Manhattan where they take a 40-hour certification course in personal care.
 
'I Saw the Difficult Time'
 Cynthia M. Brill of Thornwood, one of the first people hired as a companion, formerly worked as an office manager in a family business.
"It was my father's company, and after he sold it and retired, I saw the difficult time and loneliness he was experiencing before he passed away," Mrs. Brill said. "It made me realize that many older people really could use something else, and that made me very receptive to becoming part of the household management program."
Mrs. Brill, who has found it more fulfilling to work one-on-one with people than in an office, said: "Every case is different. For instance, I drive one woman who broke her shoulder in a fall on the ice this winter to her physical therapist three times a week. I also walk her dog, take her to the grocery store and do whatever tasks in and around the house are necessary. And for an older client, whose eyesight is bad, I go in twice a week to read to her. She loves to know what's going on and is so eager to talk about things. We discussed the Tonya Harding affair in detail, and now I'm reading her Bette Davis's autobiography, which she seems to enjoy immensely."
One of Mrs. Brill's clients, a woman who broke her arm and agreed to be interviewed only on the condition of anonymity, said: "Cindy is a treasure. It is such a help for me to have her here. She is like a good friend."
Myra Doniger, who lives in Greenwich, has an elderly mother-in-law who lives in Purchase, and she, too, is enthusiastic about the household-manager program.
"My mother-in-law has a housekeeper, so our concern was not so much for her physical care, but it was our feeling that because she had very little mental stimulation the quality of her life was sadly diminished," Mrs. Doniger said. "She was always such an active, independent woman, who was constantly on the go, that when we heard about the companion program we decided to give it a try."
Just having someone to read the newspaper aloud, Mrs. Doniger said, has made a noticeable difference in her mother-in-law's life.
"Now that she has company, she seems much more animated and happier. What do they read? Mainly the society pages of The New York Times, especially the marriages, the charity affairs and, oh, then the obituaries. But it's more than companionship that Selfhelp provides. Companions are trained to be observant and to contact us if they spot any physical change in my mother-in-law that we should know about. And that is very reassuring."
 
Cost Sharing
 Too often, older people become homebound when they are unable to drive, Ms. Radow said. "Having transportation available helps them lead fuller lives," she said. "For example, if a woman wants to have her friends over for lunch and bridge, the companion will not only call for the friends and take them back home, but shop, prepare the lunch, clean up, everything. And if four friends share the cost of having the companion, each pays $6.50 an hour."
And for two people who want to go shopping or perhaps to the theater together, the fee is $10.50 an hour for each, she said.
"It's often the children of our clients who seek out and pay for our services," she said. "They feel that by helping their parents stay independent, they are giving them a great gift."
For more information, Selfhelp's telephone number is 684-1200.

HEADLINE: ABOUT BOOKS

BYLINE: By Shirley Horner 

 BODY:

Forgotten Heroes
IT is no coincidence that Joseph G. Bilby writes about unsung heroes. A veteran of the Vietnam War, he called his latest book "Forgotten Warriors: New Jersey's African American Soldiers in the Civil War" and dedicated it to the men of the First Infantry Division with whom he served from August 1966 to August 1967. 
 "I've wanted to honor neglected phases of New Jersey history long before Vietnam," said Mr. Bilby, a resident of Wall Township, in Monmouth County. He recalled how as an 8-year-old visiting his grandparents' graves in Mount Olive, in Morris County, he discovered the grave of a Civil War veteran, Abraham Sowers, who died a few days before Gen. Robert E. Lee's surrender on April 9, 1865.
"Imagine my surprise to learn when I visited the Newark Public Library four years later that a Morris County relative, George H. Bilby, a cousin to my grandfather, served in the same fighting regiment -- the 15th New Jersey -- as Sowers," Mr. Bilby said.
Mr. Bilby's first book, "Three Rousing Cheers: A History of the 15th New Jersey Infantry From Flemington to Appomattox" ($36), is itself a surprise. After the war ended, laudatory regiment histories emerged as a matter of tradition, but this author writes with a candor permissible after the passage of almost 130 years.
The book, taking its title from a contemporary song, opens on Aug. 8, 1862, with a recruitment scene at what was then Camp Fair Oaks at the still extant Flemington Fairgrounds -- one of the many gatherings held throughout the state and sponsored by prominent citizens who, the author writes, "had no intention of entering the army themselves." Mr. Bilby says they appealed to local pride, exploited the fear of a possible draft and pledged bounty money to the volunteers.
While the 947 soldiers mostly "accepted the correctness of their cause," many, like his grandfather's cousin, an unemployed carpenter, sought escape from economic woes.
In less than three years, 240 soldiers died -- more casualties than in any other unit in the state and 12th in losses among the country's 2,000 Union regiments.
The courageous facts of history remain, but the distinction of "Three Rousing Cheers" is that its intimate profiles of the volunteers who became seasoned fighters reconstruct a war that seems to have happened yesterday.
"Forgotten Warriors" ($7.95, paper), which is Mr. Bilby's second book, is a valuable start that encourages further research into a particularly poignant omission of black history.
Until 1863 -- two years after the outbreak of hostilities -- New Jersey black men "who wanted to fight had to look elsewhere," because the state's officials ignored their military potential, Mr. Bilby writes, adding that apparently 2,782 black "Jerseymen" served in the Union cause. He cites particularly First Sgt. George Ashby of Allentown, in Monmouth County, and of the 45th United States Colored Infantry -- still alert at 100 in 1944 and following the news of World War II.
Since 1980, Mr. Bilby has worked as an investigator for the Department of Labor in Trenton, a job that no doubt honed his skills at unearthing the letters, diaries, memoirs, photos and official records that pack these histories.
His publisher, Longstreet House in Hightstown, prints books only about the Civil War and New Jersey history. The firm, said its editor, Dr. David G. Martin, is named for the New Jersey branch of the Longstreet family famed for a Confederate general, James Longstreet.
 
Poetry Celebration
 When does a magazine stop resembling a magazine? Look to The Quarterly Review of Literature, based in Princeton, for the answer.
Now 50 years old, it has not been a quarterly 1968, despite the name. It is an annual poetry publication that awards $1,000 each to four to six poets and then combines the winners' books in one volume, which is sold by subscription, at $20 a year.
The Review pokes holes in the notion that married couples wisely do not work together; its co-editors, Theodore Weiss and Renee Karol Weiss, married in 1941. He taught English and creative writing at Princeton University from 1968 to 1986 and is the author of 12 books of poems; she, a violinist and author of children's books, also writes poetry.
Mr. Weiss described the publication's beginnings as "the experience of piloting a literary cargo" through perilous waters. What came forth is an influential literary publication that has printed the work of many famous poets and provided a voice to those less well known like James Dickey, John Gardner, W. S. Merwin and James Wright.
All this permanence called for a celebration -- a continuing one, to be sure -- first with "Quarterly Review of Literature: 50th Anniversary Anthology," a 576-page collection of new poems by Review winners, representing 15 countries, along with a selection of poems previously printed ($40; $20 paper from QRL, 26 Haslet Avenue, Princeton 08540). Next came a series of events to end with a program and reception at the New School in Manhattan on April 26 at 8 P.M. Admission is $5.
 
Colorful Folk Tale
 When "Marushka's Egg" is read on the White House lawn today, it will be the second Easter in a row for this lively Russian folk tale for children, written by Elsa Okon Real and illustrated by Joanna Wezyk, who also stages a puppet show to accompany the reading.
For Ms. Wezyk, a 28-year-old resident of Elizabeth, who left her family in Poland to arrive alone in the United States five years ago, the honor holds special meaning because "my strong desire to illustrate books brought me here," she said.
In 1989, she received a Master of Fine Arts degree from the Academy of Fine Arts in Cracow with a major in children's book art. But she said she was discouraged by the inferior paper and the insistence on black-and-white drawings in her native land.
"Marushka's Egg" revels in color. The vivid story (Macmillan, $14.95) features doll-like Marushka and her captor, Baba Yaga, a wily witch and probably the best-known character in East European folklore. Ms. Wezyk uses, she said, "memories of artwork I cherish from my childhood" in her festive -- indeed, more festive than scary -- depictions of Baba Yaga, whose forest house stands on chicken legs and who gets around in a flying mortar and pestle.
But whence the inspiration for the image of Marushka? Well, that's another story. Soon after arriving in Elizabeth, Ms. Wezyk worked as a nanny for the Harms family in East Brunswick, and the rosy-cheeked, golden-haired Marushka, who finally triumphs over Baba Yaga, was, she said, modeled after Chrissie Harms -- "the little girl I loved taking care of."

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By DAVID WALTON 

 BODY:

CORRESPONDENCE
THE LAST WORD
Letters Between Marcia Nardi
and William Carlos Williams.
Edited by Elizabeth Murrie O'Neil.
University of Iowa,
cloth, $34.95; paper, $16.95. 
 In 1942, the poet Marcia Nardi consulted William Carlos Williams in his medical office, and for several months afterward they corresponded. Williams was then 59 and had not yet received full recognition as a poet. Nardi was unpublished and unemployed, with a troublesome 15-year-old son. She wrote eloquently and despairingly about being an unwed mother, being forced to accept menial labor to support herself and her son. Williams was sympathetic and tried to console her; however, Nardi's letters grew ever more demanding, to the point where Williams finally broke off the correspondence. Crushed, Nardi continued to write to him to plead her case as a woman, a poet and a legitimate claimant to Williams's aid and attention. Williams published two of these letters in his 1946 book-length poem, "Patterson," and lost track of Nardi. In 1949 she saw the book in a store and wrote to Williams asking for a copy, enclosing 20 new poems. Williams was enthusiastic about them and their correspondence resumed, on friendlier terms. Williams helped Nardi to get published and to get grants. She soon was writing at greater and greater length, making more and more outrageous appeals. Nardi, who died in 1990, was a Dickensian character of astonishing proportions, but also a poet of merit. The independent scholar Elizabeth Murrie O'Neil's collection of the correspondence, "The Last Word," does justice to what was not merely a literary footnote but a stunted, tragic career.
 DAVID WALTON

HEADLINE: After Winning Years, A Pioneer Bows Out

BYLINE: By MARY CUMMINGS 

 BODY:
WINE is a small glamour industry on eastern Long Island, and news of shifts and shakeouts in the business travel quickly. There are 17 wineries on the East End, with 3 on the South Fork. So when Lyle Greenfield offered his Bridgehampton Winery for sale in February, he knew that the word would "fly through the grapevine faster than electric current," as he put it.
Even outside the industry interest has been high. Mr. Greenfield was a pioneer on the South Fork, planting his first vines in 1979 and building the first winery in the Hamptons, in 1982. A past president of the Long Island Wine Council, he is known as a tireless promoter of Long Island wines and a hands-on vintner. 
 His decision to call it quits after 15 years inevitably raises questions about the viability of wine making in the Hamptons.
Doubters were reminded that two years ago another South Fork winery fell on hard times. In 1992, Barclays Bank foreclosed on Alan Barr's Le Reve Winery in Water Mill. After changing the name to the Southampton Winery, the bank continued operations while seeking a buyer.
Last month the owner of the largest vineyard on Long Island, Pindar Vineyards in Peconic on the North Fork, Dr. Herodotus Damianos of Stony Brook, announced the purchase of the imposing chateau-style winery and 56 acres of vineyards.
If that venture proves successful, it will be another encouraging development on the South Fork, where Sagpond Vineyards in Sagaponack, is adding acreage to cultivate grapes this year and where the owner, Christian Wolffer, is building what he calls a "state of the art winery."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Greenfield, who is seeking a buyer willing to pay $228,000 for his winery business with an option to buy the buildings and a four-acre site for an additional $390,000, aligns himself with the optimists. In an interview he stressed his continued confidence in the South Fork potential to produce high-end wines and acknowledged mistakes and miscalculations as an agricultural entrepreneur.
 
Open House for Potential Buyers
 Mr. Greenfield, who spends his weekends in the Hamptons and weekdays in New York City overseeing Bang Music, which produces jingles for commercials, was in Bridgehampton early last month preparing to greet potential buyers at a two-day open house.
He acknowledged that he knew since the summer that he would have to put the winery on the market, but that it would have been "detrimental to my business to discuss it in the middle of the season."
Mr. Greenfield was no longer growing grapes. The winery, which had made up to 4,000 cases a year at its peak, had ceased production. The 1992 vintage was the last bottled by Mr. Greenfield and his wine maker, Richard Olsen-Harbich, who worked with him for 11 years and garnered more than 75 state, national and international awards.
Bridgehampton gained major notice in 1988, when The Wine Spectator rated its Grand Vineyard Chardonnay among the top 100 wines of the year worldwide. Mr. Olsen-Harbich was also credited with gaining Federal approval for the South Fork as a wine-growing region with an official appellation in 1985. Approval for the North Fork followed in 1986.
Activity at Bridgehampton is at a standstill. Mr. Greenfield said the site he chose in 1979 was a poor location for growing grapes. The soil is good, he added, but the low-lying area traps frost.
Experts generally agree that the South Fork is somewhat less hospitable to grapes than the North Fork because it is more humid, less sunny and has a slightly shorter growing season. But Mr. Greenfield said the effort to salvage the vineyard, despite "very serious frost damage" and endless battles to control persistent regrowth on cleared land, had cost $500,000 over the years.
Even as he was struggling to overcome his vinicultural problems, Mr. Greenfield said, the winery functioned by processing the fruit of other growers on the North and South Forks.
"This is similar to what the French do, as well as a number of wineries in California," he said. "In the past several years Bridgehampton production has been from the fruit of other growers on the North Fork entirely. Every vineyard has a sweet spot and a best day for harvesting."
Mr. Greenfield said he was convinced that by shopping at North Fork sites and buying from the best of each yield Bridgehampton could create wines that would demonstrate just how high Long Island could climb in competitions among premium wines. The series that they called the Grand Vineyard Selection brought the critical acclaim and restaurant orders.
"Even a difficult French restaurant like Le Bernardin was calling to order our Grand Vineyard Selection Chardonnay," Mr. Greenfield recounted. "And a California wine writer, Anthony Dias Blue, put it on his 10-best list for the year."
The original vineyard is gone, most of it sold to a developer who hopes that a golf course will thrive where grapes did not.
Mr. Greenfield says he can offer "equity in this label and this brand, a pre-existing interest in the marketplace for this wine." Adding luster to are the labels that Mr. Greenfield designed with his sister. A set of labels is in the permanent collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan.
Like Mr. Greenfield, a new owner would depend on off-site vineyards for his fruit. A recent issue of The Wine Press, an East End publication, reports that the region has 40 growers and 17 wineries, numbers that do not assure a steady supply of grapes for independent wineries or a steady market for growers without wineries, the report suggested.
 
Not Like the Napa Valley
 That market is necessarily erratic. Some wineries continue to sell part of what they grow, and others continue to buy part of what they need each year.
"A lot of it depends on the year and on how their own vineyards are doing," Alice Wyse of Cornell Cooperative Extension said. A vintner who has sold out his chardonnay from a previous vintage may decide to space for his own use the next year, Ms. Wyse said, adding:
"You have to realize that production is relatively small. It's not like the Napa Valley, where there are 200 wineries. Here there are 17."
Mr. Greenfield, who was apparently able to obtain the grapes that he needed, said the problem was more a matter of cost than availability.
"The economics of scale just aren't there," he said. "In a business that is so capital intensive there is an important leg that just has to be under the table. You can't float these businesses on a wing and a prayer."
Mr. Greenfield said he could not think of anyone in the business who would deny that the experience had been "anything less than a trying and difficult adventure." And yet, he said, they all remain committed to promoting Long Island wines, and "very few are talking about getting out of the business."
"The bottom line is that it is impossible for me to carry on alone in a business that now needs to be recapitalized," he said.
"It is a very capital-intensive undertaking," confirmed Mr. Wolffer, who has planted 40 acres with merlot and chardonnay grapes at his Sagpond Vineyards in Sagaponack. By Mr. Wolffer's calculations, it takes eight years to make an operating profit and that, he said, "would not take into consideration all the capital improvements."
"You have to have either funds or partners available to do it," he added. "Bridgehampton and Southampton Winery has shown that with debt you cannot finance a vineyard."
As president of Euro Investors Property Inc., which operates globally, Mr. Wolffer, like Dr. Damianos, appears to deeper pockets than Mr. Greenfield. Mr. Wolffer is improving his soil in Bridgehampton and said that with the help of his wine maker, Roman Roth, he can keep the South Fork in the limelight as a wine region.
"If you produce a good grape, you can certainly produce a good wine if you have good wine maker," he said.
That view was supported by Dr. Damianos, who stressed that North Fork vintners had a head start. They have had more time to learn from successes and failures, he said, suggesting that there was no reason why the South Fork should not follow the same path. "With the right grapes and the right kind of cultural practices, it is an extremely viable cultural area," he said.
Mr. Greenfield said he was talking with prospective buyers. "I hope someone will come in and take advantage of me and my mistakes and continue with the Bridgehampton winery," he said. "The toughest thing to imagine is that it just wouldn't exist after 15 years of effort and achievements."

HEADLINE: Let's All Complain About Postal Rates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It has been suggested that, because the nominal price of first-class postage is about where it was in the late 18th century, Americans who complain about the proposal to increase postal rates are merely whining wimps who are lacking in historical perspective. 
 However, the real price of transportation (a key input in postal service) has plummeted over the last 200 years. In 1799 it took 53 days for an Army courier to travel from Detroit to Pittsburgh.
Today the same trip can conveniently be made in minutes. Likewise, the productive efficiency of the United States is vastly greater now than it was even a few decades ago.
Given the plunge in transportation costs, joined with other technological improvements and a large increase in the scale of postal activity, the price of postage should have fallen dramatically.
Americans do not oppose postal-rate increases because of their ignorance of history.
Rather, opposition to these increases grows from the correct perception that a legally protected monopolist such as the United States Postal Service can keep prices higher, and service inferior, to what these would be under competition.
Regardless of how today's postal rates compare with rates in the past, opening the delivery of first-class mail to competition would lower rates still further while improving service.
 
DONALD J. BOUDREAUX, G. A. SELGIN
Clemson, S.C., March 24, 1994
 
The writers are, respectively, an associate professor of legal studies at Clemson University and an assistant professor of economics at the University of Georgia, Athens.

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SAYS INTEREST RATE RISE MAY SLOW GROWTH

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With long-term interest rates now above 7 percent, President Clinton's top economic advisers expressed concern over the weekend that further rate increases could damage the economy and slow growth to an unacceptable level.
The Administration argues that the economy is going through a transition from very strong growth in last year's fourth quarter to less growth now. But no one can tell where the leveling-off point will be. The concern is that if interest rates rise another notch, economic growth could decline too much -- slowing the creation of new jobs. 
 "Based on what we know, our view of how strongly the economy will grow this year is not changed by an interest rate in the neighborhood of 7 percent," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "But if the level goes much above 7 percent, then that would exercise a contractionary effect on the economy."
Long-term interest rates rose nearly three-quarters of a percentage point during the last month, reaching 7.26 percent on Friday in a bond-trading session shortened in observance of Good Friday. Not since the early 1980's have rates increased so much in a single month, and the comments by Ms. Tyson and other Administration officials seemed clearly aimed at calming the markets.
The Administration's new concerns could put it in open conflict for the first time with the Federal Reserve Board, whose chief priority has been to control inflation even at the cost of economic growth. The Administration's priority has been creation of jobs through economic expansion, even at the possible cost of an inflation rate that is mildly higher than what the Fed might accept.
While Fed officials have expressed surprise at the rapid run-up in interest rates, they have not indicated whether they agree with Ms. Tyson and other Administration officials that 7 percent is as high as rates can go without choking economic growth.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, in an interview yesterday, also expressed concern about rates rising any farther. Mr. Bentsen and, separately, Robert Rubin, the President's chief economic adviser, in a television appearance on "This Week," said they expected interest rates to fall back once the bond markets settle down.
"I think the underlying economic fundamentals will in the end have their influence," Mr. Bentsen said. When that happens, Ms. Tyson expects interest rates to come back into line with the economy's true strength.
"Based on history, the normal level today for long-term interest rates should be about a percentage point below what they are now," she said.
Their views were clearly a signal to Wall Street and its traders to end what might come to be known as the great interest rate "crash" of 1994.
What has crashed, in fact, is bond prices, particularly the price for the Treasury's 30-year bond. As they have gone down, so has the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average has lost nearly 9 percent of its value since the end of January.
On Wall Street, when bond prices fall, that perversely makes interest rates rise. When a $1,000 bond paying $60 annually, or 6 percent in interest, falls to a price of $825, because bondholders are selling in a panic, then the rate, in effect, rises for the person acquiring a $1,000 bond for only $825.
For the new buyer, the $60 annual interest payment continues unchanged, but now it represents a 7.26 percent return on his $825 investment. And that is how much rates have jumped in recent months, with much of the rise coming in March.
The 30-year Treasury bond in particular is a benchmark for home construction loans, mortgages and car loans, the industries that made the economy boom in the fourth quarter, mainly because rates had fallen so low. Now rates are rising, largely because speculators had bought bonds with borrowed money, gambling that the weak economy that had prevailed since 1989 would keep bond prices high and interest rates low.
But those buyers changed their minds and started dumping bonds to repay debts after the Federal Reserve, for the first time in five years, raised rates on Feb. 4. The Fed acted out of concern that the unexpectedly strong economic growth in recent months might raise the inflation rate later this year. But the bond market took the Fed's action as a signal that the long boom in bond prices was over, that higher inflation was on the way back and that bondholders had better get out.
 
Braking a Swift Selloff
 Their rapid exodus gave the bond market a momentum of its own, and as bond prices fell, rates rose far more than what either the Fed or the Administration had anticipated. It is this momentum that the Administration is trying to arrest, but in doing so it raises the potential for disagreement with the Fed.
While the Administration endorsed the Fed's rate increase on Feb. 4 and another small one on March 22, the subsequent run-up in rates is forcing the administration to be more insistent that inflation is mild, indeed milder than the Fed might believe.
Still, the White House avoids criticism of the Fed or its chairman, Alan Greenspan.
"There is a feeling in the Administration that we respect the guy and he is trying to do the right thing," a senior economic adviser in the Administration said. "He may be wrong; he may be right. But he is trying to achieve the same goals we are."
The main goal is mild inflation. Ms. Tyson and Mr. Rubin say inflation is mild now and seems very likely to stay mild -- a declaration that no one at the Federal Reserve has publicly matched in recent weeks. Despite the increase in interest rates, the Council of Economic Advisers, which Ms. Tyson heads, sticks to its forecast: the annual inflation rate, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, might rise to 3.5 percent in the months ahead from 3 percent today, an acceptable increase brought on by a gradually strengthening economy.
If the economy grows gradually, then the normal 30-year bond rate should be between 6 percent and 6.5 percent, Ms. Tyson said, or roughly a percentage point less than the level reached last week.
Mr. Rubin yesterday also predicted that the inflation rate was most likely to remain at a moderate 3 percent to 3.5 percent in the months ahead. That is in line with an economy that the Administration says will settle down this year and early next year to an annual growth rate of between 2.5 percent and 3 percent -- enough growth to continue to create new jobs.
 
Two Causes Suggested
 Given this projection, there are two explanations for the unexpected jump in interest rates, Ms. Tyson said. "One is that the economy is stronger than we have been predicting," she said, "and the other is that the market is going through an adjustment that has to do with loans and losses that needed to be covered in a period of time."
Ms. Tyson said that bond prices might be responding both to the speculation and to an economy that is momentarily growing more strongly than anticipated. "There is agreement in the Administration that it is both factors," she said. "But no one knows yet how much weight to ascribe to each one."
The uncertainty made the surge in employment in March, reported by the Labor Department on Friday, particularly difficult to read. The Labor Department said that while the unemployment rate remained at 6.5 percent, the same as in February, the economy had created 456,000 jobs, the biggest one-month increase in years.
Such job gains suggest stronger growth than the Administration's estimate. But Ms. Tyson and other Administration officials, among them Alicia Munnell, the Treasury Department's assistant secretary for economic policy, said that the proper way to interpret March's job figures was to average the 456,000 figure with job growth in January and February -- a process that produces an average monthly gain of slightly more than 200,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: Crusading for Harmony as a Skinhead Spy;
Repentant Racist to Go Into Hiding After Giving Data on New Jersey's Neo-Nazis

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., March 31

 BODY:
Dominick Bruno Jr. says he first took a razor to his scalp when he was 15, submitting to the rites of a neo-Nazi skinhead gang that prowled the mall-encrusted landscape of suburban New Jersey. Soon he was preaching bigotry in the schoolyard and flooding increasingly diverse neighborhoods with fliers that said, "Deport Niggers, Spiks, Jews!"
But recently, something snapped in Mr. Bruno, a leader of the S.S. Action Group, one of the more virulent skinhead gangs. He said he began to feel repulsed by the subculture he had embraced: the bristling hostility to nonwhites, the throbbing racist music from Germany and Britain called oi, the violent teen-agers who seemed little more than small-town losers hungry for attention. 
 So, he said, he quit. But first, he became a spy.
He will go into hiding soon, he said, having given anti-racist groups reams of information about neo-Nazis that seem to provide a rare glimpse into the workings of a shadowy movement whose growth has alarmed the authorities in both the United States and abroad. When he surfaces, he will still be a zealot, he said, only this time he will crusade for racial harmony.
 
Fancies of Being Master Propagandist
 "I don't have it in me anymore," Mr. Bruno, now 18, said in an interview at the apartment he shares with his father. He recalled how he once fancied himself a master propagandist, spending hours a day at a computer in his swastika-adorned bedroom, chain-smoking as he wrote to racists around the world and fashioned incendiary pamphlets, fliers and letters to the editor.
"It was just seeming more and more stupid to me," he said. "My beliefs slowly drifted further and further away, until I reached a point where it was the exact opposite."
He said there was no one incident that inspired the turnaround, though he was impressed by anti-bias literature from the New Jersey Freedom Organization, a nonpartisan advocacy group that lobbies for opportunities for young people. When he resolved to resign, he called Cliff Smith, the group's 24-year-old president, seeking help, Mr. Smith said. Mr. Bruno says that the people of New Jersey may be skeptical of his conversion, perhaps remembering the many times he marched down their streets in military fatigues, taunting passers-by with the straight-armed fascist salute and calling for a white homeland in North America.
And even if everything he says is true, it remains to be seen whether Mr. Bruno, a high-school dropout with a short, slight frame, will return to bigotry in the future. For now, the anti-racist groups that he has assisted are cautious. But they say that so far, Mr. Bruno is credible.
"I would accept him as legitimate," said Irwin Suall, an expert on neo-Nazis at the Anti-Defamation League in New York, adding, "A number of things that he spoke of correspond with information that we know to be accurate."
Mr. Suall said the intelligence that Mr. Bruno was turning over to the league was "quite valuable," particularly details on how American neo-Nazis exchange information, music and aid with those in Germany, Britain and other countries.
 
Worried About Safety
 But Mr. Suall also said he was worried about Mr. Bruno's safety. "The skinheads are so impulsive and mindless in their behavior, so violence-oriented, that they are not going to weigh the pros and cons of going after him," Mr. Suall said. "They are simply going to try and seek revenge quickly."
The Anti-Defamation League says that there are as many as 30 skinhead gangs in New Jersey with about 400 members, but that because they are made up of teen-agers and people in their early 20's, the groups tend to be loosely organized. Mr. Bruno said he thought the number of members was closer to 250, though he said he regularly heard of gangs' springing up.
The gangs use names like Eastern Hammerskins, White Rights Union, Aryan Glory Skins, Doc Marten Skins and the Skinhead Assault Crew. The total for New Jersey is among the highest in the country, but officials in Trenton say it is unfair to compare New Jersey with other states because it is one of the few with systems to report bias crimes.
 
Recent New Jersey Violence
 In recent years, there have been a number of violent incidents in New Jersey involving neo-Nazis, including one in Keansburg in 1992 in which 12 skinheads were arrested on attempted murder and other charges. They were accused of attacking an acquaintance because he had a Hispanic friend.
Several were tried and convicted, the police said.
"The younger neo-Nazis are increasingly turning to acts of violence and vandalism," Mr. Bruno wrote in an 11-page report for the Anti-Defamation League that included the names, addresses and phone numbers of scores of neo-Nazis and other racists in New Jersey and elsewhere.
Through he considered himself a "full-time racial activist," Mr. Bruno said he was never arrested for violence, which he said he had disavowed except when provoked. But he was expelled from several schools for disciplinary problems. And the police said they had been monitoring him closely for months. He said he had not told officials that he was quitting, but he said he hoped to work with them on anti-bias campaigns.
The skinhead activity in New Jersey may be fueled by a recession that has wiped out many blue-collar jobs, stoking the resentment of working-class whites, and by the changing makeup of the suburbs in the nation's most densely populated state.
 
'Trying to Keep Them Out'
 "The minorities are starting to come out of the cities and they are coming into our towns, selling their drugs here, doing their robberies here, and we're trying to keep them out," said Douglas Moditz, 19, who started the S.S. Action Group four years ago in New Jersey. Mr. Moditz, once a close friend of Mr. Bruno, apparently did not know that Mr. Bruno has betrayed the group.
Though the S.S. Action Group has not been linked to serious violence, its two or three dozen members in the state have created an uproar by distributing tens of thousands of racist fliers and holding marches in Edison, Carteret, Woodbridge, Rahway, Linden and other central New Jersey communities.
"We've received a lot of complaints," said Robert W. Gluck, the Middlesex County Prosecutor. "People were obviously very offended."
The authorities in Winfield in Union County arrested Mr. Bruno, Mr. Moditz and two other gang members in early February on disorderly conduct charges. The case is about to be dismissed on First Amendment grounds.
 
Helping the Arch-Enemy
 Mr. Bruno began discussing his life as a neo-Nazi skinhead after he was contacted by a reporter about his arrest. After three interviews, he revealed that he was dropping out and helping the Anti-Defamation League, which many racist groups consider a kind of arch-enemy.
He said he became a skinhead for some of the same reasons other teen-agers enter gangs, from the Bloods and the Crips to the Latin Kings: camaraderie and an outlet for anger.
"In some ways it's another form of teen-age rebellion," he said. "It's starts off that way. But then you start getting the literature and you start getting more into it and then it's not rebellion anymore; you're in the movement. That's what happened to me."
He said the Ku Klux Klan, the Christian Posse Comitatus, the New Order and other long-established racist groups exert influence over skinhead gangs but generally do not control them. The S.S. Action Group obtained much of its literature by tapping into a network of white-power groups, including one based in West Virginia, he said. The groups are also eager to give legal and organizational advice.
 
100,000 Printed Pieces
 The S.S. Action Group traveled to marches and paid for printing from donations sent to its post office box in Colonia, which is stamped on its fliers. Mr. Bruno said the gang handed out more than 100,000 pieces of literature in 1993, a figure that officials do not dispute. People often joined after reading the literature.
Mr. Bruno said he was hoping to patch up relations with family members and others who had rejected him when he became a skinhead. He is also trying to figure out what to do about a $20 tattoo on his lower arm: a swastika coiled around a cross.
"I've been too happy since I got rid of the movement," he said. "That's another reason I want to speak out to kids. You lose so much. It's almost impossible to get a job. You lose all your friends. I kind of like to look at this as being cool timing because it's around Easter, which is about rebirth. I have a new outlook, a new life, a new way of living."

HEADLINE: Development Overtakes Island's Black Culture

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DAUFUSKIE ISLAND, S.C., April 4

 BODY:
In the quiet glens and sandy lanes of Daufuskie Island, the descendants of slaves consider nearby Hilton Head, with its expensive cars, condominiums and manicured golf courses, as almost another world.
But development is crossing Calibogue Sound, and longtime residents of this isolated island worry that growth and higher taxes may drive them from their homes. 
 "We're becoming an endangered species," said Yvonne Wilson, whose ancestors were slaves. One or two black families typically leave the island each year, and people like Mrs. Wilson hope that incentives can be found to encourage others to stay.
The island, with a history rooted in sea island cotton, timber and Union occupation during the Civil War, was a thriving fishing community of almost 1,000 people about 40 years ago, before pollution from the Savannah River destroyed the oyster beds.
 
An Ebb of Jobs and People
 Jobs and residents drifted away, and the unique culture and language of Daufuskie and other islands along the Southeast seacoast began to ebb. The dominant tongue on the islands used to be a mix of African and English dialects called Gullah, but the last census showed that only about 180 people in South Carolina spoke it at home.
Daufuskie's population had dwindled to about 60 when developers began buying large tracts on the 12-square-mile island in 1984. Now antebellum-style houses and developments line the shore, and 150 people, one-third of them black, call the island home. Several thousand people are expected to be living here within a decade, which worries some of the old-time islanders.
"When I was coming up, we were all as one," Mrs. Wilson said. "We all had clothes. They may not have been new, but we were all together. Now you look around and see $100,000 houses."
Those who stayed did so out of a deep-rooted love for the island, which can be reached only by boat. They work here or commute by boat to jobs elsewhere. Students in middle and high school have a 45-minute boat ride to Hilton Head for classes.
 
A Positive Perspective
 Twice a month, the Rev. Marion C. Taylor takes a ferry across Calibogue Sound to preach at the island's 126-year-old Union Baptist Church, with its wood stove, cross of tree limbs and simple white, wooden pillars.
"There are those of the feeling they are slowly being pushed off the island," the 68-year-old minister said. "But I'm of the feeling development has helped" by bringing jobs and opportunities. Private developments provide work for about 25 residents.
Developers say they are trying to do their part to help the old-time islanders. Jim Hardy, the manager of the Haig Point Plantation development, which is owned by International Paper, says his company has built an emergency clinic, made loans to small businesses and provided free golf lessons to students.
The company has also spent nearly $200,000 on various island projects and intends to bid on the school ferry contract, with the goal of expanding service to make it more convenient.
 
'Conrack' School Operating
 Children still attend the two-room elementary school where the writer Pat Conroy taught in the 1960's and on which he based his novel "The Water Is Wide," which in turn inspired the 1974 movie "Conrack." A larger school is planned, as is a center to provide government services to an island that until 20 years ago did not even have a telephone.
Ervin Simmons, a county social service worker who lives on Daufuskie and works on the mainland, says that islanders worry too much about the developers and not enough about building their own futures.
"I don't want to see us spending too much time pointing at those who would not do for us, and develop self-reliance," he said.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People plans to work with banks, investors and islanders to develop a conference center and a small inn near the Baptist church, which has long been the island's focal point of spiritual and cultural life.
The group's Southeastern regional field director, Nelson Rivers III, said that "we're going to make sure Daufuskie Island doesn't turn into Hilton Head," where longtime islanders were often pushed aside by development. "We're going to make sure when the goodness comes, it is shared by everybody," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The construction of expensive new homes like these on Daufuskie Island, S.C., is worrying some longtime residents, many of whom are the descendants of slaves. But others hope that, properly managed, development will provide jobs and incentives for the islanders to stay. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

HOSPITAL PARTNERS, BIG AND SMALL
Economic pressures in the health care industry are causing big-name medical centers in the New York area to pursue affiliations with small hospitals. The result is the emergence of a few huge hospital networks and a constantly shifting landscape of hospital alliances that make Balkan politics seem simple. Such consolidation is taking place all over the country, but is most striking in New York, where hospitals until recently have turned a blind eye to the inevitable arrival of managed care. A1. 

NEW YORK CITY
 
DRUG PROGRAM: SOFT OR SENSIBLE?
At a time when the Federal Government and many state legislatures are considering measures to keep repeat offenders in prison longer, a Brooklyn drug-treatment program represents a small but firm tug in the opposite direction: toward keeping them out of prison altogether. Proponents say the program keeps scarce prison cells available for the most violent criminals, saves money and, by reducing addictions, cuts crime in the long run. B3.
 
FIRE GUTS BROOKLYN TENEMENTS
A four-alarm fire roared through a row of four tenement buildings in a Brooklyn waterfront community on the East River. No one was killed, but 21 people were injured, some as they were rescued from fiery rooms, and 25 families were left homeless by the blaze, which gutted the three-story attached frame buildings on Huron Street in Greenpoint. B3.
 
GANG ARRESTS REPORTED
A leader and a person described as the senior executioner of one of New York's most violent drug gangs, the Wild Cowboys -- which controlled the cocaine trade in parts of Washington Heights and the South Bronx -- were captured in the Dominican Republic, the police said. With the arrests, investigators said, all 41 gang members named in two indictments of the Wild Cowboys last year are now in custody. Charged with a host of crimes, including 10 murders and multiple assaults, drug sales, conspiracy and witness tampering, all face maximum sentences of 25 years to life if convicted of the most serious charges. B7.
 
HELPING HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS
With $300,000 from the German Government, social workers are going to Brooklyn groceries and butcher shops, synagogues and bus stations in search of aging survivors of Nazi persecution who need help. Finding them will not be simple. Many have deteriorating physical or emotional health and live alone. But Selfhelp Community Services has long experience and knows where to look. Selfhelp estimates that there are more than 6,000 Holocaust survivors living in Brooklyn, mainly in the neighborhoods of Brighton Beach, Sheepshead Bay, Borough Park, Canarsie and Kensington. B7.
 
REGION
 
A CRISIS ON THE BENCH
One in eight Federal judgeships are empty nationwide, forcing many active judges to double their caseloads. Some senior judges are taking on as many cases at age 80 as they did at 45 to help their younger colleagues. And criminal cases have all but pushed civil cases off the docket. In the New York area, the problem has been particularly acute. But who exactly is to blame for the long-running vacancies is a matter of debate. B6.
 
TROUBLING QUESTIONS ON CHURCH DEAL
The Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America is trying to extricate itself from legal claims and troubling questions surrounding a multimillion-dollar real estate transaction in Westchester County. Leaders of the church, the largest body of Orthodox Christians in the United States, hope a proposed $7 million settlement can put to rest questions about the deal raised by some church members. Meanwhile, the New York State Attorney General has gone to court seeking access to financial records surrounding the transaction. B6.
 
MANY WAYS OF REJOICING
The faithful celebrated the Resurrection atop the Empire State Building and beside a hot-dog vendor on Fifth Avenue. They prayed in Korean and Polish, knelt at St. John the Divine in Manhattan and sang loud at New Hope Baptist Church in Queens. Some took part in a Latin Mass at Ave Maria Chapel in Westbury, L.I., while others acted out the betrayal of Christ by Judas in street plays in midtown Manhattan. B6.
