HEADLINE: MARKETS IN TURMOIL: WASHINGTON REACTION;
Fed Disinclined to Act On Short-Term Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The tumble of the stock and bond markets has surprised Federal Reserve officials but has not persuaded them so far to change short-term interest rates.
Fed officials say they are inclined for now to let investors determine the prices of shares or long-term interest rates, over which the central bank exerts limited influence. 
 "I don't think that we should be in the business of trying to, in effect, speculate ourselves on what long-term interest rates should be," said Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Fed governor.
In an interview this morning, Mr. Kelley also doubted that share prices would continue their steep decline. "It's hard for me to see how they can go to pieces in the context of a strong economy," he said.
President Clinton, in Cleveland for a baseball game, sought to reassure bond investors today. "Interest rates are still lower than they were at the bottom of the recession," he said in an interview with NBC Newschannel. "I think they're too high. I think they'll come back down."
 
Direction Is Unclear
 Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said Mr. Clinton was referring to long-term interest rates, which averaged 8.29 percent for 30-year Treasury bonds at the bottom of the recession in March 1991.
It is not clear in which direction the Fed would move if it changed short-term rates. Private economists think it would raise rates to slow economic growth and reassure the bond markets that inflation was under control.
But such an increase would make stocks, with their fixed dividends, even less attractive to investors than money market funds, possibly driving the stock market down further. Lowering short-term rates would make stocks more appealing but risk further harm to bond markets.
Susan M. Phillips, another Fed governor, also said she had few worries about the financial markets. "We're certainly watching them," she said in an interview tonight. "I can't go as far as alarm."
While investors may be hurt by the recent downturn, she said, the stock market remains high enough to fulfill its basic economic function of providing financing for companies. On Thursday she said that "when the stock market is no longer capable of providing a source of financing, that seems to be more of a consideration" in setting monetary policy.
 
Fed Funds Rate Raised
 The Fed raised the interest rate for overnight loans between banks, the Fed funds rate, on Feb. 4 and again on March 22. The two increases, each a quarter percentage point, have pushed this rate up to 3.5 percent.
Long-term interest rates rose after the first rate increase but dropped temporarily after the second. Higher short-term rates tend to slow economic growth and inflation, reassuring investors that if they lend money for long periods they will not be repaid in dollars heavily devalued by inflation.
Economists say that the first increase failed to reassure investors, even alarming them by signaling that the Fed was worried about inflation.
Fed officials are acutely aware that any move to raise or lower the Fed funds rate, which the Fed controls, would have unpredictable effects on stock and bond markets, which the Fed does not control. Long-term rates have risen 1.11 percentage points since Feb. 4, surprising Fed officials, who view the increase as unjustified.
"Given what I would regard as a realistic outlook for inflation, I was surprised they have run up as far as they have," Mr. Kelley said.
 
Effect on Economy Feared
 Administration officials fear that a further rise in long-term rates could slow economic growth.
Mr. Kelley played down the announcement last Friday of a sharp increase in nonfarm jobs during March, saying it was more appropriate to look at the average rate of monthly job creation for the entire first quarter. The average rate was 200,000 jobs a month, as opposed to the 456,000 in March cited by the Labor Department, and Mr. Kelley said such a level did not by itself signal inflation ahead.
"I think it's more useful to focus on a rate of 200,000 a month, and I think there's nothing inherently inflationary for some period of time about that," he said.
But Mr. Kelley said he remained concerned that the economy was growing at a pace that would eventually feed inflation. "As one looks a year out, one has to see a potential for renewed inflationary pressures as we approach full utilization of the economy," he said.
The nation's central bank changed policy sharply after the stock market crash on Oct. 19, 1987, pushing down the interest rate for overnight loans between banks by a full percentage point over the next several months.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Four Seasons Hotels For Sale, With a Catch

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
Isadore Sharp, the Toronto hotelier who founded the Four Seasons chain 34 years ago, has decided to check out of the hotel business.
The catch is, he has no intention of actually packing up and vacating for at least three more years. And in the meantime, he expects the new owners to give him the run of the place. 
 Four Seasons Hotels Inc. has hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it find a buyer. But Mr. Sharp, who controls 20 percent of the company's stock but 80 percent of the votes, said yesterday that he would insist that the buyer postpone the deal's closing for three to five years to allow for a smooth transition.
"What we're talking about is an orderly transition of succession," Mr. Sharp said in an interview. "It's an issue of controlling the process and that's what my control block allows me to do."
Under his proposal, the new owners would buy roughly 22 million public shares outstanding now and would be expected to purchase Mr. Sharp's 5.6 million super-voting shares later at the same price.
Not surprisingly, investors and hotel industry executives said they doubted that many buyers would line up to meet the company on its terms, especially given its well-known financial problems.
 
'Grasping at Straws'
 "They're kind of grasping at straws," said Stephen Bollenbach, the chief executive of Host Marriott, echoing others. His company owns hotel properties and might be interested in plucking up some Four Seasons hotels at the right price.
"Having taken this thing on this nightmare journey, now he wants someone to put money in and let him run it for five years," he said. "Give me a break. Who would do it?"
If Mr. Sharp is used to getting his way, he can be forgiven. Four Seasons operates 45 luxury hotels and resorts around the world, including Chicago's Ritz-Carlton, London's Four Seasons (formerly Inn on the Park) and the new Four Seasons in New York. The hotels are legendary for pampering guests.
Hit by recessions in prime markets, however, the company has had trouble turning a profit. The company has also been beset by real estate problems and questions that it might have overstated its profits through aggressive accounting methods.
 
6 Hotels Put on Block
 Skeptics fear that the company is running out of options, despite signs of a recovery in room rates and occupancies. It put six hotels on the block last year to raise cash, but has yet to announce a sale, partly because of its insistence that it be allowed to retain management contracts.
Yesterday, Four Seasons also announced that it would take a $120 million provision in its soon-to-be-released fourth-quarter results, which could be used to offset losses from 10 company-owned hotels.
Despite the setbacks, company officials insist that the decision to put the whole company on the block had less to do with its real estate and financial problems than with a desire for an orderly succession.
Mr. Sharp, 62, said his son Tony, a Four Seasons executive, had little desire to take over the business. "I came to this decision in concert with him, not against him," the elder Mr. Sharp said. "This is thinking of my family and letting them have their own life without having to be responsible for something I've created."
Choosing to sell, as Mr. Sharp has apparently decided to do, would give him a graceful way out, especially if he can negotiate a premium price for public shareholders. Four Seasons, which trades on the Toronto Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at $11 (Canadian), up 12.5 cents (Canadian). But the stock is way below its high of $21.125 (Canadian) in 1989.
George Domolky, a portfolio manager at Fidelity Investments whose three Canadian funds own Four Seasons stock, said he thought the stock would sell for $15 to $18 a share.
Besides Host Marriott, possible buyers mentioned yesterday include the financier George Soros, Morgan Stanley, Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette and the Blackstone Group.

HEADLINE: Selloff of '94 Continues, With Dow Losing 42.61, to 3,593.35

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In what passes for good news these days, the stock market fell yesterday for the sixth time in the last seven sessions, but it was not the 100-point drop that many analysts had feared.
The number of shares changing hands, although higher than normal, indicated that some traders sat on their hands yesterday, waiting for further developments. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 344.4 million shares, or only 15 percent more than a typical day's volume, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 42.61 points, to 3,593.35. 
 The bond market, by contrast, was in turmoil yesterday. Yet stock traders were heartened that the bond trouble did not seem to stampede the stock market. Indeed, some analysts predicted that the stock market would rally as early as this week.
 
Talking of a Rally
 And the gentler-than-expected drop yesterday prompted some market watchers to predict that the Dow Jones industrial average would again march toward 4,000 later this year. "This is the beginning of the end of the correction," said David D. Holt, vice president of research and strategy at Wedbush Morgan Securities in Los Angeles.
Gold, often the refuge for those alarmed by other financial markets, also seemed to indicate that investors were conducting only a careful selloff of stocks. Gold for June delivery fell $5.60, to $388.70 an ounce.
"It was not nearly as ugly as the doom sayers were predicting," said William R. Rothe, a managing director at Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore.
The Dow fell as much as 83 points yesterday before turning around. It has now dropped some 385 points, or 9.7 percent, from its Jan. 31 peak. A 10 percent market "correction" had been widely expected by analysts.
There has been a similar two-month decline in the S.& P. 500-stock index, which fell 6.84 points yesterday, to 438.92. The S.& P. has fallen some 43 points, down 8.9 percent from its Feb. 2 peak.
 
Big Drop at the Start
 The session started out troubling. A surge in sell orders in the first hour dropped the Dow by more than 50 points, setting off the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breaker" rules intended to slow market declines.
But Big Board officials lifted the circuit breaker shortly after 1 P.M. and the blue-chip index rallied for another hour until turmoil in the bond market again pulled down stocks.
The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, which helps set costs for borrowers ranging from General Motors down to the customer on the car dealer's floor, spiked to 7.44 percent, before settling at 7.41 percent. The surge has added more than a third of a percentage point to the long bond's yield in only five sessions.
Some stock and bond traders spoke of rumors, which turned out to be false, of a secret meeting of the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates. Others cited comments by the economist Henry Kaufman, who predicted that long-term interest rates could rise to as much as 10 percent, although he did not specify when.
Whatever the reason, many analysts contend that bond prices have fallen far out of proportion to economic fundamentals. Frederic T. Leiner, fixed-income market strategist for Continental Bank in Chicago, said the fast run-up in yields "was too much by any of the standards that I'm familiar with in my years in the bond business."
The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 3.92 points, to 243.14. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks by 2,121 to 376. The American Stock Exchange market-value index dropped 8.98 points, to 434.13.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 16.05 points, to 727.41. It has fallen some 77 points, or about 9.5 percent, from its March 18 peak.
Of the 30 component stocks of the Dow industrials, 23 dropped in price, led by J. P. Morgan, which fell 2 3/4, to 60, and Woolworth, which dropped 2 1/8, to 13. Morgan was probably affected by analysts' expectations that rising interest rates would hurt the profits of financial-services companies.
Woolworth was under pressure from recent disclosures of possible financial irregularities and the temporary replacement, pending an investigation, of its chairman and chief financial officer.
Of 500 stocks in the Standard & Poor's index, 423 declined, including Exxon, which dropped 1 7/8, to 61, and General Electric, which fell 2, to 98.
 
Merger Deal Under Fire
 The most active Nasdaq stock was Novell, whose planned acquisition of Wordperfect has been sharply criticized by analysts. It fell 1 1/4, to 16 7/8, on volume of 7.4 million shares.
No. 2 on the Nasdaq most active list was Sun Microsystems, which fell sharply after warning securities analysts on Thursday, following the market's close, that their estimates of third-quarter revenue were too high.
Sun makes high-speed computer work stations and is planning to introduce new products. Anticipating that, some customers delayed buying existing products, cutting into third-quarter sales. Sun closed down 5 3/8, to 22, on volume of 5.6 million shares.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Ascend In 2d Consecutive Selloff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates moved sharply higher yesterday for the second consecutive trading session, with some market participants selling off long-term bonds.
Adding pressure to yesterday's selloff was a move by dealers in other fixed-income investments to hedge against losses by selling their Treasury securities. 
 Although the start of trading yesterday was mostly firmer after plunging in Friday's abbreviated session, Treasury securities soon caved in. The selling on Friday was caused by stronger-than-expected employment data, which heightened investors' fears of inflation.
Even a two-point decline yesterday in the Commodity Research Bureau index, another closely followed indicator of inflation price pressures, failed to subdue the selling pressures.
By late in the day yesterday, the price of the long-term bond was down 121/32 , to 866/32 , yielding 7.41 percent, up from 7.26 percent on Friday. The Treasury bellwether's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, is now at its highest point since Jan. 15, 1993, when it was 7.42 percent.
 
 
Seeking Short-Term Investments
 The discount rate on shorter-maturity bills and yields of intermediate-term notes were also higher, with the volatile stock market forcing some investors to seek the short end of the Treasury market for safety.
A two-year note traded yesterday at a price to yield 5.56 percent, up from 5.40 percent on Friday, while a five-year note rose to 6.62 percent from 6.43 percent. The yield of the 10-year note rose to 7.13 percent, from 6.93 percent on Friday.
Peter Hirsch, the head of the government trading desk at Salomon Brothers, said the bond market was "looking for a level of cheapness, or a price attractive enough to bring in buyers."
Like many other traders, he saw the recent selling as overdone, or beyond the fundamentals. He recalled when the yield on the long bond was as low as 5.78 percent in October 1993, "and that was also beyond market fundamentals." Mr. Hirsch said some of the selloff was by market participants who are younger and have never seen a bear market.
 
 
Derivative Market Hurt
 He also said that derivative investments -- which were not around 5 to 10 years ago -- were now being hurt by the rise in interest rates. As a result, dealers and fund managers have been forced to raise cash quickly by selling Treasury securities to cover redemptions.
The market is so sensitive to inflation that a forecast issued by Henry Kaufman, president of Henry Kaufman & Company, an investment management firm, yesterday morning exacerbated anxieties. Mr. Kaufman said he saw short-term rates in the United States possibly rising to 7 percent and long-term Treasury yields trading in a range of 9 to 10 percent.
Even the monthly survey by the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University, an inflation indicator that does not usually interest the market because four of its components are already known, provoked some selling because of inflation fears.
 
 
'Baby Out With the Bath Water'
 "We're now at the stage when are throwing the baby out with the bath water," said Gerald A. Guild, senior manager of fixed-income investments at Advest Inc.
"Psychologically, this is as bearish as I've seen it, but it's probably a good time to be investing in bonds," Mr. Guild said. "I'm almost convinced that we'll look back and say, 'Why didn't we buy at these levels based on a 5.50 percent real rate of return after inflation?' " He noted that the rate was substantially higher than the real rate of return at the peak of interest rates in 1981.
There were many explanations for yesterday's selloff, Mr. Guild said, citing a huge inventory of mortgage-backed securities as one. He also said that municipal bonds had forced dealers and managers to sell Treasury securities to hedge their positions.
There was some good news yesterday. The National Association of Purchasing Management price index fell to 64.2 percent from 67 percent. The fall in the association's vendor delivery index, to 55.1 percent from 58.8 percent, also gave the market some opportunities to buy.
Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said: "With changes in the costs of financing, leveraged players and a lot of portfolio managers need to stay within certain constraints. As interest rates rise, their circumstances become worse as some products become more interest-rate sensitive."
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: No Details On Budget From Albany

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 4

 BODY:
Three days after they declared a budget deal, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state's legislative leaders still had virtually no details to provide about it today, including which taxes they would cut, how they would divide aid to schools, which construction projects they would finance and how they would allocate money to local governments.
Although the leaders, particularly Mr. Cuomo, were eager to extol their budget, it became increasingly clear through the day that there was no budget to extol. Instead, there was just the skeleton of an agreement, with rough numbers penciled in as totals in a number of broad categories, like tax cuts, state aid to schools and spending on pet construction and maintenance projects. 
 The announcement of the agreement on Friday, the first day of the new fiscal year, dusted off an old ritual in Albany, where political reality and illusion can be difficult to separate. Last year, a minute into the new fiscal year, Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders emerged from a closed-door negotiating session to announce a budget deal and shake hands symbolically. But they provided no details and not until five days later did the budget pass.
About the only thing that was clear today was that the state would have more revenue available for the fiscal 1995 budget than was anticipated even a month ago. Mr. Cuomo and top lawmakers said the state's economy continued to improve beyond expectations in March, adding to the state's revenue base.
 
Conflicting Estimates
 But the Governor was reluctant to say how much new money there was, and lawmakers provided conflicting estimates of between $200 million and $500 million. The state Comptroller's office said official reports on tax collections would not be available for almost 10 days.
"What's happened is that the state has gotten stronger fiscally a lot faster than we expected," Mr. Cuomo said in his only explanation of the improved revenue outlook.
While Friday's agreement ostensibly shows how much additional money would be spent on tax cuts and certain programs, no one could say today exactly where the money would come from and whether total spending would exceed the $33.4 billion that Mr. Cuomo proposed in his budget in January.
If there was any consensus in the Capitol, as budget negotiations continued into the night, it was that the talks have taken on a certain mystical quality at this stage.
"How are they going to pay for all these things?" asked Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat. "That's the magic of the budget."
Senator Joseph L. Bruno, a Saratoga Republican, said, "You need to be a magician to understand these calculations."
Mr. Cuomo, whose audience includes both election-year voters and Wall Street bond raters, was eager to trumpet the budget as if it had been passed and signed.
 
Previously Late Budgets
 "This is an extraordinarily good budget," he said. "It is also neatly balanced, very neatly balanced and that perhaps I am even more happy about. It is definitely a renewal budget."
By declaring that the budget is all but done, even though major decisions are still being negotiated, Mr. Cuomo seemed to want to insulate himself from criticism that the budget is perpetually late.
The state has continued to operate as the negotiations progress because the Legislature last week passed the portion of the budget that pays for the operation of state agencies.
Under the agreement announced on Friday, the state is expected to cut taxes by about $400 million, a relatively small portion of the roughly $30 billion in taxes that the state expects to collect this year. Much of the tax cut is expected to affect business taxes, although there will also be a new tax credit for working poor families. The amounts of those tax cuts have yet to be determined.
Aid to schools would be increased by about $400 million, but there has been no decision on whether the Legislature will tinker with the complex formula that determines how much of the money goes to various school districts. Mr. Cuomo's proposed savings of $185 million from Medicaid programs will be substantially reduced, lawmakers said.
The Legislature is expected to get money for favored capital projects, including appropriations for new construction and improvements to minor league baseball stadiums in the upstate districts of Republican senators and money for repairing aging schools in New York City and its suburbs, where many Assembly Democrats live.

HEADLINE: 'Vinyl Wars' Divide a Hamlet;
Tappan Board's Ban on Siding Angers Some Homeowners

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TAPPAN, N.Y.

 BODY:
This aged hamlet, one of the cradles of the American Revolution, finds itself enduring another revolt, one that is also about life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, though it seems at first to be mostly about vinyl siding.
A group of homeowners here and their sympathizers are rebelling against the rule of the local Historic Areas Board of Review, Tappan's version of a landmarks commission, which was formed three decades ago to preserve the hamlet's 46 historic dwellings, some almost 300 years old, as well as the hoary look of a village founded by farmers and mill hands. 
 The mutinous homeowners, many of whom are working folk themselves, want the right to replace rotting clapboards with vinyl siding, which they say is far less expensive than wood and does not need periodic painting. But the review board argues that synthetic products like vinyl spoil the gently seasoned look of the district and blot out historical details, ruining the buildings. It has barred homeowners from putting vinyl up and ordered the owner of a 1900-vintage house to strip off siding he had installed.
The argument has become known locally as the "Vinyl Wars." More than just a debate over vinyl siding, it pits the public's right to savor its history against the right of private property owners who find preservation an economic hardship.
Indeed, the working-class homeowners say they are being forced to spend cash they need for subsistence so wealthier people can enjoy the pristine look of a worker's village. "It's intruding into people's peace of mind and their bank accounts," said Mary Heaton, who owns a 100-year-old house on the district's edge.
Similar battles over the look, color and material of windows, doorways, and porches are being waged in many of the 1,800 landmark districts nationwide, said Katherine Raub Ridley, counsel to the Preservation League of New York State. In New York City, for example, the look and shape of windows has often been a point of contention. In the case of siding, those who favor vinyl have won a few victories -- in Fort Smith, Ark., and Salisbury, Md. -- and in other places have gained concessions for facades not visible from the street or for modern houses included within a district.
What galls the critics in Tappan is that the seven-member review board has extended its ban on vinyl siding to fairly contemporary houses. Moreover, the critics say, none of the current board members live within the 17-block-long historic district, choosing the larger homes on the village's periphery, yet imposing their tastes on district homeowners.
Though both sides display the genuine affection of fellow villagers toward each other, the harsher critics have taken to calling the board members "elitists" and "bullies."
"This is taxation without representation," said Joseph Fitzpatrick, a retired telephone company splicer. His 60-year-old home stands with its sky-blue insulation exposed to the world because he is fighting an order to cover it with clapboard.
 
How It Really Looked
 But Danforth Toan, a retired architect who has been on the board since its creation, says people like himself, even if they live outside the district, are taking the longer view. These Tappan residents want to retain the genuine wood and gingerbread carving, want to keep out jarring embellishments like above-ground swimming pools, so that visitors a century from now can say: "That's old; that's what it really looked like."
"We think of ourselves as caretakers of a historical tradition that far outweighs the momentary problems as they arise for people who are just passing through," Mr. Toan said.
The rangy, goateed Mr. Toan, who is 75 years old, has become the central figure of the debate.
"I liken Dan Toan to an entrenched congressional committee chairman with many years of tenure who runs his committee with an iron hand," said Reginald Thayer, a leader of the rebel band, which calls itself Concerned Orangetown Residents after the larger township.
Before he retired, Mr. Toan, a genial, cultured man, worked as an architect, designing library buildings at Brown and Columbia Universities. In his youth he was a maverick, and he came to Rockland County about 45 years ago with the idea of buying land for a cooperative community of houses for 32 Columbia students, who would share a tennis court, swimming pool and market.
 
From Communist to Capitalist
 Mr. Toan realized that vision in the Tappan neighborhood known as Hickory Hill, but time has made him a village elder and in the vinyl revolution he has been depicted as something of a Tory, fighting progress and the will of the people.
"They think of us as elitist capitalists," Mr. Toan said. "When we were first building here they thought of us as Communists."
Tappan, which is on the northern New Jersey border and a few miles south of Nyack, is proud of its role in the American Revolution, however minor.
Here stands the DeClark-DeWint house, a stone cottage where George Washington had one of his headquarters. And here, still operating as a tavern, is the Old '76 House, where the British spy John Andre was confined before his execution for plotting the surrender of West Point with Benedict Arnold.
The cluster of small, boxy wooden buildings on Tappan's Main Street, with their sagging wooden porches and decorative trim, look much the way they did in 19th-century drawings. Beyond Main Street, however, they are laced among an eclectic mix of 90 or so more modern buildings, even an occasional split-level. These were included in the historic district as a way of protecting what Mr. Toan calls the "townscape" -- the look of an old village.
Mr. Toan essentially wrote the preservation law -- which also came to cover a second historical area in the adjacent hamlet of Palisades -- and his opponents credit him with protecting Tappan's historical integrity. But they also say that he is interpreting his own law arbitrarily.
Mr. Fitzpatrick and his wife, Dorothy, raised nine children in a two-bedroom cape that was built in 1936 and is a stone's throw from the Washington headquarters, built in 1700. When water damaged the shingles covering their outside walls last year, the Fitzpatricks decided to put up vinyl siding. Vinyl, Mr. Fitzpatrick said, cost $8,000, compared with $13,000 for cedar clapboard and would be easier for Mr. Fitzpatrick to maintain.
Contractors had completed installing the insulation and were about to cover it with vinyl siding when members of the review board stopped the work in January. Mr. Fitzpatrick, who lives on a $1,061 monthly pension plus Social Security, is now asking the local zoning board to repeal the order.
Mr. Toan argues that even with houses only 50 or 60 years old it is important to keep the village look harmonious because even newer houses have historical details and, over time, "distinctions tend to mellow." Mr. Toan also contends that preserving the hamlet's overall historical flavor will enhance the values of all homes, compensating owners for the extra costs of installing clapboard.
The Concerned Orangetown Residents group is trying to remove Mr. Toan from the board and fill two other vacancies with sympathetic district residents. In an effort to bridge the gap, Mr. Toan has suggested that the town create a fund to help owners who find landmark obligations a hardship.
Once, Mr. Toan said, there was a consensus that Tappan's history should be preserved.
"It becomes the collective memory of the community," he said. "Schoolchildren come here to look at the church, the graveyard and the trees and the streams that attracted the original settlers."
"What we're seeing here is the deterioration of that consensus," he said. "The historical society people have aged, and young people are not as interested."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Investors Worried Over Fed Bring On an Attack of Jitters

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The futures markets took a nervous ride yesterday as commodity-fund investors, shaken by Government forecasts of ample crops, bailed out of some agricultural commodities but bought oil futures aggressively.
"Everything is going crazy," said Hans Kashyap, president of Analytics Research Corporation. "Everywhere you look in the commodities area, you see sharply lower prices. Soybeans, lumber, silver, orange juice, coffee, cocoa are down." 
 A few markets posted gains -- notably crude oil, wheat and livestock. But in general futures markets were hit by selling from professional funds that had bet heavily in recent sessions and either took profits or cut their losses.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 futures, a key inflation indicator, dropped to a two-month low of 225.38.
"This is not good way to start off April," said Jeff Wilson, editor of the market-watching Brock Report.
 
 
Fears of Federal Reserve
 Mr. Wilson said yesterday's selling reflected continuing jitters from last week as stock and bond prices plunged on fears of a new round of credit tightening by the Federal Reserve.
"Most of today's weakness is strictly a preservation of capital by major commodity funds," he said. "The markets are too volatile right now."
Soybeans and silver, two speculative favorites, led the selling.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, July soybeans closed down the daily allowable 30-cent-a-bushel limit at $6.53 1/2 following a bearish 1994 plantings estimate by the Government on Thursday. Seedings are expected to be up 3 percent, to 61 million acres.
Silver led a selloff in precious metals as financial market worries, falling commodity prices and rising interest rates spurred liquidation by hedge funds. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, May silver closed 19.3 cents lower at $5.592 an ounce after hitting $5.82, a life of contract high, early. June gold ended $5.60 lower at $388.70 an ounce. And July platinum fell $8.40, to $418.50 an ounce, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 
 
Energy Futures Driven Up
 "I don't think the metals were ever a flight to safety," said a Paine Webber analyst, Bernard Savaiko, who said hedge funds and other investors hit by the sagging stock market had tended to favor cash during the current period of volatility.
Meanwhile, many commodity fund investors turned to crude oil. With fundamentals bearish after last week's failure by OPEC to cut production, the professionals decided that a contrarian stand was needed and flocked in, driving energy futures higher.
May crude oil ended $1 higher, up 7 percent and at a two-month high of $15.79 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
"I think the funds have turned bullish on oil," said Morris Greenberg, oil analyst at Lehman Brothers in New York.

HEADLINE: Montreal Journal;
Quebec Bets on Subsidized Milk, Mother's Kind

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
"It's great news," Josee Paradis said, rocking her 6-week-old son, Brock, in her arms in her sparsely furnished basement apartment in an industrial suburb of Montreal.
Ms. Paradis, a 19-year-old former secretarial student, was praising a decision by Quebec's provincial government to raise the subsidy for breast-feeding from $15 to about $37.50 a month under a new program to encourage low-income women to nurse their infants. 
 For Ms. Paradis and Brock's father, Rick Flood, 23, who pay $450 a month in rent, the $37.50 subsidy was a big factor in the decision to breast-feed Brock. It represents nearly 5 percent of their monthly expenditures.
"It will be very handy for us, that's for sure," said Mr. Flood, who is unemployed but hopes to get a job as a window-washer.
Ms. Paradis added, "They say it's better for the baby."
There is no doubt that the government of Quebec thinks breast-feeding is better. "Mother's milk is the food best adapted to the newborn's nutritional needs," said Violette Trepanier, Minister of Income Security, who introduced the new benefits on March 1.
In a sharp departure from the traditional role of government, Quebec pays mothers to nurse their infants. Ms. Trepanier says it does so to further both public health and budgetary goals. Since breast-fed babies tend to be healthier babies, she says, encouraging nursing could ultimately save the publicly financed health care system millions of dollars a year.
Quebec has paid supplements to nursing mothers and subsidized the cost of some infant formula for the last quarter-century. What is new -- and highly appreciated by nursing mothers on low incomes -- is the policy shift in favor of breast milk. When the cash incentive for breast-feeding rose to $37.50 a month, the subsidy for formula was reduced.
For the 7,000 women in Quebec on public assistance who have infants up to six months old, the ministry had previously paid 100 percent of the cost of soy-based formula. That product will no longer be subsidized, except for children with lactose intolerance, but the province covers about 70 percent of the cost of milk-based formula concentrate by issuing a voucher similar to a food stamp.
The program will still cost the provincial government $3.8 million a year, since the reduction in subsidies for formula will finance the higher nursing allowances. To prevent abuses, the ministry requires that a new mother present an affidavit from her doctor to the local office of the Income Security Ministry that confirms that she is nursing.
The effort is being watched in other Canadian provinces and in the United States, which also have assistance programs for low-income mothers and try to encourage breast-feeding, though they stop short of the incentives offered by Quebec.
Statistics show that a far smaller proportion of women with low incomes breast-feed their infants than women with higher incomes, both in Canada and the United States.
The Quebec government estimates that 60 percent of the province's mothers nurse their infants in the first six months of life, compared with 9 percent of mothers on public assistance. The latter estimate is based on the proportion of women who take the breast-feeding allowance.
In the United States, an estimated three-quarters of middle- and upper-income women nurse their infants, compared with less than one-quarter of the women in the Agriculture Department's special supplemental food program for women, infants and children. The program provides Federal grants to states to help low-income families meet their nutritional needs.
Dr. Ruth A. Lawrence, director of the Breast-Feeding and Human Lactation Center at the University of Rochester, praised the Quebec program. She said she and other advocates in the United States have been urging the Agriculture Department that "they, too, need to reward mothers for doing this special thing for their infants."
Under strong Congressional pressure, the Agriculture Department has recently provided extra food vouchers to nursing mothers in the supplemental nutrition program and allowed them to stay on the program longer -- one year instead of six months.
There is no longer any dissent, even from the formula makers, that breast milk is superior to any other infant food.
The companies are careful to describe formula as a supplement or an alternative to breast milk, and all emphasize that they encourage mothers to take the advice of health professionals.
"Infant formula is appropriate for mothers who for whatever reasons choose not to breast-feed," said Marianne King-Wilson, Nestle Canada's director of corporate affairs.
Marie Alta Dorce, 31, who moved to Canada in 1986 from Haiti and now lives in northern Montreal, is breast-feeding her 10-week-old son, Andy. A single mother, she has studied to be a secretary, but is out of work.
She is thankful for the extra money, though she says that it barely covers the cost of the nutritious food she needs -- expensive milk and eggs, yogurt, oranges -- to sustain her during her nursing period. But with a nod to her sleeping son, she remarked, "If the baby is in good form, the mother will be in good form."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Quebec has increased the subsidy it pays under its program to encourage low-income mothers to nurse their infants. Marie Alta Dorce, shown here with her 10-week-old son, Andy, is thankful for the extra money. (Horacio Paone for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A 7th Month of Growth Found in Manufacturing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
American manufacturing expanded for the seventh straight month in March, although the rate of growth slowed from the month before, a trade group of corporate purchasing managers said yesterday.
The monthly assessment by the National Association of Purchasing Management substantiated other evidence that the United States economy is strengthening. The purchasing managers' survey is widely followed in assessing the state of the economy's health because it offers some of the freshest information. 
 The group said its index of manufacturing activity rose to 56.7 percent, from 56.6 percent in February. A reading of more than 50 percent indicates the manufacturing economy is expanding, a reading of less than 50 indicates it is shrinking.
"We had a very strong month of production in March," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business community and purchasing director at Pitney Bowes Inc. New orders to manufacturers continued to expand, he added "but the rate of growth seems to be leveling off in new orders and backlog of orders."
 
14 of 20 Industries Gain
 The group said 14 of 20 industries surveyed reported an improvement in March as many businesses recovered from disruptions caused by a harsh winter and the California earthquake.
Prices, a key indicator of inflation, continued to rise in March, but at a more subdued rate than in February. The association's price index fell to 64.2 percent in March, from 67 percent in February.
"The rate of growth that we had over the fourth quarter and the first month in this quarter just can't be sustained," Mr. Bretz said. He added that as the pace of the recovery slowed a decline in demand for goods should ease upward pressure on prices.
 
Scrap Steel Prices Decline
 He noted that prices for scrap steel, a bellwether commodity, had begun to decline and said that future increases in steel imports should further ease steel prices.
But he said he expected price increases in some types of paper and chemicals and in plastics.
The purchasing managers' report also said that new orders to manufacturers continued to grow at about the same high rate as in February, that new export orders continued to rise in March, but at a significantly lower rate than in February, and that imports grew for the fifth straight month, but at a slightly slower pace than in February.
Industries reporting the most improvement were leather, plastics and rubber, apparel, transportation equipment, electronic components and equipment, fabricated metals and industrial and commercial equipment and computers.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Bar Extra Fees for Dumping of Out-of-State Waste

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not impose extra fees for dumping waste from another state.
The 7-to-2 decision overturned an Oregon surcharge on the disposal of solid waste generated beyond Oregon's borders. Under the 1989 law, the fee for placing out-of-state waste in an Oregon landfill is $3.10 a ton, as against 85 cents for waste generated within Oregon. The Oregon Supreme Court upheld the surcharge last year. 
 The ruling today was the latest of several Supreme Court decisions to reject protectionist efforts by a growing number of states to restrict the flow of trash and hazardous waste.
The decision, written by Associate Justice Clarence Thomas, was based on the Constitution's commerce clause, which prohibits the states from erecting economic barriers against interstate commerce.
 
Handling Costs Cited
 "Discrimination simply means differential treatment of in-state and out-of-state economic interests that benefits the former and burdens the latter," Justice Thomas said. "If a restriction on commerce is discriminatory, it is virtually per se invalid."
The decision, Oregon Waste Systems v. Department of Environmental Qualify, No. 93-70, left open the prospect that a state could justify a surcharge if the costs of handling out-of-state waste were actually higher. But the possibility of a successful defense appeared remote.
Oregon tried to provide an economic justification for the surcharge, calling it a compensatory tax intended to force shippers of out-of-state waste to pay their "fair share" of costs that in-state shippers pay through the state income tax and other taxes. The Court rejected this explanation. Justice Thomas noted in his opinion that the state had neither explained how it set the surcharge at $2.25 per ton nor claimed that the in-state shippers pay the equivalent of the surcharge through their general taxes.
The majority opinion was joined by Associate Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist dissented in an opinion that Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun also signed.
 
Rehnquist Applauds Oregon
 Chief Justice Rehnquist said "Oregon should be applauded" for taking a comprehensive approach to its solid-waste disposal problem. "The Court today leaves states with only two options," the opinion said: "become a dumper and ship as much waste as possible to a less populated state, or become a dumpee, and stoically accept waste from more densely populated states."
"I see nothing in the commerce clause that compels less densely populated states to serve as the low-cost dumping grounds for their neighbors," the Chief Justice concluded.
According to a brief filed by the National Solid Wastes Management Association, an industry group, most states both import some waste and export some. Of the 420 million tons of solid and hazardous waste generated each year, some 20 million tons move across state lines for disposal.
Fourteen states filed a brief telling the Court that they had adopted policies similar to Oregon's or were considering doing so. According to this brief, 18 states -- none in the New York metropolitan area -- currently restrict the movement of solid or hazardous waste across state or county lines.
Cases dealing with waste disposal have become staples of the Supreme Court's docket, reflecting the economic and political stakes that are now attached to the issue. The Court is expected to rule shortly in two other cases. One, C. & A. Carbone v. Clarkstown, N.Y., No. 92-1402, reflects the fact that waste can be an economic asset as well as a burden.
 
Challenge to Ordinance
 The case is a challenge brought under the commerce clause to an ordinance that requires all trash generated in the town to be taken to a designated facility for sorting rather than shipped elsewhere. The other case, Chicago v. Environmental Defense Fund, No. 92-1639, involves Federal regulation of the ash created from municipal waste in an incinerator designed to produce steam.
There were also these developments at the Court today:
 
Airline Suits
 The High Court agreed to review a ruling by the Illinois Supreme Court that permitted members of the American Airlines frequent flyer program to sue the airline for consumer fraud for imposing new conditions on accumulating mileage credits for free flights.
American Airlines appealed the ruling with the support of other commercial airlines, several of which are facing similar lawsuits. The question for the court is whether consumer suits of this sort can be brought under state law, or whether all such suits are pre-empted by a Federal law, the Airline Deregulaton Act of 1978, which governs all regulations "relating to rates, routes, or services of any air carrier."
The Supreme Court in the past has interpreted the Federal law broadly to displace state regulation. The Justices ruled two years ago, in Morales v. T.W.A., that states could not regulate deceptive advertising of airfares. But earlier this year, the Court declined to review a Federal appeals court ruling that permitted an airline passenger who had been bumped from an overbooked flight to sue for damages under state law.
The airline industry takes the pre-emption question very seriously, because the practical issue is whether airlines are answerable to one Federal law or to the laws of the 50 states. Class-action lawsuits now pending under various state laws over cancellation penalties, as well as over frequent flyer programs, potentially involve tens of millions of plaintiffs. The suit involved in this case, American Airlines v. Wolens, No. 93-1286, has not yet gone to trial.
In finding that the Supreme Court's 1992 decision did not apply to this case, the Illinois Supreme Court held that frequent flyer programs had only a tangential relationship to airline "rates, routes and services," areas of operations that are pre-empted by the Federal law. The state court observed that airlines had operated for many years before American Airlines established the first frequent flyer program in 1981.
But the Air Transport Association, an industry group that filed a brief urging the Court to hear the case, said the programs are important marketing tools that have a substantial impact on fares and services.
 
Company Relocations
 The Court agreed to decide the validity of the National Labor Relations Board's policy governing an employer's duty to bargain with its unions over the decision to relocate the company's operations.
The subject has been a contentious one for years, with the labor board issuing a series of conflicting rulings. This case, Dubuque Packing Company v. N.L.R.B., No. 93-1103, concerns the latest policy, a 1991 ruling that provides that management is generally required to bargain over a relocation that does not reflect a basic change in the nature of the business.
The policy was upheld last year by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Associate Justice Ginsburg, who sat on that three-judge panel, is not participating in the case at the Supreme Court level.
 
Veterans' Suits
 Accepting an appeal from the Federal Government, the Court agreed to review a decision that potentially makes the Department of Veterans Affairs financially liable whenever treatment at a veterans' hospital results in a poor medical outcome, regardless of whether the treatment was faulty.
The case, Brown v. Gardner, No. 93-1128, is an appeal from a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. That court last year rejected a longstanding interpretation of a 1924 law providing disability compensation to veterans injured "as the result of" treatment in a veterans' hospital. For nearly 70 years, the Government had interpreted the law as applying only to negligent treatment, but the appeals court found that there was no such limitation in the plain language of the law. The Government is estimating that the ruling, if not overturned, will cost $1 billion over the next five years.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall St. dusts off an old theme: The bear brings opportunity.

BYLINE: By Joshua Mills 

 BODY:
FOR people in the business of selling stocks, recent days have not been a bear market, oh no. Sure, the hiccup in the long bull market has turned into a prolonged coughing fit, but many brokers prefer to see this as "an opportunity market," full of bargains for their clients.
As the Dow Jones industrial average slid 42.61 points yesterday, putting its decline from its late-January peak at almost 10 percent, a number of brokers and money managers said they were busy buying shares for their clients. 
 "We've seen people dumping stocks in an almost irrational fashion, but we recommended buying today," said Alfred Goldman, the market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "Chrysler and General Motors and Home Depot all look like good value."
He continued: "Our advice to clients has been: when value shows up, buy it. Invest in stocks -- and also in patience."
Michael Metz, the chief market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company in New York, said that while he remained bearish over all, "food and drug stocks are down to prices where I'd begin buying, for long-term investment."
"Intel is really one of the more attractive stocks right now," he added. "So is Motorola." So are life insurance and bank stocks, he said.
But Mr. Metz disputed Mr. Goldman's optimism on the auto makers. "I think we've seen the peak on them, for all consumer durable goods, housing, too," he said.
In tandem with declining share prices in recent days, brokers' cliches have been raining down, too: "They're only losses if you sell"; "this looks like a normal correction"; "buy into weakness."
If all this sounds like tough going as the Dow slides, does it make any less sense than telling investors, as a bull market thunders along to new highs: "Buy now. Prices have never been higher."
Thomas V. Reilly, the chief investment officer at the Putnam Group's value equity group in Boston, said yesterday's continued slide was no surprise, given the turmoil in the bond market. His strategy in recent years, he said, has been to invest in cyclical stocks that would rise as the economy gathered strength.
And while, like Mr. Metz, he thinks the housing market has topped out, he said other sectors still held promise. Mr. Reilly said he was optimistic about the prospects for Xerox, ITT, chemical companies like Du Pont and Dow Chemical, and also Alcoa, the aluminum producer.
"There's been such broad selling over the last six or seven trading days that we've been in buying every day," he said.
 So has Jeffrey Vinik, who manages Fidelity Investments' Magellan Fund, the country's largest mutual fund with $34 billion under management. "I've been building up positions in stocks I like for the long term," he said.
Mr. Vinik said he had been buying financial companies like Fannie Mae and General Re; Goodyear Tire, and also Caterpillar and CSX. Highly optimistic about technology, he said he had not bought much in recent days because Magellan already had strong positions in that sector.
"I don't know what the market will do tomorrow or next week, but when I can buy the stocks I feel best about in the long term at 20 percent discount to where they were a couple of months ago, I do," Mr. Vinik said.
He noted, for example, that after building up a substantial position in G.M., Ford and Chrysler, he had sold part of his holdings during the winter. "Now I'm buying them back," he said, because they have fallen an average of 15 percent from their midwinter peaks.

HEADLINE: Employees' Next Concern: Possible Cuts in Work Force

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BETHPAGE, L.I., April 4

 BODY:
With the Grumman Corporation's announcement this morning that it had agreed to a takeover by the Northrop Corporation, the big question for Grumman employees was how the merger would affect their jobs.
"On the one hand, I'm glad the guessing game is over," said Robert McHugh, a computer programmer. "It makes the few shares of Grumman stock I own worth a lot more, but that won't do me any good if I lose my job when the dust settles." 
 Grumman has already cut its local work force to fewer than 9,000 employees, from more than 23,000 in 1987. The most recent layoffs were announced in mid-February when 1,300 workers were told that the 6,000-acre Calverton operation, where Grumman built and tested four types of Navy aircraft, would be closed.
 
 
No More Planes From L.I.
 The move, a direct result of cutbacks in Pentagon orders, meant the end of airplane manufacturing on Long Island, long considered a cradle of aviation in the United States.
Local economists said they welcomed Northrop's acquisition of Grumman, saying the merger might strengthen Grumman's role in building airplanes.
"I think the question is jobs and whether Grumman would fare better under Northrop or Martin Marietta," Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for Chemical Bank, said. "And I think Grumman employees may do best with Northrop."
"Northrop is in the airplane business to some extent, while Martin Marietta is not," Mr. Kellner said. "The hope is that some of Northrop's business in that area can be transferred to Grumman.
"Northrop does make frames for the 747 and has a fighter plane in production as well, and Grumman could adapt to Northrop's needs."
Mr. Kellner said local economists and public officials feared that Martin Marietta, based in Bethesda, Md., which is a much larger corporation than Northrop, with little interest in the airplane construction business, might close most or all of Grumman's operation on Long Island and move it to Maryland or elsewhere in the country.
 
 
Company to Change Name
 Robert Harwood, a spokesman for Grumman, said shareholders would have until April 15 to tender their shares to Northrop. The $2 billion deal could be completed by mid-May.
He said Northrop, the Los Angeles-based builder of the B-2 bomber, had indicated that it would change its name to the Northrop Grumman Corporation, and consider putting the headquarters for its military electronics business on Long Island.
Mr. Harwood said Grumman retirees should not be concerned about losing any of their benefits. But he could give no such assurance on job security in the merged company.
"We have to wait and see what's going to happen as the companies are combined and where everything goes," he said. "Remember, this is still the defense business, and there's still a long way to go before the defense budget turns around. And until that time, you're going to see decreasing employment in this industry."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Little Change Despite Jump in U.S. Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar finished yesterday with little change against most major currencies after an erratic trading session, as concerns about slumping stock and bond prices offset renewed optimism about the American economy.
Traders said that despite rising interest rates yesterday, the dollar failed to follow up on its gains on Friday, when rates also climbed sharply. They said the sharp selloff in the stock market held the dollar down. 
 "The U.S. financial markets are in terrible shape," said Christopher Bourdain, a trader at Credit Suisse. "What are people going to buy with their dollars?"
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6975 German marks, little changed from 1.6970 marks on Friday. It also fell to 103.15 Japanese yen from 103.60 yen. Trading was less active than usual because London, the world's biggest foreign-exchange center, was closed in observance of Easter Monday.
The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond jumped to 7.41 percent yesterday on speculation that the strong March employment report that was released on Friday pointed to rising inflation rates. On Friday, the 30-year bond jumped to 7.26 percent from 7.08 percent in thin trading in reaction to the employment report.
Yesterday, stocks tumbled amid concern that rising interest rates would stifle the economic recovery.
Declines in stocks and bonds have kept the dollar from following interest rates higher in the last two months. Before the dollar's two-pfennig rally against the mark on Friday, the dollar had fallen almost 4 percent against the mark since Jan. 1. Higher rates usually make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
"Currency traders are obsessed with the stock market right now," said Lynn Tierney, vice president at Shawmut Bank of Boston. "It's a psychological thing, mostly."
Concern that Prime Minister John Major of Britain might lose office soon helped the dollar rise to a seven-week high against the pound. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.4670, down from $1.4740 on Friday.
Traders sold pounds after The Sunday Times of London reported that only 40 percent of legislators in the ruling Conservative Party believe that Mr. Major will lead the party into the next general election.
The Canadian dollar also fell, tumbling to a seven-year low amid speculation that interest rates in the United States would rise faster than Canadian rates in coming weeks. The Canadian dollar fell as low as 71.48 United States cents, down from 72.02 cents on Friday. It rose from its lows after the Bank of Canada bought the currency to stem the slide, traders said.
The Canadian dollar is "on its way to 65 cents," said Al Friedberg, president of Friedberg Mercantile Group, a Toronto currency trading fund.

HEADLINE: Some Optimism in Japan

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 4

 BODY:
Bank of Japan officials from various regions reported brighter prospects today for a long-awaited recovery in the Japanese economy.
The regional managers reported at their quarterly meeting that business executives appeared to be gaining confidence. 
 Bright spots are particularly evident in Osaka and neighboring cities in western Japan, where electronics giants like Matsushita Electric Industrial are based, the manager of the Osaka region, Tatsuya Tamura, said.
Industrial production rose in central Japan in the January-March period and was likely to continue upward in the April-June period, Takahiro Kawase, branch manager for the central Nagoya region, said.
Auto makers are increasing their shipments to the United States, Mr. Kawase said, adding, "The economy seems to have stopped worsening."
Household demand for washing machines, refrigerators and personal computers and facsimile machines has emerged as consumers seek replacements for old equipment and are enticed by lower prices.

HEADLINE: Quest for Evolutionary Meaning In the Persistence of Suicide

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
CONSIDERED on its face, suicide seems to flout the laws of nature, slashing through the sturdy instinct that wills all beings to fight for their lives until they can fight no longer.
Yet to some evolutionary geneticists, suicide cannot be entirely explained as a violent aberration or a human pathology lying outside the ebbs and pulls of natural selection and adaptation. These researchers note that suicide, for all its private, tangled sorrows, is surprisingly common in most countries, accounting on average for nearly 1 percent of all deaths. And when the number of serious suicide attempts is taken into account, the prevalence of the behavior jumps considerably. 
 That sort of incidence, the evolutionary geneticists say, is simply too great to be accounted for by standard explanations like social malaise or random cases of psychiatric disease.
Instead, the scientists suggest that the persistence of suicide at a fairly high rate across most cultures suggests an underlying evolutionary component, a possible Darwinian rationale for an act that too often appears starkly irrational. They propose that the tendency toward suicide could be a concomitant of a trait or group of traits that at some point in evolutionary history conferred benefits on those who bore it.
In other words, suicide may not be a freak event, or a complete breakdown of the natural order of things, but a behavior that by the sometimes cruel logic of natural selection, may make enough sense to maintain at a certain low but significant level.
"Any time you have a behavioral system that is relatively common and strongly persistent, it raises the question of whether the system is selected for," said Dr. Daniel Wilson, a clinical psychiatrist at Harvard Medical School and an anthropologist at the University of Cambridge in England. "Suicidal behaviors are relatively stable across cultural lines."
He emphasized that nobody argues that there is a single gene for suicide, or that suicide or mental illness should be thought of as good. But he and others said there may be plausible evolutionary explanations for at least some self-destructive acts.
What is more, the tendency to commit or try suicide often runs in families, suggesting that a predisposition toward self-murder is partly inherited. And while suicide occurs in nearly all countries, it is far more common among some ethnic groups.
The Hungarians and the Finns, for example, suffer from suicide rates two to three times those in the United States and most of Europe. Significantly, the elevated incidence holds true not only in those nations, where economic or social conditions could be responsible, but also for Finns and Hungarians who emigrated to other countries, again hinting at a biological substrate.
 
The Theories
Martyrdom Or Depression?
 In trying to fathom what that substrate might be, researchers propose that the impulse to kill oneself may be an expression of an instinct toward self-sacrifice for the good of surviving relatives, either because those relatives will be rescued from their own death, or because they will benefit richly from the resources that are thus freed up. The survivors will in turn pass on the sacrificial victim's genes.
"In the jungle, a hominid might well have enhanced his own genetic survival by sacrificing himself to a leopard, if that thereby saved six of his brothers and sisters," Dr. Wilson said. But because humans live in complex social groups, such an impulse toward martyrdom might on occasion show itself in complex, even distorted forms, tugging miserably at the psyches of even those who have no families to benefit from their deaths and to assure that their genetic legacies survive.
Other evolutionary biologists suggest that suicide may not be an inheritable behavior in itself but is simply the most tragic outcome of another trait that may be selected for -- the tendency toward depression. Some Darwinian-minded theorists say that extremely bleak moods are themselves too common to be the result of pathology alone. They propose that bouts of depression may be useful, forcing people into a kind of emotional hibernation and giving them time to ponder their mistakes.
But such a strategy, if sustained too long or repeated too often, becomes maladaptive and even fatal, the researchers emphasized, showing itself as the harrowing disease called major depression.
Some researchers, reasoning that human beings invent few traits but instead merely display intricate versions of behaviors seen elsewhere in the animal kingdom, have looked to other species for insights into the genesis of depression and suicide. The exercise is fraught with pitfalls.
Nonhuman animals obviously do not leave behind anything as clear as a note, nor are they likely to have sufficient awareness to do something as deliberate as jump off a cliff. But biologists have identified numerous examples of creatures that sacrifice themselves for their kin, from termites that explode their guts, releasing the slimy, foul contents over enemies that threaten their nest, to rodents that deliberately starve themselves to death rather than risk spreading an infection to others in their burrow.
 
Prozac for Monkeys
 More compellingly, scientists recently have determined that many species of nonhuman primates will suffer serious depression when stressed. And upon falling into an episode of melancholy, the afflicted monkeys may engage in all sorts of life-threatening activities -- like refusing food until they die of malnutrition, or swinging from dangerous tree limbs that no sane monkey would go near -- and sometimes perishing in the exercise. So similar is monkey depression to human depression, some scientists say, that the symptoms of melancholy dissipate when the primates are given antidepressants like Prozac.
Evolutionary geneticists admit they approach this theoretical terrain with enormous trepidation, for they are well aware of how insensitive or glib they can appear by ascribing suicide and depression to the handiwork of natural selection. But they hope that by exploring this unorthodox line of reasoning, they can come up with new insights into the kinds of behavioral changes that precede a suicide attempt, or any common features that may typify a person at risk for extreme mental illness, or suicide.
"I've had people get very angry at me because they think I'm trying to say that depression is good for you," said Dr. Randolph M. Nesse, a psychiatrist at the University of Michigan who has explored the evolutionary basis of depression and anxiety. "No matter how many caveats I bring up, no matter how cautiously I phrase my work," he added, people do not want to hear depression talked about in anything other than the most strongly condemnatory terms.
 
The Arguments
When Is Death Deliberate?
 Researchers know too well how easily a Darwinian explanation for complex behaviors can be overdone and oversimplified. Certainly, the affairs of animals much simpler than people have been misinterpreted in the past. For example, the idea of suicide in nonhuman species invariably raises the famed example of lemmings, rodents that were long thought by scientists and the public to kill themselves en masse by running into the sea, as though cued by a group alarm clock indicating that today is a good day to die.
But researchers have learned that the tale of the suicidal lemming is false. The tawny-furred rodents will die by the group, but that, it turns out, is a result of an error in judgment. Lemmings are the locusts of mammals, and they will strip a habitat bare. Then, they begin migrating forward to find a new feeding ground, swarming over boulders, around trees, whatever stands in their way. If they run into a body of water, they try to swim across.
"That's fine if it's a pond or a stream," said Dr. Paul W. Sherman, a behavioral ecologist at Cornell University. "But if they happen to hit a lake or an the ocean, well, they discover too late that they just can't make it."
Animal behaviorists often argue fiercely over whether a death they observe in the wilderness is deliberate or accidental. Dr. Raymond J. O'Connor, a professor of wildlife at the University of Maine in Orono, has developed models predicting that under certain circumstances, a hatchling bird in a multichick brood would do better to allow itself to be killed by its siblings than to fight back.
For example, he proposes, a mother crested penguin always lays two eggs a season, one small, one large. Given the harshness of her arctic surroundings, she can only rear one bird to independence, and usually that lucky penguin will come from the large egg. But she lays a double dose just in case the big egg is preyed on.
Dr. O'Connor suggests that should the big and little eggs both end up hatching, the smaller offspring might do better to allow itself to be killed by its bigger sibling without putting up a fuss: to essentially throw itself on its sibling's sword.
"There are some circumstances where it may pay to acquiesce in being killed, in committing suicide," he said, "to allow the genes that it shares with its sibling to progress faster."
Yet while researchers have observed that the little penguins do appear to die off in these encounters with few feathers ruffled, Dr. Douglas W. Mock, a professor of zoology at the University of Oklahoma in Norman, does not believe the smaller contender is going gentle into that good night.
"If I'm in a lifeboat, and the only other person on it is Mike Tyson, am I going to fight him for what little food we have left?" he said. "Or am I going to lay low and look for a chance to push him overboard, or pray that he gets zapped by lightning?"
 
Defining Suicide
 In general, scientists will call a death a suicide only when the animal has much to gain and little to lose, reproductively speaking, from the gesture. Dr. Robert Trivers of the University of California at Santa Cruz cited the example of cryptically colored butterflies that escape being eaten by blending into their surroundings. Once the adults are past their reproductive time, he said, they become a risk to their surviving offspring, for the simple reason that if they are discovered by a bird, the bird will gain clues from the butterfly to discriminate prey from background; and thereafter, the younger butterflies will also be in danger.
As it happens, the post-fertile adults usually drop to the groundcover and begin beating their wings rapidly until they die of exhaustion. "It's obliterating itself before it can be caught," he said.
Other examples of self-sacrifice abound. In some gall midges, tiny flylike insects, a mother will offer up her body as a meal to her offspring. Among naked mole rats, hairless and blind rodents that live underground and are almost as closely related to one another as are bees in a hive, an animal that is infested with parasites knows what it must do: go off to the communal toilet area of the intricate burrow and remain there until it dies.
"It never comes out, and you can't force-feed it," said Dr. Sherman, who has long studied the creatures. "It can't risk infecting the whole colony."
In applying the idea of self-sacrifice for the good of one's kith and kin to human beings, scientists cite obvious examples: mothers who will gladly die to save their children, war heroes who will go down in flames for their brethren, or even the recent spate of so-called rational suicides, in which elderly or terminally ill patients request that they be allowed to die quickly to avoid being a drain on their families. Researchers are much more reluctant to use such reasoning to justify the behavior of suicidal patients who very often are mentally ill, lonely and alienated from those who care about them.
But psychiatrists have observed that people who are contemplating suicide frequently think of it in extravagantly selfless terms, as the option that would be best for the suicide's family and friends.
"If you talk to people immediately after they made a serious suicide attempt, they'll have a very altruistic explanation for what they did," said Dr. David C. Clark, director of the Center for Suicide Research and Prevention at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. "They believed it was the wise, clever and thoughtful thing to do."
 
The Science
Personality Or Biochemistry?
 Suicide experts have long known that the great majority of people who kill themselves suffer from a psychiatric illness, most often depression or manic-depression. Such conditions are characterized by dramatic shifts in brain chemistry, particularly a drop in neurotransmitters like norepinephrine or serotonin, the molecules that allow nerve cells to communicate and that help modulate emotions and aggression.
Scientists studying nonhuman primates say they have witnessed many of the symptoms of serious depression in their subjects, including an apparent disregard for self-preservation. Jane Goodall, the renowned watcher of chimpanzees, once observed a 7 1/2-year-old male chimp experience such a profound despair after the death of his mother that he refused to leave her corpse even to eat.
"He slowly withered away, laid down and died," said Dr. Richard Wrangham of Harvard University, who worked with Dr. Goodall. "Jane talks about this as dying of a broken heart, and that seems like a perfectly good interpretation."
Others have studied the biochemistry that accompanies low mood in monkeys, and have found it to be a reasonable analogue of human depression. Dr. Stephen J. Suomi, chief of the laboratory of comparative ethology at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development in Bethesda, Md., has been studying rhesus monkeys living in free-ranging colonies. He has learned that about 20 percent of the monkeys are predisposed to becoming seriously depressed -- roughly the same as the human lifetime risk of the disorder -- when they lose a relative or close partner, or suffer a drop in social status.
 
Humanlike Changes
 Significantly, the depressed monkeys show some of the same changes in brain chemistry that neurophysiologists have observed in human patients, including a drop in cerebrospinal levels of norepinephrine.
While some, like Dr. Nesse at Michigan, propose that depression could be protective, allowing people and other animals with advanced cognitive skills to assess their situations and to consider how their tactics may have backfired and how they can avoid repeating a costly error, others take a less sanguine view. Dr. Suomi suggested that the condition is the downside of a personality that has great payoffs when times are good.
As it turns out, the same monkeys that are susceptible to depression often end up at the top of the social hierarchy. "Like so much in nature, things with potential risks also carry potential benefits," Dr. Suomi said.
The sensitive creatures are more aware than their peers of critical changes in the environment -- the sound of an approaching predator, the tentative gestures of a possible new ally. They see and hear and smell and feel everything. They are like taut strings on a beautiful violin. And if bowed too hard, the strings will snap.

HEADLINE: It's Sense to Keep Talking to North Korea

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator John McCain (letter, March 28) characterizes the Administration's response to the situation on the Korean Peninsula as concessional. First, let me make it clear that I have the highest regard for the Senator from Arizona. He is a true American hero, who fought valiantly for our country in Vietnam.
Nevertheless, his characterization of the Administration's handling of the crisis as "concession-laden" for attempting to resolve the crisis by diplomacy is unfair. United States policy has been reasoned and reasonable. We have responded to North Korean noncompliance in a tough manner, yet without unnecessarily raising the stakes. What precisely would the Senator have us do? 
 For economic sanctions, we would need cooperation from Japan and China. Japan has several hundred thousand North Koreans on its soil, and China is North Korea's only ally in the world. Yes, China can quiety help convince North Korea it has chosen a dangerous path, but quiet diplomacy is vastly different from agreement by China to negate its many contracts to provide oil and other critical consumer commodities to North Korea. We have all seen how difficult it is to persuade the Chinese to make any improvement in human rights. Does the Senator believe we can persuade China to put a stranglehold on its neighbor and ally?
I visited North Korea last October, and met President Kim Il Sung. I delivered a tough, but not confrontational, message. North Korea is, arguably, the most isolated nation on the face of the planet. With Communism destroyed in Eastern Europe, North Korea remains a bastion of hard-line Stalinist dictatorship in the same neighborhood as some of our most important allies -- Japan and South Korea. The United States and its allies must balance the need to be firm against the possibility North Korea may take precipitous action.
We have not conceded anything to North Korea. We have known from the beginning that the discussions would be protracted. But we are pursuing the right course, and we are delivering tough messages: We are deploying the Patriot missile defense system, and we will accept nothing less than full compliance with international inspection requirements.
The way out of this is not by provoking North Korea into a military attack while we proclaim, "If you do this, we will bury you."
If the North Korean leadership believes the United States may take military action, which will undermine the regime's survival, it may itself pursue a deadly course of action. There is no question that United States and South Korean forces would prevail in the event of armed conflict. But such a conflict could cost tens or even hundreds of thousands of lives.
Our first priority should be to avoid such a debacle. That means diplomacy can and must prevail. That's not concession-laden. That's common sense.
 
(Rep.) GARY L. ACKERMAN
Chairman, Subcommittee on
Asia and the Pacific
Washington, March 29, 1994
