HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE MEMO SEES HIGHER COSTS FOR WELFARE PLAN

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
President Clinton's plan to overhaul the welfare system could cost much more in the long run than previously disclosed, possibly adding $58 billion to the nation's welfare costs over 10 years, according to a confidential memorandum presented to Mr. Clinton.
The document also says Mr. Clinton should understand that "in rare circumstances" his plan to enforce a two-year limit on welfare benefits could leave families "homeless or unable to care for their children." 
 The memorandum, drafted by the 32 members of the Administration's working group on welfare, provides the most detailed information yet about the tough decisions Mr. Clinton faces in trying to fulfill one of his most popular campaign pledges. The document was discussed at the only Cabinet meeting on welfare that the President has attended, on March 22.
The memorandum outlines what aides are calling a "Cadillac version" of a welfare proposal, but it acknowledges that its cost may force Mr. Clinton to adopt a more modest plan. Mr. Clinton deferred that decision at the Cabinet meeting two weeks ago. An Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, predicted today that President would adopt a version that would add $35 billion to the cost of welfare over 10 years.
Mr. Clinton has promised to deliver a bill this spring that would expand training programs for people on welfare and require those still unemployed after two years to join a work program.
Financing the new program has become the most problematic aspect of the proposal in recent months. Cabinet officials have repeatedly rejected the program cuts or tax increases suggested by mid-level officials.
The main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, now costs about $22 billion a year. By 1999, the full Clinton plan would increase that figure by about $7 billion a year, according to the document.
The memorandum suggests that long-term costs would be even greater than previously known. Earlier estimates had suggested that the proposed changes would cost about $15 billion for the first five years. The memorandum says that in the second five years of the program, costs would more than double, reaching $58 billion over 10 years. The costs would rise as the program was phased in.
While the plan to impose a two-year limit on welfare benefits sounds like it would save money, it would actually be much more expensive, at least in the short run, than simply mailing a welfare check. That is because the Administration would create training, education and child-care programs, and subsidize the wages of the recipients it puts to work.
The document outlines possible cuts or taxes that would raise tens of billions of dollars over the next decade, but it calls all of the options undesirable. "Each faces serious political problems and raises some substantive concerns," the memorandum said. The document was provided to The New York Times by a person who argues that the money for the welfare changes could be better spent on other programs for low-income Americans.
The document suggests several strategies for reducing the $58 billion cost. One would be to reduce or eliminate a proposed $16 billion expansion of child care for the working poor, which is intended to help parents keep their jobs and stay off welfare. Another would be to cut back an $8 billion expansion of aid to two-parent families, which is meant to prevent fathers from leaving the home.
But the plan argues that Mr. Clinton could not fulfill his political pledges without preserving the work and training programs that cost $6 billion in the first five years, and $24 billion over the first decade.
The 95-page document devotes only a few paragraphs to the plan's potential to force some children into homelessness or foster care. That risk is inherent in the idea of a limit on cash assistance, since without benefits some families could not pay their rent.
Supporters of time limits in both political parties usually try to avoid discussing the possibility of homelessness and foster care. They argue that the limits will help many other poor people by giving them new incentives to find good jobs.
In acknowledging the risks of eviction or family breakups, the Clinton document said there was "no apparent alternative" if the Government was to enforce time limits.
"If the welfare system is working properly, these failures will be extremely rare," it said.
An alternative plan by House Republicans has even stricter time limits, and therefore, presumably carries greater risks that some families would be forced into the street.
 
What If There Are No Jobs?
 The Clinton plan says the instances of homelessness or increased foster care could arise when after the two years a parent refuses to join a work program, or performs the work unsatisfactorily. In such instances, the plan calls for ending cash aid. Food stamps and medical aid would continue.
The Clinton plan also suggests that states could deny cash assistance to people who complete a work assignment but do not show "good faith." While it does not define the term, it said that simply showing up for work "would not, in and of itself, establish cooperation."
The five-year costs of $18 billion reflect about $3 billion in additional expenses that were not spelled out in previous drafts. These include $1.7 billion to allow welfare recipients to keep a higher percentage of their earnings, to encourage them to work.
The plan suggests possible cuts to four programs. Capping the emergency assistance provisions of Aid to Families With Dependent Children, which make payments to families in crisis, could save $5.6 billion over 10 years. Limiting the Child-Care Food Program, which provides food subsidies to children in day care, could save $1.7 billion in a decade.
Changing the welfare eligibility rules for children who live with grandparents or other relatives could save $15 billion over 10 years. But by making it harder for such households to collect welfare, the document notes, the change could force some children into foster care.
The document also contemplates changes that would save up to $23 billion over 10 years by making it harder for legal immigrants to collect Supplemental Security Income payments. It argues that some immigrants are abusing the program by bringing elderly parents to the United States and enrolling them.
The memorandum also contemplates raising $7 billion over 10 years through a 4 percent excise tax on gambling establishments.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 9, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A subheading on Tuesday with an article about a White House proposal for the welfare system referred incorrectly to the history of the effort. The Clinton Administration has always predicted that the proposed changes would add to the nation's welfare budget; it was never promoted as a plan that would save money.

HEADLINE: Stocks Break Their Spring Slide With Strongest Surge in 2 Years

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock and bond markets rallied strongly yesterday, halting for now the sharpest decline in years, as some traders were encouraged by new signs that the economy was not growing as rapidly as had been thought.
In a surge of buying and bargain hunting, traders bid up stock prices, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average 82.06 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,675.41, the biggest one-day rally in more than two years. 
 The reversal of fortune, after sharp drops in stocks and bonds last week and on Monday, raised spirits on Wall Street even as some traders warned that the slump might not be over.
"It's an encouraging sign that we didn't falter today," said Edward J. Laux, co-head of institutional trading at Kidder, Peabody. "But I don't think the correction is over in the bond market and I don't know what that means for the stock market."
Wall Street experts had widely predicted a 10 percent correction since the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in early February. The Dow average has declined about 385 points, or 9.7 percent, from its Jan. 31 peak. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index had similar falls.
Nothing has yet fundamentally changed to alter bond traders' perceptions of another imminent move by the Federal Reserve to raise short-term rates, nor has anything fundamentally changed their apprehensions about a resurgent economy leading to resurgent inflation, despite scant evidence of that.
Yesterday, a Government report on 11 leading economic indicators showed the first decline in seven months, meaning that economic growth may be more moderate than had been thought. Bond traders were also encouraged by a report showing prices of commodities like gold and oil were rising less rapidly, underscoring that inflation was in check.
As a result, the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds fell from a 15-month high of 7.41 percent, set on Monday, to 7.24 yesterday. [Page D16.]
Whether yesterday's rise is really a "rigor mortis rally," grim Wall Street jargon for an uptick in a larger down market, will depend to a great extent on investor perceptions of the three main factors now moving the markets: interest rates, inflation and corporate earnings.
"People were just getting carried away," said Ronald K. Stribley, a senior portfolio manager who buys stocks and bonds for the Glenmede Trust Company in Philadelphia, which has more than $8.5 billion of assets under management. "Bonds had fallen too much and stocks had fallen too much. But it was mostly that there was just no way anyone could justify a bond at almost 7.5 percent."
In six of the last seven trading sessions, the share prices of some of the nation's most famous corporations had been relentlessly beaten down, so many traders came to the market yesterday poised for bargain buying.
Yesterday's action largely came from big instititional investors like pension funds. The number of shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 366.9 million shares, or little more than 20 percent above a typical day's volume.
Mutual funds reported that small investors sat on their hands for the most part. Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest manager of mutual funds, reported "modest" inflow of less than $50 million into its stock mutual funds. Phone inquiries were up, but about a third of those calls were seeking advice on tax returns.
"If we are a proxy for the small investor," said Neal Litvack, executive vice president for Fidelity, "I have to believe that most of the action today came from big investors, not small."
Next week could bring indications of vigor in the economy, which would be sour news for bond traders and, therefore, for the stock market. On Tuesday, the Labor Department is to report on the Producer Price Index for March and the next day, the Consumer Price Index. It will be surprising if Wall Street and private economists do not foresee some increased inflation, as spring weather leads to higher retail sales and stepped-up construction.
But the probability remains high that private-sector economists do not have a fully accurate consensus estimate of how fast the economy is growing, and that both the stock and bond markets will overreact to changes in inflation.
Which leads to the third great wild card, first-quarter corporate earnings. Economists calculate that as much as half of the value of a stock reflects estimates of earnings and dividends to be paid over the next five years.
The market may bid stock and bond prices down by interpreting strong earnings not as a sign of health and better earnings to come, but as a sign of an overheating economy, and therefore of sickness.
Yesterday's trading was almost a mirror image of Monday's decline.
Stock prices started up and stayed up. They rose so quickly in the first half hour of trading that the New York Stock Exchange invoked "circuit breaker" rules, limits on high-speed computer-guided trading that are more often imposed to slow market declines.
Shortly before 11:15 A.M., the Dow had risen nearly 68 points, the largest jump since January 1991.
Of the 30 component stocks, 27 rose in price, led by such economically sensitive stocks as United Technologies, which was up 3 1/4, to 65 1/2, and Caterpillar, which rose 3, to 116 1/4.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.37, to 448.29, and the smaller-company Nasdaq index rose 23.54, to 750.95. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 5.27, to 248.41, and advancing stocks far outnumbered declining stocks 2,152 to 315. The American Stock Exchange market value index was up 6.86, to 440.99.
 
Big Day for Smaller Issues
 Small stocks advanced even more than large ones, with the Nasdaq index's gain of 3.2 percent being its biggest one-day leap since it rose 3.8 percent on Aug. 27, 1990. That rise came during a short-lived rally that interrupted but did not end the stock slump that followed Iraq's invastion of Kuwait.
The Dow's 2.3 percent rise was the strongest since Dec. 23, 1991, when it rose 3 percent in an early phase of a powerful advance.
Even with yesterday's strong rises, both indexes are well below where they were only a week ago. Similarly, while the fall in the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds was large, the 7.24 percent yield is still higher than it was as recently as Thursday.
Automobile stocks like General Motors, oil stocks like Chevron, retailers like Sears, Roebuck and financial-services companies like American Express were all prominent in yesterday's rally.
 
On the Active List
 Novell was the most heavily traded stock yesterday at 7.4 million shares as traders awaited the selection of a new chief executive. After the market closed, Novell said a Hewlett-Packard executive, Robert J. Frankenberg, was its choice. Novell shares rose 1 1/2, to 18 3/8, yesterday. They had been dropping recently because of heavy criticism from Wall Street analysts of Novell's planned acquisition of Wordperfect.
Telefonos de Mexico was the most heavily traded stock on the Big Board at 6.8 million shares and it closed up 3/4, to 57 3/4. Telmex is such a large stock that some big institional investors use it as a proxy for the Mexican stock exchange. Yesterday, the Mexican Government reported progress in its investigation of the assassination last month of the leading presidential candidiate.
Woolworth was the second-most heavily traded stock on the Big Board at 5.3 million shares. Its shares have been under pressure because of news reports of late payments to suppliers and reports of possible financial irregularities. Still, Woolworth rose 1 3/4 yesterday, to 14 3/4.

HEADLINE: Minority Students Languish In Special Education System

SERIES: A Class Apart: Special Education In New York City -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
Radheya Mathews attends ninth grade in a public school for special education students in the Bronx, but it is as if he had dropped out in spirit many years ago. He sits lethargically in class. He often walks out. He has a thick file of suspensions. But at home, he is a gifted artist who quietly tucks away his fancy pencil drawings in a Timberland shoe box.
To the 15-year-old, the Lincoln Adolescent Youth Achievement Center, the public school that he attends for children labeled emotionally disturbed, is an "asylum," a place with no windows and no hope. 
 "I don't even know that much anymore," he said. "There really isn't any advantage of staying. If I was to graduate, I probably wouldn't get no job anyway because I didn't learn nothing."
Radheya has languished in the special education system since he was sent there for disruptiveness and poor schoolwork five years ago. His mother says he was evaluated independently several years ago and found able to attend regular classes as long as he received extra counseling. But since then, not only has he remained in special education, he has also been channeled into classes that are less and less challenging.
Nearly two decades after Congress passed a law requiring public schools to educate all children with disabilities, providing extra money for smaller classes, special assistance for a variety of disabilities and individual attention, many education advocates say New York City's special education system, which involves 130,000 students, insures a second-class education, particularly for black boys, becoming a trap that incubates failure. At the heart of the issue is compelling evidence that black and Hispanic students are harmed, not helped, by special education.
Nationwide, black students are twice as likely to be in special education programs as white children, with much higher rates in predominantly white districts, according to some academic studies. Yet, these same students perform better in regular classes with extra support, Federal studies suggest.
Nearly one-third of all special education students -- including a majority of those labeled emotionally disturbed -- are arrested at least once after leaving high school. Forty-three percent of those who graduate remain unemployed three to five years after high school, and about one-fourth of special education students drop out, according to several Federal reports.
Some of this is attributable to the conditions of the children themselves, but researchers in several states suggest that the system itself is at least partly to blame. Children from the same pool of students achieve more, stay in school longer and get along better with others if they stay in regular classes.
Special services for children who are labeled as having disabling conditions have rapidly expanded since the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act was passed by the Federal Government in 1975. The legislation required state and local educators to provide a free and appropriate education for disabled students in the least restrictive school setting.
And while many agree on the need for specially geared classes for profoundly retarded children or those with other special needs, many advocates and educators say New York has gone too far. Advocates for Children, a nonprofit student-rights group in New York City, says tens of thousands of schoolchildren are funneled into the system unnecessarily.
Political leaders from Secretary of Education Richard S. Riley to New York City's School Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, acknowledge faults in the system, at both national and local levels, and promise major changes.
Mr. Riley, in his State of Education speech in February, cited the nation's high dropout rate among blacks and asked: "Could it be that in our attempt to do good -- offering pullout programs and overlabeling students into special education classes -- we have contributed in some significant way to a sense of classification and racial stereotyping that tells these young people early on that they will not make it in life, so why even try?"
Mr. Riley and Mr. Cortines are among the educators calling for a greater emphasis on training children for the workplace and for raising both academic standards and expectations. At both the local and Federal levels, they are asking for reviews of the special education system to insure that children are not being unduly removed from regular classrooms.
"Most children, with the appropriate support, should be able to stay in the neighborhood school program," said Judith E. Heumann, Assistant Secretary of Education. "Children identified as having special education needs should not be de facto removed from classroom settings."
But despite such views, there seems to be little incentive to limit special education and every incentive to expand it -- the schools receive up to $10,000 per student in extra Federal money, and teachers can effectively reduce class size by funneling bothersome students to special education.
 
Lost Hopes
Once In, Always In
 In New York City, where at least $1.3 billion is spent annually to maintain the city's vast special education structure, the more than 130,000 students receiving special education services represent a quadrupling in the 19 years since the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act was passed. According to a report by the Advocates for Children, about two-thirds of them, including Radheya, are placed in programs exclusively for special education students, isolated from general education students.
Radheya's day at Lincoln, in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, begins with social studies, then science, then a free period where students play pool or go to a game room or the cafeteria. He moves on to math class, then communications arts, the only class that engages his mind. "It's work. I'm writing something. I'm occupied."
Peter Mills, Radheya's uncle who counsels schoolchildren on substance abuse prevention, says that as a result of being in special education, Radheya has fallen far behind. "It happens a lot with kids who have aggressive behavior," he said. "Things happen to kids who are not challenged."
For Sandra Mills, Radheya's mother, the promise of smaller classes and personal attention had a bright appeal during her son's primary school years.
But Ms. Mills, who is a day care worker, said she was never told that once placed in special education, students are almost never "decertified" and allowed to return to regular education, and that most never finish high school. Ms. Mills also said she did not know that fewer than five percent graduate in four years, and that of the substantial number who remain in high school for seven years until they are 21 and "age out," only one-fourth graduate with some kind of diploma.
Radheya was consigned to the city's special education system in the third grade because of unruliness and poor schoolwork. But his mother attributes those problems to trouble at home: her marriage was unraveling, and she was about to give birth to a boy who would claim Radheya's place as the baby of the family.
"I felt he was very confused because a lot of things were going on," Ms. Mills said.
School officials approached her about placing Radheya in special education. Though parents have a right to refuse the services, Ms. Mills signed her consent to place him in a modified instructional program for students identified with mild to moderate learning disabilities. Since then his mother has tried to wrest him from what she sees as a Kafkaesque cul-de-sac.
 
Drawings From a Box
 She had him independently tested five years ago by the Manhattan Eye and Ear Clinic, which evaluates students with many kinds of disabilities. She said the clinic recommended that he be placed in regular classes, but taken out daily for extra academic help. But the Board of Education disagreed and kept him in the special program. School officials declined to comment, citing confidentiality.
On a recent night, Ms. Mills's face brightened when her son pulled out his cartoon drawings from the Timberland shoe box. But her smile faded when her son picked up an old colored drawing of three close friends, one of whom was later shot to death. With her own son's prospects so seemingly bleak, Ms. Mills worries what will become of him.
"My fear is that he'll just give up and not complete school," she said. "Special education has affected his ability to even try."
Ms. Mills said her son never talks of his dream to be a cartoonist anymore.
 
Diagnosis
 The Element Of Color
 Like Radheya, the majority of children in New York's special education program are classified as either learning disabled or emotionally disturbed. Those are two of 13 diagnoses established under the 1975 legislation, but unlike some of the other areas -- blindness, deafness, mental retardation, autism or chronic illnesses like cerebral palsy -- a diagnosis for either emotional disturbance or learning disability can be based on varying perceptions about what constitutes troubled behavior or impairment.
Walter Stafford, a New York University professor who has studied problems among black and Hispanic men, said, "Congress passed the law to deal with special education at the historical moment when the education community knew something about kids with physical disabilities but didn't know anything about these areas where kids had emotional or other considerations."
"The education community had to turn around and create a new body of learning," he said. "The result has been that a lot of kids have been experimented on."
Black children are more likely to be classified as emotionally disturbed or mentally retarded in New York City schools, while children with limited English proficiency are far more likely to be classified as learning disabled or speech impaired, Advocates for Children says.
Eighty-four percent of New York students in exclusively special education classes were black and Hispanic at a time when the student population was 73 percent black and Hispanic in city schools, a 1990 schools report found. White students, who accounted for 20 percent of the city's school population, made up 37 percent of the students receiving support services alone, typically in regular schools.
 
Poverty, Not Bias
 It is difficult to tease out an overriding factor to explain the persistent pattern of overreferrals of black children to special education, but academic experts and educators suggest that cultural bias and socioeconomic influences are among the tangle of reasons.
A recent Federal study of special education students suggests that in some areas, at least, it is poverty, not discrimination that determines whether students are placed in special education and what happens to them afterward. But many education advocates disagree with assessments that discount cultural biases.
"Clearly part of the problem is a negative expectancy on the part of many educators toward the prospects and possibilities of children of color," said Galen Kirkland, executive director of Advocates for Children. "Frequently what ends up happening is that people assume that once a problem becomes apparent, there's no hope. This person is doomed."
The most critical stage of assigning a child to special education is the referral by a teacher or a school. A school-based evaluating team, which includes a psychologist, generally goes along with the teachers' judgments. Of the children referred to special education, about 90 percent are tested and about 70 percent are found to need special education, said James Ysseldyke, an educational psychology professor at the University of Minnesota.
"Studies show teachers refer kids who bother them, and we've been able to demonstrate that specifically African-American males demonstrate behavior that bothers teachers," he said.
Robert L. Green, a Cleveland State University professor and an expert on school desegregation, said cultural apathy is at the root of the imbalances. "The essential problem comes from the structure and attitudes of those in public education today who simply are not overly concerned as to whether or not minority kids learn," he said. "The burning agenda in America is to build more prisons and to find new ways to lock them up. That is more of a conscious agenda."
 
Salvation
 Teacher Makes Big Difference
 No one needs to preach to Ted Gustus Jr. about the need to send children back into the mainstream. Behind a closed door at Junior High School 275 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Mr. Gustus, a crisis intervention teacher, hears their rage.
"Many of them say, 'Since I'm in special education, I might as well act like special education,' " Mr. Gustus said. "The kids begin to act out a self-fulfilling prophecy. I make them say over and over again, 'I want to be out of special education. I want to go into the mainstream.' "
Around campus, Mr. Gustus is known as "Cut 'em Loose Bruce" because of his interventions among students he sees as trapped by the system. "It's like a kid being in prison," he said. "You are taken out of society."
Partly because of his concern, Mr. Gustus eight years ago created the "Say Yes to Success" Sports Foundation, a mentoring program for minority children with histories of delinquency, truancy and academic failure. He searches out youths on basketball courts, on the streets and in school hallways.
Mr. Gustus, who is 40, identifies with these boys. Raised poor in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Mr. Gustus said he frequently forgot to study and was forced to repeat fourth grade because his behavior and attendance were poor. His mother died of alcoholism when he was 9, and his father was not around. He moved from one relative's house to the next, shifted from school to school. He says he thinks he would have been in special education, had it existed then.
Instead, he made it through school, stigma-free. "I didn't have a label, and the teachers had to deal with it," he said.
One of Mr. Gustus's rescues is Marquis Scott, a gentle-spoken former student who is now 22 and a mental health worker at New York Hospital. Mr. Scott offers himself as a role model and recruits for the mentoring program.
In the eighth grade, Mr. Scott spent half his school days in special education classes for children with emotional problems in the basement of Ditmas Junior High School in Flatbush. He had fallen behind in school and was hanging out with a tough crowd of boys. He had moved a few years before from Trinidad, where he had lived for most of his life with his grandmother. In New York, he had a distant relationship with his biological mother and no relationship at all with her boyfriend.
Mr. Scott said he was so ashamed of the special education label that he ordered his mother not to tell a soul. "The system is telling you that you have a disability and you can't learn at the same rate as other students."
During a basketball tournament, he met Mr. Gustus, who also works part-time as an after-school basketball coach at Nazareth Regional Catholic School in East Flatbush. Mr. Gustus spirited him out of the public schools altogether, quietly engineering his placement in Nazareth.
"I thought Marquis was not an emotional problem but having a problem with schoolwork because he needed additional attention until he could catch up with students," Mr. Gustus said.
With the help of a priest who tutored him during his lunch break, Mr. Scott flourished without special education classes. He attended the State University of New York College at Potsdam, and recently helped his mother buy a home.
When asked what might have become of him without his chance meeting with Mr. Gustus, the young man paused to reflect. "There are so many things on the streets that are negative. You never know."
 
Alternatives
 Better Use Of Money
 The alternatives to special education are clear to some education observers and academic experts. They say a great deal of special education money would be better spent in regular classrooms, on tutors, classroom aides and staff development. Schools could use consultants, team teachers and instruction strategies like having children of varying abilities work together to help each other learn.
Many parents and educators worry about including handicapped students in regular classes, for fear they will be dragged down. But educators and advocates for the disabled say their presence would draw support services back into the mainstream. And studies show that many special education students showed gains in self-esteem, improved behavior and emotional adjustment, and better skills in social situations when placed in classrooms with regular students.
The degree to which children identified as disabled are taught in regular classrooms varies widely from state to state. In Vermont, 87 percent of special education students were in regular classes, compared with 7 percent in New York and nearly 25 percent in California, according to a recent Federal report.
In Philadelphia, students are being weaned from special education in experimental programs and showing encouraging results in the city's regular classrooms, said James Lytle, the assistant superintendent.
 
'Going to Drop Out'
 "Inclusion, particularly in the categories of learning disabled and emotional support, is imperative simply because the kids are going to drop out unless they become a part of the regular education setting," Mr. Lytle said.
Damon Kimber is struggling hard not to become another student lost to the mainstream.
On a bright Saturday afternoon, the 11th grader rose before a crowd that packed the basement of the Mandala Cultural Center of Harlem to celebrate black history. He told the audience how he had been taking exclusively special education classes at the High School of Graphic Communications Arts, but that he hoped to get out of the system sometime soon. This year, for the first time ever, he began taking a hygiene class with regular education students. He also has a part-time clerical job at the Health and Hospitals Corporation that is counted as regular education credit for an advanced shop class.
In the audience, his aunt and foster mother, Alberta Morgan, listened in awe. The boy was so ashamed of his diagnosis, he would barely hold his head up when he was placed in her care four years ago.
His own mother, a drug abuser, had signed her consent to have him placed in special education when he was five years old. Diagnosed as educably mentally retarded, he has been in special education programs ever since.
But Ms. Morgan, a surrogate parent for seven other foster children also in the city's special education program, believes Damon can be successful in the mainstream.
So does he.
"It will help me more than special education," Damon said. "It makes me feel good. It makes me move ahead. It's important because it makes me advance like a professional. In special education, it slows you down."

Markets
Stocks roared back in a surge of buying, with traders bidding up the Dow Jones industrial average 82.06 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,675.41, the biggest one-day rally in more than two years. The rally was fueled by a lift in the bond market and encouraged by two reports indicating that inflation was in check. [Page A1.]

The Government's chief forecasting gauge edged down in February to break a six-month streak of advances, but analysts generally dismissed the reading as a reflection of bad weather and said they saw no change in economic direction. [D1.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Peace Effort in Bosnia Withers Under Serb Attack

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 5

 BODY:
After six weeks of rapid progress that raised hopes for an overall Bosnian settlement, American attempts to resolve the Balkan conflict are floundering, beset by a worsening military situation and a diplomatic impasse over what territorial concessions are needed for peace.
United States officials said that a Bosnian Serb offensive against the Muslim-held enclave of Gorazde, in eastern Bosnia, and attacks on Muslim civilians in Serbian-held territory in northwestern Bosnia have renew serious questions about whether the Serbs are interested in a settlement. 
 On the other hand, they said, the Muslim-led Bosnian Government has been showing growing resistance to an American proposal that it should accept a peace settlement that offers the recently formed Muslim-Croatian federation 51 percent of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Bosnian Government is pressing for considerably more land.
 
Serbs Must Cede Land
 The Bosnian Serbs, after two years of largely victorious war, control 72 percent of the territory and would have to bring their share down to 49 percent under the proposal.
"We're not prepared to go beyond 51 percent for the Muslims, which is the position we have agreed with the Europeans and that Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic had indicated last year would be acceptable," said one official close to the American diplomatic efforts. "But the Muslims are now saying they want all ethnically cleansed land back, and there's just no way you can fit that into 51 percent."
The combination of Bosnian Serb brutality in Gorazde and Prijedor and the increasingly uncompromising position of Mr. Izetbegovic's Government has brought the American diplomatic effort, led by Charles Redman, a special envoy, to a virtual standstill, the officials said.
"Right now, we're treading water," said a second official.
 
Conflicting Reports
 Conflicting reports exist on the intensity of the Bosnian Serb attack on Gorazde, and some United States officials believe accounts from Sarajevo radio are probably exaggerated.
But whatever its true extent, American officials say, the attack looks more like a reflection of the divergent positions among Serb leaders in Serbia and Bosnia.
The President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, is said to be eager to find a settlement because his priority is to insure the lifting of crippling economic sanctions on the Yugoslav federation.
But the Bosnian Serb military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, appears to be opposed to the surrender of any land for which his soldiers have fought. "Mladic remains hard-core," said one official.
 
General's Daughter a Suicide
 The latest Serbian offensive in Gorazde followed a shattering personal tragedy for General Mladic. His 23-year-old daughter, Ana, a fifth-year medicial student in Belgrade, committed suicide 10 days ago, Western diplomats in Belgrade said.
For the United States, the situation poses delicate problems. "The Serbs seem to be saying they don't want peace and we can't force it on them," said one official.
The territorial division is equally delicate. Washington's view is that Muslim-held eastern enclaves such as Srebrenica, Zepa and Gorazde may not be strategically viable in the long term, and that the Bosnian Government might be well advised to exchange some of these towns for more territory around Sarajevo.
"The eastern enclaves are completely non-viable but very emotional for the Muslims," said one official. "Giving them up is like giving up part of their body. So the question is, what is as valuable that the Serbs could give up in exchange? The answer of course, is Sarajevo. But there the Serbs won't budge."

GRAPHIC: Photo: On the 100th anniversary of the opening of Sarajevo's electric power grid, hundreds of residents braved a chilly drizzle last night for a stroll down Marshal Tito Street, the main boulevard, as the city turned on some 400 street lights for the first time in more than a year. ( Rachel Cobb for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Parking-Ticket Kvetches Save Companies Money;
With Millions at Stake, Businesses Find Ways to Fight City Fines, and They Often Win

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Martha Pabon, the fleet manager for a Manhattan company, went into the Parking Violations Bureau in Greenwich Village the other day, carrying 15 tickets, a dog-eared copy of the city's traffic and parking handbook and affidavits signed by her company's drivers and customers.
She walked out 20 minutes later with 12 tickets dismissed, 2 fines reduced and 1 ticket she had to pay in full. Instead of $885 in fines, she ended up paying $110. 
 In the intimidatingly named Parking Violations Bureau Commercial Adjudication Center, Ms. Pabon has overcome the Byzantine regulations that, on this day, left one man cursing the bureau as a kangaroo court, and alternately pleading for a second hearing. At P. J. Mechanical Corporation, a heating and air-conditioning company, she holds a position that is becoming a staple in businesses making deliveries or service calls in the city: parking-ticket fighter.
For the average New Yorker with a car, simply paying a ticket is probably cheaper than fighting it. But things are different for companies with dozens of vehicles making hundreds of stops a day and receiving scores of tickets a month.
 
Good Odds for Challenges
 In a city where there is a one-in-three chance of getting a ticket dismissed in court and an equal likelihood of getting a fine reduced, ticket-fighting is a growing industry.
Last year, 11.3 million summonses were issued, 1.1 million of them to commercial vehicles with New York licenses, and 2.6 million tickets were challenged. Of these, 1.7 million tickets, worth millions of dollars, were reduced or dismissed.
But the time and staff needed to fight these tickets hurt companies and the local economy, says Sheldon Glick, president of Contractors Against Unfair Taxation Instituted on New Yorkers, a group formed last year to press for changes in the city's parking regulations. Mr. Glick says that a few of the group's 100 members are being fined between $25,000 and $50,000 a year. "Some companies have a full-time employee fighting tickets," he says.
Others, like P. J. Mechanical, give the job to an employee with other responsibilities. And for smaller concerns, there are parking-ticket mercenaries, including brokers who fight tickets for companies and a marketer of a new computer software program.
 
'If I'm Guilty, I'll Pay'
 So far, the city says, parking tickets issued in the 1993 fiscal year have resulted in $196 million in fines from New York passenger vehicles and $30 million from New York commercial drivers in New York.
Most fines are for staying beyond the limit of three hours in commercial parking spots, which occupy nearly half the street parking space in midtown Manhattan. The limit was increased from 30 minutes about a year ago. Each ticket is $55.
Michael Primeggia, the Transportation Department's deputy commissioner of traffic, scoffs at charges that the city is seeking to to raise revenues by ticketing.
The department's role is loftier, he says: it is a detached arbitrator in the Hobbesian world of Manhattan where passenger cars, commercial vehicles, buses, and taxis, as well as diplomatic, government and press vehicles all fight for a piece of the street.
"It's a situation that's kind of exciting and quite fluid where you look at the various needs the city has and you provide space for all of those needs," he says. "Not one instead of another. You balance the need and competition for that space."
 
Computers Catch Errors
 Ms. Pabon, who never drives for the company but takes fines personally, says, "If I'm guilty, I'll pay. But the point is: If I'm parked for an hour, that's not long enough to make a delivery. On a service call, you just can't tell a customer, 'I've got to go and move my van.' "
Certainly few businesses can match Ms. Pabon's ticket-killer instincts.
"I used to fight, but I don't anymore," says Lee Battle, the vice president of Beehive Beer Distributors in Long Island City. "I was paying them anyway, so I'd just be losing time." Nowadays the company, which has 50 trucks making up to 800 deliveries a day, does not contest about $30,000 in fines a year, most of them incurred in Manhattan.
Near Union Square, in a small office he shares with an advertising agent, Glen Bolofsky, a publisher, says he has come up with something for the Mr. Battles in New York: a computer software program named A.L.A.R.M., which ferrets out mistakes in parking tickets and prints out dismissal requests to the P.V.B. "It comes with a guarantee that your annual parking ticket expenses will fall by 25 to 50 percent," he says.
Since he began selling the program five months ago, sales have totaled about $50,000. The software costs between $295 and $1,495, depending on the size of a company's fleet.
 
Wrong Color Blocks Fines
 Mark Conrad, a P.V.B. judge from 1987 to 1993 who was a consultant for the program, explains that certain errors on the tickets invalidate them immediately: a vehicle's wrong color, make, model, body type or license plate number or an imprecise location on the street.
The lack of a full registration expiration date was the most frequent error he saw during his years as a P.V.B. judge, Mr. Conrad said.
"On a given day," he said, "anywhere from 10 to 25 percent of summonses were really suspect."
Don Karl, fleet manager of Kraft Food Services's New York region, just paid $1,000 for the software program for his 50 delivery trucks in New York City.
Saving only a quarter of the $30,000 in fines he pays annually would mollify him -- never mind the psychological side-benefits. "Dealing with a large city you feel inept," he said. "But this system makes you feel in control."
Not everyone is so impressed. Mark Gerstle, a parking ticket broker, sneers at the computer program, which he cannot bring himself to call by name. Mr. Gerstle, who has built up a clientele of more than 100 over 21 years, claims to be the first full-time independent parking broker in New York, though with no one to keep track of how many brokers there are, it's a title impossible to check.
 
Problems Acknowledged
 Out of his Upper West Side office, he explains his method: old-fashioned diplomacy with the parking judge. "You can't have that tete-a-tete without being there," he said. "If you're talking paper to person, it's impersonal."
Mr. Gerstle, whose fees vary depending on how successful he is, said he was able to get more than a third of the tickets he handles for companies dismissed.
Joseph A. Spencer, the P.V.B. director, said he wanted to make the commercial adjudication center so easy to use that no company would feel the need to use a broker. But he conceded there were many problems. Working through the bureaucracy was too overwhelming for many, he said. Records were inaccurate. The system was too slow.
But the commissioner pointed to recent improvements. A clerk now appears at every hearing and records the decision in a computer database, for example; in the past, judges wrote down the decisions and records were often inaccurate.
"There's still some more progress to be made," he said. "We would like to make it less frustrating for people who come upon this for the first time."
 
Dangers of Overconfidence
 No matter what the changes are, some, like Ms. Pabon, will remain better at fighting tickets than others are.
Still, as she left the P.V.B. office recently, walking through a narrow hall lined with cardboard boxes stacked seven high and filled with three-year-old files, Ms. Pabon said that three years of fighting parking tickets had taught her not to grow overconfident.
Last November, her company, which has 56 vans, trucks and station wagons, received a ticket for an illegally parked Mercedes. The Mercedes, it turned out, belonged to a Connecticut driver with the same license plate number as one of her trucks in New York. But the P.V.B. insisted the company must have a Mercedes. And Ms. Pabon, normally so unruffled, despaired.
"Do you know how hard it is to prove you don't have a Mercedes?" she asked.

HEADLINE: In St. Petersburg, a Struggle for Room at the Top

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

 BODY:
Peter the Great built this city in a monumental act of will nearly three centuries ago. And in a similar vein, Sergei N. Nikeshin, one of St. Petersburg's new, rich Russian businessmen, is planning to build himself a 40-story skyscraper high above the city's haunting neo-classical architecture.
The city's intelligentsia wants him stopped. 
 "It is an abomination," said Dmitri S. Likhachev, 87, a historian of ancient Russian literature who is one of the country's most venerated scholars. He said the tower would do what even the Bolsheviks dared not. "It will ruin St. Petersburg's historic skyline."
While such fights occur in cities like Paris, London and New York between those who want to preserve architectural purity and those who want Trump Towers, the battle here pits intellectuals against Russians who got rich after Communism collapsed and are now reveling in their success. So the underlying tension is about class and pride and history.
Preservation of the city's many pastel palaces, rococo mansions and gold-domed churches is more than an esthetic choice in St. Petersburg. For many, it is the expression of the city's resistance to the Nazis and to Communism. And residents are highly sensitive about the status of a former capital described by the Russian writer Daniel Granin as "a great city with a provincial fate."
 
The Spoils of Freedom
 St. Petersburg writers and artists believed that they had won the war against Communism. But today, members of the intelligentsia, many of whom have lost their perks and pre-eminence, complain that the spoils of freedom are being sucked up by rough-hewn businessmen and mobsters.
"We are not moving toward capitalism in Russia," Mr. Likhachev said sorrowfully. "We are going to some kind of Arab or African system, where the money and power is in just a few hands."
Mr. Nikeshin, 35, said construction of the 40-story office complex, which he named the Peter the Great Tower, would begin in June. The project, which received the blessing of City Hall late last year, is not in the historic center of town, where the Winter Palace and St. Isaac's Cathedral are located. Instead, it will face the Gulf of Finland on the western edge of Vasilyevsky Island, where clusters of nine-story concrete-and-steel apartment buildings were erected under Khrushchev.
But the island's other side, on the banks of the Neva River, bears 18th-century landmarks like St. Petersburg University, which boasts Lenin and Raskolnikov, the murderer in Dostoyevsky's "Crime and Punishment," among its dropouts. The island is also where Mr. Likhachev's stately office, lined with portraits of Pushkin and Turgenev, is located.
 
Two Opposing Views
 Mr. Likhachev said he opposed the skyscraper because it would jut high above the city's low, undulating skyline of golden domes and slender spires and be an eyesore even from the Hermitage Museum three miles away.
Mr. Nikeshin said his office tower would "beautify" the city.
The Mayor is torn. A former law professor, Anatoly A. Sobchak was himself a member of the intelligentsia, and stood by Mr. Likhachev's side during the city's huge rally to protest the attempted hard-line Communist coup in August 1991.
To attract capital to his financially strapped city, Mayor Sobchak and his aides have forged tight alliances with foreign investors and Russian business people. But almost every development deal the city has struck, including an agreement with a French bank to convert Peter the Great's shipbuilding yard into a $500 million business and cultural center, has been stalled by political controversy.
Tellingly, one of the first major protest rallies in St. Petersburg after the fall of Communism was not about politics, but about architecture: in 1987 many thousands of people demonstrated against tearing down an old hotel where, among other things, the beloved poet Sergei Yesinin committed suicide. The facade was later reconstructed. (The city recently agreed to allow Holiday Inn to manage the hotel, the Astoria.)
 
Another Scandal
 Mr. Sobchak extended Mr. Nikeshin the equivalent of $1.3 million in credit to get his building started, and set off another scandal.
The city's chief architect, Deputy Mayor Oleg A. Kharchenko, has responded to criticism that he is turning the city into a Manhattan or a Hong Kong by rejecting the architects' first draft, which looked a little like a squat Empire State Building, and sketching his own version, topped by a cupola and spire. He said this would allow the building's silhouette to "blend."
Mr. Likhachev shuddered at the very idea, calling it "horrible."
Architecture is so emotional an issue here that each of the leading antagonists accused the other of the worst behavior imaginable -- Soviet. Mr. Kharchenko told Mr. Likhachev that criticizing a building he had not seen was like banning Boris Pasternak without having read "Dr. Zhivago."
Mr. Likhachev snapped back, "I haven't seen a tank either, but I can still say it was wrong to send tanks into Czechoslovakia."
 
Dismisses the Controversy
 Mr. Nikeshin, a tall, heavyset former construction engineer who turned a state construction company into the Corporation of the 20th Century Trust, dismissed the controversy. "Around here," he said,"someone is always against something or other."
He has hired a London architectural firm, William Mason & Partners, and a New York City structural engineering firm, Weiskopf & Pickworth, to help him fashion the "world-class office complex" that he said would cost around $120 million. Mr. Nikeshin, who is also running for the city legislature as a pro-business candidate, said he would personally secure 30 percent of the financing.
Seated in his Nevsky Prospekt office, where the couches are black leather, the walls sponge-painted, and the two security guards wear cobalt-blue double-breasted suits, Mr. Nikeshin said he did not mind being called nouveau riche.
"If I was building a private home or stashing my money in Switzerland, that would be nouveau riche," he said. "But I'm doing this for St. Petersburg."
People like Mr. Nikeshin do not often mix with Mr. Likhachev's set, but unlike the much larger city of Moscow, in St. Petersburg they sometimes meet -- if only to jostle one another on the crowded sidewalks of Nevsky Prospekt.
In one of the boulevard's better bookstores, a young woman in stretch pants and a sable parka was browsing. Next to her, Melita D. Krilova, a 73-year-old retired geologist with the posture of a dancer, sold a pile of rare books for $8.
"I hate to part with them," she said with a pained smile, "but we have to eat."
Mrs. Krilova, who like many other academics has all but lost her pension to inflation, said she "never dreamed" the end of Communism would lead to such "disequilibrium" between rich and poor.
She also said she never dreamed a skyscraper could be built in St. Petersburg.
"Surely," she said quietly, "people will protest."
But it is not clear what the opponents of Mr. Nikeshin's tower will actually do. Aleksandr V. Kobak, vice president of the St. Petersburg Cultural Foundation, a nonprofit organization, is strongly against the project.
Somewhat helplessly, he said he hoped that Prince Charles, an outspoken critic of modern architecture who is expected to visit in May, would attract Western interest to the cause.
Others put their hopes in Russia's economic disarray.
 
Lack of Money a Comfort?
 "My only comfort," said Semion I. Mikhailovsky, a professor of architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts, "is that, as usual, they probably won't find the money for it after all."
Other people, however, are less protective of the city's past.
"For heaven's sake, let them build it," said Viktor Y. Demetov, who works in a beer factory and lives in one of the modern apartment buildings near the site.
"It is stupid to stop it -- it could bring in more money." He paused, and smiled wistfully. "It might even be nice."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

SPECIAL EDUCATION'S MINORITY TRAP
Nearly two decades after Congress passed a law requiring public schools to educate all children with disabilities, providing extra money for smaller classes, special assistance for a variety of disabilities and individual attention, many education advocates say New York City's special education system, which involves 130,000 students, insures a second-class education, particularly for black boys, becoming a trap that incubates failure. At the heart of the issue is compelling evidence that black and Hispanic students are harmed, not helped, by special education. A1.
CARING FOR AGING PARENTS, AT A DISTANCE
Many people who must minister to elderly relatives from a distance are turning to referral services that provide information about care of the elderly, and to geriatric care managers who, for a fee, will shoulder many of the tasks families usually take on. A1.
 

NEW YORK CITY
 
FIGHT INTENSIFIES OVER SCHOOLS BUDGET
Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dug in their heels in the tug-of-war over the schools budget, with Mr. Cortines dismissing as unrealistic the Mayor's demand that 2,500 jobs be cut and the Mayor pushing a plan to dismantle the Board of Education. B2.
 
SUSPECTS IN KILLING TIED TO HOLDUPS
The police have linked the two men indicted in the killing of Officer Sean McDonald to 10 armed holdups in the Bronx and Manhattan in the last several months. B2.
 
STATE TO ALTER METHOD OF REPORTING AIDS
State health officials want to expand their system of reporting AIDS cases to try to avoid losing an estimated $9 million a year in Federal money, but advocates for people with H.I.V. say they fear a threat to confidentiality. B3.
 
LETTER BOMB HURTS BROOKLYN WOMAN
A 75-year-old woman was critically injured when a letter bomb delivered to her Brooklyn home exploded and punctured her stomach, postal inspectors said. Investigators said the package was addressed to her brother, but do not yet have a motive for the bombing or know why it was mailed to him at an address where he had not lived for years. B3.
 
REGION
 
HEIRESS'S FAMILY SEEKS HER CHILD
The sister of Anne Scripps Douglas, the heiress to a newspaper fortune who was slain three months ago by her husband, asked a court if she could become the guardian of Mrs. Douglas's orphaned 3-year-old daughter, Victoria. B4.
 
REACHING OUT TO JAZZ MUSICIANS IN NEED
A joint venture between the Jazz Foundation of America and Englewood Hospital and Medical Center provides free care and hospitalization for jazz musicians in need. B4.
 
MISSING WOMAN BOUGHT TICKET
A Long Island woman who vanished from a shopping mall 12 days ago while shopping for a dress for a bridal shower apparently purchased a plane ticket to Canada a week before she disappeared, the Nassau County police said. B2.

HEADLINE: Albany Talks Bogging Down Over Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 5

 BODY:
A sharp policy disagreement over whose taxes to cut has emerged as a central obstacle to a new state budget, now five days late, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders made clear today.
Five days after saying they had the outlines of a new budget, several issues that from the start had been viewed as vital were clearly still in dispute. In addition to the tax fight, budget negotiators were arguing over how to allocate aid to schools and how to divide construction money that New York City wants to repair schools and that other communities want for swimming pools and minor-league baseball stadiums. 
 The tax debate was the clearest policy schism. Mr. Cuomo has found himself in this campaign year allied with the Republicans who control the State Senate, saying the cut should be focused on a general reduction in the state business tax. On the other side was the Assembly's Democratic leader, who favored cuts directed to working-poor families and small businesses.
 
Lagging Economy
 Each side argued that tax cuts should be used to spur the state's lagging economy and make it more competitive with surrounding states. The Governor and the Republicans say their business-tax cuts would do this by encouraging businesses to expand in the state. But the Democrats in the Assembly say there is little evidence such a reduction would help create new jobs.
The dispute was made possible by the agreement on all sides that economic growth, even if not as great as the politicians would like in an election year, would be enough to produce more revenues than the Governor had said he anticipated as recently as two months ago.
Mr. Cuomo had said in his budget proposal that he expected enough revenue for $210 million in tax cuts, which he proposed to spend on a reduction in the corporate surcharge from 15 percent, to 12.5 percent, as well as a phaseout over several years of the state's 5 percent tax on hotel rooms costing more than $100 a night.
But the agreement that there would be more money available in the new $33.4 billion budget led the Republicans, with Mr. Cuomo's agreement, to say the surcharge should be reduced to 10 percent and the hotel tax eliminated this year.
 
Governor's Position
 "My position is if you stay with the tax cuts I recommended, like the hotel tax and the corporate surcharge, I will have no difficulties at all," Mr. Cuomo said.
But the Democrats who control the Assembly have advanced two entirely different tax-cut ideas: one to reduce corporate taxes on certain types of small companies and another to give tax credits to companies that create new jobs. The Assembly Democrats have also called for expanding a proposal by the Governor to create tax credits for working-poor families. "They're pushing for corporate welfare," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
The lawmakers and Mr. Cuomo are haggling over additional revenue from better-than-anticipated tax collections for the fiscal year ended on March 31. Just how much more revenue was in dispute, with several hundred million dollars separating the smaller estimates from the Assembly and the larger estimates from the Senate. That difference is not huge in a $33 billion state budget, but it is enough to pay for tax cuts or spending that constituents might notice.
Disputes have even broken out on taxes yet to be collected. Some lawmakers argued that the state should anticipate a windfall of $26 million to $78 million in taxes from the estate of Roy H. Park, founder of a newspaper publishing company, who died last fall. Mr. Cuomo has said there is no evidence the state will get any taxes from the estate. "Someone wrote a story saying this guy died upstate, that he will owe $78 million, and so the Legislature said, 'Here's $78 million we can spend,' " Mr. Cuomo said last week. "This guy's not even cold."
 
Construction Projects
 The Assembly Democrats and Senate Republicans were also locked in a fight today over how to allocate hundreds of millions in construction and maintenance projects around the state. In longstanding Albany tradition, the fight has turned on whether New York City is receiving too much or too little of state programs.
The Assembly has called for financing the repair of dilapidated schools in New York City and its suburbs, where most Democratic lawmakers live, as well as building sports stadiums in some upstate cities. But the Senate has proposed building minor-league baseball stadiums, pools, soccer fields and other sports centers in the suburbs, upstate towns and rural areas they represent.
 
'It's Preposterous'
 Mr. Silver said today that Senate negotiators have argued that school maintenance money for New York City should be deducted from the city's total share of state aid to schools. Mr. Silver objected, saying the city already did not receive its fair share of school aid.
"It's preposterous," Mr. Silver said. "If school maintenance should come out of school aid for the city, then the value of their soccer stadium and pool should come out of Long Island's share of school aid."
He was referring to two proposals on the Senate's list of capital projects: a $25 million Olympic-size pool and an approximately $20 million soccer stadium, both to be built near Hofstra University in Hempstead in Nassau County. Several powerful Senate Republicans, including the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, come from Nassau County.
A spokesman for Mr. Marino, John A. McArdle, said the Senator believes the stadiums will attract international sporting events and help stimulate Long Island's economy. But Mr. Marino's first priority, he said, is cutting taxes.
 
Business Tax Cuts
 Mr. Marino has proposed tax cuts worth $700 million in the coming fiscal year, mostly for businesses. But many Republicans acknowledge there might not be enough additional revenue to make cuts that deep.
Mr. Silver said the Assembly's $200 million tax-cut package includes giving low-income families an earned-income credit equal to 10 percent of a similar Federal tax credit this tax year, then doubling the credit the next year. The proposal would double a tax credit proposed by Mr. Cuomo.
The Assembly Democrats have also urged cutting a surcharge on the taxes of small companies owned by 35 or fewer partners. Those partners pay income taxes on company earnings, but the companies also pay additional corporate taxes. Mr. Silver said the two-tier system was unfair.

HEADLINE: Texan Tries For Victory As New Sort Of Democrat

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 5

 BODY:
There is a joke among some Texas Democrats these days that the party is so desperate to recapture Lloyd Bentsen's Senate seat that it is on the verge of nominating a Republican to do it.
But the man to whom the joke refers, Richard W. Fisher, a wealthy Dallas investor, could stake a better claim as a sort of Zelig of recent American history, variously seen side by side with Democrats, Republicans and even Ross Perot. 
 As he begins to gather momentum in his effort to capture the nomination in a bitter primary runoff with former State Attorney General Jim Mattox next Tuesday, the candidacy of Mr. Fisher has become an test of whether a self-styled "New Democrat" can vault to the Senate by emphasizing his broad appeal to Republicans and independents, or whether his campaign will go down in flames as an object lesson in party loyalty.
The 45-year-old Mr. Fisher, who was an aide to Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal in the Carter Administration, has donated thousands of dollars to candidates from both parties over the years, including five of the Democrats who sought the Presidential nomination in 1988.
 
Interviewed for Bush
 He also interviewed for a unspecified job in the Bush Administration and wrote a $1,000 check to the Bush-Quayle re-election campaign in 1991. He says the contribution was supposed to be from his wife, Nancy Collins Fisher, a Bush family friend and the daughter of Jim Collins, a late Republican Congressman from Dallas. At his request, he says, the campaign returned his check, and Mrs. Fisher wrote one instead.
Then, in 1992, he emerged as a top adviser to a fellow Dallasite, Mr. Perot, "a good family friend" who attended Mr. Fisher's wedding more than 20 years ago. When Mr. Fisher last year ran for office for the first time, in a bid financed with $2 million of his own money, commercials featured him holding Mr. Perot's book, "United We Stand." Mr. Fisher came in fifth in the bipartisan special election to replace Mr. Bentsen in the Senate; the winner was Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Republican.
But just days after the 1992 Presidential election, Mr. Fisher also showed up sitting next to Bill Clinton at the economic conference the President-elect held in Little Rock, Ark. Mr. Fisher has known Mr. Clinton since the mid-1980's, when they worked to form the Democratic Leadership Council, a centrist group.
In his new bid for a Senate seat that had been in Democratic hands from Reconstruction until last year, Mr. Fisher's campaign literature features a picture of him with a smiling Mr. Clinton at the White House. If Mr. Fisher wins the nomination he will next face Mrs. Hutchison, who was recently acquitted on charges she had misused her former State Treasurer's post.
 
Democrat in His Heart
 Though he resolutely declines to say whom he voted for in the most recent Presidential election, only that it was not Mr. Bush, Mr. Fisher insists that in his heart he has always been a Democrat. Even when he worked for Mr. Perot, he adds, his real goal was to spur the Democrats to change.
"This is the major gut issue -- how do we rejuvenate my party?" he said in an interview. "We have lost all the small-business women and men in Texas. We've scared them away. That's been the backbone of our party. We've scared away the ranchers and the farmers. We're losing the up-and-coming professional classes."
Mr. Fisher, a Harvard-, Stanford- and Oxford-educated economist who grew wealthy managing rich clients' money and boasts that he can out-rope anybody who has run for the office, dismisses suggestions that he has ever betrayed his party roots.
"The old definitions of liberal-conservative, even Republican-Democrat, are being blurred," he said. "I do believe in the Jeffersonian-Jackson creed. That's the foundation of my party. I believe it has to be brought to the age of Clinton and Gore and beyond. I think the President has struggled with that himself."
As for his contributions to several candidates in the crowded Democratic Presidential field of 1988, he says, "I knew practically every dog in that hunt." Dick and Jane Gephardt slept at his house once, Paul Simon was a friend of his father-in-law's, and Gary Hart had jokingly promised to make him Treasury Secretary.
Mr. Fisher emphasizes decidedly new-Democratic themes, like welfare reform. Many Democrats have argued that Mr. Fisher, less liberal that Mr. Mattox, would be a stronger candidate in the general election.
 
'He's Bob Roberts'
 Still, he has clearly had to battle criticism that he is simply riding with the political winds.
"Fisher is like a parody of what's wrong with politics," Molly Ivins, the Texas writer, scoffed in her syndicated column recently. "He's Bob Roberts, he's Bob Forehead. He doesn't stand for anything, he doesn't believe in anything, he just goes around saying buzzwords like 'job creation' and 'the future.' "
Mr. Fisher stunned Texas's political world when he finished just behind Mr. Mattox in the March 8 primary, 41 percent to 38 percent, forcing the runoff next Tuesday. The man who had fashioned himself as Mr. Bentsen's political heir, Michael A. Andrews, a moderate Houston Congressman, was forced out of the race. Mr. Bentsen had resigned the seat to become Treasury Secretary.
Many political experts here think that Mr. Fisher is the favorite to win the runoff because he has more appeal to Mr. Andrews's voters than does Mr. Mattox and has more money to spend in the closing days. In the battle over the heavily Democratic vote in South Texas, Mr. Fisher, who spent part of his childhood in Mexico and Spain, uses commercials featuring him speaking fluent Spanish. He swept nearly all the border counties in the March vote.
Other experts, however, say the turnout on Tuesday will be heavy with hardcore Democrats, sometimes called the "Yellow Dog Democrats" because they would rather vote for a canine than any Republican, who would tend to vote for Mr. Mattox.
 
'Tricky Primary Message'
 "Fisher's got a great general-election message, but it's a tricky primary message," said Mark McKinnon, a Democratic consultant in Austin who is not working for either candidate.
And that is why Mr. Mattox has been hammering away at Mr. Fisher's party credentials. "He really is a Republican and a political opportunist with absolutely no loyalty to the Democratic Party," said the 50-year-old Mr. Mattox.
The campaign has been venomous. Mr. Mattox has all but called Mr. Fisher a racist for belonging to a Dallas country club that has no black members. And Mr. Fisher has reminded voters that Mr. Mattox, in his 1990 campaign for governor, made unsubstantiated accusations that Ann W. Richards, the ultimate victor, had once been treated for cocaine abuse.
Mr. Fisher says he is steeled for criticism.
Every morning, he said, "when I wake up and I look in the mirror, I know who I am. And I say a little-bitty chant. I got it from Marian Wright Edelman, by the way. When she gave a speech -- she didn't give it to me personally.
" 'If you're afraid of criticism, don't say anything, don't do anything, and don't be anything.' I swear, every time I enter into a debate or I get up in the morning, I chant that to myself, because I know I am going to be heavily criticized."

HEADLINE: Hispanic Families Use Alternatives to Day Care, Study Finds

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA 

 BODY:
Hispanic families use preschools and day care centers much less than those of other ethnic groups, apparently because of cultural preferences for family-like care, a new Harvard University study says. This finding, the study's authors say, suggests that government should be putting more child-care money into programs like vouchers that accommodate parental choices rather than concentrating on preschool programs like Head Start.
The researchers at Harvard's Graduate School of Education found that among families with a mother employed full time outside the home, 32 percent of the Hispanic families surveyed placed children in preschools or day care centers, compared with 55 percent of the black families and 43 percent of the white families surveyed. 
 Many Hispanic families appear to be deliberately avoiding such care; in a previous study researchers found no shortages of preschools or day care centers in counties with large Hispanic populations. The new research indicates that Hispanic families often prefer asking relatives to watch their children or placing youngsters in family day care, in which one person watches a number of children in a home.
"This raises questions about the progressive, liberal view that it's better to have institutionalized care," said Bruce Fuller, an education professor at Harvard and one of the study's four authors, who will present the results next week at an education meeting in Seattle.
 
Questions of Discrimination
 Professor Fuller suggested that President Clinton's campaign pledge to expand Head Start to serve all eligible children might discriminate against some Hispanic families. "If we put all our eggs in the Head Start basket, it will economically penalize parents who prefer non-Head Start arrangements," he said.
Professor Fuller advocates spending more government money on vouchers, so that parents can buy the kind of child care they want, and improving the quality of family day care. Conservative groups led a successful drive to include vouchers in the 1990 child-care block grants.
Head Start officials challenged Professor Fuller's recommendations. Most educators believe that preschool prepares children for elementary school. "To be successful, you've got to know and be exposed to all cultures and values," said Sarah Greene, the chief executive officer of the National Head Start Association. "That's what Head Start's about: giving minority groups exposures they might not otherwise have."
Many Hispanic families do enroll in Head Start programs. Gregg Powell, Head Start's director of research and evaluation, said that of the 713,903 children in Head Start in the fiscal year 1993, 24 percent were Hispanic, 36 percent black and 33 percent white.
 
Family Preferences
 But other child-care experts said the study bolstered their belief that government policies need to accommodate family preferences. "On this one, I think the conservatives were right, and even this Administration seems to accept that," said Douglas J. Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. "It may not only be the most financially efficient, but may be the most socially appropriate approach."
In fact, President Clinton has called for increased financing for both child-care block grants and Head Start, although the Head Start increase would be larger.
The research may also contribute to the debate about overhauling the welfare system, because Hispanic mothers on welfare may resist taking jobs when their children are young or try to avoid placing those children in formal day care centers, Professor Fuller said.
The Harvard study drew on a survey of families with children ages 3 to 5 conducted in 1991 by the National Center for Education Statistics, a research arm of the Department of Education. Using a national sample of 5,095 families, the Harvard researchers re-analyzed the data to examine what influenced choices of child care. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percentage points.
 
Education Level a Factor
 The researchers found that two-parent families and families with relatives living in their households tended to use day care centers less than other families surveyed. Hispanic families were more likely than black families to be two-parent households (75 percent versus 45 percent) and were more likely than white families to have relatives living with them.
More important in the choice of day care were parents' education levels and their emphasis on early literacy. The better educated the parents, the more likely they were to place their children in preschools, the researchers found, and compared with black or white parents, fewer Hispanic parents had any post-secondary education. Hispanic parents were also less likely than white parents to read to their children once a day or visit the library with them.
But a cultural preference for keeping children in a warm and family-like atmosphere seemed to play a large role in Hispanic families' choice of day care, an analysis of the data showed. To gain insight into this issue, the Harvard researchers conducted in-depth interviews with four Hispanic families over two years, a sample too small to be reliable, yet still suggestive to policymakers.
 
'A Kind of Foreign Turf'
 The families said, for example, that they found many day care centers or preschools too formal and cold. Some said they chose family day care because they thought it would enable them to build a more personal relationship with the person caring for their children. And some families said they preferred to keep their children in a Spanish-speaking, or at least a bilingual, environment when they were young.
"The reasons parents gave are very indicative of the problem," said Elizabeth Weiser Ramirez, an official of Aspira, an organization that serves Hispanic youth. "They say, in essence, that a day care center is a kind of foreign turf."
Professor Fuller noted, "The evidence does suggest that the learning gains for kids are going to be higher in quality preschools." But he added, "I don't think anyone's taking into account how these may erode the more indigenous ways of raising kids."
