HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Longtime Hewlett Executive Named Novell Chief

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5

 BODY:
Novell Inc. today named Robert J. Frankenberg to succeed Raymond J. Noorda as chief executive.
Mr. Frankenberg, who is 46, has spent his entire 25-year career at the Hewlett-Packard Company, most recently as the head of its personal computer business. He takes command of Novell at the most challenging time since Mr. Noorda turned the struggling start-up company around a decade ago. 
 Mr. Frankenberg was named president and chief executive, not chief operating officer, as previously reported; Mr. Noorda, who will turn 70 in June, continues as chairman.
The company is dissolving its office of the president, whose former members, Mary M. Burnside, chief operating officer, and James R. Tolonen, chief financial officer, will continue their responsibilities and report to Mr. Frankenberg.
 
News Broadly Leaked

Shares of Novell rose $1.50, to $18.375, in Nasdaq trading today in anticipation of the announcement. Although Novell released its announcement after the close of the market, it had been broadly leaked.
In addition to the market's decline over all, Novell shares had been pounded in recent weeks by investor uncertainty about the company's $1.5 billion acquisition of the Wordperfect Corporation and the Quattro Pro spreadsheet product of Borland International Inc.
Long the leader in software for connecting personal computers on networks, Novell has, through those acquisitions, put itself in more direct competition with the Microsoft Corporation in application programs, like word processors and spreadsheets, and operating systems, which control basic computer and network functions.
Although speculation about Mr. Frankenberg's joining Novell had appeared in the trade press for months, he and Mr. Noorda said in a telephone interview that serious discussions about the move had begun just three weeks ago. That was before the Wordperfect deal, which Mr. Frankenberg said he "very enthusiastic about."
"For me, it was a pivotal item in my decision to join Novell because it makes possible an entirely new category of networked applications which no one else can provide," he said.
As general manager of Hewlett-Packard's personal information products group, Mr. Frankenberg is credited with having revived the company's struggling personal computer unit. He has been the company's liaison with Novell on various partnerships and joint projects.
"He'll bring an understanding of how to deal with big corporate customers, which Novell needs, as well as a lot of understanding of mobile computing, which will be important to Novell's future," said Heidi Dix, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "He does have his work cut out for him; Novell has done a lot of stuff lately but they haven't been real good at following through."
Even before the controversial deal for Wordperfect, Novell was straining to rationalize its acquisition in June 1993 of Unix Systems Laboratories from A.T.& T. in a stock swap valued at about $320 million. While presenting Unix, long the preferred operating system software for technical computing, as an "open" alternative to Microsoft's dominant MS-DOS and Windows, Novell gave the rights to the Unix name and specifications to an industry consortium.
 
Core Product Under Attack
 At the same time, Novell's core product, the Netware operating system, has come under fresh attack by Microsoft's Windows NT, a new operating system with networking.
Large customers have deferred moving to the latest version of Netware, but that reflects not so much the impact of Windows NT than the difficulties inherent in a big systems software upgrade. As a result, Novell earnings have disappointed Wall Street analysts for several quarters. Write-offs associated with Novell's acquisitions resulted in a net loss of $35 million in the 1993 fiscal year, which ended on Oct. 30.
"Bob's a superb manager, but he's walking into a real quagmire because of Ray's decision to try to go head to head with Microsoft," said Rich Edwards, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens & Company, who worked with Mr. Frankenberg at Hewlett-Packard from 1975 to 1983.
Although Novell's somewhat unusual corporate culture stresses cooperation with competing companies and explicitly places customers' and employees' interests ahead of shareholders, Mr. Noorda said he thought his successor would have no problem fitting in.
"We've always modeled ourselves after Hewlett-Packard," he said. "I and Novell have long had a good relationship with Bob and with H.P. in general."
Mr. Frankenberg joined Hewlett-Packard in 1969 as a manufacturing technician and got a bachelor's degree in computer engineering from San Jose State University in 1974. He is married, with two children.

HEADLINE: Hope Offered on Wider Use of Alzheimer's Drug

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 5

 BODY:
Many Alzheimer's patients who find they cannot tolerate the only drug approved for treating the disease may be able to use it if they stop taking it briefly, then start again, researchers report.
Liver abnormalities developed in 29 percent of patients who took the drug, tacrine, but the disorders disappeared a few weeks after the drug was stopped, the researchers said. Their findings appear in the issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association being published on Wednesday. 
 In 87 percent of the patients who then began taking the drug again, the abnormalities never returned, said the study, which was led by a clinical scientist for the drug's maker, the Warner-Lambert Company.
The study of tacrine involved 663 patients with mild to moderate cases of Alzheimer's disease. It found small but meaningful benefits in thinking skills among some patients taking the drug compared with patients who received a dummy drug.
Tacrine only sets the clock back on the advance of Alzheimer's disease by about six months, however. After that, decline continues.
"Improvement, it needs to be emphasized, appears to be temporary," said Dr. Barry Reisberg, a member of the medical and scientific advisory board of the Alzheimer's Association. He was not involved in the study.
Tacrine, the only treatment for Alzheimer's disease, was approved in September by the Food and Drug Administration. Warner-Lambert said 50,000 to 60,000 patients are taking the drug.
More than one-third of the study's patients quit taking tacrine because of the side effects, which include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain, as well as the liver abnormalities. But many were able to resume taking it later, sometimes at lower levels, according to the study.
"The majority of patients can tolerate it," said Margaret J. Knapp, a clinical scientist with the Parke-Davis division of Warner-Lambert.
Dr. Knapp led the study, which formed the basis for F.D.A.'s approval of tacrine. Results had not been made public previously, she said at a news conference today at the Williams Club in Manhattan.
 
No Permanent Damage
 A separate study, also published in The Journal of The American Medical Association and led by Dr. Paul B. Watkins of the University of Michigan, found that no permanent liver damage resulted from taking tacrine.
Still another study found a correlation between Alzheimer's and economic status. It suggested that people with higher educational and job levels may have a reduced risk.
The highly educated may have more "reserves" of skills or coping mechanisms that could delay the disease, said the researchers, who were led by Yaakov Stern of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

HEADLINE: Weak Canadian Dollar Raises Rates, Limits Jobs

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 5

 BODY:
Though Canada may deserve plaudits for its low inflation rate, a plummeting Canadian dollar has forced interest rates higher, threatening recovery from the double-digit unemployment lingering after the country's most severe recession since World War II.
The currency's dive to its lowest point in almost eight years mainly reflects growing nervousness over the Canadian Government's ability to control the ballooning public debt. 
 The risk of secession by Quebec is also rattling foreign investors. If separatists, whom polls now strongly favor, win province elections this year, there is concern that they could persuade a majority of Quebecers to say yes to sovereignty for the province in a referendum.
 
Bank Economist Is Vexed
 "Canada's chronic dependence on foreign capital to finance bloated payment shortfalls leaves the financial markets very exposed to sudden shifts in investor confidence," said Aron Gampel assistant chief economist at the Bank of Nova Scotia.
On Monday, the exchange rate of the Canadian dollar fell to 71.60 cents, its lowest point relative to American currency since August 1986. It recovered slightly today to 72.34 cents, still about 3 cents below its value at the beginning of March. By contrast, the Canadian dollar was worth nearly 90 cents at the end of 1991.
As a result, interest rates, including those for mortgages and installment payments for cars and home appliances, have jumped one to two percentage points since early March.
Although rates have also climbed in the United States, the rise has been more dramatic in Canada because it depends more on foreign capital to finance its deficits.
As a percentage of the gross domestic product, both the balance-of-payments and the budget deficits in Canada are running twice as high as comparable American deficits.
Canada's reliance on foreign borrowing, chiefly from the United States, to finance national health, unemployment insurance and other domestic programs has caused the level of foreign debt to rise two-and-a-half times since the early 1980's.
Foreign debt stood at 252.8 billion Canadian dollars by the end of 1993, representing 8,792.61 Canadian dollars for every person in this country, more than three times the American foreign debt on a per-capita basis.
Canada has one of the lowest inflation rates in the world. At 1.8 percent, it is half that of the United States. Yet Canadians -- saddled with their huge debt, which is now raising questions of creditworthiness -- must pay one to two percentage points more to borrow money than Americans.
Many critics blame the Liberal Government's budget, announced by Finance Minister Paul Martin on Feb. 22. for the lack of deep spending cuts. Major retrenchment occurred only in defense, which is not a big consumer of Canadian dollars.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at the investment firm of Burns, Fry, echoing the view of many on Bay Street, Toronto's and Canada's financial center, said the currency weakness "is reflective of a loss of confidence in our Government's ability to significantly reduce the budget deficit."
Mr. Martin projected a budget deficit in the new fiscal year, which began on April 1, at 39.7 billion Canadian dollars, down from 45.7 billion in the year just ended. But the increased yields of Canadian Government bonds and Treasury bills since February have already forced a rise of a billion to two billion Canadian dollars in annual debt-servicing costs, wiping out much of the expected savings.
Mr. Martin says his budget was intended to withstand the sort of volatility that has shaken the currency market. "We are on track for our deficit targets," he recently said in the House of Commons, saying there is "sufficient room to maneuver."
Most economists from private business do not agree. They say the overall federal debt of 570 billion Canadian dollars translates almost immediately into enormous added interest costs. Every rise of one percentage point in interest rates adds about 1.7 billion Canadian dollars to the deficit.
Mr. Martin wants to reduce the deficit to 3 percent of the gross domestic product by 1996. In the fiscal year that just ended, the deficit was 6.4 percent of G.D.P., compared with 3.9 percent in the United States.
 
Bond Raters Displeased, Too
 Canada's financial imbroglio has not escaped the notice of bond-rating services, three of which have downgraded Canadian debt. The latest to do so was the Toronto-based Dominion Bond Rating Service Ltd. Dominion lowered Canada's foreign-currency debt rating to AA from AAA. In a statement explaining its action, it said that if Mr. Martin wanted the AAA rating restored, "meaningful expense reductions must be achieved."
The Canadian Bond Rating Service Inc. of Montreal a year ago lowered all Federal debt to AA+ from AAA. In October 1992, Standard & Poor downgraded the foreign currency debt from AAA. Moody's Investors Service still regards all Canadian Government debt as triple A.
The higher interest rates needed to attract money from abroad compound the problems of reducing the deficit and put a brake on consumption, which could derail Canada's fragile economic recovery.
The five-month-old Liberal Cabinet had counted on economic growth to put Canadians back to work. Although by economists' measurements, the recession officially ended in 1992, Canada still has more than 11 percent unemployment, compared with 6.5 percent in the United States.
A positive element is the help that the cheaper Canadian dollar is giving to exports, especially goods sold in the United States. Canada's American trade surplus is at a record $15.8 billion, although its deficit with the rest of the world lowers the overall surplus to $8.6 billion. To balance all its international accounts, including interest payments, Canada would need a trade surplus of more than $25 billion, at the current exchange rate.
The decline in the Canadian dollar is felt by businessmen like Serge Racine, chief executive of Shermag Inc., a furniture manufacturer in Sherbrooke, Quebec. Mr. Racine's business last year increased its sales 90 percent, and this year he projects a further gain of 50 to 60 percent, chiefly as a result of American business.
But Mr. Racine talks about "imported inflation," because Shermag buys hardwood lumber and fabric in the United States for its dining room and bedroom sets.
"We don't want the dollar rate getting too low," he said, "because then our costs start really going up."

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
The Clintons' Health Care Nemesis: The Man Behind 'Harry and Louise'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
In the history of the health care wars, "Harry and Louise" may well go down as the killer yuppies.
The couple, 40-something suburbanites fretting about big changes in health care in an advertising campaign for the Health Insurance Association of America, are now widely viewed as one of the most effective attacks to date on the Clinton health plan. To the Administration and its allies, the ads symbolize an industry desperately fighting change -- and willing to terrify the public to do so. 
 But the man who brought the public the $10 million "Harry and Louise" campaign, Bill Gradison, the president of the Health Insurance Association of America, says he sleeps very well at night, thank you.
Mr. Gradison, an amiable former Congressman from Ohio who specialized in health issues during his 18 years in the House -- and who was widely considered a good guy by advocates of health care restructuring -- refuses to be cast as the arch-enemy of reform.
In perhaps a commentary on modern political life, Mr. Gradison said that he cares deeply about health care and wanted to be a player in its restructuring but that he had to leave Congress and become a lobbyist to do so.
 
He Sees a Broad Fight
 Serene in his archetypal corner office overlooking the legal and lobbying canyons of Connecticut Avenue, he contends that his organization is simply trying to prevent a disastrous health plan from being inflicted on the American public -- and the American insurance industry.
Mr. Gradison says his organization was ignored by the White House as the Clinton plan was being developed. Later, he says, it was accused of "everything but child abuse" when the Clintons took their plan to the public.
"We're big boys; we can deal with this," he said. "But they seem to prefer us to have as an enemy." Mr. Gradison said he "regrets that it was necessary" to unleash the anxious yuppies, but with a set of "survival issues" at stake, he argues, his group had no choice.
"Being in the Rose Garden is not our objective," he said, referring to the ceremony site where all the favored parties gather to celebrate the signing of a bill into law. "It's getting a workable bill to insure that every American is covered by private health insurance."
These days, every interest group trying to influence the health care bill faces similar decisions. Should they quietly keep trying to change the Administration's mind, mount a tough campaign aimed at the public, concentrate on the relevant Congressional committees? Nobody wants to be on the wrong side of history, but, as Mr. Gradison suggests, nobody wants to be standing in the Rose Garden next fall, picking up souvenir pens from the signing of a bill they hate.
 
All-Out Attack
 Amid all this delicate maneuvering, the Health Insurance Association has become an exemplar of the empty-the-missile-silos approach.
Mr. Gradison and his organization have been chastised by former Congressional colleagues -- "in public, yes, but not in private," he says, a tad defensively -- assailed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, even parodied by the Clintons at a recent Washington dinner as "the Coalition to Scare Your Pants Off."
"H.I.A.A. has clearly been the pit bull in the fight against health care reform," says Paul Begala, political adviser to the White House. Senator Jay Rockefeller, the West Virginia Democrat and Clinton ally who is also a staunch advocate of health care restructuring, said: "I think the role they've played has been significant, and I think it's been destructive. He's done damage, and nobody's had the money to counter it."
In a recent interview, Mr. Gradison seemed more the moderate, reasonable Republican than the pit bull from inside the Beltway. He noted that his organization totally supported the President's goal of "guaranteeing private health insurance" for every American.
"The notion that the Government is going to come along and require people to buy what we have to sell is rather appealing," he said, "as long as it's set up on a basis that permits us to stay in those markets and be able to raise the capital and go out there and compete."
 
Critics See Transparency

Critics say the insurance industry's objections are transparent enough: It is perfectly content to sell insurance to big new markets, but wants to do so on its own terms, without an array of new rules on how much it can charge, whom it must insure and the like. Lorrie McHugh, a spokeswoman for the White House on health, said: "H.I.A.A. sees that the reform process is moving forward, and they want to maintain the status quo."
The Health Insurance Association has concentrated its fire on two central features of the Clinton plan. One is the regional insurance purchasing pools known as health alliances, agencies through which about 70 percent of Americans would be required to purchase their coverage. The other target is the system of price controls on insurance premiums that would be administered through the alliances.
The association's advertising has presented those alliances as a terrifying new intrusion by government into the private health insurance market, one that could limit people's choices on health care and force them to deal with a new bureaucracy. The Administration and its allies deny those accusations.
The insurance industry is not a united front behind "Harry and Louise." The biggest insurance companies are considered to be well positioned for a "managed competition" system like that envisioned by the Clinton Administration's plan. The system would concentrate the purchasing power of consumers and force health companies to vie for their business on the basis of cost and quality. Over the last few years, the five biggest insurance companies have split away from the health insurance association to pursue their own interests.
The association, on the other hand, has many small and medium-size companies among its 270 members, which might have a hard time competing in this vast, newly reorganized market.
If the aggressiveness of the association's campaign surprised Washington, the man chosen to lead it was a stunner. Mr. Gradison, first elected to the House in 1974, had just won re-election in 1992 when he announced that he was retiring to go to work for the organization. He was a senior member of the House Ways and Means Committee and had been the ranking Republican on its Subcommittee on Health.
 
'Dedicated to Health Care'
 "He was one of the most respected people up there -- dedicated to health care and interested in working in a bipartisan manner," said John Rother, director of legislative affairs for the American Association of Retired Persons.
Thomas Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, said, "The hard-edged position, the aggressive stand, are just not characteristic of his style as a legislator."
Speculation abounded on why he took the job, from a desire to earn more money (the Health Insurance Association will not say what his salary is) to frustration with the hard lot of trying to make policy as a House Republican in an era of seemingly permanent Democratic majorities.
William Frenzel, another longtime Republican member of the House who recently retired, said, "When you sit down with Pete Stark or Henry Waxman" -- two Democratic subcommittee chairmen -- "they say, 'How many votes have you got?' And Republicans always have to say, 'not enough.' So they roll you."
Mr. Frenzel added with a chuckle, "When Clinton said that to H.I.A.A., they said, 'O.K., we'll see you on television,' and they roughed them up a little bit."
The 65-year-old Mr. Gradison said the reasons for his shift were simple: He was at an age where "if I was going to try something new, I'd better get started on it."
He said he could see that the nation was about to get moving on health care restructuring, and he wanted to be involved. At the same time, the defeat of President George Bush, a classmate at Yale, meant that he "would not have the kind of close working relations with the White House that I had had."
 
A Player From the Outside
 He added: "I didn't leave in frustration or anything like that. I've worked a long time to try to understand health issues, and I wanted to be a player. It was that simple. If President Bush had been re-elected, I believe I would have been a player. I was less certain with this new group."
He has, in fact, become a player. His advertising campaign has had such an effect that there is talk of a backlash. The last "Harry and Louise" round of commercials finished up about a month ago, and there are no plans for a reprise. "We're encouraged that on our issues we're making progress," he said, "and that's all we're trying to do."
He added: "Our worst fear would be no action. We want legislation passed. We'd like to know the ground rules for competition. It's a little hard to be in this business with plans floating around ranging from ones that would put you out of business entirely to ones that would put you at the tender mercies of some new state agency, which is mandatory alliances."

HEADLINE: Cherokee Losing Chief Who Revitalized Tribe

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TAHLEQUAH, Okla., April 5

 BODY:
Wilma P. Mankiller, who is widely credited with revitalizing the Cherokee Nation in the last 10 years, has announced that she is resigning as the tribe's principal chief.
During her tenure as head of the second-largest nonassimilated tribe in the United States, after the Navajo, Chief Mankiller appeared before Congressional committees dozens of times, met with three Presidents and established herself as one of the premier authorities on Indian affairs. 
 The 48-year-old chief told about 500 tribal employees on Monday that she would not seek re-election next year.
"Almost all of my life I've been blessed with the ability to know when it's time to make a change," she said. "I've come to the point where I feel certain that it's time for another change for myself and the Cherokee Nation."
 
A Time to Every Purpose
 After citing the biblical passage, "To every thing there is a season," she added, "My season here is coming to an end."
Ms. Mankiller cut her speech short when employees began crying, and she, too, wept when employees rose to their feet in applause and met her with handshakes and hugs.
When Ms. Mankiller began working for the Cherokee Nation in the 1970's, after participating in the occupation of Alcatraz island in 1969, the tribe had fewer than 10,000 members.
She was elected deputy chef in 1983 and became the first woman to lead the tribe when she was appointed chief in 1985. She was elected to a four-year term in 1987 and re-elected with 83 percent of the vote in 1991.
 
Evidence of Growth
 During her tenure, membership increased from 55,000 to 156,000 and the number of tribal employees nearly doubled, to 1,271. The budget is $86 million, up from $44 million in 1986. The tribe added three health centers and nine children's programs.
She has testified before Congress on issues ranging from Indian sovereignty to health care.
Ms. Mankiller said she would stay active in Indian affairs. "You don't have to have a title or a position to be effective," she said.
After taking part in the Alcatraz occupation -- a failed attempt by Indians to gain title to the island, which had been the site of a Federal prison -- Ms. Mankiller left California in 1977 to return to Cherokee land.
With no money, car or job, she started as a volunteer and later headed economic and community development programs before becoming deputy chief.
Ms. Mankiller was severely injured in an automobile accident in 1979 and underwent 17 operations. She also suffers from myasthenia gravis, a disease of the nervous system, and underwent a kidney transplant in 1990. But she said her health was not a factor in her decision to retire.

HEADLINE: Stock Market Diplomacy;
Clinton's Foreign Policy Includes a Regard For How a Move Plays in Global Trading

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration weighs whether to revoke China's preferential trade status and whether to impose trade sanctions on Japan, a new factor is creeping into its calculations: What impact would such moves have on already volatile global stock and bond markets?
The diplomacy of the stock market is an increasingly important calculation for American officials. Fifteen years ago, the impact of a foreign policy decision on the stock and bond markets might only have been a small consideration. But now it is being taken much more seriously. 
 This is because American interest rates, growth rates and pension funds are more directly tied to Asian and European economies and their financial markets. A foreign policy decision in Washington can affect investors in Asia, which then reverberates on Wall Street and Main Street. This linkage is especially on the minds of Administration officials as the world's markets gyrate wildly, as they have in recent weeks.
"Whenever you have this kind of instability it creates caution and conservatism in decision makers," David Hale, the chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, said. "There is so much integration now, everyone is terrified of being blamed for causing a global stock market crash."
Already, some American officials shudder at the thought of what they would do if today, and not June 3, were the day President Clinton had to decide whether to extend China's most-favored-nation trade status -- knowing that a revocation would set off political and economic shock waves that could slash a few hundred points from the Dow.
While Administration officials insist that how China handles human rights remains the paramount consideration in deciding whether to renew Beijing's trade benefits, clearly the impact of such a move on financial markets has to gnaw at them.
"You cannot have tensions with your biggest supplier of foreign capital -- Japan; the biggest country in the world -- China, and the area of the world that is right now the most dangerous -- the Korean peninsula -- without it having a significant negative effect on markets," Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said.
 
Dealing With Japan
 Many analysts feel that stock market diplomacy is already apparent in Administration dealings with Japan, where President Clinton has quietly told aides he wants to maintain a low-noise-level approach to persuading Japan to open its markets.
The American intelligence community has recently provided the President with a series of analyses on Japan, arguing that underlying, long-term political trends there are toward a more open, consumer-oriented and deregulated society -- the kind Mr. Clinton wants.
The President intends to keep the pressure on Tokyo to open more markets, aides say. But he apparently does not want to do it with high-profile sanctions that rattle the Dow, Nikkei and European stock exchanges. Rather, he seems to prefer raising the value of the yen against the dollar -- thereby making all of Japan's exports more expensive and harder to sell -- just enough to make sure that the Japanese business community keeps pressing the Japanese Government to take more market-opening actions.
But Mr. Clinton clearly wants to proceed in a "measured way," aides say, so as not to upset the trend of events in Japan, either by sparking a trade war or by destabilizing the currency and bond markets so that Japan cannot climb out of its recession.
 
A Sense of the Interplay
 Indeed, stock market diplomacy seems to come naturally to Mr. Clinton, who may not have much of a feel for traditional diplomacy, like arms control or Bosnia, but clearly has a strong intuitive grasp of the interrelationship between global markets and political trends.
As Japan's Ambassador to the United States, Takakazu Kuriyama, put it: "He understands international economics and the interaction between domestic and international policy better than any President I have seen."
In addition, Mr. Clinton's whole foreign policy vision is based on the notion that global economic growth will be the engine for growth in the United States and other industrialized democracies. All the more reason, then, for the President to keep one eye cocked on the markets, as he decides on Japan and China.
"You don't have to explain it to him," said a top Administration foreign policy official. "Even during the campaign he would ask how the markets were reacting to this or that event."
But while acknowledging that fact, aides insist up and down that the President will make his decisions on Japan and China with a lot more than just the Dow on his mind.
 
'A 24-Hour Money Cycle'
 The impact on global markets "will not be the determining factor" in Mr. Clinton's decisions on China and Japan, said George Stephanopoulos, Presidential adviser. But, he added, "When you are having the policy discussion about these issues, one of the talking points you have to address is the market-impact question."
"Just as you have a 24-hour news cycle, now you have a 24-hour money cycle," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "And just as with the news cycle, if you have traders going around the clock with access to markets around the world, policy makers can literally never rest. You have to be ready to respond at anytime.
"But just as we learned with the news cycle, you can't overreact to it either. Everything gets bounced around and washed through much more quickly."
Clearly, though, the linkages cannot be ignored. It was the threat of a United States-Japan trade war in February, after trade negotiations had collapsed, that drove the value of the yen up and the dollar down. A depreciation of the dollar, whether across the board or against one major currency, tends to push interest rates higher, because the cheaper dollar forces the Government to offer higher interest rates to attract foreign capital to buy its Treasury bills and finance the deficit. Higher bond prices drove down the stock market.
At the time, traders say, Japanese finance ministry officials hinted that they would not rule out heavy selling by the Japanese of American bonds, which could exacerbate the situation. It was a subtle reminder to Washington that two can tango when it comes to applying financial pressure. It was also a reminder that in today's financial markets, what goes around comes around.
"Let's face it," Mr. Hormats said, "the guy who holds a mortgage in Paducah, his interest rate depends on whether Japanese investors buy American bonds. And the guy whose pension fund is partially invested in Asia will be affected by what the President does with China."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Vigorous Rally in Bonds Halts Run of Down Days

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The bond market's stunning reversal yesterday, which pushed bond prices back up to last Friday's levels, may be a sign that the current down cycle is running out of steam.
The prices of Treasury securities moved sharply higher after a firm opening, on what market analysts described as retail buying and "short covering" by speculators who had bet that prices would keep dropping. The gains came after two trading sessions that saw prices plunge and interest rates jump to 15-month highs. 
 For days traders and dealers had been aware that the market was oversold, a message that may have attracted some buyers yesterday.
 
Some Tempered Optimism
 "The other side of de-leveraging was undoubtedly going on today," Walter S. Frank, chief economist for The Bond Fund Report in Ashland, Mass., said yesterday. "And while it's a little too early to say that the selling is over and rates are going to be coming down in a straight line, the rates we saw yesterday could well turn out to be the highs for the year."
Many market participants said the bond market's activity had little to do with economic reality, Mr. Frank said.
"You had a market that was highly leveraged and quite rickety, but we didn't know it," he said. The slight tightening of interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board on Feb. 4 should have drawn a mild reaction from the bond market, but instead caused it to fall sharply, he said. No one knew the point at which the selling would cease, he said, because the market was not being driven by fundamental pressures.
But Mr. Frank said those speculative pressures were easing and he doubted that "we'll see them again in this interest-rate cycle, with yields coming back to levels consistent with the underlying economic realities and substantially lower than what we have today."
He then added a warning: "It won't be quick. A lot of damage has been done in the market and the scars need to heal."
By late in the day, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was up 126/32 , to 882/32 , with a yield of 7.24 percent, down from 7.41 percent on Monday.
 
A Partial Comeback
 Until yesterday the long bond had shed more than 3 1/2 points in two days, or about $35.63 for every $1,000 of bonds held. But by the close of the New York cash market yesterday, investors had recouped about $18.13 of that.
Market analysts said the recent declines in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity futures prices and falling gold prices suggested that investors' fears of inflation might be exaggerated, and that may have given the bond market some support yesterday.
The market was also given encouragement by the European bond markets, which resumed trading yesterday after a long Easter weekend. Traders said that while bond prices were down in most markets, the losses were not as big as those that have rattled the Treasury bond markets in recent days.
Some analysts said the resilience of the European markets could mean that they were separating themselves from the United States market, or that European investors had bet correctly that the American market would rebound.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said he had received many calls from his portfolio managers who said there was plenty of value in the market.
"Even before trading, the active managers instinctively believed that the bond market had reached an emotional extreme where it discounted all the bad news ahead that we could imagine and then some," he said. "These active bond managers were simply waiting for someone to go first, waiting for a catalyst to ignite a predictable rally."
He said it was difficult to identify the trigger for the rally yesterday. It could have been release of the index of leading economic indicators, which registered a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in February, implying that the economy would slow from the breakneck pace of the fourth quarter.
"Rarely does the index move the markets, but because the market has been so sensitive, it very well may have," Mr. Johnson said. "Or, it could have been commodity prices, which continued to decline, with the C.R.B. index down 1.64 points, to 224.38 yesterday, down from its late March high of 231."
Mr. Johnson said today's session would be crucial for the bond market and would indicate to what extent the confidence in bonds had been rebuilt. "My guess is that the bond market will stabilize until we get to important inflation numbers next week," he said. The Producer Price Index for March will be released next Tuesday, followed on Wednesday by the Consumer Price Index for March.
"The market will require good inflation numbers to rebuild confidence in the bond market another notch because that confidence has been badly shaken," Mr. Johnson said.
Economists polled by Reuters said they still expected the Fed to raise short-term interest rates during the next couple of months. Some said the central bank would wait until the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on May 17, while others said a move could come sooner.

HEADLINE: W.L. Parkerton, 49; Ran Credit Agency

 BODY:
William L. Parkerton, the senior vice president and a founding board member of Consumer Credit Counseling Services of Connecticut in Hartford, died on Friday at his home in West Hartford, Conn. He was 49.
His family said the cause was cancer. 
 Mr. Parkerton's association with the Connecticut credit service began with the organization's establishment in 1974 as a nonprofit organization helping individuals and businesses avoid bankruptcy and resolve financial difficulty. From modest beginnings, the service grew to a statewide network of 12 offices.
On graduation from Dartmouth College in 1966, Mr. Parkerton joined the Peace Corps. He spent two years in India, where he met his wife, the former Patricia Hostetter of Sacramento, Calif. He earned a graduate degree in economic behavior in 1970 from the University of Kentucky.
A trained singer, he was a member of the Hartford and New Haven Chorales and the Unitarian Society of New Haven Chorus. He also was a member of a number of municipal commissions.
Besides his wife, he is survived by his daughter, Melissa, and a son, Jesse, both of West Hartford.

HEADLINE: Indicators Falter, but No Big Shift Is Seen

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
The Government's chief forecasting index edged down in February to break a six-month streak of advances, but analysts generally dismissed the reading as a reflection of bad weather and said they saw no change in economic direction.
The biggest factor by far was a shrinking workweek, caused by exceptionally severe weather during the early part of February. The Labor Department's jobs report on Friday showed that the workweek expanded in March, more than making up the February decline. If the workweek had been unchanged in February, the composite index of leading indicators would have gained two-tenths of 1 percent instead of slipping one-tenth of 1 percent. 
 Although some stock market analysts cited the forecasting index as helping to fuel powerful rallies in the bond and stock markets today -- on the theory that it showed the economy not headed for inflationary overheating -- economists said anybody trading on this basis was ill informed.
"That strikes me as pretty adventurous," John P. Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said of such an interpretation.
Not only did bad weather muddy the results, he and other analysts noted, but nobody should have been surprised since nearly all the index components had been previously published and individually analyzed.
The tiny decline, the first since July, did not meet the Commerce Department's standard that a change in the index's direction must be of "significant size, duration and scope" to signal a turn in the economy.
Lincoln F. Anderson, an economist at Fidelity Management and Research, the Boston-based mutual fund group, called today's report "weather related" and probably "irrelevant" to thinking investors.
Two companion indexes, those made up of coincident and lagging indicators, also registered inconsequential changes in February. The coincident index, designed to turn at the same time as the economy, rose five-tenths of 1 percent with the help of a big rebound in personal income after the earthquake in California.
The index of components that normally move only after the economy does edged down one-tenth of 1 percent.
For the forecasting index, 6 of the 11 components contributed to February's decline, with the shorter workweek and a drop in building permits the only ones that could be regarded as sizable.
The other negatives were a lower M-2 measure of money supply, a decline in the University of Michigan's index of consumer expectations, a decline in new factory orders for consumer goods and a small drop in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index.
Four components made positive contributions, more or less equally. These were a rise in prices for materials especially sensitive to the business cycle, slower deliveries by corporate suppliers, a decline in first-time claims for unemployment benefits and a rise (though backlogs continued to fall) in unfilled factory orders for durable goods.
 
 
Rounding to Zero
 The 11th component, contracts and orders for plant and equipment, edged up but by so little that the Commerce Department rounded its contribution to zero.
Small revisions today raised January's rise in the forecasting index to four-tenths of 1 percent while lowering December's rise to six-tenths of 1 percent, the report also showed.
The ratio of the coincident to the lagging index -- an alternative predictor -- rose modestly in February following a small January decline.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Against Mark As Stocks and Bonds Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against other leading currencies yesterday, rising to a four-week high against the German mark, as stocks and bonds rebounded from their recent selloff.
"The buck is back," said David De Rosa, director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "There's a massive dollar-buying binge going on." 
 The dollar rose almost two pfennigs, to 1.7180 marks, in late New York trading yesterday, its highest level since March 8, from 1.7142 marks on Monday. It also rose to 104.30 Japanese yen from 103.15 yen.
Plunging stocks and bonds helped depress the dollar over the last few trading sessions. The rout in the bond market subsided yesterday and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.24 percent, from 7.41 percent on Monday. The declining interest rates helped stocks to rebound, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 82.06 points, to 3,675.41.
 
A Note of Caution on Future
 "People became more interested in buying dollars because the stock and bond markets appeared to stabilize," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Bank of Montreal.
But it is too early to say "if the dollar has turned the corner and is heading higher," said Ezra Zask, president of Ezra Zask Associates, a currency trading fund with $150 million under management. However, he added, "today's rally should make people reluctant to sell it aggressively."
Flows of capital into American stocks and bonds pushed the dollar higher, Mr. Zask said. Those flows are important to determine exchange rates now because so many currency speculators have been "blown out of the market" by huge losses, he said.
"Capital flows are driving everything right now," he said. "A lot of the speculators are on the sidelines."
Many speculators suffered when the dollar fell against other currencies in the first quarter of this year. The financier George Soros said his hedge funds lost $600 million when the dollar tumbled against the yen in February.
Concerns about the political future of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan helped the dollar gain against the yen. The yen fell after Japanese news services reported that Mr. Hosokawa was eager to resign, traders said. Mr. Hosokawa denied the reports.
The Canadian dollar also rebounded, rising from seven-year lows against the United States dollar, to 72.34 United States cents from 71.60 cents on Monday.
Meanwhile, the British pound fell to $1.4645 in New York from $1.4662.

HEADLINE: Japan's Surplus Barely Rises

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 5

 BODY:
Japan's current account surplus rose a modest one-tenth of 1 percent in February from a year earlier, the Government said today. The current account, the broadest measure of trade, includes goods and services.
The Finance Ministry said the current account surplus inched up to $11.94 billion in February from $11.93 billion in February 1993. 
 Japan's trade surpluses have drawn harsh criticism from the United States. Trade talks are deadlocked, with Washington arguing that Tokyo has failed to meaningfully open its markets.
The Japanese world trade surplus rose to $12.93 billion in February from $12.62 billion a year earlier.
Recession has smothered consumer demand in this country, helping to trim imports. Japan managed to limit the volume of its exports in February, but their value was higher, largely because of a stronger yen compared with the dollar. The yen has risen about 10 percent in a year.
Economists said signs of a reduced Japanese surplus might appear when the yen stopped rising against the dollar and the Japanese economy was on a firm track to recovery.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
"BREAST is Best." This slogan promoting breastfeeding has been widely publicized. But the practice, which peaked among American mothers in 1982 after a decades-long decline, is far from commonplace.
According to periodic surveys, women who are young and unemployed, who live on low incomes and who lack college educations are the least likely to attempt to breastfeed, and if they do try, are the most likely to abandon it before their babies are 6 months old. Babies of such mothers face the highest risk of health problems that could best be countered by starting life on breast milk. 
 Even among immigrant mothers from countries where breastfeeding is nearly universal (and even when these same mothers nursed babies born when they were still living in their native land), their American-born babies are often bottle-fed.
These facts are especially discouraging to researchers who continue to uncover health-saving and possibly life-saving benefits of mother's milk to the newborn child.
But a 10-year slide in breastfeeding may be reversing, according to national surveys of tens of thousands of new mothers by Ross Laboratories, a baby formula company. In 1992, the last year for which data have been released, 53.9 percent of babies were breastfed in the hospital and 20.1 percent were still being nursed at 6 months of age. The comparable figures in 1990 were 51.5 percent in the hospital and 19 percent at 6 months, significantly lower than in 1982, when breastfeeding in the hospital peaked at 61.9 percent. A preview of the 1993 data indicates that breastfeeding is continuing to regain popularity.
Yet, the practice still lags among less affluent and less educated women, whose babies, for many reasons, including low vaccination rates and greater exposure to environmental contaminants like cigarette smoke, especially need the nutrients and disease protection that mother's milk bestows. And many affluent and well-educated mothers continue to choose bottle-feeding for reasons of convenience or, for lack of support, give up nursing as soon as any difficulty arises.
The United States is still far from the goal established in 1990 by the Department of Health and Human Services that by 2000, 75 percent of mothers nurse their babies at least in early infancy and 50 percent continue to nurse until their babies are 5 or 6 months old.
 
Obstacles to Nursing
 In Patient Care, a magazine for physicians, Dr. Carole A. Stashwick, a pediatrician at Dartmouth Medical School, recently listed these reasons for the waning of breastfeeding:
Less emphasis on its benefits in lay publications; inadequate attention to nursing by professionals involved in newborn care; direct marketing of infant formulas to mothers; the common practice of hospitals' sending new mothers home with a sample of formula, and a general failure of modern society to pass on breastfeeding skills to new mothers, most of whose own mothers and grandmothers had chosen the bottle over the breast.
Most people assume, incorrectly, that breastfeeding comes naturally. Actually, it is a learned skill for both the mother and her infant. Although babies are born with a "rooting" tendency to nuzzle the breast and with an instinct to suck, neither baby nor mother knows instinctively how to breastfeed, Dr. Stashwick wrote. First-time mothers often need help in getting started with breastfeeding, but nowadays most leave the hospital within two days of delivery, before the mother's milk even comes in. Once home, there is no one to help when breastfeeding fails to go smoothly.
The first weeks of nursing can be a challenge. Some mothers become anxious when their babies cry a lot or seem to reject the breast or lose too much weight. Some mothers' nipples become cracked or sore, and others lack support for breastfeeding from their babies' fathers or grandparents.
As one 33-year-old first-time mother put it: "Nursing seemed to be going well in the hospital, but as soon as we got home, the baby refused the breast. She began crying incessantly and wouldn't even sleep. She was obviously hungry but still refused to nurse. So I gave up, and as soon as I gave her a bottle, she was happy."
The mother said that at the hospital, "three different people gave me conflicting advice: hold the baby this way, hold her that way, feed on demand, feed on a schedule, never give her a bottle, supplement with formula if she still seems hungry."
Then, too, there are important socioeconomic obstacles. Many new mothers must return to work -- sometimes within weeks and often within three months of the birth -- and decide, again mistakenly, that there is no point in nursing for so short a time. And in the case of mothers receiving Federal aid under the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC), infant formula is provided for those who bottle-feed, and additional foods but no monetary supplement are offered to those who nurse.
In Quebec, to encourage breastfeeding, the comparable program now pays a cash allowance of $37.50 a month to mothers who breastfeed.
 
Nursing Successfully
 Breastfeeding specialists are founts of helpful advice. For example, it helps to change the baby's position from one feeding to another to assure that milk is drained from all areas of the breast. Besides the traditional cradling position, try a football hold, with the baby tucked under one arm so she approaches the breast from the side, or try nursing lying down face to face with the baby.
Be sure that the baby latches on to the nipple properly. The entire nipple and most of the areola (the surrounding dark area) should be in the baby's mouth and the baby's lips should spread out around it. Women with flat or inverted nipples can wear plastic breast shields called Swedish milk cups for several hours a day at the end of pregnancy and at the start of nursing to help pull out the nipple.
As the baby begins to suck, the milk is "let down" from the breast ducts into the nipple. (Often some milk drips from the opposite breast at this time.) The baby's gulping noises are an indication that milk is being swallowed. During the first days of nursing, the mother often feels brief uterine contractions when the baby begins sucking.
In a society accustomed to precise measurements, many mothers who breastfeed worry about whether their babies are getting enough to eat. A baby will mostly empty a breast in about 10 minutes of nearly continuous sucking. Those who fall asleep after a few minutes of nursing need to be awakened and kept stimulated (for example, by tapping the feet) until they have eaten enough. To maintain a good milk supply and to assure that the baby is getting enough, newborns should be nursed every two to three hours.
Success at nursing can be measured by whether the baby seems content afterward, produces at least six wet diapers and several fairly liquid, mustard-colored stools each day and wakes up at least every four hours around the clock to be fed. A baby who is gaining weight normally is well fed, but experts advise against home baby scales, which are often inaccurate and can be anxiety-provoking instead of reassuring.
 
Sources of Support
 Breastfeeding is most likely to succeed when both mother and father are well informed. Many hospitals now have lactation specialists on staff; be sure to leave the hospital with a phone number to call if nursing difficulties begin at home. The hospital specialist may also be able to refer you to a local breastfeeding support group. Other useful resources include the following:
La Leche League International, 9616 Minneapolis Ave., Franklin Park, Ill. 60131; phone (800) LA LECHE (525-3243) or (708) 455-7730.
International Childbirth Education Association, Box 20048, Minneapolis, Minn. 55420; phone (612) 854-8660.
Lact-Aid International, Inc., Box 1066, Athens, Tenn. 37371; phone (615)744-9090.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
How U.S. Barred Holocaust Refugees

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Since the end of World War II, evidence has accumulated that before and during the war the State Department was in effect a pioneer in Holocaust revisionism. Tonight's troubling documentary -- "America and the Holocaust: Deceit and Indifference" -- adds the power of pictures and first-hand testimony to accusations that Washington played down the known facts of Nazi persecution of Jews as a matter of policy and prejudice.
This 90-minute offering in "The American Experience" series brings home the effects of the official policy through the experience of Kurt Klein, who came to the United States in 1937 as a 17-year-old refugee from Germany, leaving his parents behind, temporarily, they hoped. As the narrator recalls the growing threat to European Jewry, from Kristallnacht in November 1938 to the death camps of the 1940's, Mr. Klein tells how his parents' efforts to flee to America were repeatedly blocked by State Department functionaries. The pictures of Jews being rounded up and herded to camps, no less painful for their familiarity, make a grim counterpoint to the fate of one family. 
 "America and the Holocaust" traces the Government's apparent indifference to the anti-Semitism of the 1920's and 30's, with the German-American Bund, the Rev. Charles Coughlin and nativist politicians leading the way. A former Treasury Department official says State Department professionals also shrugged off the plight of the refugees in deference to America's perceived economic and political interests in the Middle East. The record may stir uncomfortable thoughts about current American behavior toward refugees from despotism.
A particular villain of this account is Assistant Secretary of State Breckenridge Long, who is blamed for exaggerating security concerns in order to keep refugees out. His technique is revealed by a memorandum he wrote in 1940: "We can delay and effectively stop for a temporary period of indefinite length the number of immigrants into the United States. We could do this by simply advising our consuls to put every obstacle in the way, which would postpone and postpone and postpone the granting of the visas."
Tonight's assault relies heavily on David S. Wyman, the author in 1984 of "The Abandonment of the Jews" (Praeger), without noting that some of his broader charges, particularly against President Franklin D. Roosevelt, have been forcefully challenged by so eminent a Holocaust historian as Lucy S. Dawidowicz. Such an acknowledgment might have weakened the program's case somewhat, but it would have enhanced the reputation for scholarship of "The American Experience."
Nevertheless, few historians have anything kind to say about the "postpone and postpone and postpone" tactic. Among the many thousands of European Jews whom the narrator calls "victims of calculated, bureaucratic delay" were Kurt Klein's parents. Mr. Klein, who returned to Europe in World War II with the American Army and was one of the soldiers who found themselves freeing concentration-camp survivors, was notified after the war that in August 1942 his parents had been deported from Vichy France "in the direction of Auschwitz."
 
The American Experience
America and the Holocaust: Deceit and Indifference

 (Channels 13 and 49 in the New York area)

A documentary produced, written and directed by Martin Ostrow for the American Experience; editor, Stephanie Munroe; associatiate producers, Liz Carver and Ruth Tofler-Riesel; Judy Crichton, executive producer for the American Experience; Hal Linden, narrator.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 525 words

HEADLINE: Wall Street Is Not Main Street

 BODY:
The Dow Jones Industrial stock average soared more than 80 points yesterday, bringing relief to anxious investors. But the ups and downs of the stock market are more important to them than to other citizens. Even severe gyrations in the stock market often have no effect on jobs or the rest of the economy.
President Clinton points out what truly matters: The economy is expanding at a brisk pace, employers created a huge number of jobs last month, and inflation is subdued so far. The White House knows that keeping recovery alive is paramount. That is why it got upset about the recent run up in long-term interest rates. 
 Companies use long-term rates to calculate whether it makes sense to invest in new plants and equipment. If these rates were to stay high, let alone rise further, business investment could be choked off and recovery stunted.
Administration officials railed this week against high interest rates, a signal that they wanted the Federal Reserve Board to put off further rate hikes. The Fed would be wise to take heed.
The Fed raised short-term rates by a small amount (one-half percentage point total) in February and March because the economy had grown at a surprisingly brisk pace at the end of 1993 and looked poised to continue to grow quickly. The strong growth raised fears in financial markets that inflation would pick up.
Those fears would cause lenders to boost long-term rates to offset the expected inflation, thereby threatening to attenuate the recovery. The Fed hoped, by raising short-term rates early, to convince financial markets that it would not let inflation get out of hand. That way, long-term rates could stay low.
That was the theory. The markets, for unknown reasons, reacted otherwise -- driving up long-term rates despite the Fed announcement. Yet most economists and, at the time, the Administration agreed with the Fed's policy. Waiting too long to control inflation can be fatal. Once inflation rates march upward, they can be controlled only by clamping down hard on the economy; in the early 1980's, the Fed pushed the economy into a steep recession to overcome an inflationary surge.
There are experts who say the Fed's pre-emptive strike against inflation was premature. They bolster their case by pointing to data indicating the economy is not overheated. Unemployment rates, though down, still exceed 6 percent; inflation remains inconsequential, and growth has slowed since the end of last year to a modest 3 percent annual rate. For these critics, the Fed's rate hikes were unwarranted.
Whether the Fed or its critics are right is not clear. What is certain is that the Fed has acted responsibly. But the chaotic events of the past week, especially in the bond markets, should caution it against proceeding with any further rate hikes lest they have unpredictable effects.
The Fed set out in February to slow recovery from its brisk pace and, thereby, keep inflation under control. The economy has slowed; interest rates rose; prices are rising slowly. The prudent course would be for the Fed to declare tentative victory and wait before clamping down any harder.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Hands Reach Out Between Communities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "A Liberalism of Heart and Spine" (Op-Ed, March 27), Henry Louis Gates Jr. proposes moving beyond a "politics of identity" to a process of "identification" among communities, with an increase in "shared humanity." I concur fully. But this process is already well under way at the grass roots. 
 Community activists such as Daniel (Nane) Alejandrez, co-director of the National Coalition to End Barrio Warfare, Marcia Choo of African-American/Korean Alliance and Fred Williams of the Los Angeles-based Cross-Colors Common Ground Foundation are working at cooperation.
The Asian Immigrant Workers Alliance enlists thousands of Chinese, Filipino, Vietnamese and other workers to challenge sweatshop conditions. The Southwest Network for Environmental and Economic Justice brings together 70 organizations including four native American nations, Chicano, African-American and Mexican communities, north and south of the border, to grapple with environmental problems. Such organizations, to name a few, are building on diverse cultural identities to create cooperation.
For me the chief defect of Dr. Gates's article is that it emphasizes group hatreds and leaves out the organizations that are constructively meeting the challenge of creating a "shared humanity."
Sadly, many academics and policy makers do not know about or work with these organizations. As Daniel Alejandrez argues, "Academics need to come down off the hill and work with community coalition efforts." Engaged scholarship requires more understanding of cooperation, as well as conflict.
 
JOHN BROWN CHILDS
Prof. of Sociology, U. of California
Santa Cruz, Calif., March 28, 1994

HEADLINE: Corporate Priorities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was amazed at a quotation from a Lehman Brothers analyst in "Novell Acquisitions Hinge on Stock Price Fluctuation" (Business Day, March 24), concerning the networking giant's planned acquisition of the Wordperfect Corporation and the Quattro Pro spreadsheet business of Borland International Inc.: "The motto at Novell is customers first, employees second and shareholders third." 
 The analyst intends this as withering criticism of Novell. He says this motto "seems to be what this transaction is all about," and he finds "irate" Novell shareholders justified in their March 23 selloff of shares.
The American economy would be transformed if every company put customers first, employees second and owners last. I would venture to say success in the marketplace (and return on investment) ultimately depends on a company's adopting this approach.
 
PAUL M. STOKES
Miami Springs, Fla., March 25, 1994

HEADLINE: Doctor Asserts A Fall Injured Rodney King

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 6

 BODY:
A judge today allowed a doctor whose testimony was challenged in previous trials to testify that Rodney G. King's injuries came from a fall, not from blows by police clubs.
"The fractures and soft tissue injuries were most consistent with a fall, a head-in-motion injury on a flat surface," said Dr. Dallas Long. 
 He based his opinion in part on a grain of gravel that was discovered embedded in Mr. King's face weeks after he was beaten by the police.
"It would probably be the result of a head-in-motion impact on the surface where the gravel was centered, such as a roadway," Dr. Long said.
Dr. Long, of Newport Beach, Calif., acknowledged that he had never examined Mr. King and that his review of medical records had not included those of Mr. King's orthopedist.
Dr. Long's testimony was questioned in two criminal trials stemming from Mr. King's beating by police because he specializes in emergency medicine and family practice, not orthopedics or ophthalmology. Mr. King's lawyers this time sought to disqualify Dr. Long, but Judge John G. Davies of Federal District Court ruled that the doctor's examination of medical records was sufficient basis for testimony.
Dr. Long's analysis differed sharply from that of a surgeon and ophthalmologist who treated Mr. King and testified in his civil suit.
The two-phase trial is being held to determine compensatory damages owed to Mr. King by the city and punitive damages that could be levied against individuals, including the four police officers originally charged with his beating. The city offered to settle for $1.25 million; Mr. King's lawyers wanted $9.6 million.
The city, which began its defense on Tuesday, is disputing the extent of Mr. King's injuries in his beating on March 3, 1991, and the truthfulness of his testimony last week about the beating and his troubled life.
 
What He Could Have Earned
 Earlier on Tuesday, Mr. King's lawyers rested their case after calling their 18th witness, an economist, Robert Johnson, who told jurors that Mr. King could have earned more than $1.6 million during a lifetime as a construction worker or $1.3 million as a diesel mechanic.
Mr. King was on parole and set to return to a construction job at the time of the beating and was also studying to be a diesel mechanic, his lawyers said.
Outside the courtroom today, members of Mr. King's panel encountered a juror from another case who pointed them out and said: "Those are Rodney King jurors. Don't they know they're wasting taxpayers' money?"
Mr. King's lawyer, Milton Grimes, moved for a mistrial, but Judge Davies denied the motion after quizzing each juror about the incident.
"These people have the intelligence and desire to put this incident behind them and treat it for what it was, an encounter with a discourteous person," Judge Davies said.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Rise By 19.7%

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 6

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks in the United States outstripped expectations yet again in March, raising the possibility that the auto recovery may be more robust than analysts and industry executives had predicted.
With both consumer confidence and employment increasing, vehicle sales surged 19.7 percent over the March 1993 level. The Big Three auto makers all set records for one month's truck sales. Taken as a whole, car and light-truck sales for the 1994 first quarter have startled many industry analysts. 
 "I think the word stunning is appropriate, and that leaves one wondering about just how good 1994 is going to be," said Phil Fricke, auto analyst with Prudential Securities in New York. "The industry would not want to see a sales blowout this year," he said. In part because some factories have closed for model change-overs, the industry may not have enough capacity to meet soaring demand in 1994, Mr. Fricke said.
 
Too Much Good News?
 In fact, such apparently good sales news could worry two groups that intently follow the auto industry: investors in auto stocks and the Federal Reserve.
Strong sales could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates further to ward off inflation. But Dave Healy, auto analyst with S. G. Warburg, pointed out that the Fed took interim March auto sales figures into account in raising rates on March 22. As a result, he predicted, the central bank was unlikely to react to today's news.
Some auto executives also said they did not expect the Fed to react. "I hope not," said J. Michael Losh, vice president and group executive for vehicle sales, service and marketing at General Motors. "One of the things I hope the Fed's primarily concerned about is inflation, and inflation seems to be in good shape."
Investors may worry that the auto market is peaking sooner than expected, meaning that the stocks would not generate the kind of earnings analysts have predicted for 1995 and 1996. "Investors would rather have a longer, gentle recovery this year, rather than have it all at once," Mr. Healy said. But, like other analysts, he argued that sales were likely to stay strong over the next two years at least.
 
Recovery Over, Boom Starts
 "I think the recovery is over, and the boom has started, but the boom is only 15 minutes old," he said.
In March, dealers sold 1,446,542 domestically built and imported vehicles, up from 1,208,036 a year ago. Car sales rose 19.2 percent, to 882,841, while sales of light trucks -- a category that includes mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups -- rose 20.6 percent, to 563,701.
The seasonally adjusted selling rate for domestically built cars was 7.6 million, up from 7.3 million in February and 6.6 million a year ago.
The sales jump left some dealers wrestling with the kind of headache they long to have. "My inventory is so low it looks like I'm going out of business," complained Stuart Wullenweber of Wullenweber Jeep-Eagle-Chrysler-Plymouth in Cincinnati.
Mr. Wullenweber said that another dealer called him Tuesday night trying to buy one of his Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicles and offering $800 over invoice. "Just think of what he's getting from the customer if he's paying $800 over invoice," Mr. Wullenweber said. Today, Mr. Wullenweber received a call from yet another dealer, this time offering $1,000 over invoice.
Mr. Wullenweber said that he had turned down both offers.
 
G.M. Car Sales Up 14.9%
 Several auto makers reported their strongest March sales in years.
At G.M., car sales rose 14.9 percent, to 299,768, while light-truck sales climbed 18.7 percent, to 185,133. "There's strength across the board," Mr. Losh said.
The recovery so far has been led by strong truck sales, but in March car sales appeared to show similar strength. But Mr. Losh said that the auto makers could not build enough trucks to keep up with demand. "We're constrained on the truck production side, so cars look stronger," he said.
Ford Motor's car sales increased 9.6 percent, to 181,210, while the company's light- truck sales rose 18.2 percent, to 167,340.
Chrysler's truck sales surged 29.4 percent, to 141,715, while the company's car sales rose 13 percent, to 88,671. It was Chrysler's best month for car sales since August 1989.
The Nissan division of Nissan Motor Corporation reported its strongest sales month in almost five years. Including sales by the luxury Infiniti division, Nissan's car sales rose 48.9 percent, to 54,233. Truck sales rose 20.7 percent, to 21,271.
The Honda Motor Company's cars sales increased 24.9 percent, to 66,158, as sales of the Accord -- available as a sedan, coupe or wagon -- shot up 46.4 percent, to 30,110.
The Toyota Motor Company's car sales in the United States rose 19.7 percent, to 76,411, while truck sales rose 7.3 percent, to 26,845.
At the Mazda Motor Corporation, car sales rose 47 percent, to 34,953, while truck sales rose 27.1 percent, to 6,192.
The Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's car sales rose 78.5 percent, to 22,374, while truck sales rose 24.8 percent, to 1,390.

HEADLINE: Derivatives Study Sought

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
Representative Edward J. Markey, a Democrat from Massachusetts, called today for the Securities and Exchange Commission to study the links between the $7.5 trillion derivatives market and recent swings in the United States stock and bond markets.
Mr. Markey said in a letter to the S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., that he was worried that speculators had used derivatives contracts to make huge bets on lower stock and bond prices and caused recent plunges in those markets. 
 Mr. Markey asked the S.E.C. to study "the extent to which market participants may be developing and using derivative products that may be introducing increased levels of volatility into the markets."
Derivatives are contracts whose value is tied to the price of some other asset, like a stock or a bond. They are traded over the counter by Wall Street firms that customize contracts to meet specific investment views of big institutional clients.
The market has come in for regulatory scrutiny in the last two years, because of fears that a failure by one firm to meet its derivatives payments could cause a string of defaults and ultimately a financial crisis.
Investors can buy derivatives for a fraction of the cost of trading in actual stocks or bonds. They can also use complicated derivatives contracts to raise the potential return on their bet, without putting up much extra cash.
