HEADLINE: Riverboat Casinos Seek A Home in Pennsylvania

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 6

 BODY:
Pennsylvania politicians see jobs, waterfront development and tax revenue spinning in the little windows of slot machines on riverboat casinos waiting to take their place along the state's waterways.
Using research provided by the gambling industry, these public officials say that Pennsylvania's gamblers lose $1 billion a year in Atlantic City, about 60 miles southeast of here, and that it would be better if this money were lost closer to home. Tourists who come to Philadelphia to see the Liberty Bell, they add, might also liberate some cash on riverboats plying the Delaware River. 
 But fiscal experts and social scientists say the gambling industry could end up costing the state money, generate crime and, in particular, sully Philadelphia's image as the cradle of American democracy
 
Action in Legislature
 The State Legislature is considering a measure to permit gambling on Pennsylvania's navigable rivers and lakes, subject to state and county referendums, within two years. Many elected officials in the cities of Erie, Pittsburgh and Philadelphia and in the suburban Philadelphia counties of Bucks and Delaware support the proposal.
Anticipating legislative approval of the bill early next year, casino owners have either bought outright, or bought options for, seven pieces of property along the Delaware River here as well as sites in Pittsburgh. Owners of waterfront properties say two dozen to three dozen gaming companies are shopping for sites around the state, creating a real estate boom along major rivers.
Riverboat gambling has already been legalized in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Louisiana, Mississippi and Missouri. And legislatures in many other states, including New York, are considering the option.
Pennsylvania already has a state lottery and allows betting on horse races. But approval of riverboat casinos is far from certain, since Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat, has vowed to veto any casino bill that he receives before his term ends next January. In addition, the bill faces strong bipartisan opposition in the state Senate, said Senator Robert C. Jubelirer, the president pro tempore of the Republican-led body.
Still, Arthur M. Goldberg, chairman and chief executive of the Bally Manufacturing Company, expressed confidence in approval of the casinos, saying, "It's just a matter of time." Indeed, industry consultants say Bally has already agreed to pay about $60 million for 31 acres on Philadelphia's waterfront south of Penn's Landing and has bought a site in Pittsburgh as well, with plans to invest $125 million in each city.
 
Words of Caution
 Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia is a leading advocate of riverboat gambling. "If you can tell me about any economic development enterprise that will employ 6,000 to 8,000 Philadelphians, give the city $300 million for the right to develop the waterfront and produce $25 million in tax revenues each year, please bring them in to see me this afternoon," Mr. Rendell said in an interview.
But fiscal experts say $25 million is not that much in a city with a $2.3 billion budget. They caution that any windfall might be gobbled up on new city services along the waterfront and in dealing with predictable increases in crime, compulsive gambling's corrosive effect on families, traffic congestion and local business failures.
They note that Atlantic City lost many retail establishments after casinos came in. For example, 97 of the city's 243 restaurants closed in 1977-87, the restaurant industry says, because of competition from casinos, which subsidize food and drinks to promote gambling.
"The idea that casinos are the answer for a state or city with serious economic development problems is a mirage," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany.
 
Fast-Growing Industry
 Gambling is one of the nation's fastest-growing industries. In 1993, industry figures show, there were 93 million visits to casinos, and industry analysts say the American market is only a third developed.
More and more states are trying to tap into an industry that takes in more than $30 billion a year. Indeed, politicians around the country say that states that do not legalize casino gambling risk being left behind with all the problems and none of the profits if casinos are built in adjacent states.
Assemblyman Wayne R. Bryant of New Jersey set the competitive tone for the Mid-Atlantic States recently when he introduced legislation calling for a state referendum on riverboat gambling on the New Jersey side of the Hudson and Delaware Rivers if Pennsylvania or New York approved riverboat gambling.
"This proposed referendum is a warning shot to Philadelphia and New York City that New Jersey will aggressively protect the Atlantic City casinos against outside competition," Mr. Bryant, a Camden Democrat, said last month at a news conference.
 
Effect on Atlantic City
 Interestingly, it is the very companies that own casinos in Atlantic City that are among those acquiring waterfront property in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. Mr. Goldberg of Bally said that riverboat gambling in Pennsylvania would spur interest in Atlantic City's gambling palaces, which include two Bally casinos.
But another Atlantic City casino owner, Donald J. Trump, said in a interview that he was buying property in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh primarily to capture the business of Pennsylvanians who would stop going to Atlantic City if gaming were available closer to home.
If the Legislature does not legalize casino gambling, Mr. Trump said, he will probably build condominiums and retail stores on his 22 acres near downtown Philadelphia.
"That would probably be better for Philadelphia anyway," said Mr. Trump, who owns three casinos in Atlantic City. "Gambling would make a relatively small amount of money for Philadelphia and would increase crime and problems that aren't existent now."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Mixed Amid Fear of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Government securities finished mixed yesterday in a choppy session.
Investors, still wobbly after three days of surging and plunging interest rates, attributed some of the early weakness in bonds to concerns about inflation. Those concerns stemmed from an article in The Washington Post yesterday that quoted unidentified officials of the Federal Reserve Board as having said that the Fed would delay a third increase in interest rates until the bond and stock markets had settled down. 
 Shorter-maturity bills and notes gained on the prospect that the Fed would make no immediate move.
 
Worries Over Inflation
 The possibility of a delay in a move on rates, which most market participants expect will come at the Fed's Open Market Committee meeting in May, made some investors worry that the Fed could lose its initiative in containing inflation.
Analysts said weaker-than-expected car sales in March helped the market pare some of its early losses. Late in the day, the 30-year bond was unchanged, at 882/32 , with a yield of 7.24 percent. Intermediate maturities like the three-year note traded at a price to yield 5.82 percent, down from 5.83 percent, and a 10-year note yielded 6.90 percent, down from 6.91 percent.
The three-month Treasury bill shed 10 basis points from its discounted rate, to 3.55 percent, while a one-year bill was off four basis points, to 4.44 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The market seemed to have difficulty sustaining moves in either direction, contributing to yesterday's bounce in prices. "With no new news, it was left to its own devices," one analyst said.
 
Municipals Attract Attention
 Potential buyers were wary of activity in the less liquid mortgage and municipal markets, which had caused declines recently in the price of Treasuries, as portfolio managers sold Government securities to offset losses they had incurred in other fixed-income investments as a result of higher rates. But the mortgage and municipal markets, which had tumbled with the Treasuries, are beginning to draw attention, traders said.
The long bond's failure to sustain the move below 7.25 percent in early trading put sellers in control in the morning, they added.
A few traders said the front end of the yield curve had received a slight lift after The Washington Post's article on the Fed was published. Several analysts said that for the most part, many potential buyers were still sitting on the sidelines, unconvinced that the bear market had run its course.
Tim Heathon, vice president of Nikko Securities, said, "What the Fed is going to do, or not going to do, is of no real consequence to the market, since it's already looking far, far ahead."
 
Financing for Chinese Airline
 Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, the First National Bank of Chicago, a unit of the First Chicago Corporation, and Bank of China, said they had closed on the financing for the $261 million purchase of seven Boeing 737 aircraft by China Southern Airlines.
The transaction, backed by the Export-Import Bank of the United States, is the first by a Chinese company to raise long-term funds in the United States, with support from the Export-Import Bank, officials of the Chicago bank said.
Under the arrangement, First Chicago Capital Markets Inc., also a unit of First Chicago, will underwrite $201 million of triple-A rated certificates, which will be sold to institutional investors, with the Export-Import Bank guarantee extending to $201 million.
The remaining $60 million will be financed through a syndicated loan arranged by First Chicago and the Bank of China, and guaranteed by the Government-owned Bank of China.
China Southern Airlines, based in Guangzhou, China, has 100 aircraft, including 60 Boeing jets and 40 small or medium-size planes, operating on 17 international, 19 regional and 140 domestic routes.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Auctioning off the airwaves will be a formidable undertaking.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
FOR decades, free marketeers labored to convince Congress that licenses to use the airwaves should be sold rather than given away. But now that the opposition has cracked under pressure to reduce the Federal budget deficit, true believers are beginning to realize that the job is only half done: design of the spectrum auction may prove almost as difficult as establishing the principle.
Last month the Federal Communications Commission offered tentative thoughts on how space on the spectrum for "personal communications services" -- a souped-up version of cellular phones -- would be sold. And in the view of Chuck Jackson, a communications consultant at Strategic Policy Research Inc. in Maryland, the F.C.C. has done its homework. "The caliber of input from economists was remarkably high," he concluded. But the route to a well-managed auction still has more than a few potholes. 
 Truly embarrassing missteps are unlikely, saysJohn McMillan, an economist at the University of California at San Diego, because other countries have already made them.
Consider the pioneering effort by New Zealand in the late 1980's. By one respectable (if unintuitive) theory, the best way to get bidders to reveal what winning is really worth to them is to award the prize to the highest bidder -- but charge the winner the price bid by the second-highest. That way, points out Vernon Smith of the University of Arizona, it does bidders no good to try to "game" the auction by guessing what the competition is doing and bidding just a tad higher.
New Zealand tried this "second price" strategy in the late 1980's in a sealed-bid auction for television and cellular phone licenses, only to find that in a handful of cases the second-highest bids were frivolously low -- as little as a few dollars. The moral: While the method did insure that the bidders who valued the licenses the most got them, "reserve" or minimum bids are needed to generate revenue if bidders are scarce.
Australia faced a parallel fiasco last year when it auctioned two separate licenses for direct-broadcast satellite television, only to discover that neither winner had any intention of paying the full price. Each had made dozens of bids at sequentially lower figures, with the plan of defaulting on all but the lowest figure needed to win. And since the Government had made no provision for penalties for defaults on bids, this strategy worked like a charm.
The most difficult problem faced by Washington is how to hold an auction when the value of a license depends on the ability to serve adjacent localities as well. Indeed, it is no secret that a half-dozen companies are aiming to provide nationwide service or none at all.
One solution would be to auction preassembled national packages. That, however, would close the bidding to all but the deepest pockets and preclude assembly of custom-tailored combinations intended to mesh personal communications system markets with existing cellular phone markets.
The straightforward solution would be a simultaneous auction in which all parties could bid for any or all localities, withdrawing bids as their strategies changed in response to the competition. But this might take a very long time. In fact, there would be no obvious end, since every bid could lead to a new round of bid withdrawals and rebidding.
The rules announced reflect a variety of compromises. In recognition of the interdependence problem, licenses for the largest markets will be auctioned simultaneously. Smaller markets, considered less vital in assembling networks, will be auctioned sequentially to save time and reduce complexity. But the F.C.C. is reserving the right to stop after a fixed number of rounds in the simultaneous auction. And those who withdraw bids will be forced to pay a penalty equal to the difference between the withdrawn bid and the final auction price, if the latter is lower.
Yet to be decided is how much information should be made public in the midst of the bidding. Full disclosure sounds right on general principles. But the F.C.C. staff, worried that truly transparent bidding might facilitate collusion or encourage a predator to knock a poorly financed competitor out of the game, is urging a compromise: continuing disclosure of the high bids, but not the bidders' names.
Will the auctions, likely early in 1995, be free of surprises? Probably not: the sale of rights to use technology that is changing rapidly cannot be entirely predictable.
"But don't lose sight of the big picture," cautions Peter Pitsch, a consultant and former adviser to the F.C.C. chairman. "An auction is bound to be better than the alternatives" of giving away licenses by lottery or awarding them to the best lobbyists.

HEADLINE: Making Jury Duty Less Painful and More Efficient

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
Imagine the impossible: that jury duty could be almost pleasant.
A juror who wasn't picked for trial on the first day would be excused altogether. Compensation would be raised from $15 a day to $40, as it is in the Federal courts. The summonses to serve would be fewer and further apart because the lists of people who could be called to jury duty would be nearly doubled. 
 These are among the recommendations issued yesterday by a state panel studying the overhaul of what it said was New York's clanking, inefficient jury system. The panel was appointed last summer by Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye and Chief Administrative Judge E. Leo Milonas.
Many of the proposals can be put into effect administratively by Judge Kaye, while others require legislative approval. Yet if even a modest number of changes are adopted, court observers say, not only will conditions for the state's jurors be markedly improved, but also the selection of criminal and civil juries will undergo some fundamental changes.
The panel's suggestions included matters of basic comfort, like providing clean bathrooms and heating, as well as curbs on lawyers to speed jury selection.
The panel said the changes are meant to streamline the system and make participation in a jury pool feel like a valuable civic service, not an exasperating duty to be shirked by any means necessary.
In recent years, many other states have struggled to improve their jury systems, adopting some of the ideas suggested by the panel yesterday. But experts on jury systems say that the New York proposals, if put into effect, could be the most extensive overhaul in the country.
Though the panel did not try to calculate the exact costs of its proposals, it said that the increase in jurors' compensation could be partly offset by other recommendations, including ending the mandatory sequestration of felony juries.
Judge Kaye, who took over as the state's top judge last year and made the appointment of the panel her first major project, spoke glowingly about the report, calling it remarkable. Declining to list which proposals she would adopt as priorities, she said they were all of equal urgency.
She added that she would hold a 90-day comment and review period on the proposals.
Legal observers said that several proposals would face particular difficulty in the Legislature, including the abolition of occupational exemptions and the ending of mandatory sequestration.
Judge Kaye and the State Office of Court Administration can control some initiatives, however, such as authorizing some judges to supervise civil jury selection or voir dire, streamlining the summons, deferral and questionnaire procedures, and requiring county jury commissioners to move toward the one day, one trial system.
To make the juror experience more dignified, she said, an inventory of "every broken tile, every decrepit bathroom" in the state's courts had been completed and money appropriated for repairs.
One proposal by the panel that has already drawn opposition from prosecutors and defense lawyers is trimming the number of peremptory challenges that lawyers can use to strike a prospective juror.
The lawyers who handle civil suits have their backs up too. Swamped by complaints about long, querulous civil jury selection, which, unlike any other state, is run by lawyers in New York, the panel advised that judges be appointed to supervise lawyers in a pilot project.
Castigating the increasingly common and time-wasting practise of settling civil cases after a jury is picked but before the first witness takes the stand, the panel recommended that a presettlement conference just before a jury is selected be mandatory and that a $1,000 fee split by litigants be imposed if a case goes to trial.
The panel was also showered with complaints about rude and patronizing judges, lawyers and court officers, so it called for civility training for court personnel. Pointing out that courthouse conditions were less than ideal, the panel said that jurors should be entitled to such amenities as chairs with backs and seats.
 
Critical Public Comments
 The mandate of the Jury Project, headed by Colleen McMahon, a partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, was to find ways to make juror pools more representative of the local communities, and to make the experience of being a juror both efficient and satisfying. The 30-member commission conducted public hearings and received thousands of letters and calls. A vast majority of the comments, the report noted, were sharply critical.
Chief among them, Ms. McMahon said, was that the experience was a waste of time. "The courts can no longer view the juror pool as a drinking fountain," the report said, "ready at all times to supply attorneys and judges with a fresh flow on a moment's notice. When water sits around for too long, it becomes stagnant. The same is true for jurors."
But almost uniformly, Ms. McMahon said, high marks were given by those who actually did get to hear a case. "Jury service is painful, like childbirth," she said. "You have to make arrangements with your boss and get a sitter for the kids and there is no parking and it's raining and you walk five blocks to court and there are no chairs and you sit on the floor and you wait to be called.
"But when you get to sit on the jury and listen to the evidence, you forget all about the pain."
To reach the goal of making more jurors eligible so every juror would have to serve less time and be called less frequently, the panel made several suggestions.
In addition to motor vehicle, tax and voting lists, it said, names should be drawn from welfare and unemployment rolls. New York, which now permits more occupational exemptions than any other state, should do away with all but those for sitting state or Federal judges.
Although 90 percent of eligible names are now culled for service, perhaps only a third to a half are chosen at random. Jury commissioners rely repeatedly on that short list. To end the practice of summoning the same people again and again, the report suggested that the random list be revised annually.
The report also looked at ways to reduce the time that jurors must spend in court. Buffalo, like Philadelphia, Miami and Houston, allows jurors to be excused if they are not picked for trial on the first day. Many trials only take a few days and if a juror does get on a panel, service would conclude at verdict.
The report reserved its harshest condemnations for lawyers who pick juries merely as a threatening tactic to force a settlement. In some counties, it said, 80 to 90 percent of the civil juries were picked, sent home to wait, and then told weeks later that the case had been settled.
 
Settlement Conferences
 To reduce the number of civil juries picked and then sent into limbo, the report recommended that mandatory settlement conferences be held just before jury selection, and that plaintiffs and defendants each pay a jury-use fee of $500. The report also proposed that judges supervise lawyers during voir dire, both to speed up proceedings and to reduce what many jurors described as abusive questioning.
But Craig A. Landy of the New York County Lawyers Association said he had an "allergy to fees that cut off access to the courthouse." And Richard Godosky, a prominent plaintiffs' lawyer, said: "After the jury is selected, most cases are settled. If the selection of the jury is the end of the case, select as many juries as you can!"

HEADLINE: New Speaker Recasting an Image;
Successor to Weprin Is Reasserting Assembly's Influence

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 6

 BODY:
In the two months since Sheldon Silver became Speaker of the New York State Assembly, the former yeshiva boy from the Lower East Side has cast aside his unassuming ways and waged a calculated campaign to reassert his house's influence on a broad range of issues.
After the two-year tenure of Saul Weprin, who was perceived by many Democratic colleagues as too cozy with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Silver has set out to establish the Assembly as an independent force on criminal-justice policy, the state budget, welfare reform and Staten Island secession. 
 His tactics have often been confrontational, particularly in picking fights with Mr. Cuomo. But his manner has been so unthreatening, with his monotone voice as soft and mesmerizing as morning prayers, that he has managed thus far to walk the thin line between dissent and discord.
 
Confronting the Governor
 Some lawmakers thought that Mr. Silver's anti-charismatic style and the awkwardness of his ascension after Mr. Weprin's death last February would lead him to proceed slowly.
But almost immediately after taking office, Mr. Silver announced his opposition to the Governor's plan to imprison third-time violent felons for life without parole, a proposal that was to be a centerpiece of Mr. Cuomo's re-election campaign. Then he came out against expanding the state's pilot program of electronic fingerprinting for welfare recipients, a priority of both the Governor and the Republican-controlled State Senate.
Four weeks ago, he singlehandedly arrested the building momentum behind the Staten Island secession movement by declaring that the Assembly would take up the issue only if New York City's Mayor and City Council approved it first. And last week Mr. Silver scored what Assembly Democrats hailed as a major victory by negotiating a budget compromise that would significantly increase drug-treatment and vocational-education programs in the state's prison system. The agreement also would provide new money for programs that allow drug defendants to avoid criminal charges by entering treatment, a favorite Silver initiative that is viewed skeptically by the Senate Republicans.
"I think we basically showed the Governor and the Senate that this house has leadership," said Mr. Silver, "that this house is not getting dragged along in any process, that this house is going to have its say in any three-way negotiation."
Some Republican leaders say Mr. Silver risks losing allies by overplaying his hand in the name of assertiveness. And lawmakers in both major parties agree that politically it may not be the best time for Mr. Silver to distance the Assembly from the Democratic Governor's office.
 
Liberal Prescriptions
 Mr. Cuomo may face a difficult re-election campaign this fall and needs the support of his partisans in the Assembly. Furthermore, some of the more liberal prescriptions proposed by Mr. Silver and his colleagues on taxes and crime seem to run counter to public sentiment.
But Mr. Silver, the first Speaker from Manhattan since Al Smith, clearly knows how to play to his constituents, the 99 other Democrats in the 150-member Assembly, most of whom are from New York City.
Although he has been criticized in his district for fighting the integration of Lower East Side cooperative buildings, he won accolades from minority members by appointing Herman D. Farrell Jr. as the first black chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Although he is often typecast as a Manhattan liberal, he endeared himself to moderate members by allowing a vote supporting a constitutional ban on flag-burning, a measure he personally opposed.
Most of all, Mr. Silver's Democratic colleagues have reacted enthusiastically to his forcefulness.
"We needed it," said Assemblyman Albert Vann, a Brooklyn Democrat. "We have to stand for something. There have to be bottom lines and he represents our bottom lines very well."
Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, a Bronx Democrat, said, "He's managed to convey in both specific and subtle ways the independence of this house."
 
Deeply Held Beliefs
 Although Mr. Silver seems eager to differentiate himself from Mr. Weprin, who grew up in Queens politics with Mr. Cuomo, the new Speaker said he has not orchestrated disputes with the Governor merely for political effect. Rather, he said, his stands are the product of deeply held beliefs, particularly on criminal-justice policy.
He has long called for controlling the growth in the state's corrections budget, which has tripled in the last 12 years, by diverting nonviolent offenders into drug treatment and other alternatives to incarceration. Meanwhile, he supports harsher penalties for violent felons, including the death penalty.
"What I want to accomplish," Mr. Silver said, "is to stop the charts from going off the wall in terms of how much we spend on the corrections budget so that we can use some of that money for productive things, including education and economic development that will create jobs. It may come to mind that I'm a criminal-justice liberal. I tend to think of myself as a fiscal conservative. It's a question of practical dollars."
He said he opposed the three-strikes-you're-out concept because it would cheapen the penalty of life without parole by applying it to a broad spectrum of felonies. He also said it would create a class of inmates with nothing to lose who might endanger guards and other inmates. And he said the state would have to maintain expensive geriatric wards in prisons for elderly inmates who no longer pose a threat to society.
Mr. Silver said he was troubled by welfare fingerprinting because of its suggestion of criminality. He also said a state study of a pilot program in two counties, which suggested that fingerprinting could save significant sums, had been shoddy and inconclusive.
 
Public Praise From Cuomo
 Mr. Cuomo reportedly has been annoyed by several of Mr. Silver's pronouncements, especially his opposition to the three-strikes-you're-out plan. But in public he has offered high praise for the Speaker.
"Every Speaker we've had has been required to stand up to the Governor," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview. "That is to guarantee the dignity of the Assembly. Shelly has great natural ability. He's extremely bright. He has what is universally regarded as a pleasant personality."
That personality, as unflappable and gray as the suits Mr. Silver prefers, has served the 50-year-old lawmaker well during the 18 years he has represented the Lower East Side in Albany.
"No matter how tough it gets, you're not going to find Shelly running around in a tizzy," said Harold Jacob, a Lower East Side real-estate manager who has known Mr. Silver for 25 years. "I've never seen him lose his temper. But I'll tell you this about Shelly. Don't step on his toe. He will remember that you attempted to hurt him or his community. He's not a patsy for anybody."
Within his polyglot district, which is divided among Asian, Jewish and Hispanic residents, Mr. Silver has faced tough criticism for not backing plans for low-income housing in the Seward Park development. He is also accused of not supporting efforts to integrate the heavily Jewish cooperative buildings along Grand Street. Over the years, those buildings have served as both a home and a political base for Mr. Silver, an observant Orthodox Jew who searches diligently for kosher meals in Albany.
"Shelly is a charming, hard-working, bright, honest legislator," said Frances Goldin, vice chairwoman of the Lower East Side Joint Planning Council, a coalition of 35 groups that supports low-income housing. "He has one blind spot and that is the integration of his community." By not pressuring his Jewish constituents to accept integration, she said, Mr. Silver "is encouraging racism."
When confronted, Mr. Silver gives as good as he gets. Ms. Goldin, he said, "is a person who gets paid to make sure there's controversy" and who "obviously wants to deny her birth" as a Jew. He said he receives significant political support from all ethnic groups on the Lower East Side and has not supported low-income housing at Seward Park because the community is deeply divided over how to develop the property.
 
Sending Messages
 As Speaker, Mr. Silver has shown that he knows how to send messages to those who offend him.
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani scheduled a City Hall meeting with the city's Democratic Assembly delegation without first checking to see whether Mr. Silver could attend, the Speaker pointedly stayed in his office two blocks away. He was already peeved that Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, seemed to place too much faith in the Senate Republicans and did not fully appreciate the Assembly's role as the city's chief advocate in Albany. The breach of protocol seemed to symbolize that, Mr. Silver's aides said.
"I don't stand on ceremony," said Mr. Silver. "But if he had wanted me to be at the meeting, he should have checked with me before he scheduled it."
Mr. Silver can be equally assertive with his own members. Two weeks ago, Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio, a Queens Democrat, used the word "fag" in a floor debate on a gay-rights bill. Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick, a Manhattan Democrat, who is open about being a lesbian, complained to Mr. Silver, who studied a transcript and then chastised Mr. Seminerio in a private meeting.
"I indicated to Tony that I was disappointed and that I thought it was not appropriate conduct," Mr. Silver said. "I indicated that he should do something about rectifying the situation." Mr. Seminerio apologized publicly to Ms. Glick at the next caucus of the Assembly Democrats.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 4.32 as Most Indexes Barely Move

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After the largest one-day gain in more than two years on Tuesday, the stock market closed essentially unchanged yesterday, almost a mirror image of the bond market, which despite some large swings, also closed little changed from the previous session.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose by 4.32 points, to 3,679.73, but the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined by 0.24 point, to 448.05. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index dropped 0.23 point, to 750.72. 
 "The Dow's up two days in a row! How can we stand it?" laughed Don Hays, director of investment strategy for Wheat First Butcher Singer in Richmond. "But seriously," he added, "we're not out of the woods yet. You're going to see two or three days of rally, then you'll have a testing time" of possible market declines.
 
Familiar Worries
 Thomas Gallagher, head of equity trading for Oppenheimer & Company in New York, said the stock and bond markets remained worried about future inflation and the prospects of an imminent increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board.
A market decline, possibly sharp, is still likely, Mr. Gallagher said. On Tuesday, the Labor Department is to report the Producer Price Index for March, and on Wednesday, the Consumer Price Index -- two statistics that are capable of moving markets. "People will start to get scared about them on Friday," Mr. Gallagher said.
The stock market generally tracked the bond market yesterday, but without the minute-to-minute parallel movements of previous sessions. From the beginning, bond prices fell slightly, as many traders apparently waited for higher yields to coax them into buying. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to as much as 7.327 percent, before settling at 7.24 percent.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.25, to 248.66, on volume of 302 million shares, about the volume of a typical day. Advancing stocks outnumbered those declining by 1,268 to 956. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 0.01 point, to 440.98.
 
The Dow's Big Gainers
 Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 13 showed price increases. They were led by Caterpillar, which rose 3 3/4, to 120; J. P. Morgan, which rose 1 3/4, to 62 1/4, and General Motors, which rose 1 1/2, to 58 3/4. There was no discernible news for Caterpillar or J. P. Morgan. General Motors, along with Ford and Chrysler, reported stronger vehicle sales in March.
Of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. index, 229 dropped in price yesterday, led by General Electric, which fell 1 1/4, to 97 5/8, and Wal-Mart, which declined 3/8, to 25 7/8.
Just before the market closed, G.E. disclosed that it expected its first-quarter earnings to be at the high end of analysts' estimates of $1.45 to $1.50 a share. Wal-Mart fell on no discernible news.
Over all, a wide variety of S.& P. industry groups saw their share prices fall yesterday. Health care companies like Bristol-Myers Squibb; electric utilities like SCE, the parent of Southern California Edison; long-distance telephone companies like A.T.& T. and electrical equipment companies like Westinghouse all saw their share prices fall.
 
A Hard-Hit Sector
 The biggest news event for the stock market occurred in Missouri, where voters on Tuesday narrowly defeated a state constitutional amendment that would have allowed slot machines and other games of chance in the state, where several riverboat casinos had been planned.
President Riverboat Casinos, the company in St. Louis known for developing floating casinos on the Mississippi River, was the most actively traded stock yesterday, at 12.6 million shares. It had planned a casino for Missouri. President Riverboat lost about a third of its value, dropping 5 3/8, to 12 1/2, on Nasdaq.
Other gambling stocks declined sharply, including Station Casinos; Hilton Hotels; Promus, the owner of the Harrah's casinos, and Argosy Gaming.
The American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico were the most actively traded stock on the New York Stock Exchange, at 6.6 million shares. A single A.D.R., which represents 20 ordinary shares of the company, rose 1 1/8, to 58 7/8, on no discernible news.
But because the company is the largest stock on the Mexican exchange, it is often bought and sold as a proxy for the exchange and for Mexico. Shares of the company rose despite investors' concern that Mexican interest rates would rise soon.

HEADLINE: G.E. Says Earnings Are Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 6

 BODY:
The General Electric Company said today that its first-quarter earnings rose as much as 11 percent a share from last year, bolstered by excellent profit in its finance and brokerage businesses.
G.E., one of the world's 10 largest industrial companies, also said it expected record earnings in 1994. 
 The company said quarterly earnings "will be at the high end" of the range of $1.45 to $1.50 a share estimated by analysts. A year ago, G.E. earned $1.16 billion, or $1.36 a share, before an accounting change.
G.E. stock, which traded as high as $99.25 today, closed down $1.25, to $97.625, the lowest closing price since Nov. 18. More than 2.3 million shares were traded, twice the daily average during the last three months.
The company made its statement in response to questions about the performance of its brokerage firm subsidiary -- Kidder, Peabody & Company. The 129-year-old brokerage firm dominates Wall Street's mortgage-backed bond business.
As interest rates have surged in the last month, the prices of mortgage securities have tumbled as demand dried up. In addition, traders at Kidder, said the G.E. unit had lost money in connection with Askin Capital Management, a manager of highly leveraged investment funds, that failed last week. An official of Kidder said a preliminary estimate of the firm's losses ranged from $20 million to $30 million.
While G.E. declined to say how much Kidder made in the quarter, a Kidder executive said the period was among its best on record. Kidder, Peabody earned a record $439 million from operations last year, an increase of 46 percent from 1992.

HEADLINE: Clinton Finds a Lesson in Congressman's Life

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL 

DATELINE: BOWLING GREEN, Ky., April 6

 BODY:
In eulogizing a member of Congress who never became a creature of Washington and until last month never missed a vote, President Clinton suggested today that Representative William H. Natcher, the Kentucky Democrat who died last week, may have struck the perfect balance.
Mr. Natcher "taught us a lot about how to live in Washington," Mr. Clinton said after he left the funeral service. "I come from a place not unlike this Congressional district," he said. "And it's hard for people like me to adjust, I think, sometimes to the life in Washington. 
 "Bill Natcher understood that. He understood you had to try to live in Washington and operate in Washington like you would if you were back home."
During his 15 months in office, Mr. Clinton has seen some of his old Arkansas friends become some of his Administration's most high-profile casualties. And he has frequently complained of the confinement of the White House and the loss of privacy since becoming President.
 
Praised for Simplicity
 Mr. Natcher, who became chairman of the House Appropriations Committee shortly after Mr. Clinton was elected President, cast 18,401 consecutive votes in 40 years in office, the last four from a stretcher wheeled into the House chamber on March 2.
But those who eulogized him today spoke more often of his simplicity and Kentucky roots than of his record voting streak. Starting with his first election as county prosecutor, Mr. Natcher had held public office since the age of 27.
"Most of us in the second district would rather vote for a dead Bill Natcher than for a living someone else," said his pastor, the Rev. Richard W. Bridges, of the First Baptist Church.
Mr. Clinton said he had been reassured by Mr. Natcher during the fight to win the passage of his economic plan that he would eventually win. He also said he came to be charmed by Mr. Natcher's anachronistic ways.
"He found a way to live in Washington and work in politics and still found a way to be exactly the way he would have been if he'd been living here in Bowling Green running a hardware store," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: Insurers' Double-Edged Sword

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
As some of the nation's largest investors in bonds, insurance companies have seen the value of their $1.4 trillion in bond investments fall by tens of billions of dollars since yields began rising in October.
Insurers' stock prices have dropped in lock step: shares of life insurance companies are down more than 20 percent since October and shares of property insurers are down about 12 percent. The declines are far steeper than the 5 percent decline posted by the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks in the same period. 
 But analysts and insurance company executives say higher rates are not all bad news, despite the accompanying fall in bond prices.
"A lot of companies have been oversold in the stock market because of the pervasive belief that insurance companies' earnings suffer from higher interest rates," said Jeffrey R. Schuman, an analyst at Conning & Company, a Hartford securities firm that specializes in insurance company stocks. He said that the higher rates should push up investment income as insurance companies buy new, higher-yielding bonds.
 
 
Silver Lining in Higher Rates
 The silver lining from higher interest rates is most noticeable for life insurance companies, which say that they will be able to offer higher dividends to policyholders and higher interest rates to annuity holders. Annuities are contracts sold by insurers that promise payments to the policyholder either for a specified period of time or for their lifetime after a certain date.
Walter T. Kirkbride, president of Conseco Capital Management of Carmel, Ind., said that higher rates on annuities would help sales, after several years of reducing interest rates to annuity holders. Annuities, he said, are looking more attractive compared with some of the investment alternatives, with the stock market weak and rates on bank certificates of deposit remaining low.
Annuity sales have grown faster than ordinary life insurance in recent years. And premiums from the 20 million policies in force last year produced more income for insurance companies than ordinary life insurance.
While losses in the bond market in recent weeks have been substantial, most insurers say that their bond holdings are still worth more than their purchase prices. At the Equitable Life Assurance Society, for example, Brian S. O'Neil, chief investment officer, said the company's more than $20 billion of bonds were still in the black because Equitable, like other insurance companies, holds large amounts of bonds bought when interest rates were much higher.
Lee Roberts, treasurer at the Keyport Life Insurance Company of Boston, noted that the $10 billion of bonds held by his company were still worth $200 million to $300 million more than what the company paid. Several months ago, before bond prices began falling, Keyport's bonds were worth $500 million to $600 million more than what the company had paid.
 
 
Learned the Hard Way in '80's
 Although insurance companies could be hurt by further declines in bond prices, investors do not expect the bond market to return quickly to the dark days of the early 1980's, when double-digit interest rates were common. Then, losses in insurers' bond portfolios were so large that some companies would have been insolvent if accounting rules had required them to show their bonds at market prices rather than at the prices at which the bonds had been purchased.
For property insurance companies, higher interest rates do not confer any benefit to the insurance policies they sell. But Charles B. Gates, an analyst at CS First Boston, noted that there were "some companies in the fortuitous position of having positive cash flow, and for those companies, higher interest rates lead to increased earnings."
For both life and property insurance companies, the benefit of higher interest rates comes from the continuous inflow of new funds -- from policy premiums and from the interest and principal repayments they receive on their existing bond portfolios -- which allow the companies to make new investments at higher interest rates.
 
 
Sticking With Investments
 Unlike mutual funds or speculative investment partnerships, which often sell large blocks of bonds when their prices fall, aggravating market downturns, insurance companies tend to stick with their investments.
While the old investment strategy of "buy and hold," is beginning to change, it is still practiced by some industry giants like State Farm Mutual. The commitment of insurance companies to stay with bond investments even when the market is declining promotes stability and provides a kind of safety net for the financial markets.
But life insurance companies take a chance offering higher interest rates on new annuities because it could lead holders of old annuities with lower interest rates to cash in. Companies could face a problem if enough customers cashed in their annuities, forcing the companies to raise cash by selling the old bonds backing those annuities. Since those old annuities were backed by older, low interest bonds, selling those bonds would result in losses.
 
 
Cashing In Annuities
 One alternative -- raising interest rates on old annuities -- might keep policyholders from cashing them in, but it would reduce insurance companies' profit margins.
Insurance executives, however, say they are not likely to be hurt by the cashing in of old annuities. Earlier interest-rate fluctuations, they say, have taught them how to estimate customer activity and to organize their investments so that there is ample cash on hand and a profitable spread between the rates they pay customers and the rate they earn on investments.
Many companies are also setting the new annual rate for those annuities that may be cashed in without penalty much lower than the renewal rate they offer for annuities that have such penalties.
But in the eyes of the stock market, the benefits of higher interest rates are too remote and are overshadowed by the habit of assuming that higher interest rates must be bad for insurance company stocks.
 
 
Street's Conventional Wisdom
 "The stock market still follows the classic old arguments that insurance companies are hurt by higher interest rates," said Max Bublitz, senior vice president at Conseco Capital Management. Insurance companies are in disfavor, he said, even if they have shown in past years an ability to modify their annuities and insurance dividends when interest rates change.
For property insurance companies, however, which cannot change their policies as interest rates fluctuate, "the timing of the bond market decline couldn't have been worse," said Christopher Snyder, a specialist in property insurance companies at A. M. Best & Company, an insurance rating firm.
He explained that under new accounting rules, insurance companies must show the market value of bonds they hold for sale, with increases or declines in market values added or subtracted from the company's capital, though not from earnings. Gains or losses on bonds actually sold are included in the profits or losses.
Even though property insurance companies have $115 billion of capital to absorb unexpected losses, Mr. Snyder said, the effect of the accounting changes is still noticeable to investors. Declining bond prices are now seen as another element of volatility facing property insurers in addition to losses from catastrophes and payments for environmental cleanups.
"You now have more of what Wall Street and the stock market hate most: volatility and uncertainty," he said.

HEADLINE: Report Proposes Combining County Services and Localities

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, April 6

 BODY:
A report released today proposes merging local governments and services throughout Westchester County to eliminate overlapping jurisdictions and contain government spending.
"We have too much government and too little resources to pay for it," the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said at a news conference where the report was released. 
 The report, titled Westchester 2000, was eight years in the making. It was compiled by a nonpartisan partnership of government officials and business leaders who solicited the ideas of hundreds of people, including academics and taxpayers.
But in a county where the loyalties to local governments and small communities run deep, the recommendations are unlikely to be enacted soon, if ever. Many residents have moved to the suburbs to, among other things, escape the sluggish bureaucracy of large cities.
 
Expecting Strong Reactions
 Further, such recommendations are hardly new in the metropolitan region, where blue-ribbon panels have issued reports calling for similar streamlining and reform. But those calls have largely been ignored.
"Merging governments gets you up against some very strong political feelings about communities," said Richard P. Nathan, the director of the State University of New York's Rockefeller Institute of Government. But he saw such efforts at consolidation as critical.
"I think the real reinvention of government is on the local level," he said. "That's where you have the most complex problems of duplication, parochialism, layering and fragmentation of government."
Mr. O'Rourke acknowledged that the report would inspire strong reactions, noting that he himself did not support all of its recommendations. "Every one of these is not going to happen," he said. "Some are going to fall politically."
He added, "It's not going to be easy."
 
Creating New Localities
 Still, the proposals are very likely to provoke debate at a time when villages, towns and cities throughout the county are struggling to reduce the cost of running government while continuing to provide adequate levels of services.
"It has to be talked about, and it has to be done somewhere along the line," Mr. O'Rourke said, adding: "It used to be that no one would talk about this."
Among other proposals, the report calls for creating 17 localities from the 39 villages and towns that now exist. For instance, Greenburgh, Tarrytown, Irvington, Dobbs Ferry, Ardsley, Elmsford and Hastings-on-Hudson would form a single government under the proposal.
The report also recommends consolidating police departments within the villages and towns, proposing a total of 17 departments. (Those departments operating within the county's six cities would not be affected.)
 
Reducing School Districts
 Also, while the report would leave the number of cities at six, it proposes the expansion of Peekskill and New Rochelle. The latter, for instance, would absorb two of its neighbors: the town of Pelham and the village of Pelham Manor.
The other recommendations included reducing the county's 40 public school districts by more than half, instituting term limits for the county executive and Board of Legislators and establishing collective bargaining for all local municipal workers.
The report noted that the cost of government rose by more than 105 percent from 1980 to 1990, from $1.7 billion to $3.5 billion, in Westchester, where there are more than 500 jurisdictions that often overlap and thus create "waste and complication."
"Each city, town and village has its own set of police, fire, and court districts and maintain separate facilities for each," the report concluded. "This kind of fragmentation creates vast inefficiencies, both in terms of monetary costs and in the availability and quality of service delivery."
The report said it was important to act on the proposals because a number of economic and demographic factors have eroded the finances of local governments, businesses and individuals in the county. Those, the report said, include a decline in the county's job base, its high cost of living and the cost of providing social services to the county's growing elderly population.
But in the village of Elmsford where voters rejected a proposal to merge with the Town of Greenburgh in the mid 1980's, Mayor Arthur DeAngelis said people were still not ready to give up the accessibility and other advantages that small governments offer.
"My door is always open," Mr. DeAngelis said. "You can't do that in a big city. The bigger the city, the bigger the problems."

HEADLINE: Dances So Beloved They Are Hated

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
The history of ballet and modern dance is studded with works that have attached themselves to the companies that performed them, like an extra arm or leg or sometimes a whole new persona. Alvin Ailey could not escape "Revelations." For a time, "Tommy" was Les Grands Ballets Canadiens' middle name.
And now, ladies and gentlemen, the Joffrey Ballet has arrived with "Billboards," a ballet set to music by Prince, which opens tonight at the New York State Theater and will be performed nine times during a season that ends on April 17. 
 "Billboards" has been credited with luring the common man into the elegant precincts of classical ballet. The hottest of tickets, this ballet is said to have saved the Joffrey from financial collapse. Now the company is discovering that it is easier to book a rock dance than the jewels of 20th-century world ballet for which its repertory is -- or was -- known.
 
With Other Hits
 The company has had other rock hits before, among them Robert Joffrey's "Astarte" and Twyla Tharp's "Deuce Coupe," but there has been nothing like "Billboards," which threatens to outstrip its chief rivals among dances whose popularity has just refused to call it quits.
One dance is "Tommy." For years, Les Grands Ballets Canadiens was known as the company that danced that ballet, a version of the rock opera choreographed by Fernand Nault in 1970. Its Carl Orff trilogy just couldn't compete with the Who.
Another is "Revelations." Not long into his career, Ailey learned to flinch at the "r" word. His "Revelations" had been a huge success at its first performance, in 1960. The normally sedate 92d Street Y rang so loud and long with applause and cheers that William Kolodney, the director of the Y's dance program, stepped before the curtain to reassure the audience, in what was a unique announcement there, that the dancers would return in a month.
Life was never the same for Ailey, and he would never create another dance as popular as "Revelations."
 
Basking in Ovations
 The dance had an astonishing ripple effect. Ves Harper, who designed the costumes for the version of "Revelations" performed today, was startled to discover that he had suddenly become famous in Copenhagen, where he lives and had worked for years, after Danish audiences saw "Revelations."
Basking in ovations around the world, the performers would in later years sometimes lose sight of the finer points of choreography and character in this piece set to black spirituals. How could he work with them on it, Ailey once asked an old-time member of the company, with the cheers ringing in their ears? Unwary interviewers who asked him about the dance were likely to meet with exuberant groans from the choreographer. "Not 'Rev' again!" Ailey would exclaim.
 
Money Talks, Loudly
 Ailey once told Masazumi Chaya, who was his rehearsal director, that he wanted no performances of "Revelations" in the next season. Mr. Chaya knew better than to argue. Instead, he added up box-office receipts for performances with "Revelations" on the program and without it, then brought the figures to Ailey, who quickly changed his mind.
Kurt Jooss had a similar problem, though on a smaller scale. It is the rare balletomane who has heard of Jooss's "Dithyrambus" or "Gaukelei." But anyone with more than a passing acquaintance with dance knows "The Green Table," an antiwar ballet with a Brechtian bite. Created in 1932, it became the signature work of Jooss and his company after they fled Nazi Germany.
Jooss knew that audiences expected him to include the piece on programs. He did, on most. And sadly, "The Green Table" is the only one of the Joffrey's loving re-creations of ballets by Jooss that has survived.
For many Americans, ballet was defined by the lovelorn birds of the second act of "Swan Lake," a fast-forwarded one-act version of "The Nutcracker" and hot sex and cold-blooded murder in an Asian harem, as depicted in Fokine's "Sheherezade." No small-town opera house or school auditorium was spared, it seemed in the 1940's, from that increasingly threadbare touring program of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo.
 
Choreographed and Appropriated
 Would the New York City Ballet ever go back to Balanchine? The question arose in the aftermath of Balanchine's immensely successful "Dances at a Gathering." No one seemed to be able to get enough of the simple, sumptuous dancing-party Jerome Robbins choreographed to Chopin piano music 25 years ago. Then there was "The Moor's Pavane," a distillation of "Othello," choreographed by Jose Limon and appropriated for a time by ballet troupes like the Joffrey and Nureyev and Friends.
There were enough thudding falls to the ground for the stately "Pavane" to qualify as unruly modern dance. But in the end, it all looked strangely like ballet. Modern dance had at last been made safe for ballet audiences.
Will "Billboards" make ballet a household word throughout America?

GRAPHIC: Photos: Regardless of its repertory, a ballet company is often identified with one work. Clockwise, from top left, Rudolf Nureyev danced "The Moor's Pavane" in 1974 (Linda Vartoogian, 1974); Cheryl Madeux was in the Joffrey Ballet's "Billboards" last year (Jack Vartoogian, 1978); and the Alvin Ailey Company performed its classic "Revelations" in 1978. (Herbert Migdoll/Joffrey Ballet)

HEADLINE: China Makes It Tough

 BODY:
Beijing's domestic political anxieties probably explain the latest charges against Wei Jingsheng, China's leading democracy campaigner, and the criminal investigation of his office assistant, Tong Yi.
Deng Xiaoping has always put political control ahead of China's international reputation, and Mr. Wei, who has been fearlessly outspoken since his release from a long prison term last fall, has had a special knack for getting under the paramount leader's skin. 
 In fact, Mr. Deng is widely reported to have boasted to party colleagues a few years back that the indifferent reaction of foreign governments to Mr. Wei's earlier incarceration proved that China could take a hard line on dissent without damaging its basic interests.
But this time Beijing may have miscalculated, badly. Mr. Wei is too symbolically important, and the May deadline set by the Clinton Administration for deciding the future of U.S.-China trade relations too near at hand, for Washington to look the other way again. Congress and American public opinion would rightly see such a show of indifference as legalistic hypocrisy.
Beijing has correctly concluded that the Clinton Administration -- including human rights champions in the State Department as well as trade and economic officials -- is looking for a plausible way to justify renewing China's favorable tariff status this year. With that goal in mind, Secretary of State Christopher has been scrambling to portray his recent bumpy visit to Beijing as a pragmatic success. But Beijing's latest high-profile crackdown -- which also includes a Draconian sentence imposed on a Hong Kong journalist this week -- threatens to make full renewal of China's trade privileges politically impossible.
That is surely not what Beijing wants. China, despite its public posture of indifference, knows that the economic development plans on which the Communist regime's survival depends would be devastated by U.S. trade sanctions. But without some timely help from Beijing, the Clinton Administration could be forced into imposing those sanctions, harming American economic interests as well as Chinese.
The freedom of Wei Jingsheng is not one of the explicit conditions Mr. Clinton set down last May as the basis for deciding whether to renew China's trade privileges before they run out this July. On the two absolute conditions, policing prison labor exports and allowing freer emigration, China is already within reach of compliance.
The other conditions deal with issues like treatment of Tiananmen Square prisoners, respect for the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (which includes the right of all people to freedom of opinion and expression), honoring the distinctive traditions of Tibet and ending the jamming of Voice of America broadcasts. On these, nothing more is required than a judgment call by the Secretary of State that there has been overall, significant progress.
But that judgment call will be hard to make, and to sustain in Congress, if China continues its provocative campaign against all dissent.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Small Businesses Certainly Do Create Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Myth: Small Business as Job Engine" (Business Day, March 25) tries to make the case that large companies are at least as proficient as small ones at job creation. This is certainly a point that can be illuminated empirically. Curiously, however, you provide no data to do so, while ignoring ample evidence to the contrary. 
 The crux of your article is a recent study of manufacturing employment that, you state, "is regarded by many other researchers as the most careful analysis of job creation and destruction to date." Paraphrasing the study, you state: "Companies with 500 employees or more created slightly more than half of all the new jobs from 1973 to 1988."
The results presented from this study in chart form, however, demonstrate that no single size category of manufacturer created net new jobs from 1973 to 1988. This, of course, is consistent with data you do not report, which shows that manufacturing's share of total employment declined from 26 percent in 1973 to less than 16 percent last year. In the 1973-88 period, meanwhile, the American economy created some 30 million jobs overall.
You ignore a mountain of available data that show smaller companies have indeed been the engine of job creation. You create a straw man out of one lone researcher, David Birch, whose work, you say, is widely credited with creating the "image" of small business job creation. There are ample sources of information that support his thesis.
For example, the 1993 Statistical Abstract of the United States includes a chart based on Small Business Administration data. It shows that companies with fewer than 500 employees created more than 13 million of the 19.3 million new jobs between 1980 and 1990. Of these, 82 percent -- 10.75 million -- were in companies with fewer than 20 employees.
Backed by Clinton Administration sources, your article proceeds to postulate that small businesses are not worthy of special tax and regulatory treatment because they are not the mythical job creators of the public imagination. It's worth noting, however, that far from providing special relief, the tax legislation of recent years -- especially the 1993 budget -- placed an added burden on job creating small businesses relative to larger companies. They now face the prospect of expensive new health care mandates.
 
DAVID GITLITZ
Morristown, N.J., March 29, 1994
 
The writer is with Polyconomics, a political and economic consulting organization.

HEADLINE: Small Businesses Certainly Do Create Jobs;
Both Contribute

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The fundamental issue confronting advanced economies -- communities, countries or trading blocs -- was obscured by the discussion of job growth in "Myth: Small Business as Job Engine" (Business Day, March 25). Most analyses find that when all economic sectors are considered, both large and small make net job contributions. (Although when the entire sector is declining, as in manufacturing, the issue is relative.) 
 But those who are uncomfortable with the overstatements of politicians have done us all a disservice by implying that policy alternatives should focus on large versus small. The implication that economic growth is a zero-sum game distracts attention from other, more critical issues.
Advanced economies involve a complicated interdependency between large and small companies. The central issue is to determine the appropriate mix of large and small such that the entire system is efficient, competitive and adaptive. Whether this should be left to (a) the "natural" processes of economic markets, which are socially constructed mechanisms, or (b) influenced by public policy, is an important topic for study and debate.
Then, the analysis portrayed in these large-is-good discussions reflects the available Federal data sets, developed over decades, and assumes a static economic structure. There is an emerging body of evidence to suggest that economic regions with greater turbulence -- birth and death of companies, creation and destruction of jobs -- have greater subsequent economic (job) growth.
The complementary roles of new (usually small) companies in innovation and established (usually large) companies in implementing it, thus leading to changes in economic structure, would also be a fruitful topic for attention. The central problem continues to be economic growth and change, not comparisons of large versus small.
 
PAUL D. REYNOLDS
Milwaukee, March 28, 1994
 
The writer holds the Coleman Foundation chair in entrepreneurial studies at Marquette University.

HEADLINE: For the Air and the Economy, Try Ethanol

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Coming Soon: The Alternative Fuel of the Future," Mobil Corporation's March 24 advertorial on alternative fuels and reformulated gasoline, is a thinly disguised attempt to sidetrack the Environmental Protection Agency's program to clean up gasoline and the air we breathe by blending it with clean-burning additives such as ethanol. 
 Mobil's ad omits ethanol as a fuel of the future. The E.P.A. is convinced ethanol makes economic and environmental sense as an alternate fuel and as a component in reformulated gasoline. The reason for Mobil's omission? Ethanol, a renewable product made from corn, other grains and potentially all forms of biomass, would compete with nonrenewable methanol, which major oil companies
largely import from the Middle East.
The international methanol interests and proponents in the oil industry are fighting a ruling the Environmental Protection Agency is still expected to announce in June to require ethanol, which reduces carbon monoxide emissions, to be mixed with the gasoline sold in our smoggiest cities.
I represent and chair the Governors' Ethanol Coalition, made up of 19 governors who believe the Federal Government is on the right track with a clean air ethanol-based program, which offers a job-creation bonus. More than half the country's governors support this program. In Nebraska, for example, new ethanol plants will result in nearly 4,500 new jobs. Iowa benefits from 15,000 ethanol industry jobs. Construction of new ethanol plants could add up to 75,000 jobs nationally every two years, according to our coalition's estimates.
In contrast, the petroleum industry has recently thinned its ranks by 450,000 employees. In 1992, four huge United States oil companies, including Mobil, pumped $6.5 billion into countries they used to call unstable to develop oil (and foreign jobs) while investing only $3.3 billion here at home. It should be no surprise that foreign imports and our trade deficit are spiraling skyward.
Public policy will be well served by working with United States refiners and encouraging the use of ethanol, a future fuel that reduces oil imports, cleans our air, stimulates economic development and creates American jobs.
 
E. BENJAMIN NELSON
Governor of Nebraska
Lincoln, Neb., March 30, 1994

HEADLINE: Resignation News Jolts Japan Stocks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 8

 BODY:
The shocking announcement today that Japan's embattled Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, intends to resign put stock prices into a temporary tailspin.
But analysts said the news created a sense of uncertainty rather than panic, and the world's second-largest market later rebounded to close slightly higher for the day. 
 Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange had been hovering earlier in the day, having changed little, when the news about Mr. Hosokawa hit the wires early this afternoon. Immediately, the Nikkei index of 225 issues plummeted about 300 points from its midday level, hitting a low of about 19,520.
But analysts said that, despite the obvious uncertainty the resignation announcement has created, there were some potential positives, at least in the short term. Those prospects caused prices to rebound, although most investors retreated to the sidelines.
At the close, the Nikkei index stood at 19,934.99, up 44.01 points, or about two-tenths of 1 percent, for the day.
Mr. Hosokawa had been well received by the stock market because of his strong rhetoric backing deregulation of the economy, a strong stimulus to end the recession and an end to the political corruption that brought down a string of governments in recent years.
But he failed to deliver on his promises and his economic stimulus packages were generally regarded as modest at best. Then, in recent weeks, he was swallowed up by a money scandal, which is what eventually brought him down today.
For the market, the worst problem was that battling over the scandal, which involved a loan from a trucking company at the center of other scandals, held up passage of the Government's budget. The new fiscal year began April 1 without a budget in place.
Because the budget included big spending increases to try to infuse new life into the economy, investors worried that the delay could forestall an economic recovery. It is now expected that at least a makeshift budget will be passed, even if the process of choosing a new Prime Minister drags on.
"The market is very dependent right now on getting an economic recovery," said Geoffrey Barker, the chief economist here with Baring Securities. "So if this helps pass a budget, that is a plus for the market."
He added that the resignation could also remove another source of uncertainty, heavy American pressure for a trade agreement from Japan. The American Government is expected to moderate its demands, at least until a new Prime Mininster is in place, Mr. Barker said.
"Over the long term this could be a problem because it could remove the momentum for deregulation, which was positive for the market," said Tim Hayashida, an analyst at Merrill Lynch Japan. "But the deadlock on the budget had people worried. This may clear that up."
Tokyo stocks generally held up well through the international financial turbulence of the past month. The jump in interest rates in the United States pushed rates up here slightly, and the plunge in American stock prices created jitters. But the market has clung to its optimism that the deep two-year-old recession will lift later this year.
"We'd fallen less than in New York here because people have taken a wait-and-see attitude on the economy," Mr. Barker said. "Even with today's news, we're still in that position."
