HEADLINE: Fed Shares In Chief's Rate Power

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Without a vote or even a formal discussion, the Federal Reserve's top policy makers are taking over the process of raising and lowering rates, rather than allowing their chairman, Alan Greenspan, to act on his own between meetings, as he often has in the past.
Several Federal Reserve officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, described the new approach not as implying criticism of Mr. Greenspan, but as a sign of growing reluctance to delegate authority to any single person. In fact, both of the Fed's recent moves to raise rates, in February and March -- the first increases in five years -- were made by the policy makers as a group. They acted in the face of faster economic growth and growing concerns about inflation. 
 The new approach to decision-making has evolved through consensus, and while it has not been made formal, neither has Mr. Greenspan challenged the change. It comes partly in response to pressures from Congress for the Fed to be more open and accountable for its actions.
"We are under enormous pressure from some quarters to stand up and be counted," a senior Federal Reserve official said, referring to Congressional demands for more disclosure of Federal Reserve deliberations. "This change we are making may be a halfway house for taking on that accountability as a committee rather than individually, by making rate changes committee decisions."
The Federal Reserve has said that its job has become more difficult because the economy is behaving in ways that traditional statistics fail to measure adequately.
"If our national indicators were more reliable, there would not be as great a need for a collective decision, and we would be delegating more authority to the chairman," said Harvey Rosenblum, director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank in Dallas. "But you don't have one economy in the United States today. The national data are not representative of what is going on in every region. This recovery has been more uneven than any other since World War II."
In the past, the policy makers, collectively known as the Federal Open Market Committee, adopted directives that gave the chairman guidance. Actual changes were almost always made by Mr. Greenspan in the six to eight weeks between each meeting. He either acted on his own or after consulting with his colleagues in a conference call, a practice that Wayne D. Angell, a Fed governor who resigned in February, described as less than satisfactory.
"It is difficult for the members to politely disagree in a conference call the way they can at the meetings," said Mr. Angell, whose views sometimes clashed with Mr. Greenspan's.
 
 
 
Directives Cloaked in Jargon
 The directives adopted at each meeting are called, in Fed jargon, "symmetric" or "asymmetric." An asymmetric directive toward higher rates, or toward lower rates, would give Mr. Greenspan the green light to move in the indicated direction -- if he wished to do so -- between meetings. A symmetric directive is essentially an instruction to leave interest rates alone. Before the Fed's two recent moves, rate changes during Mr. Greenspan's nearly seven years as chairman have typically occurred in this fashion between meetings.
But significantly, the policy makers voted at their Feb. 4 meeting to raise rates that day. And instead of adopting an asymmetric directive to reflect their view that rates should be going up, they took the unusual step of adopting a symmetric one -- in effect, telling Mr. Greenspan not to act between meetings. The March 22 meeting produced another vote to push up rates that day.
 
 
Speculation About a Rift
 While the minutes of that closed-door meeting will not be published until May 20, the Fed policy makers may have adopted another symmetric directive -- again urging Mr. Greenspan not to act before the committee reconvenes on May 17.
"I don't like the symmetry-asymmetry stuff," one policy maker, who insisted on anonymity, said. "To me, the world would be better off without that little piece of subtlety."
The new insistence on changing rates at meetings, and not between them, has inevitably raised speculation that some members of the Open Market Committee were losing faith in Mr. Greenspan. The policy-making group comprises Mr. Greenspan and the six other Fed governors based in Washington, as well as the presidents of the Fed's 12 regional banks.
 Despite denials by many policy makers of differences with Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Angell said the chairman had not always responded as all the policy makers thought he should. Last May, for example, the policy makers gave the chairman a green light to raise interest rates, Mr. Angell said, but the chairman did not act, perhaps costing the Fed some credibility.
"I would say that to provide leadership, the chairman has to constantly renew the confidence of the members of the policy-making committee," Mr. Angell said. "And if anything tends to diminish that confidence, then the committee itself concludes that it should be making more decisions."
The committee has made other changes, too, in response to Congressional demands for more openness. When policy makers raised rates on Feb. 4 and again on March 22, both increases were publicly announced. That was a significant departure from the past practice of saying nothing at all, leaving Wall Street experts scrambling to figure out what happened.
The new approach to setting rates may, in fact, suit Mr. Greenspan, some Fed watchers on Wall Street say. They speculate that the chairman may welcome having the committee take responsibility for raising interest rates, a measure never popular among millions of Americans who end up paying more for such things as mortgages and car loans.
 
 
'A Powerful Chairman'
 But some Fed watchers, including Allan H. Meltzer, an economist at the Carnegie-Mellon Institute, argue that Mr. Greenspan is likely to retain substantial power in manipulating the decisions of the policy-making committee. "A powerful chairman can always get a committee to do what he wants, and Greenspan is a powerful chairman," Mr. Meltzer said.
The press office at the Federal Reserve headquarters in Washington, asked for comment from Mr. Greenspan, did not provide any.
The new procedure seems to be pushed the hardest by some of the regional bank presidents, undoubtedly concerned about their own future. Under one recent Congressional proposal, they could lose their power to vote on interest rate changes because they are essentially representatives of specific regions, neither nominated by the Administration nor approved by Congress.
Whatever the motivation, the new practice is more in line with central bank procedures abroad. For example, Germany's central bank acts on interest rates when its members meet every other week. Under the Fed's new procedure, if no rate change comes forth, the public and the credit markets can assume that no change will be made until the next meeting, six or eight weeks in the future, unless an emergency arises.
In the past, stock and bond prices have often fluctuated in the weeks between meetings in response to speculation on Wall Street -- often unfounded -- that Mr. Greenspan was about to take some action.
 
 
No Barriers to Action
 Speaking mostly off the record, several policy makers noted in interviews that there are no formal prohibitions that bar Mr. Greenspan from acting between meetings. They dismissed as unfounded speculation that they were seeking greater control of policy out of concern that Mr. Greenspan had grown too close to the Clinton Administration and might be reluctant to push up interest rates.
They also dismissed speculation that the regional bank presidents were insisting on the change because they wanted to push rates up faster than Mr. Greenspan and the four other governors now in office. (Two seats are currently vacant.)
There have been frictions in the past between Mr. Greenspan and some colleagues. The tensions arose in spring 1991, when the economy was still weak from recession and the Fed was pushing rates down to encourage more borrowing and spending. More than once in that period, Mr. Greenspan lowered rates on his own, without consulting the regional bank presidents.
Under pressure, Mr. Greenspan began to make greater use of telephone conference calls. For 14 months, from December 1992 until Feb. 4 of this year, the Fed made no rate changes at all, because the economy remained weak. And now that changes have resumed, Mr. Greenspan's colleagues have moved to confine the Fed's actions to the meetings themselves.

Upbeat Greenspan View
 SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 (AP) -- A widening income gap has Americans fearful of the future despite generally good economic news, Mr. Greenspan said today.
The Federal Reserve chairman avoided any discussion of interest rates or the stock and bond markets' recent turmoil in a speech to business leaders here. Many in the the financial markets had been looking for Mr. Greenspan to give some hints in the speech as to what action the Fed might take.
Instead, he gave a long-range and generally upbeat assessment of the American economy -- but said polling data showed that the public did not share his optimism. "There seemingly inexplicably remains an extraordinarily deep-rooted foreboding" about the future, Mr. Greenspan said. "Half those polled expect the next generation will face lower living standards."
The basis for the gloomy outlook, he said, appears to be the increasing income gap between rich and poor Americans. The gap has widened in the last 20 years after narrowing for several decades before that.

HEADLINE: Europeans to Build Supersonic Plane

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 7

 BODY:
With Europe and the United States increasingly jockeying for leadership in efforts to build a new generation of supersonic passenger aircraft, the leading French and British aerospace companies said today that they would link up with their German counterpart to step up development of a successor to the Concorde.
British Aerospace and Aerospatiale of France, which built the Concorde together and which have been studying the possibility of a new supersonic plane for the last four years, said they would now be joined in that effort by Deutsche Aerospace, their partner in the Airbus consortium. 
 Today's announcement was seen by some within the industry as an attempt to present a united front to the governments of Europe in the quest for more financial aid. The European companies have been lobbying for more government money for research into supersonic aircraft to compete with the American industry, which is heavily involved in research sponsored by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
 
Growth on Long Routes
 "We are looking for government to be supportive," said Ian Woodward, a spokesman for British Aerospace.
With much of the growth in airline traffic coming from long-haul routes like those from the United States and Europe to Asia, the aerospace industry worldwide has been increasingly enthusiastic about a new plane that would slash flying times and offer greater range and seating capacity than the Concorde.
In their announcement today, the European companies said they believed airlines would purchase between 500 and 1,000 of the new planes if and when they became available, presumably sometime after the turn of the century. Because of cost and environmental concerns, British Aerospace and Aerospatiale sold only 14 Concordes, seven each to British Airways and Air France.
Every major aerospace company in the United States, Europe and Japan has been working on supersonic research, and the companies have been cooperating to a certain degree through a joint international study group established four years ago.
 
Competition Is Intense
 But beneath the veneer of international cooperation, there is intense competition. The Europeans, having built the Concorde, want to maintain their leadership in the field, with all the jobs and money that a big new project would bring.
In the United States, the Boeing Company, which designed a supersonic plane in the late 1960's only to abandon it in the face of protests about noise, and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation both have active programs going, as do the major engine manufacturers, the General Electric Company and the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies.
Under American law, much of their work cannot be shared with foreign companies because it is partly financed by NASA. However, executives from both the United States and Europe said today that any plane that was built would have to involve partners from all over the world, if only because of the huge development cost; estimates start at $10 billion. Still, it is likely that one company or group will emerge as the prime contractor.
But such a plane faces daunting hurdles, including concerns about the noise from its sonic boom and its powerful engines, and its effect on the ozone layer.
 
Overcoming Concorde's Legacy
 Moreover, it will have to overcome the legacy of the Concorde, which was a financial disaster both for its builders and for the British and French Governments, which subsidized it.
"This airplane will not be built by Boeing unless it's economically viable and environmentally benign, and the barriers between the present situation and that eventuality are very significant," said Randy Harrison, a spokesman for Boeing in Seattle. But he added: "We do feel that progress is being made. Momentum is building."
The European partners said they had now decided on the general features of the plane, including a range of 6,200 miles, which is 2,500 miles more than the Concorde and sufficient to reach Asia from the United States or Europe. Passenger capacity would be 250, or 150 more than the Concorde, and it would offer three classes of service to Concorde's one. Like the Concorde's, its cruising speed would be about 1,500 miles an hour, or twice the speed of sound.
Perhaps most ambitiously, they said the new plane would have to operate cheaply enough that airlines could charge only slightly more than normal subsonic fares. The standard round-trip fare between London and New York on the Concorde is about $7,700, compared with about $6,000 for a normal first-class seat and under $500 for discounted economy fares.
"How much of the available market a supersonic aircraft will actually capture depends on how close it proves possible to come to the design objectives, and in particular the objective that fares for supersonic flights should not be significantly greater than normal subsonic fares," the companies said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Goldman Sachs Signs Major New Lease

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a reflection of financial vigor and an uptick in hiring on Wall Street, Goldman Sachs and Company, one of the nation's biggest brokerage concerns, has leased a large block of office space in lower Manhattan to expand its staff.
Although Goldman declined to disclose details, real-estate executives said it has rented 425,000 square feet, or roughly 25 percent of the space, in One New York Plaza, a 50-story office building just north of the Staten Island Ferry Terminal. 
 Although the office market in lower Manhattan continues to stagnate, analysts said that the lease by Goldman Sachs underscores Wall Street's response to a pent-up demand for new employees and new office space.
"But because firms have delayed hiring, they are under strain," said Jeffrey Schaefer, chief economist for the Securities Industry Association, a trade organization that represents 700 firms that are members of the stock exchanges. "As long as there is no dramatic downturn in the markets, I see more growth."
People in the industry said Goldman has rented the space to accommodate new employees, not to relocate them.
Employment among the firms in Mr. Schaefer's group, now 244,000, has increased by 34,000 since the end of 1990, he said. That followed widespread layoffs in the aftermath of the dramatic stock market fall in October 1987, when the employment by the firms had reached a peak of 262,000.
Roughly half of those working for the securities firms in Mr. Schaefer's group are employed in New York City or its suburbs.
By signing a lease at One New York Plaza, Goldman Sachs has filled a building that was left nearly vacant in 1989 by its owner, the Chase Manhattan Bank. In that year, Chase moved all of its New York staff not assigned to its headquarters to two buildings it had constructed in Metrotech, a huge new complex in downtown Brooklyn.
The largest lease at One New York Plaza was signed in 1992 by Prudential Securities, which rented one million square feet of space in the building, which has a total of 2.3 million square feet of space.
Although the Wall Street area has a firm hold on the distinction of being the world's busiest and best-known financial district, it suffers from a surplus of old buildings that are difficult, if not impossible, to retrofit.
According to Edward S. Gordon, the real-estate firm, 23.6 percent of the office space in lower Manhattan is vacant, a record rate. In contrast, vacancies have been shrinking in midtown Manhattan, which has been attracting a wide spectrum of new tenants, including many from Wall Street.
The vacancy rate in midtown is 15.2 percent, down from a high of 18.5 percent in March 1992, according to Edward S. Gordon.

HEADLINE: Rise in Capital Outlay Is Projected at 8% for '94

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Businesses plan to increase spending on their factories and equipment by 8 percent this year, the largest gain in five years, as they scramble to meet stronger demand from consumers, the Commerce Department reported today.
The increase, to $633 billion, shows that "the economy is still on a strong footing," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Money Watch in New York. "We haven't had any effect from the higher interest rates." 
 As if to back up the report on capital spending, the Whirlpool Corporation announced plans to spend more than $100 million to build an appliance factory in Tulsa, Okla. Construction is to begin this summer.
The capital-investment figures follow previous Government estimates of a 5.4 percent gain in such spending this year, before adjustments for inflation. In 1993, spending on factories and equipment advanced 7.1 percent.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said today that the number of Americans entering unemployment lines for the first time increased last week -- the first gain since the beginning of March.
Initial jobless claims rose a larger-than-expected 6,000 last week, to 337,000, though analysts said the increase did not mean that the economy was weakening. Last Friday, the Government said the economy added 456,000 jobs in March, a figure that surprised the bond market, sending interest rates surging on fear of too-rapid growth.
 
Greenspan Perplexed
 Consumers, though, remain worried about the economy "despite what is obviously solid evidence of economic strength," said Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, in a speech in San Francisco today.
Perhaps reflecting this unsettled mood, consumer borrowing rose in February at about half the pace expected by analysts, according to new Fed figures. Installment credit rose by $3.54 billion in February, the ninth straight increase, after rising $6.38 billion in January.
The Commerce Department's report on capital spending showed that the industries with the largest planned increases included steel works and blast furnaces; stone, glass, and clay producers, and auto and truck makers.
The Roanoke Electric Steel Corporation in Virginia is planning to spend $10 million over the next two years to install a ladle furnace to meet demand. "We can hardly keep up," said Thomas Crawford, the company's assistant vice president and secretary. "We're producing a lot of steel, and it doesn't seem to be enough."
Coca-Cola intends to increase spending by 50 percent, or $400 million, this year, with 75 percent of the money going toward international expansion. Other American businesses are spending more on their international operations, too. On Wednesday, the Commerce Department said foreign affiliates of United States companies planned to raise spending on factories and equipment by 8 percent this year, the biggest gain since 1990.

HEADLINE: In Maryland, Taking Free Papers in Protest May Soon Be a Crime

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
In cities and towns across the country, neighborhood and alternative city newspapers and campus dailies sit stacked in public places so that anyone can grab a free copy. But increasingly, those doing the grabbing are taking entire stacks because they disagree with the editorial content.
Yet even with witnesses and confiscated papers as evidence, publishers have been unable to convince the police and prosecutors that it is a crime to take something that is already free. 
 Maryland is the first state to consider legislation branding as censorship these acts of protest that others say are expressions of free speech. The State Senate recently passed the bill, 46 to 1; the House is expected to pass it on Friday with equal ease. Gov. William Donald Schaefer has said he will sign it into law.
The bill would make it a misdemeanor to take "one or more newspapers with the intent to destroy the newspapers or prevent other individuals from reading the newspapers." Those convicted could be fined up to $500 or imprisoned for up to 60 days.
That has drawn fire from opponents, including the editorial pages of The Washington Post and The Baltimore Sun, who contend that seizing free papers is in itself an expression of free speech.
 
Core Issue Is Intent
 "Taking extra stacks of papers does not add to the symbolism of protest; it seems intended only to keep others from reading them," said Rodney Smolla, a law professor at the College of William and Mary and author of "Free Speech in an Open Society," published by Alfred A. Knopf in 1992. "If the law is written to make this the core of the crime, then it's perfectly consistent with the First Amendment" provision protecting free speech.
At the Student Press Law Center in Washington, a nonprofit group representing student journalists, its executive director, Mark Goodman, said his group had received 20 reports of seizures for the 1992-93 school year, and 25 since colleges and universities opened last fall. "Two years ago," he said, "we had three or four in the entire school year."
Last fall, campus newspapers at the University of Maryland were snatched by minority students protesting what they said was its racist content. But it was the repeated seizure from public libraries of a Washington weekly for homosexuals that prompted State Senator Howard Denis, a Republican from the Maryland suburbs of Washington, to sponsor the legislation.
Those confiscating the paper have said they were anti-family and should not be on display in libraries. But even after members of the weekly's staff photographed a man loading the papers into a car, the state would not prosecute.
"But it is a crime, and this is a free speech bill," Mr. Denis said. "There are fundamental First Amendment issues at stake here. We're not book-burners or newspaper-burners."
 
Elements of Theft Law
 Matthew Campbell, the Maryland state's attorney who decided not to prosecute, said papers that are available free of charge do not have the same legal status as papers for which people pay.
"The requirements of theft law are such that you have to prove certain elements," Mr. Campbell said. "One is that the property is wrongfully taken from its rightful possessor. In this instance, the paper gave up its possession by placing the papers in libraries.
"Second, you have to prove value," he continued. "It's a free paper. The ordinary, objective economic value of something is its sales price. Here there is no sales price."

HEADLINE: Bronx Leaders Boycott Ceremony on Federal Aid

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Borough President Fernando Ferrer and other elected officials from the Bronx boycotted a ceremony announcing an agreement on a Federal inner-city development program yesterday, saying they were upset that the program would benefit only a small portion of the borough around Yankee Stadium.
The agreement, between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Representative Charles B. Rangel, designated all of Harlem and a slice of the South Bronx as the area the city hopes will be selected as one of six urban "empowerment zones." 
 Most officials expect that New York's application will be accepted, if for no other reason than that Mr. Rangel sponsored the legislation creating the program. The empowerment zone will bring $100 million in direct grants that can be used for job training, drug and alcohol treatment and emergency shelter, and create tax credits for companies that employ residents within the zone.
Mr. Ferrer, who in recent weeks has battled with Mr. Rangel over whether the money should go to Harlem or the Bronx, said that while he was pleased the program would benefit the borough, he was upset that the area included an industrial area and Yankee Stadium rather than areas where low-income people live.
"The empowerment zone is intended to help the poorest of the poor," said Mr. Ferrer, who attended the dedication of an athletic building at Lehman College rather than the news conference that Mr. Rangel and Mr. Giuliani held to announce the agreement. "But it includes Yankee Stadium, which is not as important. It is a disappointment and I hope there can still be some minor changes made so that other areas can be included."
Although the inclusion of part of the Bronx was part of a compromise intended to satisfy Mr. Ferrer and other Bronx officials, Mr. Rangel, who represents Harlem, was the clear winner.
But the compromise also benefits Mayor Giuliani. By including Yankee Stadium, he was able to appeal to George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, who has been pressing the city to improve conditions around the stadium and who has dropped broad hints that he might move the team elsewhere.
In general the plan is expected to aid the Yankees and other businesses near the stadium by giving them special tax-exempt bonds and tax credits in return for employing local residents.
"We haven't yet been made aware of the funds available," said David Sussman, general counsel for the team. "But we've studied the legislation and there are tax benefits to the Yankees."
The Mayor defended the inclusion of the stadium, saying: "It's one of those things that draws people to New York City. If you have an important asset, you should be considering the area around that asset so it doesn't decay and you lose it."
And he rejected criticism that he had tailored the compromise to appeal to Mr. Steinbrenner. "This will help the city fulfill an obligation that the city has to the people in the area surrounding Yankee Stadium," he said.
The boundaries of the empowerment zone have not yet been fully determined. But under the agreement between Mr. Rangel and Mr. Giuliani, the area covered will include Harlem and a section of Washington Heights as well as an industrial area of the Bronx that includes the Harlem River Rail Yards, the Port Morris section and Yankee Stadium.
Several Bronx officials, including Mr. Ferrer and Representative Jose E. Serrano, had lobbied for other areas of the Bronx, including Hunts Point, Mott Haven and Melrose. And while yesterday's announcement at the State Office Building on 125th Street was attended by four City Council members who represent Manhattan, the Bronx delegation was represented by just one member, Adam Clayton Powell 4th, most of whose district is in the East Harlem section of Manhattan.
 
Powell's Objections
 But Mr. Powell, too, said he had troubles with the final outcome. "The Yankees have the richest franchise in the country," Mr. Powell said. "There are poor people in the Bronx who are not going to see the benefit of this that they are entitled to."
Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Rangel defended the boundaries covered in the agreement, saying the empowerment zone would help produce jobs in both Harlem and in the South Bronx. "I think we've achieved a good deal for the South Bronx," Mr. Giuliani said. "What we've achieved for the South Bronx is consistent with the rationale of this empowerment zone. If you were to disperse the benefits much more than we've done, then you would not be able to have the impact that we have had."
Mr. Rangel also defended the inclusion of Yankee Stadium. "The only reason I thought of the Yankees was jobs, to get more people working," he said.
"It just happens to be the Yankees that are the engine of development in the area. If the Yankees left and someone else wanted to use the credits, they could. When we say it's for Yankee Stadium, it's for an entire grid on the map, not just for the stadium."

HEADLINE: The New South Americans: Friends and Partners

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 7

 BODY:
On Rio's bay, two huge Brazilian cannons have been waiting for Argentine warships for decades, monuments to the long enmity between South America's two regional powers. But today the guns are frozen with rust, visited by tourists, many of them Argentines.
Ten years ago, Argentina and Brazil were run by military dictators, who inflated defense budgets and sharpened nationalist tensions. Now, with both countries under civilian rule, they have discovered that former enemies can make good trading partners. 
 The new friendship and economic interplay between the two neighbors are part of a quiet revolution taking hold across a continent long dominated by militarists and protectionists.
Military barriers are coming down, and new webs of free-trade pacts, of highways and waterways and of oil and gas pipelines are rapidly binding South America together as never before. Generals are taking a back seat to free traders.
 
An Invasion by Tourists
 "The countries of South America have become so interdependent that it lessens the possibility of an outbreak -- Brazil against Argentina, or Chile against Argentina," said Jerry Haar, a senior research associate at the North-South Center at the University of Miami.
Today, when Argentine tourists invade Brazilian beach resorts wielding Southern Cone bank machine cards, it is hard to remember that only a few years ago Brazilian engineers designed international road bridges so they would collapse under the weight of an Argentine tank.
In Argentina, as memories fade of 1977 blackout drills against threatened Chilean air raids, engineers push a railroad tunnel, a gas pipeline and an oil pipeline through the Andes. Inaugurated in February, the oil pipeline now supplies half of Chile's petroleum needs.
Reworking foreign policies traditionally oriented toward the United States and France, Latin leaders are discovering that their fastest growing trade is with their neighbors.
"Our trade with Paraguay is now greater than our trade with France," Celso Amorim, Brazil's Foreign Minister, said in an interview. "Our trade with Uruguay is now at the same level as our trade with Britain."
Brazil is negotiating the formation of a South American Free Trade Area, with 1995 to be the starting point. "Following the North American example, we want to abolish tariffs on 80 percent of South America's regional trade over 10 years," Mr. Amorim said:
 
Military Spending Drops
 Greeted favorably by many South American nations, the Brazilian proposal capitalizes on forecasts that most trade within the continent will be duty free by the end of the 1990's. Benefiting from Latin America's opening to outsiders, American business executives have already converted the region into the world's fastest growing market for United States exports.
And it is easy to see how detente is soothing national tensions.
With the advent of civilian rule in the three major countries of the Southern Cone -- Argentina, Brazil and Chile -- annual military spending has dropped by one-quarter, from $4.9 billion in 1985 to $3.7 billion in 1992, according to the International Institute for Strategic Studies.
Since 1990, trade between Argentina and Brazil has more than tripled, hitting $6.3 billion last year and making Brazil Argentina's largest trading partner.
What kind of Argentine ships would Rio's shore guns blow out of Rio's harbor today? Certainly not oil tankers, now that Argentina is Brazil's second-largest source of imported oil after Saudi Arabia. Certainly not freighters loaded with wheat, now that Argentina supplies 75 percent of Brazil's imported wheat.
Regional trade is expected to continue to leap again after Jan. 1, the day that four neighbors -- Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay -- introduce tariff-free trading under a common market known as Mercosul. (In Spanish-speaking countries, the agreement is known as Mercosur.)
"The whole hypothesis of war between Argentina and Brazil has been junked," said Thomas A. O'Keefe, president of Mercosur Consulting Group, a New York business consulting concern. "I don't think that anyone in the Argentine military or in the Brazilian military still sees the other as a potential threat."
In the last century, Brazil and Argentina built their railroads with different track gauges to prevent an enemy invasion by rail. Today, integration is the order of the day.
Brazilian engineers are drawing up plans for a 1,500-mile highway to speed products between Sao Paulo and Buenos Aires. This month, a Washington consulting firm, Louis Berger, started feasibility studies on one link, a $1 billion, 30-mile bridge, joining Buenos Aires and Colonia, Uruguay. In March, the Inter-American Development Bank agreed to finance almost half of a $718 million project to improve road and river links between Argentina and its neighbors.
 
United by Their Rivers
 By the end of this decade, Mercosul nations hope to complete the Hidrovia, a five-nation inland waterway that will allow barges to travel 2,140 miles down the Paraguay and Parana Rivers, from eastern Bolivia to the South Atlantic. By next October, Brazil plans to inaugurate a separate system of river locks that will allow barges to travel 1,500 miles from Paraguay to Sao Paulo.
Spilling over national borders, 200,000 Brazilian farmers now grow most of Paraguay's soy crop. An additional 10,000 Brazilian farmers have moved into eastern Bolivia. Brazilian investment is so heavy in the the thinly populated interior of Uruguay that newspapers predict that Brazilians will own one-quarter of that nation's farmland by the end of the decade.
Nowhere is the improvement in relations in South America clearer than on the Chilean-Argentine border.
In 1977, with generals ensconced in their presidential palaces, the two neighbors came to the brink of war over ownership of islands at South America's southern tip. Ten years of civilian rule in Argentina and five years of it in Chile have reworked the landscape. Since 1991, the year the countries settled 22 border disputes, trade has tripled, and Chilean investment in Argentina has jumped from about $100 million to $2 billion.
 
A Tunnel Through the Andes
 Construction started last year on a 750-mile pipeline to supply Santiago, Chile, with natural gas from Argentina. This year, engineers are to begin studies on the building of a 14-mile electric railroad tunnel through the Andes.
On a smaller level, the regional detente is seen in the relations between Paraguay and Bolivia, which had more than half a century of animosity after Paraguay won the Chaco War of 1932 to 1935.
"Stroessner was wounded in the war, and he kept the animosity going, preventing commerce with Bolivia," Timothy Towell, a former United States Ambassador to Paraguay, recalled of Alfredo Stroessner, a general who ruled Paraguay from 1955 to 1989.
But last May, Juan Carlos Wasmosy, a businessman, was inaugurated as Paraguay's democratically elected civilian President. In September he visited Santa Cruz, Bolivia.
"He met with ancient old war veterans on crutches and returned a bit of war booty, a rusty old Bolivian tank that had been sitting on a plaza in Asuncion," Mr. Towell recalled.
On a return visit to Asuncion last month, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, Bolivia's civilian President, signed agreements calling for the paving of the Trans-Chaco Highway and for the construction of a gas pipeline from Bolivia to Asuncion.
 
A Good Neighbor Policy
 Elsewhere, countries that were once locked in arms races now discover that former enemies can be their best markets.
While many Peruvians nurse grudges with Chile over the loss of territory in the 1879 War of the Pacific, Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, has pursued a good neighbor policy, visiting Santiago five times in the last two years. Chile is now a major investor in Peru's privatization of state companies.
By reducing border tensions with Chile and Ecuador, Mr. Fujimori has been able to divert scarce military dollars away from tanks and jet bombers to counterinsurgency warfare against Shining Path guerrillas.
Colombia and Venezuela, neighbors who competed in arms races in the 1980's, have also discovered the benefits of free trade. After they adopted a tariff-free trade pact in 1991, trade between them tripled, hitting $1.6 billion in 1993.
Border incidents that used to inflame tensions are increasingly muffled. In January, a Venezuelan National Guard helicopter landed inside Colombia and detained several Colombian fishermen. On trying to take off, the overloaded helicopter crashed. Hoping to blame Colombian guerrillas for the crash, another Venezuelan unit machine-gunned the helicopter wreckage from the air.
When the fraud became known, a Venezuelan general granted an interview to Colombian television. He apologized.

HEADLINE: Nottingham Journal;
Who's Merry Now? Sherwood Forest May Be Sold

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NOTTINGHAM, England

 BODY:
There isn't much left of Sherwood Forest, and what there is, Robin Hood would hardly recognize.
Farmland, pasture, coal mines and urban sprawl have claimed most of the trees. Where there is greenwood -- scattered pockets like islands adrift on the dull Midlands plain -- it consists mostly of dense stands of Mediterranean pine, imported and planted by the Government after World War I as a timber cash crop.
Bu 
 t while Sherwood Forest is only a thin wisp of its medieval past, when the thick gnarled oaks and spindly birches offered sanctuary to the bandits and rebellious woodsmen who once harried the Sheriff of Nottingham, its scattered remnants are at the heart of national debate over the future of Britain's public forest lands.
Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Government is contemplating whether to turn over to private investors control of 4,355 square miles of woodland and heath, nearly 5 percent of the nation's land area. The land is now managed by the Forestry Commission, Britain's largest landowner.
Proponents of free-market economics in the Tory Government argue that privatization of Britain's forests, like the earlier privatization of airlines and utilities, would draw fresh investment and help renew the moribund timber industry.
But a coalition of local government officials, conservationists and recreation enthusiasts has mounted a loud campaign, warning that selling these lands would sharply reduce public access to them.
"Now that the coal industry has collapsed, we view our forests as the heart of our county and the key to our future," said Gareth Broome, the forestry officer for Nottinghamshire. "We obviously don't want to see them fall into the hands of private owners more interested in profit than public access."
Few groups are as organized and vocal as Britain's vast army of hill walkers, hikers and bird-watchers, who have a passionate attachment to what is left of the countryside. Walking is ritually listed in surveys as Britons' favorite outdoor activity.
But unlike the national forests and parks of the United States, nearly all of Britain's undeveloped forest, coast and moorland is in the hands of private owners -- landed families, mostly, who have controlled it for centuries.
Government officials insist that no decision has been made on the fate of the forest lands, and have promised to do whatever is necessary to insure public access. But they also concede the land is less marketable if the Government insists on attaching covenants guaranteeing public access.
According to a study published in February by the Ramblers' Association, a hikers' group, nearly 85 percent of the 250,000 acres of Forestry Commission lands sold off to private owners since 1981 has since been closed to the public.
"Robin Hood and his colleagues would rise from the grave if they knew what this wicked Government was doing," said Paddy Tipping, a Labor member of Parliament from Nottingham. Robin Hood and his Merry Men are the legendary 12th-century heroes who lived in Sherwood Forest and robbed rich Normans to help poor Saxons.
Sherwood Forest's fate illustrates Britain's changing perspective toward its forest lands. As Britain became more densely settled, wide areas of Sherwood Forest disappeared to make way for farms and, later, the exploitation of the rich Nottinghamshire coal fields. Now most of the mines have closed, and with thousands of miners out of work local officials are focusing once more on the forest, seeing its scattered remnants as a way to lure tourists.
The Robin Hood legend already draws large numbers of visitors each year to a nature center and 450-acre tract managed by the Nottinghamshire government. The very heart of the old hunting forest, it is now a thinning woodscape of birch, yew and brooding oaks.
Nearly half of the forest that remains in the county is in the hands of the ducal estates. Of the remainder, all but a small part is managed for timber production, consistent with a national policy historically aimed at reducing dependence on imports.
But with domestically produced lumber currently accounting for barely 12 percent of national consumption, the policy has been shifting toward recreation and other uses, said Austin Brody, a Forestry Commission official here.
Mr. Brody leads a program called the Sherwood Initiative, working with local landowners to use vacant land to re-create as much of the original forest as possible, including replanting stands of oak cloned from the remaining ancient trees.
As chain saws echoed across part of the forest recently, with woodsmen harvested pines for a company that makes rustic fences, workmen elsewhere were building a playground and tending roads and bike trails carved through the woods for weekend visitors. Forest managers will organize spring horseback treks, archery contests and guided walks.
"It's not the wonderful old oak forest of Robin Hood's time," Mr. Brody said, standing among the tall Corsican pines, which give the Midlands landscape the look of a Mediterranean hillside. "But it is a forest, and after all, this is Sherwood. So the point is, let's be creative and make the best use we can of all of it."

HEADLINE: Trenton Panel Offers Plan On School Aid

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 7

 BODY:
A special commission named by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today recommended solving New Jersey's nettlesome school financing problems by making all but the very poorest districts pick up substantially more of the costs of running their schools.
The commission's plan would also limit special aid from the state to only that which is essential to bring the poorest districts into closer parity with the richest ones. And richer school districts could not increase their own spending by more than the rate of inflation each year -- a proposal that would put a stringent brake on wage increases for teachers. 
 In another move that is certain to provoke a storm of protest from the state's 589 school districts, the proposal would shift most of the financing of teacher retirement expenses from the state to the local taxpayers. Former Gov. Jim Florio tried a similar move in 1991, so provoking the teachers' union that the Republican legislative majority shifted the pension and Social Security costs, amounting to about $767 million a year, back to the state budget.
 
Cabinet to Evaluate Plan
 Governor Whitman described the report as recommendations, not policy, and said she would turn the report over to her cabinet for evaluation.
"I am neither endorsing this report nor distancing myself from it," she said. At the same time, Mrs. Whitman seemed prepared for the expected complaints from local school boards that the new state rules would force local taxes to rise.
"I object to the basic premise that says that whenever something happens at the state level it necessarily means higher taxes at the local level," she said.
The Governor created her 15-member Education Funding Task Force last December to sort out a school financing system that is under court order to spend more on poor districts, plagued by fierce competition for state aid, and dominated by a politically powerful teachers union that has, in the past, defeated all attempts to shift money from the rich to the poor. Another commission, appointed last year by Mr. Florio with a similar mandate, has been unable to agree on a solution; its leader, Albert Burstein, a former Assemblyman, said today that the Whitman group had come up with a plan similar to the one he favored.
Twelve states, including Connecticut, Texas and California have, like New Jersey, had their school financing policies ruled unconstitutional on the ground of unfairness to poor districts. New York's school aid plan was challenged and upheld in court in 1982, but an appeal by plaintiffs is expected.
Today, the New Jersey School Board's Association reserved judgment on the Whitman commission's plan until its officers had a chance to study it, but officials there made it plain that the recommendations were not welcome ones.
 
Report's Key Points
 "From listening to the presentation it's obvious that the report plans to go in the opposite direction in school funding that we want," said the group's spokesman, Frank Belluscio 3d. "On the pension costs, we are opposed to local districts absorbing what amounts to a state mandate. At a time when the state is talking about controlling mandated expenses, we find giving the districts a new one is no way to ask districts to control costs."
These are the commission's key recommendations:
*School districts would be required to spend a minimum of $6,750 per pupil in elementary schools, $7,425 in middle schools, and $8,438 in high schools. The state would continue to pay 37 of 41 percent of this amount, as it does now, and local school systems could spend more if they wished.
*Increases in school aid would be limited to the amount of increase in state per capita income, while increases in local spending would be capped at the rate of inflation.
*State aid to the state's 37 poorest districts, the ones at the heart of the case that went to the New Jersey Supreme Court, would be increased by 10 percent a district a year until each district had reached 80 percent of the average per pupil spending of the wealthiest districts, or about $8,000.
A former state education commissioner, Saul Cooperman, and Sam Thompson, an education consultant, who headed the 15-member commission, said the group believed the 80 percent rule would satisfy the court's ruling that poor districts must achieve "substantial parity" with rich districts for the state financing system to be deemed constitutional.
The Florio group that has failed in two public votes to agree on a plan has one significant difference from the Whitman panel: among its members is the president of the teachers union, while Mrs. Whitman's commission included no union partisans.
Under the group's proposal, the state would shift all Social Security costs and half of the pension costs to the school districts over four years. During the current school year, pension and annuity costs amount to $375 million, while Social Security costs run at $392 million annually.
Because pension costs are tied to wage levels, the members of the New Jersey Teacher's Association, the teachers union, would face much tougher resistance to wage increases if local districts were required to shoulder pension and Social Security expenses.
"We are opposed to any proposal to shift pension and Social Security costs to the local districts," said a spokeswoman for the union, Karen Joseph. "That is a state responsibility since 1955, and all that will do is raise local property taxes. It is unacceptable."
The Cooperman and Burstein school financing commissions have their roots in a 1990 state Supreme Court ruling, Abbott v. Burke, that held a state financing mechanism relying on local property wealth as its tax base violated the state constitution by depriving cash-poor districts equal financing with the rich ones.
Mr. Florio tried to bridge the gap by shifting some $380 million in state aid from rich to poor districts, to be paid for in part by local districts assuming their teachers' pension costs. Known as the Quality Education Act, the Florio plan was watered down by the legislature until no rich-to-poor shift took place.
An important question about today's recommendations is whether the state courts will accept the commission's view that bringing poor districts to within 80 percent of rich ones meets the state Supreme Court's definition of "substantial parity."
Governor Whitman, for one, was not prepared to say that the court would accept that view, or even that she would argue it.
"The arguments before the court are going to go forward on their own, and they are not going to be contingent on this recommendation," she said today. "This is a report, a recommendation to the administration, and it is yet to be studied and we have have yet to adopt parts of it, or all of it, or however we want to modify it, before we go before the legislature."
Besides Dr. Cooperman and Dr. Thompson, the commissions members were: Barbara Wright Bell, President of the Amelior Foundation; Richard DiPatri, vice president of Educate America, a consulting group; John Klagholz, a member of the state Board of Education; David Rand, a school board lawyer; Robert Swissler, a former assistant education commissioner for finance; George Gilmore, the commission's counsel; Marie Parnell, superintendent of the Sayreville public schools; Peter Contini, Gloucester County schools superintendent; David Warner, Red Bank schools superintendent; Carol Choye, Scotch Plains superintendent; Elsa Gomez, president of Kean College; Harold J. Raveche, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology, and Joanne Kenny, a teacher in Jersey City schools.

(Laura Pedrick for The New York Times) (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: Word of Plans for Additional Tax Cuts Puts Albany Lobbyists in a Frenzy

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 7

 BODY:
With a proposal to cut $400 million in taxes on the budget negotiating table, but no decision on which taxes to cut, the State Capitol was filled today with furious lobbying by companies large and small seeking reductions for their industries.
Lobbyists for soda and beer companies stalked the corridors, brief cases brimming with memorandums on how to cut beverage taxes. The New York State Home Builders Association rousted its 4,000 members to call lawmakers with a proposal to reduce real-estate-gains taxes. Securities companies in Manhattan launched fax machine assaults with proposals for a tax credit worth $30 million to their industry. Industrial giants like Eastman Kodak, I.B.M. and General Electric pressed for arcane tax code changes as valuable as they were oddly named: double-weighted sales, NOLs and the AMT. 
 "It's a feeding frenzy for people who pay business taxes," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat who says he is pigeonholed six times daily by business lobbyists peddling pet cuts. "Name an industry, and they've been to see me. I've never seen it like this before."
What has churned the Capitol's waters into such froth is the slowly improving economy and an agreement by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders to cut taxes by at least $400 million in the coming fiscal year as part of a $33.4 billion budget that is now a week late.
 
Little Movement in Talks
 Despite their general agreement on how much to cut, Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders have each advanced competing tax-cut proposals, and for the last week there has been little movement in closed-door talks over what to select from the long and growing menus.
The relatively small amount of money for cuts has made the work of lobbyists more urgent as they hustle the hallways trying to push their cuts to the top of the list. But the confusion at the negotiating table has spelled opportunity for late comers.
"Normally this would be kind of late for lobbyists to jump in," said Assemblyman Joseph Crowley, a Queens Democrat who received three phone calls from business lobbyists on Wednesday. "But they smell something and want to get a piece of it."
While lobbyists pushed for new or deeper cuts, welfare advocates, labor unions and a growing number of lawmakers raised concerns that the $400 million tax-cut package, while perhaps affordable this fiscal year, could cost the state between $1 billion and $2 billion in future years as phased-in reductions took affect.
They warned of parallels between 1994 and 1987, when the Legislature approved deep cuts in personal income and business taxes during a flush period, only to postpone the cuts later because of the recession and a steep decline in tax revenues that caused severe budget deficits.
"In 1987 we were falling over each other to see who could top who in how fast and how deep we cut taxes," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat. "In our desire to one up the other party, we passed tax cuts than we could afford."
When he introduced his budget in January, Mr. Cuomo proposed a package of tax cuts that would cost $210 million in the fiscal year that began on April 1, with the cost growing to $710 million by 1998. Mr. Cuomo's plan includes reducing the corporate surcharge, phasing out the state hotel tax, creating a tax credit on operating losses and giving working poor families a credit on income taxes.
Mr. Cuomo said today that he could not project the long-term impact of a $400 million tax cut because there has been no agreement on which taxes to reduce. He said he would oppose any tax cuts that would jeopardize future budgets. But when asked how he would know what those cuts are, he invoked a former Supreme Court Justice: "It's like Potter Stewart's definition of obscenity. You know it when you see it."
The Republicans who control the State Senate have pushed a plan costing $703 million this year which builds on Mr. Cuomo's proposals, deepening or speeding up some of his cuts while adding others to the mix.
Democratic lawmakers have projected that the Senate plan could cost as much as $1.8 billion by 1997. To make up for that revenue loss, the state's economy would have to grow by a robust 8 percent a year, a rate the Democrats called improbable.
But the Republicans, who have not said publicly what their plan would cost in future years, argued that the Democrats failed to calculate the economic growth and improved tax receipts resulting from the tax cuts. They said the impact of their plan could be lessened by spreading their cuts over many years.
"Pick a number; if you are against tax cuts, you can make the cost as high as you want," said John A. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I. "But it can be structured so we do not find ourselves in a difficult situation."
The Democrats who control the Assembly have also pressed for tax cuts for small businesses and working poor families that would cost about $200 million this year and at least $350 million in 1995.
Some critics of the business tax cuts say they are pinpointed for specific industries, and in some cases for specific companies. "You have a coalition of special interests pushing an agenda against a tax cut of more general scope," said Mr. Brodsky, who has advocated cutting property taxes for the middle class.
One proposal by Mr. Cuomo and the Senate would benefit companies that own much property and have many employees in New York State, but sell most of their products elsewhere. Eastman Kodak, Bausch & Lomb and Finch, Pruyn & Company, a forest products company, have been among the most active lobbyists for that change, lawmakers said.
Another Cuomo proposal to give retroactive tax credits for operating losses would largely benefit securities firms. And a Senate proposal to extend the life of investment tax credits from 7 to 15 years has been strongly pushed by I.B.M., which holds a large number of those credits.

HEADLINE: U.S. Gains Trade Forum For Labor-Equity Issues

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 7

 BODY:
Sidestepping opposition from some developing nations, the United States won approval today for labor-related issues to be taken up by the new World Trade Organization that will be created when a global trade-liberalization package is formally signed on April 15.
The deal worked out today at the headquarters of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva averted the threat of embarrassing public disputes when ministers from 121 nations gather in Marrakesh, Morocco, next week to complete the so-called Uruguay Round of trade-liberalization talks. 
 Agreement on the broad outlines of the trade agreement was reached in December after seven years of difficult negotiations, but several developing countries complained bitterly that the United States was raising new issues when it proposed future debate of labor questions.
 
A New Protectionism?
 These nations, led by India and Singapore, charge that Washington is trying to set the stage for a new form of nontariff protectionism against low-wage exporting countries where workers do not enjoy the same rights and working conditions as those in the industrial world.
The United States insists that it is not motivated by a desire to blunt the trade advantage of low-wage economies, and it has been backed by France, which has frequently complained about unfair competition from third-world countries that offer their workers minimal social rights.
The dispute has focused in recent weeks on preparations for the agenda of the World Trade Organization that is to replace GATT next year. The United States is eager for the new body to be authorized so that it can discuss the relationship between trade and "internationally recognized labor standards."
As a step toward that, the American delegation sought to include a reference to labor questions in a ministerial declaration that will be issued after the Uruguay Round agreement is signed next week.
 
Viable Compromise
 Fearing that the Marrakesh meeting would be overshadowed by a dispute between industrial and developing countries, instead of celebrating the biggest trade-liberalization package to date, GATT's Director General, Peter Sutherland, scrambled this week to find the compromise reached today.
Now, labor will not be mentioned in the ministers' declaration, but the chairman of the Marrakesh meeting, Foreign Minister Sergio Abreu Bonilla of Uruguay, will take note in his final statement of the "importance" some countries give to examination of links between trade and "internationally recognized labor standards."
It was agreed, as well, that "additional items" could be suggested for inclusion in the World Trade Organization's work program, a formula that will permit discussion of labor and other trade-related issues.
Although the United States gave some ground, John Schmidt, the head of the American delegation in Geneva, said, "We got what we regarded as our basic objective -- explicit acceptance that this issue will be discussed" by the World Trade Organization. Andrew Stoler, another American delegate, added, "We're very pleased with the outcome."
 
Third-World Forum
 Yet, substantive debate about international labor standards may be far away. Like GATT, the new global trade body will make all its decisions by consensus. Developing countries will be well placed to block any moves to weaken their wage advantages in trade.
The World Trade Organization will nonetheless have a broader mandate than GATT. It has already been agreed that it will discuss the environmental effects of trade. Japan has also signaled that it will raise trade and national-security concerns, so-called juridical protectionism and regional trade arrangements.
Expressing relief over today's compromise, Mr. Sutherland told a news conference in Geneva that "everything ended in harmony, " adding, "Had we started in Marrakesh on a rancorous basis, it would not have been a good signal for the start of the new organization."
He also hinted that contrary to expectations, he might not become the first head of the World Trade Organization. A former Irish Attorney General who took over the GATT post only last summer, he said he was "not prepared to express any long-term commitment to being an international civil servant."

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 13.53 Points in Subdued Trading

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks ended higher yesterday, moving from early losses to their strongest point at the close of the session. Trading was subdued after a huge gain on Tuesday and mixed results on Wednesday.
The absence of any anti-inflationary signs from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, along with a moderate advance in the Treasury market, helped to buoy the stock market. So did the release of better-than-expected retail sales for March, a day after auto makers announced strong sales for the month. Both are significant signs of strength in the consumer sector of the economy. 
 "It's still too early to tell if the market is back in a normal trading pattern," said Alan Ackerman, executive vice president of Reich & Company, "although there was less volatility throughout the day and many players were waiting for the dust to settle."
 
 
Yesterday Was 'a Pit Stop'
 "For the moment, the wild ride has calmed down to a bit more than a pit stop," he said.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down more than 21 points at midmorning, closed at 3,693.26, up 13.53 points. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.83 points, to 450.88, and the broader Nasdaq composite index gained 4.45 points, to 755.17.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 289.3 million shares, down slightly from 302 million shares on Wednesday. Advancing issues outnumbered declining issues, 1,370 to 761.
Mr. Greenspan, in a speech in San Francisco yesterday, did not specifically refer to interest rates, which led many traders to conclude that an increase in short-term rates might not be on the horizon. By the end of the day, the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond had eased to 7.21 percent, from 7.24 percent on Wednesday.
 
 
Strong Gains by Retailers
 Robust sales numbers were responsible for pushing up the stocks of big retailers. Wal-Mart Stores rose 3/4, to 26 5/8; Kmart gained 3/8, to 18 3/8; Dillard Department Stores jumped 2 1/4, to 35 3/4, and the Gap rose 2 1/4, to 49.
Stocks of some of the large banking companies -- particularly those based in California, where the lagging economy may be strengthening -- also advanced. Wells Fargo rose 3, to 146 1/2; BankAmerica jumped 1 1/2, to 41 3/8, and First Interstate gained 1 1/4, to 79 5/8.
Bargain-hunting helped selected technology stocks, market analysts said. Intel rose 1, to 70 5/8, and Motorola gained 1/4, to 106 5/8.
Telefonos de Mexico was the most active issue on the Big Board. Its American depository receipts rose 1/2, to 59 3/8, a move analysts attributed to an easing of the political tension in Mexico.
General Motors gained 1 3/8, to 60 1/8, on a positive outlook for the company's sales.
 
 
Cyclical Stocks Turn Down
 Some cyclical stocks, which rise and fall on economic expectations, were lower yesterday. Caterpillar dropped 1 1/2, to 118 1/2; Reynolds Metals fell 1 1/4, to 46 7/8, and International Paper declined 1, to 66 1/8.
Shares of the Software Publishing Corporation, which said on Wednesday that it would take a restructuring charge and cut its work force in half, were down 1, to 6 1/8. Great Lakes Aviation tumbled 3 1/4, to 8 5/8, on a lower first-quarter earnings estimate by Piper Jaffray. And Molecular Dynamics plunged 3 7/8, to 6 1/8, after it said it expected a loss for the first quarter and results for 1994 that would be well below expectations.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
In big-city schoolyards, basketball backboards may become billboards.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A COMPANY that specializes in outdoor advertising is seeking to bring advertising to a new outdoor venue: basketball backboards in schoolyards.
Van Wagner Communications, best known for producing the extravagant electric billboards in Times Square, is proposing to create a National Backboard Network in the playgrounds of public schools in 11 big cities, including Boston, Dallas, New York, Philadelphia and Washington. 
 Advertisers would pay a new Van Wagner division, Van Wagner Playground Programs, $187,500 to $375,000 a year to remove thousands of dilapidated, damaged backboards and replace them with new ones designed to better withstand the punishment meted out by young athletes and neighborhood vandals.
Van Wagner would also make maintenance calls every three months, handling tasks like removing graffiti, and provide emergency service to deal with problems like missing nets. Above the rim of each backboard would be a motivational public service message like "Stay in school" or "Say no to drugs."
"What initiated the concept was that backboards, for the most part, haven't been repaired or replaced in 20 years, simply because the schools have no money," said Jason Perline, chairman of Van Wagner in New York.
"There often are no rims, no backboards and sometimes no poles," he added. "The kids have had to fend for themselves." Prototypes -- about 125 new backboards -- have been installed by Van Wagner in 53 schoolyards in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Manhattan and Queens.
The proposed network represents a novel blend of two hot trends in consumer marketing. One is called place-based media, which involves introducing ads at sites where they have never appeared: doctors' waiting rooms, supermarket checkouts, airport baggage claim areas, restrooms. There is even a company, Stopwatch Entertainment, that provides electronics retailers like Circuit City with laser disks that mix programming and commercials, to be played on the television sets displayed in their stores.
The Van Wagner network would also be an example of cause-related marketing, in which corporations link themselves with social and political issues to curry favor with consumers. The most popular method is to help offer solutions to vexatious problems, from homelessness and AIDS to hunger and child abuse.
In seeking to do well by doing good, marketers' motivations are, of course, not solely philanthropic. Under the Van Wagner proposal, participating advertisers would get to turn small spaces in the upper left corners of the backboards into mini-billboards featuring their corporate logos under a "Donated by" tag. Because no advertisers have been signed, the prototypes bear the logo of the backboard network.
"It's a unique way to provide a message in a schoolyard and do something civic minded for the community as well," said Richard M. Schaps, president of Van Wagner.
For all its altruistic aspects, the idea raises the hackles of critics of the growing commercialization and commoditization of the nation's schools. No longer is the corporate intrusion into the classroom confined to food companies donating study guides to home economics classes that just happen to feature recipes requiring their name-brand products as ingredients. In the last decade, the role of corporations has broadened into previously sacrosanct realms like sponsoring curriculums.
For instance, the Eastman Kodak Company and the KmartCorporation announced last month "It's a Snap!," a curriculum for second graders that a news release said used cameras "to teach a quarter-million children about their environment and the art of photography."
The most castigated purveyor of sponsored communications aimed at students is Whittle Communications, which produces "Channel One," a news program interrupted by commercials, and has been a lightning rod for rancorous debate.
"What we object to is holding kids captive in a classroom and mandating they watch a program where commercials are an integral part," said Lyle Hamilton, manager of broadcast services in Washington for the National Education Association, the biggest teachers' union. "The purpose of classrooms is to promote ideas, not products."
Michael Jacobson, the co-founder of the Center for the Study of Commercialism, an activist organization in Washington, said the Van Wagner proposal "is certainly different from 'Channel One' because it doesn't have that compulsion." Still, he added, it represented "a continuation of a trend in which public property is privatized."
"It's really sad our playgrounds are now fair game," he added. "Ideally, corporations and wealthy individuals would be taxed so cities and park systems had adequate resources rather than relying on the whims of advertisers."
Van Wagner executives said they were sensitive to the concerns about their sponsored backboards.
The goal was for "the good to greatly outweigh any negative interpretations," said Tom Turner, the account manager. He said there would be limits on the number of advertisers and a ban on product categories like alcoholic beverages and cigarettes. Ads would also be restricted to 360 square inches of a backboard's total of 3,024 square inches.
Mr. Jacobson chuckled when told about that last stipulation. "I'm shocked by their restraint in not covering the entire backboard with the corporate logo," he said.
Mr. Hamilton said he was not sure whether his organization would object to the Van Wagner network, because it would be outside, not inside, the classroom.
"Even if it had the sponsor's motto on there, I don't even think we'd object to that," he added. "Where we part company is when they present advocacy messages, purchasing-type messages, to the children."
Among the companies the Van Wagner executives said they had contacted about possible participation are Consolidated Edison; MTV; Nobody Beats the Wiz, the electronics retailer, and Starter, which sells athletic apparel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Speculation That Rates Will Rise Again

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against several leading currencies yesterday amid speculation in the currency markets that American interest rates were likely to rise again soon.
"The dollar was itching to go higher before today's rumors about a rate increase," said Amy Smith, a currency market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm. With robust economic growth in the United States, the dollar should be stronger, she said. 
 But Ms. Smith and other analysts do not expect the Federal Reserve to push up short-term rates before its next policy meeting next month. The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, did not provide clues about the central bank's next step in a San Francisco speech yesterday that was the focus of the markets' speculation.
 
Dollar vs. Mark and Yen
 The dollar fell from the day's highs as talk of an increase in interest rates gave way to concern about reports showing growth in Germany's economy. Traders speculated that the Bundesbank would not have to cut interest rates as much as expected to spur German growth. German interest rates are more than two percentage points higher than American rates, making mark-denominated investments more attractive to investors than dollar-denominated ones.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7170 German marks yesterday from 1.7105 marks on Wednesday. It also rose to 104.95 Japanese yen from 104.55 yen.
Some traders bought dollars early yesterday on the expectation that Mr. Greenspan would disclose an increase in interest rates. The Fed has pushed up the Federal funds rate twice this year, to 3.5 percent from 3 percent. The rate is what banks charge each other for overnight loans.
Concern about strong economic growth in Germany kept the dollar from moving higher, traders said. "Things in Germany are looking up," said Albert Soria, foreign-exchange manager at Kansallis Osake Pankki. "The Deutsche mark appears to be a reliable bet right now."
The dollar held onto its gains against the yen, meantime, amid lingering concerns about the political troubles of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan.
"Some people in the market think they can take the dollar higher against the yen anticipating Hosokawa's resignation," said Gary Sakamoto, vice president at National Westminster Bank P.L.C. "I have a feeling Hosokawa will be O.K."
The British pound rose to $1.4740 in New York yesterday from $1.4680 on Wednesday. And the Canadian dollar rose to 72.25 United States cents yesterday from 72.14 cents.
