HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Related by Money
A bit of nail biting is going on behind the scenes at art galleries and auction houses. Will the recent volatility in the financial markets and uncertainty about interest rates hurt the big New York auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art that are less than a month away?
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed yesterday at close to what it was during the week of the Impressionist and modern art sales in November. But financial experts say the mood now is different than it was then: a lot of the optimism has evaporated. 
 "It makes sense that people are nervous," said Robert S. Salomon Jr., the chairman and chief executive officer of Salomon Brothers Asset Management in New York City. "All the major markets of the world are under strain; there's a lot of political instability in the world. I would be surprised if this had no impact on the art market."
Traditionally, Mr. Salomon said, the cycles of the art market have reflected wealth as it moves around the world. "In the 70's, oil wealth dominated the art world; in the 80's it was led by the Japanese," he said. "Then it moved to the United States. At this juncture the question is, where is the wealth being created?"
David Nash, Sotheby's worldwide director of Impressionist and modern art, said: "The way the world works, things will balance each other out. People like Michael Steinhardt probably won't be buying art this spring. On the other hand, there are a lot of people who have realized substantial profits in the stock market. It's going to be hard to tell who's pulling in their horns and who will be spending money." Mr. Steinhardt is the prominent New York investment manager whose clients lost $1 billion of their $4.9 billion in investments in the first quarter of this year.
Robert Mnuchin, a retired partner of the Goldman, Sachs investment house, who in January opened his own Manhattan gallery, C&M Arts, said, "There may be a little caution, but it shouldn't have a significant impact on prices."
Historically, the art market has lagged behind the stock market by six months to a year, but many art experts say that what's happening on Wall Street now is simply a correction and that it won't affect buyers' confidence in art. "The key is how the economy is doing as a whole, not just the stock market, and I think the signs are good," said David Tyler, the president of Christie's in New York. "We're seeing more people prepared to spend money in art than there were three years ago."
Stephen Mazoh, a Manhattan art dealer, suggested, that "art is a good vehicle to ride the wave of inflation," but other dealers, like Brooke Alexander in SoHo, have a more cautious attitude. "The point is that the art market has been showing definite signs of recovery recently," he said, "and what's happening on Wall Street has made people nervous that this recovery will falter."
 
Museum and School
 After more than a year and a half of negotiations, the three-year-old Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center in the Westwood section of Los Angeles has agreed to be managed by the University of California at Los Angeles.
Under a 99-year agreement, the school will operate the museum with money from the museum's bond portfolio and from the operating budgets for the university's Wight Art Gallery and Grunwald Center for the Graphic Arts, both of which will move into the Hammer building.
The museum's $60 million building was paid for by Dr. Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation until his death in 1990. Occidental provided the museum with a $35 million endowment.
The museum has had problems from the start. It ran out of money before it opened, leaving the building's auditorium unfinished. The original staff had little museum experience. When plans for the museum were unveiled in 1988, Dr. Hammer was accused of reneging on a promise to donate his art collection to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. And Occidental's shareholders unsuccessfully sued Dr. Hammer, charging the corporation had spent $95 million on his private project.
In 1990, after Dr. Hammer died, Joan Weiss, the niece and sole heir of Frances Hammer, Dr. Hammer's wife, who died in 1989, challenged the museum's ownership of its art collection. The collection consists of about 100 Old Master, 19th- and 20th-century works, estimated to be worth $450 million at the height of the art market. Ms. Weiss's lawsuit is pending, said Henry Hopkins, the museum's director. "We're setting aside a certain portion of the permanent collection in escrow," he said, "until it is settled."
Mr. Hopkins, the chairman of U.C.L.A.'s art department and a former director of the Wight Gallery, became director of the Hammer Museum under the agreement. David Rodes will continue as the director of the Grunwald Center, whose charter requires that it have its own director.
But the merger is not only administrative. It puts several art collections under one roof: the museum's original collection will be joined by works owned by the school, including a Matisse collage, and 35,000 works on paper from the Gunwald Center.
And Mr. Hopkins has been planning exhibitions. The first, "Selections From the Eli Broad Family Foundation Collection in Los Angeles," opens on June 7 and runs through Oct. 9.
 
Like Museum
 Occasionally an auction house can function not simply as a commercial venue but also as a kind of museum, a place to give the public an opportunity to see historically significant work.
When the Impressionist and modern paintings to be auctioned next month in New York go on view at Sotheby's, the auction house will also show several works to be offered in London in June. Among them will be Manet's "Bar at the Folies-Bergere" from 1881. It is the first version of the famous painting, now at the Courtauld Institute Galleries in London, which depicts a man's conversation with a barmaid against a background of spectators reflected in a mirror.
The composition of the earlier version, which is being sold by a descendant of Franz Koenigs, the German investment banker, can be seen beneath the surface in an X-ray of the Courtauld's painting. "There are differences," said Melaine Clore, head of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's in London. "The woman is looking at a different angle and the size of the man is different. He used this painting as a starting point."
Sotheby's estimates the painting will sell for $4.5 million at the June 28 auction. It will be on view at Sotheby's in New York from May 7 through 11.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MOLECULAR DYNAMICS STOCK REACHES A LOW

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The stock of Molecular Dynamics Inc. fell 38 percent and hit its lowest level ever yesterday after the company said late Wednesday that it expected to report a "substantial" first-quarter loss. The company's stock was down $3.875, to $6.125, in Nasdaq trading. Molecular Dynamics, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., also reported a 20 percent drop in revenue from the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The company said it expected its poor first-quarter results to carry over to the second quarter. The maker of instruments for life-science research attributed the weak forecast to economic weakness in Europe and the Pacific Rim and spending cuts in the United States pharmaceutical market linked to proposed health care changes.

HEADLINE: No Economic Index

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Law as the Free Market's Rogue" (Law page, March 25) addresses the effects of law on the economy, but does not note the burgeoning empirical evidence on the issue. The one study you cite is four years old. The two most recent major articles (by Charles Epp of the University of Wisconsin and by myself) identify errors in previous research and present studies showing there is no association between the number of lawyers and economic growth. 
 One may believe the European "inquisitorial" trial system is more efficient, but where are the data? Then, too, economists get caught up in economic efficiency to the detriment of all other ends. There is considerable evidence that law, lawyers and litigation promote individual liberties, civil rights and other social objectives that might even be worth a slight loss of share value.
 
FRANK CROSS
Assoc. Prof. of Business Regulation
University of Texas
Austin, March 30, 1994

HEADLINE: Islamic Banking: Faith and Creativity

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN 

 BODY:
Dr. Ala-ud-Din, a dentist in San Jose, Calif., had two choices: save for years to buy a house with cash, or take out a mortgage and violate the law of the Koran.
That was until a third choice emerged. A small Islamic financing company bought the house and leased it back to Dr. Din in a 15-year deal that made him a homeowner without violating the religious law that bans Muslims from paying or earning interest. 
 While still on the far edge of American finance, Islamic banking is making inroads as several groups of bankers and Muslim scholars work to create an interest-free banking system that relies on lease agreements, mutual funds and other methods to avoid paying interest. And a new emphasis by lenders on improving service to minorities, including black, Arab and Asian Muslims, may be the key to their success.
"I wouldn't say that this is a major part of American finance, but it's definitely growing," said Nicholas Kaiser, the president of the Saturna Capital Corporation of Bellingham, Wash., which manages two mutual funds that follow Islamic law.
 
 
Lease Deals Instead of Loans
 At least six Islamic financial companies, in areas with large Muslim populations like Los Angeles, Detroit and New York, are offering mortgages and investment opportunities that comply with Islamic law.
Muslims are not allowed to pay or receive interest because the body of law of the Koran, called sharia, prohibits them from making a guaranteed profit on capital. Investors can get around the ban by making investments that involve risk, like stocks, or by carrying out lease deals rather than loans for homes and cars.
"Most of the Muslims who practice Islam would not buy houses with interest-based mortgages," said Dr. Din, who is from Pakistan.
The good news for the country's Muslims, who number three million to four million, is happening on several fronts. One group of Muslim experts is trying to put together a mortgage that complies with sharia. Others are refining lease agreements to bring them into compliance with Islam while making the agreements more palatable for lenders. And, coincidentally, car companies have embraced leasing, allowing Muslims to avoid the ethical problem of car loans.
But as Islamic banking becomes more common, some specialists warn that there is a risk that small investors will be duped by hustlers claiming to offer Islamic financial services. "You cannot invest money on faith alone, that's a very bad investment," said Vincent J. Cornell, a professor of religion at Duke University who studied Islamic banking in Malaysia.
Experts in Islamic finance say that what they propose varies only slightly from conventional banking. "The irony is that it doesn't take a lot of work, it takes creativity to convert a conventional home mortgage to a deferred payment sale" that complies with Islamic law, said Steven Thomas, the publisher of The American Journal of Islamic Finance.
Mr. Thomas, who works for a bank, has tried to use the newsletter to educate Muslims on the requirements of Islamic banking and show that it can be done in the United States. "Islamic finance is just another form of asset-based investment banking," he said.
In its most basic form, Islamic banking covers both savings and credit. Instead of being paid interest, depositors are considered shareholders and receive dividends when the bank turns a profit and lose money when it has a loss.
The Amana mutual funds, which Mr. Kaiser runs, work this way. Amana's income fund began in June 1986 and has between 1,200 and 1,300 shareholders and total assets of $11 million. Amana has relied on word of mouth among Muslim Americans to attract new investors. Its income fund has kept pace with the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, Mr. Kaiser said.
But managing the income fund is not easy. The prohibition on interest prevents investing in bonds, as well as in shares of companies that make money on interest, like banks. This makes the fund an equity fund by default.
The income fund also does not invest in companies that make or sell liquor or have gambling operations, as well as some movie studios, following the Muslim laws against drinking, gambling and pornography. The fund's advisers recently decided to stop investing in preferred stocks because dividend payments were too regular, and now puts money only in common stock.
 
 
Principles Before Performance
 "It does probably hurt the performance a little bit," Mr. Kaiser said. "Banking stocks have been a good place to be for the last few years."
Such a fund, he adds, "may not be the world's greatest investment, but it does what it says it's going to do."
On the debt side of finance, Islamic banks concentrate mainly on leasing deals. For example, a bank buys a house and leases it for 30 years to a customer, who then takes ownership. The lease payments would total more than the bank paid for the house, but that is not considered interest.
"From the Islamic point of view, if I used your asset from my benefit, you could have used it for another benefit, so I owe you," Mr. Thomas said.
The effort to construct an Islamic mortgage that is acceptable to major lenders as well as to the Internal Revenue Service is one of the most dynamic areas of Islamic finance. It comes at a time when banks are struggling to meet requirements that they lend more money to inner-city areas and minorities and when more and more Muslims command economic influence.
 
 
Banks Are Interested
 "Profitability makes banks interested," Mr. Thomas said. "There's a huge understanding that vanilla fudge mortgages are a volume business, so you have to have access to minority and niche markets." He said that a group of Muslim experts had held discussions with major lenders and that several expressed interest in the group's plan, which is scheduled for release at the end of this month.
Few lending organizations know much about Islamic banking, but they are interested. "That's the type of thing that we search out," said Julie Gould, vice president for community lending for the Federal National Mortgage Association in Washington, known as Fannie Mae. She said Fannie Mae had handled lease arrangements before and would be interested in working with Muslims as part of the association's push to better serve minorities.
Typical of the small companies in the United and Canada lending to Muslims is the MSI Finance Corporation of Los Angeles, which has arranged 25 mortgages around the country -- including Dr. Din's -- and many more car and equipment leases, said Gulz B. Joya, the company's general manager.
MSI's home leases work like this: The buyer puts down about 20 percent and MSI covers the rest in a partnership agreement. The buyer, called the resident owner, pays rent on the value of the property that MSI owns, plus a little more to increase equity.
 
 
Home's Value Reassessed
 One important difference is that the home's value is reassessed every year. If the real estate market is hot, the resident owner may feel like he or she is walking up a down escalator, paying every month while owning less and less of the house, even though the value of the resident's equity remains the same, because the house is worth more. The risk goes both ways, of course, and the California real estate slump has hurt MSI, Mr. Joya said.
Critics of Islamic banking see two problems. First, they say the banks are far from interest-free but use "interest under a different name," said Timur Kuran, an economics professor at the University of Southern California. The Muslim fundamentalist movement, he said, has helped accelerate the growth in Islamic banks, which now operate in about 50 countries.
 Others see a high potential for fraud and point to the dramatic failure of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International in July 1991. Even though B.C.C.I., which had Arab and Pakistani links, was not an Islamic bank, many Islamic banks made deposits in it, and thousands of people who had invested in Islamic banks lost their savings as a result.
"Because you are taking yourself out of the mainstream, there is relatively higher risk that you will be taken advantage of, and that was one of the things that happened with B.C.C.I.," said Jonathan M. Winer, who was the chief Senate investigator on the B.C.C.I. scandal.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Unable to take out a mortgage because religious law prohibits Muslims from paying interest, an Islamic financing company is offering to buy property and then lease it. With this service, Dr. Ala-ud-Din was able to settle in San Jose, Calif. He enjoyed his new home with his daughters. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times) (pg. D6)
 
Chart: "Buying a House Without Interest"
 Muslims who follow Islamic law are forbidden to pay or earn interest. MCI Finance Corporation in Los Angeles Developed a lease acceptable to Islamic law and has made 25 mortgages around the country in the last five years. Here's how the lease works.
 
For a house that costs $200,000, a buyer puts down $40,000 or 20 percent. In a partnership agreement, MSI Finance puts up the remaining $160,000 and leases its portion of the house to the buyer.
 
The buyer, called the resident owner, pays rent based on the portion of the home that the finance company owns plus a little more to increase equity. As the portion of the home that MSI owns decreases the resident owner's equity increases (as it does with a standard mortgage).
 
The home's value is reassessed every year and rental payments are adjusted accordingly. If the real estate market is doing well, the resident owner's rent will increase. Although he loses no money invested, his equity will be diluted. If the home's value falls, so do rent payments, cutting into MSI's income.
 
If the resident owner defaults on the deal and MSI sells the house, the owner does not lose his equity, as could happen with a conventional mortgage. MSI and the owner split the proceeds, depending on the percentage each owns of the house.

HEADLINE: A Defense By Banker

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gustavo Gomez Lopez, the man at the center of the collapse of Banco Latino C.A. of Venezuela, emerged in New York yesterday to deny the Venezuelan Government's accusations of fraud.
He had disappeared almost three months ago after the Government shut down Banco Latino, Venezuela's second-largest bank, after a run by depositors. 
 The Government subsequently accused Mr. Gomez, who was a former president of Banco Latino, and other bank officials of embezzlement, falsifying balance sheets and other fraud charges in connection with losses estimated at $1.4 billion.
Mr. Gomez said in an interview yesterday in New York that he fled Venezuela the day after the bank was shut down on Jan. 13. He said the bank's failure was caused by politics.
"Instead of treating the collapse as a crisis," Mr. Gomez said, "the Government has turned it into a criminal scandal."
Mr. Gomez, 43, said Government officials were seeking "political revenge" because of Banco Latino's political alliances.
Mr. Gomez acknowledged that Banco Latino was crippled by the high interest rates it paid, its money-losing equity investments, the run on deposits and its inflated balance sheets. But these practices were no worse than those of other banks, he said.
He accused unnamed Government officials of floating rumors of the bank's shaky financial situation and starting the run by depositors.
Government banking officials could not be reached for comment yesterday.
The Government has attributed the bank's failure to corruption, falsified books and a reckless acquisition binge in the late 1980's that earned Mr. Gomez the nickname "Pac Man," after the video game character that gobbled up all he could reach.

HEADLINE: Long Bond Price Dips; Yield 7.25%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates rose yesterday as the bond market began to brace for two important reports on its growing obsession: inflation.
The market had started the week in turmoil as it focused on almost every hint of potential inflationary pressures -- and possible moves by the Federal Reserve to eliminate them by pushing up interest rates. 
 After calming a bit, investors and traders began to turn their attention to the Government's report on March producer prices on Tuesday, followed by the consumer prices report on Wednesday.
Yesterday, prices of Government securities were down across the board, while yields, which move in the opposite direction, headed higher. The Treasury's 30-year bond fell 17/32 , to 8728/32 , with its yield rising to 7.25 percent, from 7.21 percent on Thursday, after trading as high as 7.29 percent during the day.
The selloff in the bond market put pressure on stocks, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 19 points, to 3,674.26. [Page 38.]
 
A Tumultuous Week
 The long bond's yield of 7.25 percent is little changed from 7.26 percent a week ago, but that comparison is somewhat misleading.
On April 1, Treasury yields surged in very thin Good Friday trading in reaction to a Government report showing unexpected growth in the creation of new jobs -- and thus a signal that the economy might be overheating. The market's fears exploded further on Monday and the long bond's yield rocketed to 7.41 percent, its highest level in nearly 15 months.
Traders said yesterday's selloff was not unusual before a weekend, especially after a tumultuous week for the Treasury market and before a week filled with the release of important economic data.
 Some traders said they saw an opportunity to take profits yesterday, with the long bond near the top of its trading range in the morning. But any gains were limited by concerns that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates soon.
Several analysts said that as long as there was a chance that interest rates would rise, most rallies in the market would be short-lived.
At the shorter end of the market, bill rates increased slightly, with a three-month issue at 3.54 percent, up from 3.52 percent on Thursday.
Market analysts at MMS International said the decline in bond prices, which move in the opposite direction of yields, weighed on Treasury securities after a Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, said labor market slack was "diminishing." They also pointed to comments by Silas Keehn, president of the Chicago Federal Reserve, who said some areas of the manufacturing sector were approaching full capacity.
Kim Rupert, an analyst for MMS, said that while Mr. Keehn's comments did not help the market, they were nothing new. She said that while Mr. Keehn's remarks seemed more ominous than those of Mr. Lindsey, she did not see any near-term inflation threat.
 
Strong Auto Sector
 Historically, the high use of factory capacity has been related to inflation, so it was not unusual for the market to become concerned with the remarks of the Fed officials, one trader said. Market watchers said potentially strong inflation pressures were still keeping the market on edge.
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, said Mr. Keehn might have been referring to the auto sector, which is at virtually full capacity, a condition that is not expected to last.
"Strength in consumer spending, residential housing and some inventory buildup will probably give us 3.5 percent to 4 percent in real gross domestic product growth in the first quarter, while construction and defense spending act as drags," Mr. Hoffman said.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines 19 Points, Ending a 3-Day Run-Up

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Breaking a three-day winning streak, stock traders bid down the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday by 19 points, to 3,674.26, in restrained trading. Still, the Dow finished ahead for the week by some 38 points.
As they have for the last two months, stock traders followed their counterparts in the bond market, who worried that more hedge funds were overextended and thus selling bonds at any price. More fundamentally, traders are worried that the Federal Reserve Board will raise interest rates soon. 
 Long-term interest rates trended higher yesterday ahead of the release next week of the producer and consumer price indexes. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond settled at 7.25 percent, up 4 basis points from the previous day's close.
 
 
'Crux of the Problem'
 If the price indexes show that inflation is in check, that may convince the stock and bond markets that the Federal Reserve Board will not raise interest rates again soon. In turn, the market reaction may indeed persuade the Fed not to raise rates.
Indeed, recent market volatility has cast doubt on whether the markets will react logically to a low inflation reading. "That's the crux of the problem in the markets today," Mary C. Farrell, investment strategist for Paine Webber Inc., said.
Yesterday provided a good example of how the stock market was looking to the bond market for clues on how to invest, but bonds were following their own peculiar agenda.
There was thin trading until 2 P.M., said Christopher J. Madell, head of government bond trading for First Chicago Capital Markets in Chicago. Then a rumor swept traders that a large hedge fund was selling a huge block of 10-year bonds, sending bond prices down and yields up. As it became clear that the rumor was false, bond prices inched back up and curtailed yields.
 
 
Signs of Jitters
 For all of the yield fluctuations this week, "information-wise, nothing has changed" regarding inflation or interest rates, Mr. Madell said. He noted that early in the week the bond market had overreacted to an article in The Washington Post that said the Fed would not raise rates until the markets became less volatile. "We knew that already, but that's just a measure of how jittery the markets are," he said.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 3.78 points, to 447.10, and the Nasdaq composite declined 6.46 points, to 748.71. The American Stock Exchange market value index dropped 0.55 point, to 441.21.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 1.93 points, to 248.29, on trading volume of 264.1 million shares, about 12 percent lower than that of a typical day. Declining stocks outnumbered those that rose by 1,406 to 800.
 
 
19 Dow Stocks Drop
 Of the 30 Dow component stocks, 19 fell in price, led by General Motors, whose shares fell 2 3/8, to 57 3/4, the day after the company reported strong vehicle sales. Philip Morris, the tobacco and foods giant and another Dow component, saw its shares fall after National Public Radio reported that 5 of 13 secret cigarette ingredients were dangerous. The ingedients included methoprene, which is used in insect pesticide. Philip Morris shares fell $1.375 to $49.125.
MCI Communications, the long-distance telephone company, was the most active stock yesterday, with 3.8 million shares traded. The company announced that Gerald H. Taylor, head of its domestic operations, would become president of both domestic and foreign operations. Shares of MCI fell 1/8, to 22 1/8.
Microsoft, the world's largest computer software company, was the second-most-active stock yesterday, with 3.7 million shares traded on no discernible news. Its price declined 2 3/4, to 87.
Tele-Communications Inc., the largest cable-television operator, was also active, with 3.6 million shares traded. The company is reported to be close to deciding whether to organize an initial public offering of its British cable holdings, which it owns jointly with U S West, the regional Bell telephone company. Shares of Tele-Communications fell 1/4, to 20.

HEADLINE: The State of the State, Proudly Restated;
Cuomo Writes the Book on New York's Strengths, and (Surprise!) Finds Much to Like

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 8

 BODY:
It is only in the next-to-last paragraph of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's new book, "The New York Idea: An Experiment in Democracy," that he explains why he decided to write a 250-page treatise about the programs, policies and philosophical underpinnings of New York State government.
"For too long -- I think -- we have dismissed our strengths, shrugged off our achievements, and allowed the headline writers to concoct the whole image of New York," Mr. Cuomo writes. "Sometimes we have even been made to doubt ourselves." 
 When he first announced that he was going to write the book, in a speech to New York newspaper publishers in 1992, he was a bit more explicit: "You have a litany of accomplishments here that are absolutely dazzling. You get no credit for them. Why? Because there is a public perception out there that New York State is New York City, and New York City is Manhattan, and Manhattan is a subway that murders people every night."
That perception, of course, is unlikely to be a political asset for an incumbent running for his fourth four-year term. And so Mr. Cuomo has set out to enlighten New York's detractors and, by implication, his own critics about the state's accomplishments of the last 12 years.
The book, which was written largely by two Cuomo aides on the state payroll, serves as something of a sequel to the collection of speeches that the Governor published last year ("More than Words: The Speeches of Mario Cuomo," St. Martin's Press). Together, they represent Mr. Cuomo's effort to define himself as an orator, thinker and policymaker and to educate a public that he suggests has been misled by negativist reporters.
Mr. Cuomo, who appears frequently on statewide and local television and radio broadcasts, said in an interview that he had been astonished at "how difficult it is to communicate the facts" about New York State.
"Your town, your village, your city are always on your mind and in your consciousness because they pick up your garbage, give you your school, protect your children," he said. "You see them in your mayor. Your President is always with you. But your governor and your state are barely visible.
"The only way to get this story told honestly and visibly is to write a book and at least offer it to serious students of the business so the truth about New York is not lost forever."
Mr. Cuomo and his editors at Crown Publishers maintain that "The New York Idea" is not intended to be a campaign book. In fact, they said, it was supposed to be published last fall, before Mr. Cuomo announced his decision to run in 1994. Delays in writing pushed the publication date to May 11. Stephen Topping, Mr. Cuomo's editor at Crown, said the book would sell for $25 and that between 15,000 and 20,000 copies would be printed for the first run. Any profits are to revert to the state.
Fearful that it would appear "like too much boasting," Mr. Cuomo said he ordered that two appendixes written for the book -- "Highlights, 1983-July 1993" and "Innovations, 1983-July 1993" -- be left out. He did decide to leave in Appendix B, a three-page list titled "National Firsts, 1983-July 1993" that includes the Child Health Plus Insurance Program, the New York State Games for the Physically Challenged and the Office of Rural Affairs.
To a degree, Mr. Cuomo's book reads like a 250-page State of the State address. In paragraphs packed with statistics that define both the state's problems and its successes, he catalogues virtually every state policy and program in existence.
No program or accomplishment is too minor to merit mention. While Mr. Cuomo devotes significant space to discussing the state's approaches to education, welfare, economic development and crime, he also finds room to mention that the Architecture Planning and Design program of the State Council on the Arts won the Thomas Jefferson Award from the American Society of Interior Designers.
The Governor does not ignore the state's failings, but neither does he dwell on them. And as might be expected, his descriptions of them can be somewhat selective.
While he mentions in a section on borrowing practices that Wall Street credit rating agencies lowered the state's bond rating a few years ago, he does not say that they are now the lowest in the country. Nor does he write that a major reason for the downgradings were the fiscal gimmicks, some outlandish and a few later ruled illegal, that the state employed during the recession, like raiding pension funds and selling state highways to quasi-public authorities.
Instead, Mr. Cuomo uses a footnote to dismiss New York's situation as part of a national trend. "Fourteen states had their bond ratings reduced by one or both of the major ratings agencies between 1987 and 1991, and only three states (as of this writing) have been upgraded since then," he writes.
 
An Activist Approach
 Mr. Cuomo also cites the Cato Institute, a conservative Washington think tank, for being "honest enough to admit in 1992 that 'the Governor who has cut tax rates the most, perhaps surprisingly, is Cuomo.' " He fails to mention that the same Cato report criticized his spending policies, gave him a grade of C, and ranked him lower than 15 of the 25 other governors who had been elected before 1990. A new Cato report issued this year again commended Mr. Cuomo for his "supply-side" tax-cutting policies, but added that "he seemingly never met a spending program he didn't like."
In his book, Mr. Cuomo defines the New York idea as "government using its resources to help create private-sector growth, then requiring those who benefit from that growth to share some part of it."
Mr. Cuomo suggests that all states should embrace such an activist approach to government out of self-interest, if not compassion. Otherwise, he writes, "We will all share in paying to maintain the number of people living at subsistence levels. We will all spend more on jail cells and police. We will all live in fear, in enclaves separated from each other's struggles -- but never free of them."
Mr. Cuomo did not write the book alone. While he is the author of the introduction and conclusion, he said much of the book was compiled by two former aides who were placed on the payroll of the State Urban Development Corporation, Luciano Siracusano and Doug Garr, who earned annual state salaries of $48,300 and $55,125, respectively, in 1993.
Despite the coincidence of the book and his campaign, Mr. Cuomo said he needed no justification to use state resources to help write the book. The same objection, he said, would have to be leveled at his State of the State speeches, his state-supported travels around New York, and even the "I Love New York" tourism campaign.
"It's supposed to tell the truth about New York on the grounds that it's good for New York State," he said. "You can't separate this from every other communication about the State of New York that's honest."

HEADLINE: Murmansk Journal;
Port Is Dying, but You Need a Tuxedo

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MURMANSK, Russia

 BODY:
If not for all the platinum blondes in little black dresses, it would be tempting to say that the world's largest Arctic city is dying.
Once among Russia's mightiest and most active ports, Murmansk now sits practically idle, the rusting hulls of a dozen ships rotting in the harbor. Thousands of workers at the enormous Murmansk Fish Cannery, one of the largest in the world, have lost their jobs because of changes in the country's economy. Most of the rest simply get paid for doing nothing. 
 Hundreds of commercial vessels have been junked and sold for scrap. And the Northern Fleet of the Russian Navy, based near here in Severomorsk, has tucked many of its nuclear submarines into the fjords north of the city and begun to slink away.
"It used to be so busy here you couldn't even move in the water," Sergei I. Greshov said as he maneuvered his tugboat about the harbor on a clear, cold day when no other ship was in motion. "Around the clock, all the time, the port was filled with people. Now nobody comes here unless they have to. And we all have less than we had before."
Everybody, of course, except for the blondes, and the tough guys in Armani suits who escort them from one nightclub to the next. Recently, the maitre d'hotel at one such restaurant called the Iceberg looked disgusted as he turned away three Americans.
"You have no invitation, no reservation and no tuxedo," he said curtly, before shutting the door. "Why would you think you could eat here?"
It is unclear how many of the city's 450,000 residents have tuxedos -- although the number is clearly high enough to keep the Iceberg in business. There are no formal-wear shops in Murmansk. Yet there is a thriving young set -- cool guys in sleek Mercedes who carry big rolls of dollars and machine guns with silencers -- enough to fill the Iceberg every night until it closes at 5 A.M.
As much as any Russian city, Murmansk displays the surreal contrasts of a nation where anything goes for those who are crass, smart, deadly or lucky enough. The aching gulf between the rich and poor grows more apparent every day. Apartment blocks with names like Arctic 77-B and Polar 176 stand in long ugly rows along the edge of the tundra. There are, on average, only 14 clear days a year here. When the sun sets on Nov. 29, it does not rise again until the middle of January.
Gloom is an accepted part of life here. But even for Russia, with all of its current problems, Murmansk has fallen on particularly harsh times. Most people are scraping by on smaller paychecks and less government support.
According to the Regional Office of Statistics, the standard of living here has plummeted over the last three years, since the Soviets stopped subsidizing nearly every aspect of life in the industrial arctic. Good bread -- at 40 cents a loaf -- costs 10 times what it did last year.
Less meat, milk and vegetables were produced in the district in 1992 than at any time since 1965. Industrial production here has fallen 25 percent each year since 1991. Exports from the port fell in each of the last three years. Schools closed, construction stopped.
Salaries, which were once higher than in Moscow, now average less than $60 a month, down by 50 percent. In the mid-1980's, with 4,500 heavy ships calling at Murmansk each year, every day began with the radio announcement of which ships were due to arrive. Now, with one or two boats slipping into town on a good day, the announcements have been stopped.
The train station, a pastel green monument to Stalin's neo-classical obsession, used to run 19 locomotives a day from this, the northernmost passenger depot in the world. Now the number is nine, mostly to Moscow and St. Petersburg.
"It's dirty, really dirty," Pavel V. Lukianitz, a 28-year-old member of the army special forces, said as he stepped off the Polar Night train from St. Petersburg recently. He used to work on one of the nuclear-powered ice breakers that were fixtures on the waterfront.
When the Government ran out of money to operate them, he was transferred. "The train used to be such a pleasure from here," he said. "Now we just hold our nose and hope to get where we are going."
Along with many residents of Murmansk, Mr. Lukianitz has never heard of the Medved ("bear" in Russian), a fancy new club only a mile from the train station that caters to the sharp set.
Inside on a recent evening, at red leatherette banquettes, about a dozen men sat with their blonde dates, smoking endlessly and drinking Hungarian champagne. For $100 a plate, everyone seemed happy with their sodden roast beef and salty salmon. A man in slicked hair and a pale blue dinner jacket danced with a woman in a diamond necklace whose dress kept slipping off her shoulders as she shuffled slowly beneath the mirrored ceiling.
"We are a new class of Russians, a private club," said Anatoly D. Tretvoskov, the manager. "We do not want publicity or interference."
When asked how his members earned their handsome livings, he smiled and uttered the word on so many Russian lips these days. "Entrepreneurs," he said. "They are all entrepreneurs."
But down at the docks they have another word for it.
Unloading a month's worth of frozen cod and sole, several local fisherman explained the economy in terms that most of Murmansk could understand.
"We take this fish and we sell it at the market," said one of the fishermen, a lifelong Murmansk resident. None would be quoted by name because they were afraid of the "mafia."
"We don't sell our fish to the factory anymore because they steal from us and they are fools," the fisherman said. "We stay away from the fancy businessmen because they want all our profits. We don't export anything because the tax collectors and the customs men steal it all. We do the work, and they get the money. That is the new Russia."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Murmansk was once a busy fishing port, but now it is practically idle, with ships rusting in the harbor. (Otto Pohl for The New York Times)
 
Map of Russia showing location of Murmansk.

HEADLINE: U.S. Goals on Trade Ebbing With Japan Reformer Gone

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The res ignation of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan has deprived the Clinton Administration of the agent of change it was counting on to open Japan's closed markets, and it has left the White House uncertain it will achieve its trade objectives with Tokyo anytime soon.
Mr. Hosokawa was widely viewed by American officials as the Japanese leader most willing to accommodate American demands for more open markets. His downfall is expected to lead to a period of political weakness and uncertainty in Tokyo. 
 American officials believe that in the short run it is not likely that any Japanese figure will emerge strong enough to make the hard decisions Washington is demanding.
 
Reality Sets In
 Some analysts wonder whether the Clinton Administration did not exaggerate Mr. Hosokawa's willingness to accede to American demands, much the way it built up President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. In both cases, the United States seemed to be counting on reform-sounding leaders and seemed unaware that they were steadily losing public support.
Whatever the case, the Hosokawa resignation raises certain tactical questions for the Administration, most notably whether to proceed with its policy of steadily increasing the pressure on Tokyo with the threat of trade sanctions.
President Clinton, asked about the Hosokawa resignation, said: "I do not expect there to be a marked deterioration in our relationship with that country. We're too important to each other and to the rest of the world."
 
Viewing the Options
 The three leading contenders to replace Mr. Hosokawa inspire little excitement in Washington. The leading candidate is Foreign Minister Tsutomu Hata, who once said that the Japanese could not import more American beef because Japanese intestines could not fully digest American hamburger.
Another candidate is former Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe, who once said that the problem with America is that blacks do not pay their credit card bills. The third likely option is some sort of coalition spearheaded by the Socialists, the most protectionist party in Japan. And a fourth is a minority government that is hardly likely to have the strength to push through reforms.
Many of the President's top economic, foreign policy and trade officials gathered at the White House this morning for a discussion of where to go from here. For the moment, the line is to stay the course.
"Sometimes in trade, as in life, patience is a virtue," said the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor.
Mr. Kantor added, though, that the United States would continue to look for "meaningful steps by Japan" to reduce its $131 billion global trade surplus and to eliminate market access barriers.
American officials remain convinced that this is the direction that the Japanese public wants to take. Some analysts are not so sure.
"Hosokawa's fall demonstrates the fallacy of the view that somehow a new political leader was going to emerge, be the savior, change the Japanese system, resolve the trade conflicts with the U.S. and spare us having to take difficult measures to solve the problems," said Clyde V. Prestowitz, Jr., head of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research center that advocates a hard-line approach to Tokyo.
"The power center remains the bureaucratic mandarins and big business cartels, who do not want to see the kind of change we are advocating."
American officials note that they are not taking the pressure off of the bureaucrats. One thing the Americans believe they have going for them is that currency speculators have kept the value of the yen very high against the dollar. That makes all of Japan's exports more expensive and squeezes Japan's export-oriented business community. American officials hope these business leaders will squeeze the bureaucrats to agree to a market-opening arrangement.
But this is a delicate game. President Clinton does not want to have to resort to punitive trade sanctions, aides say, which he knows would undercut political cooperation in dealing with the North Korean nuclear issue and other global problems.
Sanctions also run the risk of triggering a trade war that would unhinge global markets.
A few weeks ago, President Clinton told aides he wanted to keep the pressure on Mr. Hosokawa, but not "to rub his nose in it." In return, Mr. Hosokawa offered Mr. Clinton a sketchy package of unilateral measures he was prepared to take to open Japanese markets. The fate of that whole package is now highly uncertain.

HEADLINE: Japanese Coalition Scrambles to Replace Premier

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 8

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's announcement today that he would resign sent his governing coalition scrambling to form a new government and to salvage at least some of the economic and political reforms Mr. Hosokawa promised when he took office last year.
Mr. Hosokawa's sudden resignation nonetheless appeared to usher in a new period of political instability that Japanese and American officials feared could slow, and possibly derail, his program to empower consumers and urban voters and deregulate a country choking on bureaucracy. 
 Emerging as a front-runner as a successor to Mr. Hosokawa was Tsutomu Hata, the Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, who is also known as a champion of reform but is regarded as less articulate and politically appealing.
Throughout the country, there was a palpable sense of disappointment that Mr. Hosokawa, a 56-year-old former Governor of a southern prefecture who took office promising to rid the political system of corruption, had fallen prey to precisely the kind of financial scandals he had denounced.
With his informal style and attacks on vested interests, Mr. Hosokawa swept into office on a wave of demands for change among voters tired of nearly four decades of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party, which was seen as protective of the bureaucracy and big business in Japan.
He achieved a sweeping change of Japan's electoral system, including new curbs on campaign contributions and a vast redistricting that promised to make elections more open and competitive. He also opened Japanese rice markets to imports for the first time and apologized to the country's Asian neighbors for Japan's aggression in World War II.
But in recent months, under increasing attack, Mr. Hosokawa lost his focus and was quickly overrun by many of the forces he was trying to combat. His approval ratings suffered, although at a current level of around 50 percent, his popularity remained high by Japanese standards.
Supporters of Mr. Hosokawa insisted today that he had begun an unstoppable tide toward economic and political reform, and that it would continue no matter who is chosen. But they acknowledged that their first mission now is political survival.
The governing coalition consists of some rebels who broke from the Liberal Democratic Party, along with the Socialists and members of smaller longtime opposition parties.
There were many predictions today that the coalition could splinter apart in the battle to find a successor to Mr. Hosokawa. Such a step that could even bring the Liberal Democrats back to power, although most analysts regarded the chances of that as remote. Also considered remote were the chances of a new election.
Mr. Hosokawa, appearing at a news conference today, had lost his usual self-confident air. "I sincerely apologize to the people of Japan," he said. "Many reforms are still under way and have not been completed, and my role will now be different. But I will continuously work toward the fruition of the goals we set."
The man who came to office with a reputation as Japan's cleanest politician left many questions unanswered about his financial connections to a trucking company, Tokyo Sagawa Kyubin, that spent much of the 1980's buying influence from the country's leading politicians.
The company has also been linked indirectly to Japanese gangsters. Mr. Hosokawa took what he described as a loan of nearly $1 million from the company in 1982. Though he insisted that he had paid back the principal, he conceded today for the first time that he did not pay the interest on the loan. Instead, the interest was diverted and "used for my political activities," he said.
He said he had decided to resign after receiving other specifics about how his office had let "an old personal friend of mine," whom he did not identify, profit from the management of other political funds when he served as Governor of Kumamoto Prefecture, in southwestern Japan.
Many of the details remained vague, and it was unclear whether any laws were broken. Nor was it clear that Mr. Hosokawa had been trying to cover up or simply had been misled by his staff.
The Clinton Administration had invested heavily in Mr. Hosokawa's success, and counted on him to bring about reforms that would make Japan's markets far more open.
The disappointment today was evident in the face of Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador here.
"I'm very sad," the former Vice President said. "I liked Hosokawa, I consider him a friend, and I feel very sorry for him."
"Here is a guy who offered a new Japan," Mr. Mondale continued. "He appealed to the young; he had a Kennedy-esque appeal; he talked about political reform, administrative reform, opening Japan to the world, finally responding to the consumers. There was such hope. Here was the fresh political persona, coming from prefectural politics, and ending up in charge of a system that needed so many changes."
 
Possible Scenarios Cited
 Amid the chaotic juggling for position under way in Tokyo today, three rough scenarios for the creation of a new government have been sketched out -- none of them very promising for the Clinton Administration's goal of speeding up the process of reform and opening the Japanese market.
The simplest calls for the elevation of Mr. Hata as prime minister. After Mr. Hosokawa, he is clearly the most personally popular member of the Government, a former bus company executive who helped lead the revolt last summer that ousted the Liberal Democrats after endless scandals.
But Mr. Hata will probably not be acceptable to the Socialists, the biggest party in the coalition. He is closely associated with Ichiro Ozawa, Japan's most powerful politician and the other end of the coalition's ideological spectrum from the Socialists.
Another, more drastic scenario involves a deal in which Michio Watanabe, a former Foreign Minister and leader of one of the biggest factions in the Liberal Democratic Party, would abandon that party and join the Hosokawa coalition.
In return, Mr. Watanabe, who is believed to be suffering from cancer, would fulfill a lifetime dream and become prime minister.
But Mr. Watanabe would have to bring 40 so members of his political faction from the Liberal Democratic Party with him to the coalition. Even that might not compensate for the loss of roughly half the Socialists, who would undoubtedly bolt the coalition if Mr. Watanabe took office.
A third scenario involves stalemate. If neither the Liberal Democrats nor the coalition can put together a convincing majority, the country could be run, at least in theory, by a minority government. But it would be so weak that few believe that it could last. That would be the worst case for the United States, because it would leave the bureaucracy even more free to run the country in the absence of political leadership.
 
Surprise to Close Allies
 Mr. Hosokawa's decision came as a shock even to some of his closest political allies.
"Just yesterday afternoon I had a long discussion with him, and he indicated many points on how he planned to overcome his difficulties," said Hajime Ishii, a leader of the Shinseito party and one of the Prime Minister's key strategists in Parliament. "His feelings must have changed quite suddenly."
Others suggested that Mr. Hosokawa had simply been outmaneuvered by his enemies in the Liberal Democratic Party, who skillfully used the investigation into his past to bring Japan's Parliament to a halt.
They held the national budget hostage, demanding that Mr. Hosokawa allow his private political secretary to testify under oath.
Mr. Hosokawa received little aid from allies in his own party. The Socialists regularly abandoned him on key votes. The chief Cabinet Secretary, Masayoshi Takemura, who is supposed to act as the Prime Minister's spokesman, has publicly feuded with Mr. Hosokawa for several weeks.
"I think the psychological pressure on him was enormous," said Mr. Shimada, a longtime adviser to Mr. Hosokawa. "He had too many enemies surrounding him, and he could no longer survive."

HEADLINE: Fed Official Disputes Times Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A top Federal Reserve official said yesterday that Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, continued to exert strong leadership of the committee that determines interest rate policies.
William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, disputed a report in The New York Times yesterday suggesting that top Fed policy makers had limited Mr. Greenspan's leeway in changing interest rates. 
 The Times article said that the policy makers of the Federal Open Market Committee had taken over the process of raising and lowering rates, rather than allowing Mr. Greenspan to act on his own in the period between meetings.
"The viewpoints expressed in today's New York Times are nonsense," Mr. McDonough said in a statement. "They are completely opposite to my experience as the vice chairman of the F.O.M.C. Alan Greenspan continues to exert strong leadership in the committee, built on the great respect we all have for him."
Asked for comment, Joseph Coyne, press secretary at the Fed's headquarters in Washington, referred a reporter to Mr. McDonough's statement.
Mr. Greenspan is chairman and Mr. McDonough is vice chairman of the committee, the central bank's policy-setting body. It comprises the 7 Fed governors based in Washington and 5 of the 12 presidents of the regional Fed banks.
The committee issues guidelines for setting short-term interest rates in the six-to-eight-week periods between meetings. Until recently, Mr. Greenspan usually carried out those directives on his own, or after consulting with his colleagues in a conference call. But at the committee's meetings on Feb. 4 and March 22, the policy makers as a group raised the Federal funds rate, the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans. They were the first increases in five years.
The Times quoted several Federal Reserve officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, as saying the new approach was a sign of growing reluctance to delegate authority to any single person, but did not imply criticism of the Fed chairman or his leadership. The report said the change had evolved through consensus, had not been challenged by Mr. Greenspan, and was partly a response to pressures from Congress for more openness in the central bank's decision-making process.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Hits 5-Month Low On Bearish Housing View

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber prices plunged their daily trading limit yesterday, setting a five-month low, amid speculation that housing demand would not be as robust this year as thought.
The drop in lumber prices helped send the Commodities Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities down 0.82, to 223.78. 
 Lumber for May delivery fell $10 for its 10th straight daily decline at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, settling at $349.10 for 1,000 board feet. Lumber prices have fallen fell 28 percent so far this year.
Higher interest rates are choking off an expected surge in building activity this year, sending lumber prices lower, traders said. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 8.47 percent this week, up from 6.74 percent as recently as October.
The rise in interest rates prompted the National Association of Home Builders to lower its forecast for new housing starts in 1994 to 1.392 million, from 1.432 million earlier.
 
Builders 'Not Confident'
 Builders are "not confident the building season is going to be as buoyant as they thought a little while ago," said Bill O'Neill, chief futures strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Lumber mills are loaded with inventory that they cannot sell, traders said, further depressing prices.
"I've just been hearing there's an awful lot of footage on the docks" waiting to be shipped, said Edy McCartney, a lumber buyer for Parr Lumber in Portland, Ore.
Such excess supply has sent prices for delivered lumber falling as much as $35 for 1,000 board feet over the last week.
On other commodity markets, platinum prices fell after South Africa's political leaders took new steps in their efforts to stop the political violence in Natal province. South Africa is the world's largest producer of platinum and gold.
Platinum for July delivery sank $3.30, to $407 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Other precious metals prices were little changed. June gold rose 20 cents, to $386.30 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange, while May silver gained 3.5 cents, to $5.492 an ounce.
Elsewhere, gasoline prices fell as refiners sold production to take advantage of rising prices. May unleaded gasoline dropped 0.36 cent, to 48.46 cents a gallon, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Other petroleum products were narrowly mixed. May crude fell 1 cent, to $15.57 a barrel, and heating oil gained 0.25 cents, to 45.06 cents a gallon.

LENGTH: 419 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Slightly on Yen Amid Tokyo Political Shift

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar made a small gain against the Japanese yen yesterday after Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigned amid questions about his personal finances, raising concern about Japan's political future.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.26 yen, up from 104.95 yen on Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo, it jumped as high as 105.80 yen after Mr. Hosokawa's resignation was announced, but soon retreated. 
 A country's currency often falls during political crises. The yen did not drop further against the dollar because many traders thought the change in leaders could delay resumption of the trade talks between Washington and Tokyo that broke off in February.
Without progress on trade, the Clinton Administration could resume calls for a strong yen, traders said. The dollar plunged more than 20 percent against the yen last year after the White House said a strong yen would curb Japan's $60 billion trade surplus by making Japan's exports more expensive.
"You can read Hosokawa's resignation in many different ways," said Lynn Tierney, a trader at Shawmut Bank of Boston. "The question for currency traders is whether this is going to slow down the trade talks or speed them up."
Mr. Hosokawa was expected to provide details by June on a package of measures aimed at opening Japanese markets to American goods. His Foreign Minister, Tsutomu Hata, is scheduled to meet Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, in Morocco next week.
In trading against the German mark, the dollar fell in New York to 1.7130 marks, from 1.7170 on Thursday. The decline came because traders sold yen for marks, a move that often requires them to sell yen for dollars, then sell dollars for marks.
Traders in Tokyo drove the dollar higher against the yen just after Mr. Hosokawa resigned. The rise was short-lived because Japanese exporters sold the dollar to take advantage of its rise. Japanese exporters often have dollars to sell because they earn revenue in foreign currencies.
Elsewhere, the Australian dollar rose to a six-week high of 72.50 United States cents, from 71.76 cents on Thursday, buoyed by signs of strength in the Australian economy.
"There's a real love affair with the Aussie dollar going on," said Richard Tauberman, a trader at the Westpac Banking Corporation. "People see a lot of growth and no inflation in Australia."
The British pound rose to $1.4765 from $1.4735 late yesterday. And the Canadian dollar was virtually unchanged, at 72.25 United States cents.
